HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Is There Life After Silicon Valley's Fast Lane?

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif., April 8 

 BODY:
Silicon Valley's true believers are having second thoughts.
 If there is a religion here in the nation's high-technology heartland, its first commandment has long been Moore's Law, the 1965 observation by an Intel co-founder, Gordon E. Moore, that the number of transistors on a silicon chip would double annually. Dr. Moore later refined his projection, and the doubling rate has held to about every 18 months ever since, virtually dictating the pace of product obsolescence and innovation, and indeed the pace of life, in Silicon Valley. 
 Now some experts warn that Moore's Law may soon reach its theoretical limits, with dire consequences for the technology industry's economic engine. Yet an influential cadre of heretics is arguing that seeing an end to the slavish demands of Moore's Law could be the best thing to happen to the culture of Silicon Valley and maybe even to the future of technological innovation that is affected by that culture. 
"Forget Moore's law, because it is unhealthy," Michael S. Malone, a longtime member of the valley's technology community and an eBay founder, wrote recently in a trade publication. Forget Moore's law, "because it has become our obsession," Mr. Malone wrote. "Because high tech has become fixated on it at the expense of everything else -- especially business strategy."
"It is precisely this fixation," he added, "at the cost of other considerations like profit, product and market, that led to the dot-com bubble and bust." Fittingly, perhaps, Mr. Malone's article appeared in the February issue of Red Herring, a venture capital magazine, which has since ceased publication, another victim of the technology bust.
Sentiments like Mr. Malone's seem to find amplification in a new book by Po Bronson, an author who has chronicled life in Silicon Valley. His book "What Should I Do With My Life?," (Random House, 2002) explores "stories of people who found peace and fulfillment by giving up the frantic chase for their dream."
Several of Mr. Bronson's case studies are about people who found the valley's 24/7 relentlessness to be a "toxic environment." Tim Bratcher, for example, worked at Cooley Godward, one of the region's most prestigious law firms, but hated the pressures. He left Silicon Valley for Atlanta and ultimately turned to teaching law for satisfaction.
In an interview, Mr. Bronson said he found that during the boom, even though many people complained about the pace of work and the way their jobs dominated their lives, they were intoxicated by the action and left only after being laid off.
Others, like Mr. Bratcher were burned out by a corollary to the tyrannical Moore's Law: a pace of business that Intel's co-founder and chairman, Andrew S. Grove, referred to as "Internet time" in 1996, at the onset of the dot-com boom.
Dr. Moore's is not a law in the physical sense, but rather a prediction derived from the economics of the semiconductor industry. For more than three decades it has accurately predicted the accelerating power and plummeting cost of computing. Because of the exponential nature of Moore's prediction, each change has arrived faster and more furiously than the one before.
In 1968, for example, the cost of a transistor was $1. By 1995, a dollar bought about 3,000 transistors. It now fetches 50 million. Or take the clock speed of Intel's microprocessor chips, which rose gradually from about 100,000 instructions a second in 1971 to 25 million by 1989. By 2000, an Intel microprocessor was firing off 1.5 billion instructions, and now the rate is 3 billion -- and climbing.
It is a business burn rate that continues to claim casualties. Recently, for example, National Semiconductor, a pioneering chip maker, said that rather than continue fighting a multifront war against obsolescence the company would sell its formerly promising information appliance business.
"Hanging in there with the products that keep chasing Moore's Law is increasingly expensive," said Brian L. Halla, National's chairman and chief executive.
Not everyone in the valley is ready yet to call time out. Those who are still thriving have little time or patience for the new wave of reflection -- including Intel's Mr. Grove. Asked by e-mail message whether he had new thoughts about the meaning of Internet time, Mr. Grove issued a terse reply: "I am too busy to contemplate this."
Other executives argue that the bust simply provided a much-needed pruning of deadwood and that the valley's round-the-clock style of innovation was alive and well.
"Some people get burned out, but a lot more people come back and continue to participate in the ecosystem," said Kim Polese, co-founder and chairwoman of Marimba, a company in Mountain View, Calif., that makes software for corporate computing systems. "The valley is healthy and innovation is thriving, and we're marching forward."
Dr. Moore, for one, is standing by his principle. At the International Solid State Circuits Conference in February, Dr. Moore, who at 73 is Intel's chairman emeritus, predicted that the law would play out for another decade or so before designers reached fundamental physical limits that would prohibit the doubling of transistors in a given space.
"No physical quantity can continue to change exponentially forever," he said. But, he added, "Your job is delaying forever."
A growing number of Silicon Valley's technical experts, however, question whether Moore's Law can hold for another decade.
Each year, the Semiconductor Industry Association, which closely tracks the latest in manufacturing technology, issues a detailed International Technology Roadmap. The map is color-coded to indicate where potential challenges might develop in the future. Areas where a clear path can be seen are marked in green, and those that require more engineering in yellow. Obstacles for which there are yet work-arounds and which could stop progress entirely are marked in red -- known in the chip industry as the "red brick wall."
Commenting on the latest road map at a February meeting of the International Society for Optical Engineering in Santa Clara, Calif., an I.B.M. scientist said the industry could hit a wall well before the decade was out.
William D. Hinsberg, an I.B.M. chemist at the company's Almaden Research Center in San Jose, Calif., reported that the light-resistant materials that are currently used in projecting circuit patterns onto chips may fail at dimensions below 50 nanometers. (A human hair is roughly 100,000 nanometers in width.) To keep Moore's Law on track, Mr. Hinsberg said, the industry would need to devise materials that can accommodate circuitry narrower than 50 nanometers -- and would need to do so by 2007.
At the same meeting, Chris A. Mack, a vice president for lithography technology at KLA-Tencor, a company in San Jose that makes semiconductor manufacturing equipment, said in a presentation that the popular conception of Moore's Law had become outdated.
"Moore's Law is not about scaling up, it's about scaling down," Mr. Mack said in a telephone interview after his talk.
The Moore's Law race to put more transistors on a single chip is losing relevance, he said, because of limitations in the Microsoft Windows desktop computer operating system, which can process information only in 32-bit chunks and which restricts a PC's memory to four billion bytes.
If Moore's Law is reaching practical as well as physical limits, the implications could be far-reaching in Silicon Valley.
"In the future, maybe faster and cheaper would not be as important as functionality," said Doug Henton, founder and president ofa Silicon Valley consulting firm, Collaborative Economics. He argues that the valley's designers and engineers took a wrong turn in adopting 24/7 lifestyles that emulated the machines they were creating.
"Productivity should be about producing more with less rather than more with more," he said.
He is far from alone in his conclusion.
"The skill sets and people's lives didn't adjust as fast as the stock market ticker," said Randy Komisar, 48, a longtime Silicon Valley executive whose credentials include tours through Apple, the Go Corporation and WebTV.
Mr. Komisar is author of a 2001 book "The Monk and the Riddle: The Art of Creating a Life While Making a Living," (Harvard Business School Press) and now works as an independent consultant -- but on his own terms. He rides his motorcycle to client meetings, and he finds time most days to take a long bicycle ride in the hills above Silicon Valley.
"The ultimate question that is getting asked more and more," he said, "in a way that it wasn't being asked in 1999, is, What really matters?"

HEADLINE: Power Broker Has No Post, But Big Role 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 7 

 BODY:
There is no mutually agreed-upon term to describe the role George E. Norcross III plays in New Jersey politics, and most state residents barely know his name, but within the halls of the State House, he has recently emerged as one of the most powerful and most vilified figures in the state.
 Although he commands a powerful bloc of South Jersey labor leaders, municipal lawyers, elected officials and fund-raisers, Mr. Norcross bristles at the suggestions that he is a political boss or that his organization is a machine. And while he has at times described himself as an "activist," Mr. Norcross, a wealthy bank executive, moves in far more moneyed circles than most protesters or political outsiders do. 
 He holds no elected office or any official position within the Democratic Party, and has no college degree, yet Mr. Norcross has nonetheless played a pivotal role in deciding many of the most pressing issues facing state government. 
Members of Gov. James E. McGreevey's administration have blamed Mr. Norcross's allies in the Legislature for hobbling their plan to solve the state's projected $5 billion budget deficit, by blocking the governor's proposal to increase taxes on casinos. Some legislators have accused Mr. Norcross of orchestrating a series of critical newspaper articles that have imperiled the career of the highest-ranking Republican official in the state, John O. Bennett, co-president of the Senate, as part of a feud that began last year.
His allies, meanwhile, have used their key committee assignments in the State Senate and General Assembly to promote a broad political agenda -- some bills that would benefit their constituents in South Jersey, and others that seem specially tailored to boost Mr. Norcross's business ventures.
Mr. Norcross insists that he is simply an organizer, trying to insure that the oft-ignored taxpayers in South Jersey receive their fair share of resources.
"Finally, we have a seat at the table," he said in a recent interview.
But others say that Mr. Norcross is the inevitable evolution of the New Jersey political power broker in a state that has become wealthier, more suburban and less dependent on manufacturing.
"He combines the smoothness and outward style of a business leader with the wiles and savvy of an old-time political boss," said Ross K. Baker, a political science professor at Rutgers. "Then he has a volcanic temper, which is the sheathed sword that makes many people afraid to cross him. It's a very formidable combination."
Mr. Norcross, 47, was raised in Pennsauken, N.J., the son of a politically active A.F.L.-C.I.O. regional president. He left Rutgers during his freshman year, founded an insurance brokerage firm and in 1981, at the age of 25, served as campaign finance chairman for Randy Primas, the first black mayor of Camden.
But Mr. Norcross was quick to internalize the political maxims of the Reagan era: if Democrats wanted to rebound and win back middle-class voters, they had to preach fiscal restraint and emphasize the concerns of suburbanites. While serving as Camden's Democratic County chairman from 1989 to 1995, and developing a stormy relationship with Gov. Jim Florio, a fellow Democrat, Mr. Norcross worked tirelessly to elect an assortment of county freeholders, state legislators and municipal officials.
By the time Mr. McGreevey was elected in 2001, Mr. Norcross was the undisputed political power in South Jersey, whose political organization has influence over hundreds of patronage jobs and millions of dollars in municipal contracts.
Last year, during the first months of Mr. McGreevey's term, Mr. Norcross was a welcome guest in the governor's office. Although he had briefly backed Senator Robert G. Torricelli's unsuccessful bid to seize the Democratic nomination for governor from Mr. McGreevey, Mr. Norcross had enough power within the Legislature that he could not be ignored.
He rallied legislators to kill Mr. McGreevey's plan for a new tax that would hit South Jersey residents who work in Philadelphia. Mr. Norcross helped shape a $175 million bailout package for Camden, which included $15 million for Cooper Hospital, where he serves on the board of directors. The state also agreed to commit $24 million for a sports arena in Pennsauken, where Mr. Norcross owns a minor league hockey team.
His high profile during the budget negotiations last June also became something of a political legend. With his shock of silver hair and crisp blue suits, Mr. Norcross was hard to miss as he made frequent forays into the governor's inner office, and his hard-knuckle bargaining led to news reports that he shoved Mr. Bennett during a disagreement about financing for the arena.
This year, Mr. Norcross's role has been less ostentatious, but just as pervasive. Mr. Norcross and his allies have forced the governor's economic team to reshape its budget plan. The Assembly majority leader, Joseph Roberts, who is Mr. Norcross's business partner, also proposed a bill that would allow optometrists to perform laser eye surgery. (Mr. Norcross and Mr. Roberts own a chain of optometry shops, but say they would not profit from the laser-surgery law because only 1 percent of the chain's business is in New Jersey.)
State Senator John Adler, a Democrat from Cherry Hill, said Mr. Norcross had also helped persuade the state government to lower tax rates and improve schools and the infrastructure in economically troubled South Jersey.
"I don't see him, at a state level, trying to dictate policy," said Mr. Adler, who has received financial backing from Mr. Norcross. "He wants Democrats to win so they can do good things for working families."
With recent polls showing Mr. McGreevey with weak approval ratings, some of the governor's advisers have urged him to distance himself from Mr. Norcross and from John Lynch, the powerful former state senator. Republicans dismiss any such talk as political posturing, and point to the fact that Commerce Bank, where Mr. Norcross is chairman and C.E.O. of the insurance division, made $3 million in commission on state bond work during the first year of the McGreevey administration. They have also challenged Mr. McGreevey to prove his political independence by rescinding the $24 million for the sports arena.
But Mr. Norcross said that he would donate the profits from his hockey team to charity.
Mr. McGreevey's advisers say that the arena plan will be judged on its own merits rather than any political symbolism, and insist that any talk of a feud is overblown.
"It's not a major rift or a calculated distancing," said Kathleen Ellis, the governor's communications director. "It's policy differences."
With the struggle over this year's budget about to enter its grueling final months, the relationship between Mr. McGreevey and his Democratic allies will be severely tested. Mr. Norcross has increased his influence during the past year, by helping Democrats win county executive races in Bergen and Essex Counties. His brother Donald is the Camden County Democratic chairman, and his brother Phil is partner in a law firm that recently opened an office down the block from the State House, and serves high-powered clients involved in several major policy disputes.
Mr. Bennett, who blames Mr. Norcross for inspiring a series of newspaper articles that accused his law firm of overbilling a client, predicted that Mr. Norcross's combative political tactics will eventually be his undoing.
"He wants to have absolute power," Mr. Bennett said. "And a lot of people, Republicans and Democrats, are uncomfortable with what he's willing to do to get it."
Mr. Norcross denies that he inspired the negative stories about Mr. Bennett, but concedes that his tenaciousness provides a convenient target for his political adversaries. In recent months, Mr. Norcross has tried to maintain a lower public profile, and he declined to be photographed for this article. But as a lifelong resident of South Jersey -- he lives with his wife and two children in Cherry Hill -- Mr. Norcross vowed to continue fighting for his home turf.
"I'm driven by success," he said. "And I'm passionate about the interests of South Jersey."

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: NUCLEAR STANDOFF; 
North Korea's Neighbors Seek Crisis Role

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, April 8 

 BODY:
Three months after North Korea announced its withdrawal from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, the United Nations Security Council will meet Wednesday to discuss the nation's nuclear program.
 On the surface, prospects look bleak for action by the 15-member Security Council. 
 North Korea has rejected United Nations authority over its nuclear program, and said on Sunday that any move by the Security Council would be "a prelude to war." On Monday, China declined to join the other four permanent Council members in drafting a condemnation of North Korea for its unregulated nuclear program. 
"We think intervention by the U.N. Security Council now cannot help resolve the North Korean nuclear issue," Liu Jianchao, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said today in Beijing.
Even South Korea, smarting over the North's cancellation of economic talks for this week, has suggested that a meeting of countries in the region, not the United Nations, would be the best way to bring the North's nuclear program under control.
"We can resolve North Korea's nuclear issues without going through the official channel of the U.N.," Yoon Young Kwan, South Korea's minister of foreign affairs and trade, said Sunday on television here.
On Thursday, North Korea's withdrawal from the treaty becomes effective, making it the only nation among 188 signers to do so.
While there may be pessimism about the ability of the United Nations to rein in North Korea, there is growing optimism that China is now wielding influence over its neighbor.
Three months ago, North Korea seemed to be on the way to restarting a reprocessing plant that could produce enough plutonium to make one nuclear weapon a month. Studying the initial pace of actions, many analysts predicted that the North would use the distraction of the Iraq war to declare itself a nuclear weapons nation or even to conduct an underground bomb test. But reprocessing apparently has not started.
There has also been little in the way of provocative actions recently on the part of North Korea. The last major one occurred on March 2, when North Korean fighter jets intercepted an American reconnaissance plane and signaled it to land in North Korea. The signal was ignored.
Over the last six weeks, there has been a steady flow of high North Korean officials, military leaders and diplomats to Beijing. Separately, Japan's foreign minister, Yoriko Kawaguchi, was in Beijing on Monday, and his South Korean counterpart, Mr. Yoon, is to be there on Thursday. China, the source of most of North Korea's food and energy, is offering to be host to multilateral talks.
Compared with the similar 1993-94 North Korean nuclear crisis, when relations between China and South Korea were only two years old, South Korea is now vastly more important to China, probably China's third largest economic partner after the United States and Japan. With North Korea talking in apocalyptic terms of a new war on the Korean peninsula, China quietly sent a high-ranking Communist Party delegation to Pyongyang last month. It was part of a wider Chinese effort to restrain the North Koreans and to guide them to negotiations, said Scott Snyder, Korea representative for the Asia Foundation, a research group.
"The Chinese are looking at this through the lens of realpolitik," Mr. Snyder said, adding that he believed that China signaled its will last month by cutting off an oil pipeline to North Korea for three days.

MEADWESTVACO WARNS OFLOWER-THAN-EXPECTED RESULTS

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 The paper and packaging company MeadWestvaco Corporation warned yesterday of lower first-quarter results because of economic weakness and higher energy costs, driving its stock price down more than 5 percent. MeadWestvaco, based in Stamford, Conn., said it expected to report a first-quarter net loss of 36 to 41 cents a share, including a charge of 2 cents a share related to the adoption of a new accounting standard. It said the results were hurt by higher costs of energy, maintenance and wood as well as the weak economy and "operating challenges" at some paperboard mills.

HEADLINE: The Postwar Invasion of Iraq 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, April 8 

 BODY:
Of all the companies and countries clamoring for a piece of Iraq's reconstruction, one is virtually certain to be invited: the Philippines.
 No matter which companies ultimately win contracts from Washington to rebuild Iraq's roads, airports, hospitals or other structures, officials in Manila expect to supply thousands of Filipino laborers to them. "I'm confident that if they're looking for skilled workers, they'll come to us," said Patricia A. Sto. Tomas, the secretary of labor and employment. 
 Inexpensive, skilled labor is one of the most lucrative exports of the Philippines. Faced with record unemployment at home, where the average income is just over $1,000 a year, about seven million Filipinos work overseas. Whether they work as doctors, nurses, maids or nannies, the $7 billion they send home to relatives each year is one of the country's most important sources of hard currency.
Analysts and economists in Manila hope the country will soon be able to count on income earned in Iraq. About $2.5 billion of the Bush administration's $80 billion war budget has been allocated for rebuilding Iraq, a task that could cost as much as $100 billion. Last month, Washington awarded a $4.8 million contract to rebuild the port at Umm Qasr to Stevedoring Services of America, based in Seattle. And Bechtel, based in San Francisco, is said to be a front-runner for a contract to rehabilitate the country's vast oil industry.
The exclusion of any foreign bids has sparked protests from Britain, America's main ally in the war, and coincided with a determined bid by France and Germany for greater participation in the cleanup after a war they opposed from the start.
Smaller participants in the American-led invasion effort are, meanwhile, quietly positioning themselves for their share of the spoils. Bulgaria, Romania and Slovakia, for example, hope that sending chemical-weapon specialists will entitle them to contracts. South Korea intends to send 700 medical and engineering workers to smooth a return by its big construction companies to a market they abandoned after the first Persian Gulf war.
The Philippines has yet to make an official offer, but President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo told local reporters last week that her government was prepared to send peacekeepers, doctors, nurses, engineers and construction workers.
Responding to concerns that joining the invasion effort might expose the Philippines to further reprisals by Muslim insurgents in the country's south, a spokesman for Mrs. Arroyo tried to highlight the economic advantages, saying those who joined were assured of getting "first crack at the development efforts."
In the previous gulf war, the Philippines sent medical teams to Saudi Arabia to treat the wounded. When the war was over, Filipinos poured back into Kuwait, first to help extinguish oil well fires, working for companies like Bechtel, Brown & Root and Blount. Afterward, they found jobs as domestic helpers, waiters and mechanics.
And not only in Kuwait. From just 500,000 before the 1991 gulf war, the number of Filipinos working in the Middle East -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Syria, Lebanon, Bahrain and Israel -- tripled by the time the first missiles flew into Iraq last month.
But as war grew imminent, Mrs. Sto. Tomas's department suspended travel by Filipino workers to the region and made plans to evacuate those still there.
Economists worried that if the war dragged on or expanded, it would not only reduce the number of jobs for Filipinos in the Middle East but also hurt the global economy and its demand for Filipino labor.
But Iraq is not Kuwait. Though the country is oil rich, Iraqis are poor and the number of Filipinos employed there was dwindling for years before the gulf war of 1991. Thousands of poor Iraqis will be looking for work when this war is over.
But where Filipinos may have the edge for companies rushing to rebuild the country is in their skills and education. Ninety-five percent of Filipinos can read, compared with only about 60 percent of Iraqis. And most Filipinos still learn English in school, a legacy of America's occupation of the country early in the last century.
The Philippines has already lent a helping hand in the war against terror beyond cracking down on terrorist groups at home and expelling Iraqi diplomats thought to be helping them. Imported Filipino laborers and engineers, many working for less than the American minimum wage, helped build the detention center holding Al Qaeda and Taliban prisoners in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
Even if Philippine companies fail to win a single contract in Iraq, Filipinos are likely to find work there, analysts and officials say. "Filipino workers would benefit because American companies could hire them," said Edser Trinidad, a senior analyst at BNP Paribas Peregrine Securities in Manila.
With American troops fighting in the heart of Baghdad, recruitment agencies in Manila say they are already seeing the first, tentative inquiries from American companies, including some of the same ones that hired Filipinos to work in Kuwait more than a decade ago. Those employers that do not have contacts with a Philippine recruitment agency can go to the Department of Labor and Employment's Government Placement Branch, which is dedicated to finding them Philippine employees.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Skilled and inexpensive labor is one of the most lucrative exports of the Philippines. Last month, these Filipinos filled out immigration forms at the Manila Airport as they waited to fly out for overseas jobs. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A U.S. Push on Accounting Fraud 

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
A new emphasis at the Justice Department on accounting and securities fraud cases is already producing indictments and will almost certainly lead over the next several months to a wave of additional cases, according to prosecutors, defense lawyers and independent legal experts.
 Nine months after President Bush ordered the formation of a federal task force to prosecute corporate fraud, the former chief executives of Enron and WorldCom, who have come to symbolize corporate corruption, have not been charged, and may never be. 
 But in other cases, federal prosecutors are moving aggressively to bring criminal charges for accounting gimmickry or securities fraud that in the past might not have been pursued.
Prosecutors and regulators were not willing to speculate about which companies might face criminal charges, or how many new cases might be brought. And they cautioned that securities cases, especially those where companies appear to have manipulated accounting rules to inflate their earnings, can be complicated and difficult to prove. 
But they broadly agree -- and criminal defense lawyers concur -- that the Justice Department's commitment to pursuing fraud is serious, not just a public relations effort.
"These have become the hot, sexy cases," said Christine A. Bruenn, president of the North American Securities Administrators Association, a group of state and Canadian stock regulators that works with the Securities and Exchange Commission and with prosecutors. "I think a lot of people have changed their focus in termsof how seriously they're taking these cases."
Investigations that would once have been conducted solely by the S.E.C. now involve federal prosecutors and F.B.I. agents from the start, officials said.
The commission -- which in the 1990's had a difficult time persuading prosecutors outside Manhattan, Brooklyn and San Francisco to follow up on its referrals of potential fraud cases -- is now working with prosecutors in offices across the country. When there are accusations of serious fraud at companies based in states where prosecutors lack experience in accounting investigations, the Justice Department is dispatching specialists from Washington to help them.
All this is producing faster results. When prosecutors are convinced that they have clear evidence of fraud -- as at HealthSouth, the operator of rehabilitation hospitals and clinics, or Symbol Technologies, a Long Island manufacturer of bar-code scanners -- they quickly pursue indictments of midlevel and senior managers to prod them to turn in top executives. 
Last month, for example, Robert Asti, a vice president at Symbol Technologies, pleaded guilty to helping inflate Symbol's sales and profit. In announcing the plea, prosecutors noted that the investigation into Symbol is continuing.
At the same time, the longer prison sentences provided by the Sarbanes-Oxley Law have become a strong incentive for lower-level managers to cooperate with prosecutors.
With the new priority given such cases, Ms. Bruenn said she expected many more criminal indictments in the next few years.
"My sense among regulators and prosecutors is that we're all rather surprised as to how much fraud is out there," she said.
Joel Seligman, dean of the Washington University law school and a historian of the S.E.C., agreed.
"There's been a lot more activity," Mr. Seligman said. "You've seen it in the number of indictments. You've seen it in the focus on major cases. My impression is that you have a good deal of open cases going on where you're likely to see a good deal more."
Defense lawyers agree on the trend but say it may have unintended consequences, like discouraging qualified people from serving as executives or directors at public companies and even harming prospective economic growth by discouraging private companies from selling shares to the public. "Why would someone want to be a director and face all this potential exposure?" said Ira Lee Sorkin, a former federal prosecutor and director of the New York office of the S.E.C. who is now a white-collar defense lawyer at Carter Ledyard & Milburn.
But Mr. Seligman said he thought such fears were groundless. Prosecutors appear to be bringing cases where fraud has resulted in large losses for investors and they have clear evidence of criminal intent by executives, he said.
"You want the Justice Department prosecuting appropriate cases," he said. "So far, they've done a pretty effective job."
Mr. Sorkin also expressed concern that the new punishments in fraud cases are overly strict. "If a C.E.O. commits a willful fraud," he said, "he can get 25 years. If he commits manslaughter, he's going to get 15."
Seth T. Taube, who specializes in white-collar defense cases at McCarter & English, said that some investigations were being complicated by the early involvement of prosecutors and F.B.I. agents. 
Increasingly, he said, those officials were sitting in on so-called proffer sessions -- meetings with his clients to discuss what they know about potential fraud cases -- that in the past would have involved only investigators from the S.E.C. The increased threat of criminal prosecution makes it hard for him to advise his clients to cooperate with investigators, Mr. Taube said.
But Wayne Carlin, director of the S.E.C.'s Northeast regional office, said he thought the threat of prison time made suspects much more willing to cooperate with investigations.
"Proffer sessions at a U.S. attorney's office are a better way of extracting the truth," Mr. Carlin said. "The person coming in has an even more heightened sense of the stakes, and of the consequences."
The Justice Department's focus on these cases is in marked contrast to its attitude a few years ago. Over the years, prosecutors have been intimidated by complex fraud cases, especially those that involve accounting, said Leslie Caldwell, who is heading the Justice Department task force investigating Enron.
"It was sort of fear of the unknown: Oh, no! Accounting fraud, and I don't know anything about accounting fraud," Ms. Caldwell said.
But prosecutors soon discover that many of the new cases -- if not the Enron case -- are relatively straightforward, once they have stripped away the accounting jargon, she said. And as they become more comfortable with accounting and learn how to explain it to juries, they are more willing to bring cases.
"You do one, and you see it is just fraud, and I can do a fraud case," Ms. Caldwell said.
Ms. Bruenn said she hoped that the increased threat of prosecution might deter executives from breaking accounting rules. The rampant gimmickry and fraud during the late 90's market bubble raised questions about the effectiveness of the S.E.C.'s penalties, she said.
"I think that the civil proceedings are somewhat of a deterrent because they're so expensive to the company," she said. "But criminal prosecutions are the way to go."

HEADLINE: Budget Ax Threatens 3,200 School Workers 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER MEDINA 

 BODY:
The New York City Department of Education said yesterday that it planned to lay off 3,200 school employees, most of them part-time school aides. The plan is not likely to affect teachers or instructional aides, who are protected from layoffs under the teachers' contract.
 The department's announcement came just a day after the Bloomberg administration announced it intended to lay off 3,400 city employees in other departments and to close several firehouses. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is expected to announce a more detailed plan next week, but numbers released yesterday show that the number of layoffs in the Education Department is more than double the number of positions being cut in any other city agency. 
 The cuts come as the mayor and the schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, undertake a major overhaul of the education system. The city has already included the elimination of about 1,000 positions at the department's headquarters in the Tweed building and at the School Construction Authority.
School officials said yesterday that the 3,200 layoffs are the equivalent of 1,958 full-time positions. The paraprofessionals being laid off work in jobs like lunchroom supervisor and hall monitor.
The layoffs will save about $180 million, or about 3.5 percent of the department's budget for the coming fiscal year, education officials said. There are about 150,000 employees in the Department of Education, officials said. Mr. Bloomberg has said he needs to save about $600 million to help close the city's budget gap and has rejected most of the cost-cutting proposals from the city's unions. 
After the Education Department, the Sanitation Department faces the largest number of layoffs, 941, according to numbers released by the Bloomberg administration yesterday. Also scheduled to be laid off are 848 employees from the Administration for Children's Services, 382 from the Fire Department, 109 from services for the homeless, 463 from the Department of Correction, 97 in transportation and 69 in finance.
Layoff notices for the school employees are not expected to go out until late next month, so that the job reductions will coincide with the end of the school year. The cuts will be the biggest since 1991.
Any savings that unions can now find will not reverse the layoffs, city officials said, but could go toward a $1 billion contingency plan that Mr. Bloomberg must include in his executive budget next week. The contingency plan is needed in case Albany refuses to approve the commuter tax that Mr. Bloomberg is counting on to close the approximately $3.5 billion deficit in the fiscal year that begins July 1, said Edward Skyler, a spokesman for the mayor.
"The mayor gave the unions months to come up with potential savings and they never materialized," Mr. Skyler said, "and at this point he has no choice but to reduce the city's work force through layoffs."
In earlier rounds of budget cuts, the city had emphasized that classrooms would be spared. But as deficits continue to widen, such cuts seem more likely.
"The mayor has said from Day 1 that he will do everything he can to protect the classroom from budget cuts, but that is becoming more and more difficult," Mr. Skyler said. 
The layoff details came on the same day that Mr. Klein and Richard P. Mills, commissioner of the State Education Department, announced two programs to recruit new teachers and lure former teachers back. The city expects to need 11,000 fully licensed teachers for the next school year.
The recruitment efforts will focus on finding math, science and special education teachers for the weakest schools, Mr. Klein said.
"Even in these tight times, we need to get the best people into our classrooms," he said. 
Randi Weingarten, who leads the teachers' union, praised the recruitment effort but criticized the budget plans.
"The numbers we are hearing now are different than the numbers we heard even hours ago," Ms. Weingarten, who is also chairwoman of the Municipal Labor Committee, said last night.
"This is part of our concern about how disrespectful they are with negotiations. Ultimately if you really respected your workers, you would make sure everyone knew where management was going with this," she said. "Now it feels very much like a game as opposed to a really bad situation."
Ms. Weingarten specifically questioned how the city could recruit teachers even as it moved forward with layoffs. In the last few years, several hundred aides have become classroom teachers in their schools, she said.
"This isn't sending a message that we want those teachers and that we value their work," she said. "We do not understand why the mayor has basically slapped our face."
Brian McLaughlin, president of the Central Labor Council, said in a statement that union leaders have worked in recent weeks to find ways to save money while keeping jobs, including pressing state legislators to pass the commuter tax.
"In this dire economy, we should not add more people to the list of unemployed," he said. "Now is a time to think creatively to come up with solutions, not just cut jobs and services."

HEADLINE: Pataki Asks Business Group To Postpone Backing Tax 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 8 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki has asked a powerful group of New York City business leaders to postpone releasing an open letter in which they strongly support reinstating a commuter tax to help the city weather its financial crisis.
 The governor asked for more time and told leaders of the business association, the Partnership for New York City, that he would find other ways to provide the city about $1 billion in state aid, aides to the governor and members of the partnership said. 
On Friday, Mr. Pataki made the request after the co-chairmen of the organization, Henry R. Kravis and Jerry I. Speyer, told him they were considering publishing the letter, which was signed by dozens of city business executives, members of the group said. Mr. Pataki, who strongly opposes reinstating a tax on commuters, asked that the group not take a public position for at least three weeks. In the meantime, he said, he will propose alternatives to the tax. 
"I can confirm the governor had discussions with the partnership," Lisa Dewald Stoll, the governor's chief spokeswoman, said. "The governor has made his position known on the commuter tax and urged the partnership to reconsider the release of its letter."
Restoring a tax on commuters is the biggest component of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to close a $3.4 billion deficit in the fiscal year beginning July 1, but the idea has gotten a cool reception not only from Mr. Pataki but also from the Republicans who control the State Senate. And yesterday, elected officials from Long Island and Westchester County demonstrated against the plan at City Hall. They had what they said were 15,000 letters from suburban residents opposed to it.
Mr. Kravis and Mr. Speyer circulated a draft of the letter among members of the partnership last week. Dozens signed it, but dozens of others chose not to. Among those who oppose reinstating the tax are some of the city's largest employers, said members of the partnership who insisted on anonymity. "There was not unanimity," one member said.
The people who signed the letter did not express support for Mr. Bloomberg's proposal to tax commuters at the same rate as city residents, with a top rate of 2.7 percent. Instead they called for a revival of the old commuter tax at a level of 1 percent of one's income or less. The Legislature repealed that tax in 1999.
"We don't think it will cause great hardship or lead to significant job losses," the draft letter read, according to members who signed it. "As employers we represent most of those commuters who will be affected by this tax."
The letter also urged Mr. Pataki not to cut state aid for education. The governor's executive budget calls for a $1.2 billion reduction in state grants to local school districts. "We urge the state to restore aid to public education at last year's levels," the letter said. "Without those funds our monumental push for school reforms in jeopardized."
In the end, however, the two chairmen of the partnership decided to hold off. They sent an e-mail message to other members of the group, which was given to The New York Times by a member of the group. "We will respect the governor's request and hold off sending the letter for now, but we will monitor the progress of his efforts to help the city, leaving open the option to send the letter if we are not satisfied," the e-mail message said.
Mr. Speyer declined a request to be interviewed. Mr. Kravis did not return telephone calls from a reporter. The president and chief executive of the partnership, Kathryn S. Wylde, also declined to comment on the letter.
One member of the partnership, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said many business leaders thought the City Council and the mayor have already done as much as they can to solve the city's fiscal crisis, raising property taxes 18.5 percent and cutting billions from the budget. They also fear that if the state does not help the city more, property taxes will go even higher.
"The time is now for the state to be more supportive," said the business leader, who signed the letter. "I think people feel the city has done more than its fair share at this point."
Aides to the governor would not disclose any details of what Mr. Pataki intends to propose to help the city in lieu of the commuter tax. But they said Mr. Pataki has no intention of allowing a new tax on commuters to pass in any form. He campaigned last fall on a promise not to reinstate such a tax and attacked his Democratic opponent, H. Carl McCall, for supporting the idea.
The letter suggests at least some of New York City's business leaders disagree with Mr. Pataki's argument that a commuter tax would drive businesses away. On Monday, Mr. Pataki said he had heard from many city business leaders who told him they would move their headquarters if the commuter tax was restored.
Even if Mr. Pataki were to change his stand, the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, who is also a Republican, is set against reinstating the tax. There are about 17 Republican senators who represent commuters in the city's suburbs. All oppose the idea, and it would be hard for Mr. Bruno to overrule their wishes.
"Our position on the commuter tax is unchanged," said John McArdle, a spokesman for Senator Bruno. "We along with the governor continue to oppose reinstating it."
Mayor Bloomberg has said that restoring the old commuter tax will not bring in enough money to balance the city's books. He is counting on Albany's passing his commuter tax plan, which would raise about $1 billion by extending the city's income tax to commuters but dropping the rates. The old tax, which cost most commuters between $1.10 and $1.25 a day, netted the city approximately $500 million a year.
Still, the mayor's aides said it was a welcome sign that Mr. Pataki had told business leaders he would present new proposals for helping the city. "We are pleased that our leaders in Albany are beginning to focus on the city's fiscal difficulties, and we will continue to press forward with our legislative agenda and urge them to support tax reform," said Edward Skyler, a spokesman for the mayor.

D1); Elected officials from Long Island and Westchester County demonstrated yesterday at City Hall against the plan to reinstate the commuter tax. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)(pg. D7)

HEADLINE: The Budget No One Wants 

 BODY:
Less than a week before he unveils his executive budget plan to close New York's $3.5 billion budget gap, Mayor Michael Bloomberg is already cutting thousands of jobs and closing eight firehouses. New York City would be lucky indeed if that was the extent of the layoffs and lost services this year. But the mayor has rightly warned that more pain -- perhaps a great deal more -- will follow. 
 That is because the city's financial hole is deepening while the unions and Albany -- the partners that helped save the city in the financial crisis of the 1970's -- are so far not adequately answering Mr. Bloomberg's calls for help. Union leaders offered a plan that relied in part on manipulating pension funds to produce savings of $600 million while preserving jobs. The mayor declined. City Hall has said it wants workers to lengthen their 35-hour workweek and begin paying some of their health care costs. These concessions would be hard for city workers to swallow, but they would put city benefits more in line with the private sector. Most critically, they might help to preserve some of the 3,400 jobs that would be lost to layoffs in the next round of cuts. 
 There is no shortage of cold shoulders for New York in its time of need. But worst of all are those of Gov. George Pataki and lawmakers in Albany, who hold most of the "get out of crisis" cards. Saddled with their own fiscal mess, state leaders seem to have forgotten about the dire consequences for the state if New York City sinks. Mr. Pataki's proposed state budget would actually hurt the city by cutting $480 million from education and increasing local Medicaid costs. The mayor is still counting on a $1 billion commuter tax, which needs state approval, but Albany has treated that idea as dead on arrival. The governor and the Senate Republican majority should at least consider an alternative commuter tax offered by Gifford Miller, speaker of the City Council, which would share revenues with outside localities. Without an awakening in Albany, the city will probably have to find $1 billion more in cuts for jobs and services. City residents will have every right to call them Pataki layoffs.
Mr. Bloomberg, who has made it clear that he wants a second term, is nevertheless taking on political hot potatoes, including the firehouse closings. The savings, almost $11 million, may seem paltry. But right now, every little bit helps.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: DIPLOMACY; 
Chirac to Join German and Russian Leaders

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 8 

 BODY:
A meeting of the leaders of Russia and Germany planned for this weekend acquired a sudden new cast late today when President Jacques Chirac of France said he would attend the session, and suggested that the situation in postwar Iraq would top the agenda. 
 The announcement raised the prospect of another bitter split over Iraq among the three nations and the United States and Britain, this time centering on whether the United Nations should take the lead in governing and rebuilding the country once the war has ended. 
 The potential for rancor was underscored late today when the United Nations issued a cryptic denial of an earlier Kremlin announcement that Secretary General Kofi Annan would also meet with the leaders in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Saturday. 
Mr. Annan has struggled to maintain a semblance of unity during a crisis that has left the United Nations' oldest and most powerful members sharply divided over its role in settling global conflicts.
In remarks in Paris today, Mr. Chirac said the United Nations, "and it alone," should be responsible for administering Iraq's reconstruction and governance. "We are no longer in an era where one or two countries can control the fate of another country," Mr. Chirac said at a news conference in Paris after meeting with the United Nations' high commissioner for refugees. 
Both President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany have also called for the United Nations to assume the lead role in rebuilding Iraq. 
"The sooner it happens, the better it will be for all the countries involved in this conflict," Mr. Putin said last Wednesday.
That sentiment appears at odds with the White House, which has signaled that the United States and Britain would assemble an interim government of Iraqi nationals to take control when the war ends, and that many further decisions would lie with the Iraqis themselves. 
At a meeting with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain today in Northern Ireland, President Bush said the United Nations "will have a vital role" in the shaping of postwar Iraq. 
But he stopped short of giving the United Nations carte blanche over Iraq's future, limiting his explicit support for the organization to an advisory role in forming an interim government and in helping supply aid.
Before today's announcement that Mr. Chirac would fly to St. Petersburg on Friday, the meeting between Mr. Putin and Mr. Schroder appeared as much a routine and regular get-together of two close friends as a discussion on Iraq. 
Mr. Chirac's addition recasts the meeting as an effort to coordinate the three nations' effort to place Iraq in the hands of international stewards. In Paris last Friday, the foreign ministers of all three nations called for the United Nations to take an early role in running postwar Iraq and voiced concern about a humanitarian emergency. 
Mr. Putin met at the Kremlin on Monday with President Bush's national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, and Russian involvement in Iraq's reconstruction was a leading topic, a senior United States diplomat said.
In Moscow today, a United Nations official initially confirmed to news services that Mr. Annan would join the Russian and German leaders this weekend. But that announcement was later withdrawn without explanation by United Nations officials in New York, and the extent of Mr. Annan's travels this weekend were not clear.
In Paris today, Mr. Chirac delivered a thinly disguised attack on the White House's position that the two nations that fought to oust Saddam Hussein should take the lead in Iraq's revival. 
While saying he shared Mr. Bush's commitment to a "vital" role for the United Nations, Mr. Chirac added, "It is up to the United Nations -- and it alone -- to take on the political, economic, humanitarian and administrative reconstruction of Iraq."

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: RECONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS; 
2 Democrats Call for Scrutiny Of Bidding to Reconstruct Iraq

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8 

 BODY:
Two senior Democratic lawmakers asked today for an investigation into how the Bush administration is awarding contracts for the reconstruction of Iraq, with special attention to contracts already given to a subsidiary of Halliburton, the company once headed by Vice President Dick Cheney.
 The lawmakers, Representatives Henry A. Waxman of California and John D. Dingell of Michigan, asked the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, to examine the bidding process at the United States Agency for International Development, which will award at least $1.6 billion in contracts to rebuild Iraq, and at the Pentagon, which will award tens of millions of dollars of contracts. 
 No one in the White House was available to comment on the request.
A spokesman at the development agency said officials had briefed Congress on the contracts and "had answered each and every question in this regard." 
"We have followed the same expedited procurement procedures under federal law allowing us to limit the number of competing firms in order to shorten the decision time," said Jeffrey Grieco, the agency's deputy assistant administrator for public affairs. "These procedures have been used by the U.S. government in previous conflicts and are completely consistent with the federal acquisition rules." The administration has been accused of bias since it restricted the competition for the major contract to reconstruct Iraq to a handful of companies. The winner would then have a toehold in one of the most lucrative building programs in decades, a task expected to cost up to $100 billion. 
The administration has said that time constraints and the need for security clearances led it to restrict the bidding. The companies selected are among the most politically connected in the country and include the Bechtel Group, which has emerged as one of the top two contenders, the Louis Berger Group, Fluor and the Parsons Corporation.
The lawmakers wrote to David M. Walker, comptroller general of the accounting office, saying that "because the administration has released few, if any, details about these contracts, little is known about the authority to enter into the contracts, or whether proper procurement procedures were followed."
The lawmakers questioned the contracts awarded by the Pentagon without competitive bidding to Kellogg Brown & Root, a subsidiary of Halliburton.
After noting problems with recent Brown & Root contracts -- including questionable cost controls for work in the Balkans and $2 million in fines to resolve claims of fraud for work at a military base -- the lawmakers asked why the administration had given it "a string of lucrative contracts over the last two years."
"Ties between the vice president and Halliburton have raised concerns about whether the company has received favorable treatment from the administration," the two lawmakers said in the letter.
Mr. Cheney was Halliburton's chief executive from 1995 until 2000.
The method of awarding the postwar reconstruction contracts has angered allies, especially the British, who say that their companies have been cut out even though their service members are fighting alongside United States troops.
Experts have questioned whether the restricted bidding violates international trade rules, because the procurement agreement of the World Trade Organization requires an open and transparent bidding process.
The aid agency has awarded two of its eight contracts for postwar Iraq. Stevedoring Services of America was awarded a $4.8 million contract to operate the port of Umm Qasr. The International Resources Group won a $7.1 million contract to provide support for planning, monitoring, coordination, management and reporting on reconstruction and rehabilitation activities.
House Republican leaders said today that they might restore President Bush's ability to choose which agency supervises the reconstruction, a decision that could allow the Pentagon to take charge of an effort that would normally be handled by the State Department.
Last week, the House and Senate passed bills to pay for the war in Iraq that would require rebuilding money to be spent mostly by the State Department and other civilian agencies. The White House, which had asked for flexibility to choose which agency ran the rebuilding effort, and had indicated it preferred military control, had asked congressional leaders to rethink their position.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR; 
Excerpts From Remarks by Bush and Blair: 'Iraq Will Soon Be Liberated'

 BODY:
Following are the text of a statement on Iraq issued yesterday by President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain after their summit meeting in Northern Ireland, and excerpts from their joint news conference as transcribed by Federal News Service Inc. A full transcript is at nytimes.com/iraq.

STATEMENT ON IRAQ
 The future of Iraq belongs to the Iraqi people. After years of dictatorship, Iraq will soon be liberated. For the first time in decades, Iraqis will soon choose their own representative government. 
 Coalition military operations are progressing and will succeed. We will eliminate the threat posed by Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, deliver humanitarian aid, and secure the freedom of the Iraqi people. We will create an environment where Iraqis can determine their own fate democratically and peacefully.
We are grateful to our men and women in uniform, as well as to the brave troops of Australia and Poland, and to forces contributed by other members of the coalition. They have demonstrated enormous bravery and professionalism in the face of great danger. We mourn for the members of the armed forces who have sacrificed their lives, and extend our deepest sympathies to their families.
We also grieve for the loss of civilian life in Iraq. Coalition forces take great care to avoid civilian casualties. The Iraqi regime has done the opposite. It has deliberately put Iraqi civilians in harm's way, and used women and children as human shields. It has sent execution squads to kill Iraqis who choose freedom over fighting for a brutal regime. We condemn Iraqi regime forces' attacks in civilian clothing, false surrender and mistreatment of prisoners of war. These acts are an affront to all standards of human decency and international law.
We are taking every step possible to safeguard Muslim holy sites and other protected places in Iraq that are important to the religious and cultural heritage of Islam and of Iraq. We have no confidence that the Iraqi regime has done the same, and are deeply concerned by reports that it is deliberately endangering such sites and using them for military purposes.
The coalition is delivering food, medicine and other humanitarian assistance to the Iraqi people. This flow will increase as more of Iraq's territory is liberated and United Nations specialized agencies and nongovernmental organizations are better able to operate. We welcome the adoption by the United Nations Security Council of Resolution 1472, which will allow shipments of humanitarian items to Iraq to resume under the oil-for-food program.
As we said at our March 16 meeting in the Azores, we will uphold our responsibility to help the people of Iraq build a nation that is whole, free and at peace with itself and its neighbors. We support the aspirations of all of Iraq's people for a united, representative government that upholds human rights and the rule of law as cornerstones of democracy. We reaffirm our commitment to protect Iraq's natural resources, as the patrimony of the people of Iraq, which should be usedonly for their benefit.
As the coalition proceeds with the reconstruction of Iraq, it will work with its allies, bilateral donors, and with the United Nations and other international institutions. The United Nations has a vital role to play in the reconstruction of Iraq. We welcome the efforts of U.N. agencies and nongovernmental organizations in providing immediate assistance to the people of Iraq. As we stated in the Azores, we plan to seek the adoption of new United Nations Security Council resolutions that would affirm Iraq's territorial integrity, ensure rapid delivery of humanitarian relief and endorse an appropriate postconflict administration for Iraq. We welcome the appointment by the United Nations secretary general of a special adviser for Iraq to work with the people of Iraq and coalition representatives. 
The day when Iraqis govern themselves must come quickly. As early as possible, we support the formation of an Iraqi interim authority, a transitional administration, run by Iraqis, until a permanent government is established by the people of Iraq. The interim authority will be broad-based and fully representative, with members from all Iraq's ethnic groups, regions and diaspora. The interim authority will be established first and foremost by the Iraqi people, with the help of the members of the coalition, and working with the secretary general of the United Nations. As coalition forces advance, civilian Iraqi leaders will emerge who can be part of such an interim authority. The interim authority will progressively assume more of the functions of government. It will provide a means for Iraqis to participate in the economic and political reconstruction of their country from the outset. 
Coalition forces will remain in Iraq as long as necessary to help the Iraqi people to build their own political institutions and reconstruct their country, but no longer. We look forward to welcoming a liberated Iraq to the international community of nations. We call upon our partners in the international community to join with us in ensuring a democratic and secure future for the Iraqi people.

NEWS CONFERENCE

Prime Minister Blair
Of course our discussions have naturally continued to focus upon Iraq, upon the continuing military campaign, where once again our forces have performed superbly, and I want to pay tribute to the U.S., U.K. and other coalition forces. In all parts of the country our power is strengthening, the regime is weakening, the Iraqi people are turning toward us. . . . 
On weapons of mass destruction, we know that the regime has them. We know that, as the regime collapses, we will be led to them. We pledged to disarm Iraq of weapons of mass destruction, and we will keep that commitment. 
On Saddam, his grip on power has been prized away. He has ruled by fear, but as the knowledge sinks in that we will get the job done, the people realize there's not going to be a repeat of 1991, there's not going to be a repeat of the past. The power of Saddam is ending. . . . 
As we said, our forces will not stay in Iraq a day longer than is necessary. We will take on the legal and moral obligations that will fall to us as the forces on the ground to stabilize the country, to keep basic services going, to protect civilian life. 
Then we will help Iraq move as swiftly as possible to an interim authority run by Iraqis, and that in turn is designed to pave the way for a truly representative government which respects human rights and the rule of law, which spends Iraq's wealth not on palaces and weapons of mass destruction, but on the well-being, prosperity of the people of Iraq. . . . 

President Bush
As this war has progressed, the world has witnessed the brutal desperation, the true character, of the Iraqi regime. The world is also witnessing the liberation and humanitarian aid our coalition is bringing to that country as a new day begins in Iraq. In fighting this war we're taking every precaution to protect innocent life. We're showing respect for the Iraqi people, respect for their culture. There will be difficult fighting ahead, yet the outcome is not in doubt. Iraq will be free. 
After the current regime is removed, our coalition will work to restore electricity and water supplies, medical care and other essential services in Iraq. We will move as quickly as possible to place governmental responsibilities under the control of an interim authority composed of Iraqis from both inside and outside the country. The interim authority will service until a permanent government can be chosen by the Iraqi people. 
The rebuilding of Iraq will require the support and expertise of the international community. We're committed to working with international institutions, including the United Nations, which will have a vital role to play in this task. This work when the war is finished will not be easy, but we're going to see it through. 
A free Iraq will be ruled by laws, not by a dictator. A free Iraq will be peaceful and not a friend of terrorists or a menace to its neighbors. A free Iraq will give up all its weapons of mass destruction. A free Iraq will set itself on the path to democracy. 
The end of Saddam's regime will also remove a source of violence and instability in the Middle East. Prime Minister Blair and I are determined to move toward our vision of broader peace in that region. We're committed to implementing the road map toward peace, to bring closer the day when two states, Israel and Palestine, live side by side in peace and stability. 
Peace in the Middle East will require overcoming deep divisions of history and religion, yet we know this is possible. It is happening in Northern Ireland. You're proving that old patterns of bitterness and violence, the habits of hatred and retribution, can be broken when one generation makes a choice to break those habits. 

Questions and Answers

Q. Mr. President, how reliable was the intelligence that put Saddam Hussein at the site of last night's attack? Did he survive? And given the incursions in Baghdad recently, is the war nearly over?

MR. BUSH -- You know, I don't know whether he survived. The only thing I know is he's losing power. I know that, because the Royal Marines in Basra worked so hard, the people of Basra are beginning to understand a couple of things. One, when we said we come and stay to achieve their liberty, we meant it; that in Basra, for example, the presence of the Royal Marines is providing enough comfort for people to begin to express their own opinions. They're beginning to realize freedom is real. . . .
The only thing I can tell you is that grip I used to describe that Saddam had around the throats of the Iraqi people are loosening. I can't tell you if all 10 fingers are off the throat, but finger by finger it's coming off. And the people are beginning to realize that. It's important for the Iraqi people to continue to hear this message: we will not stop until they are free. Saddam Hussein will be gone. It might have been yesterday. I don't know. But he'll be gone. They just need to know that. Because we're not leaving. And not only that. They need to hear the message that we're not leaving after he's gone until they are ready to run their own government. 
I hear a lot of talk here about how, you know, we're going to impose this leader or that leader. Forget it. From day one, we have said the Iraqi people are capable of running their own country. That's what we believe. The position of the United States of America is the Iraqis are plenty capable of running Iraq. And that's precisely what is going to happen. 

Q. -- Picking up if I could, just on that last point for both of you. Have you agreed whether the United Nations will have any role in selecting the interim Iraqi authority? Or will that be entirely for the coalition?

MR. BUSH -- Yes. I mean, when we say vital role for the United Nations, we mean vital role for the United Nations in all aspects of the issue, whether it be humanitarian aid or whether it be helping to stand up an interim authority. The Iraqi people will decide who's on the Iraqi -- the interim authority. The interim authority is a transition quasi-government until a real government shows up, until the conditions are right for the people to elect their own leadership.
And the United Nations will have a vital role. When we say vital role, that's precisely what we mean: that they will be involved along with the coalition in helping to stand up an interim authority. But the Iraqi people are responsible for who's on that authority. And Tony can describe what's happening in Basra. . . . 

MR. BLAIR -- . . . People are coming forward. People are talking about those who have got support within the local community. Iraq -- it's not just that it's right that Iraq is run by Iraqi people. They want the chance to run their own country. You know, they haven't wanted to be under the yoke of tyranny for all these decades. The reason you had this incredibly tyrannical, repressive security apparatus was in order to suppress the proper feelings of the people there.
Now, of course we're going to work with everyone. We'll work with the U.N. We'll work with everyone in order to bring this about. 
But if I can just make this point to everyone: The important thing is not to get into some battle about, you know, words of the precise role here or there. But let's all work together internationally -- the coalition forces, the international community together -- to do what we really should be doing, which is making sure that that will of the Iraqi people is properly expressed in institutions that in the end they own, not any outside power or authority. 
And I think if we keep that vision in our minds, then we'll get this right. And rather than having sort of, you know, endless diplomatic wrangles over it, let's all just agree that the basic things that the Iraqi people want is they want to have a country where they are able to exploit their own wealth for their own prosperity, where they have basic protection of human rights, and where they have a government genuinely representative of Iraqi people, of the full diversity of Iraqi people. 

Q. -- Mr. President, what exactly is the vital role for the U.N. that you both mentioned? How do you explain it? What is a vital role? And are we going to see the same U.N. debate over postwar Iraq that we saw before the war?

MR. BUSH -- Yeah, well, I view a vital role as an agent to help people live freely. That's a vital role. That means food. That means medicine. That means aid. That means a place where people can give their contributions. That means suggesting people for the I.A.E.A. That means being, you know, a party tothe progress being made in Iraq. That's what that means. And I want to thank Kofi Annan for naming a personal representative to the process yesterday. It is a positive step. . . .

MR. BLAIR -- Absolutely. And there is no reason whatever why we need to go back into the wrangles we had over, you know, the so-called second resolution.
If people keep in mind the key objective, which is the well-being of the Iraqi people -- you know, whatever is the past is the past, but this country is in the process of being liberated. If they keep in mind the well-being of the Iraqi people, then I think we all then share a responsibility to make that objective be fulfilled in terms of what the Iraqi people want, in terms of their democratic rights, in terms of their prosperity, in terms of their freedom. And with goodwill and common sense, I'm sure it can be done.

HEADLINE: India Pressed on Kashmir Attacks 

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, April 7 

 BODY:
At first glance, the argument is seductive: if America can strike out at a suspected sponsor of terrorism and hugely destructive weapons thousands of miles away, why can't India hit out at one next door?
 As India sees it, its neighbor Pakistan is a nuclear-armed state that is backing anti-Indian terrorism in Kashmir. The latest provocation came last month, when 24 Hindus were massacred there. India wasted little time blaming Pakistan, which denied responsibility. 
 The two nations, which were carved from one, have been sparring over Kashmir since their founding more than a half century ago. Last year a series of terrorist attacks against India nearly prompted it to go to war against Pakistan.
The pressure to act had receded in the last few months, but with the most recent incident and with reports of militants massing in Pakistan and waiting to cross into India, it is growing again.
"There is actually a problem shaping up," said C. Raja Mohan, the strategic affairs editor of The Hindu, a national newspaper. "This time the government's under pressure to do something."
Last week, India's external affairs minister, Yaswant Sinha, said what had been on at least some Indian minds. In an interview with the Press Trust of India, Mr. Sinha said India had a "better case" for a pre-emptive strike against Pakistan than America did against Iraq.
American officials moved quickly to respond, with a State Department official saying any comparison between Iraq and Kashmir was "overwhelmed by the differences between them." Pakistan, in turn, warned that pre-emptive strikes would constitute a "major miscalculation" on India's part that would lead to "grave consequences." 
Few experts here think India will make a pre-emptive strike based on the American precedent. India has been increasingly critical of the United States action in Iraq, which would make it difficult to then turn around and emulate it. India's Parliament passed a resolution on Tuesday deploring the allied attack against Iraq. "Change of regime through military action is unacceptable," the resolution said, and it called for the quick withdrawal of coalition forces from Iraq. 
India also lacks the military superiority over Pakistan that the United States has over Iraq. 
That does not, however, mean that India will not act against Pakistan, diplomats and experts say, if there is another major attack in Kashmir or elsewhere in India. With each incident, one senior Western diplomat said, "the patience is wearing thinner." 
In a sign of their concern, President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain took time to approve a joint statement on the subcontinent at their Camp David summit meeting on Iraq on March 27. It urged a cease-fire and called for Pakistan to discourage militancy.
Military action has its own perils for India, experts say. Diplomats and Indian officials who have discussed the situation with Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee said he seemed to have a particularly acute sense of them. 
Airstrikes or special forces operations against militant training camps would probably prompt new camps to spring up, only better secured or hidden. A bigger thrust into Pakistan to "teach it a lesson," as some hawks advocate, could prompt a dangerous escalation, or even a humiliating defeat.
But India has few options, experts here say. 
"There really isn't a game plan, other than just hoping something like American pressure will work over time," said Kanti P. Bajpai, a professor of international politics at Jawaharlal Nehru University in New Delhi. "Nobody has any ideas."
Successive prime ministers, he noted, have tried just about every approach to Pakistan over the last decade, from a middle path of "talking about talks" to a concerted effort at cooperation, to the current cold war. When it comes to Kashmir, nothing has worked.
The Vajpayee government has tried talking to Pakistan, and not talking to it. It tried a huge military buildup. It has opened the door to international involvement in the standoff, something it long resisted, in the hope that American pressure on Pakistan would end cross-border terrorism. 
It has not, despite a pledge to the Americans by President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan to end infiltration by militants into India. Indian officials cite intelligence reports that some 1,000 militants are concentrated along the Line of Control that divides Indian and Pakistan-held Kashmir, waiting to cross into India when the weather permits. About 3,000 more are believed to be in training camps in Pakistan-held Kashmir. 
In a sign that America and its allies recognize that efforts to put pressure General Musharraf have had limited success, the British foreign minister, Jack Straw, recently discussed the potential for escalating violence across the Line of Control with his Chinese counterpart in the hope that the Chinese could exert influence on Pakistan, a longtime ally.
"How to put pressure on Musharraf when we know Pakistan is aiding and abetting terrorism is very difficult," the senior Western diplomat said, particularly given Western countries' need for Pakistani cooperation in the war on terror.
The United States and Britain, meanwhile, would like India to do more, starting with talking to leaders in Kashmir who want more autonomy or secession. The central government has appointed a new intermediary for talks, but similar efforts in the past have failed.
Western nations are pushing India to talk to Pakistan as well, but India is not biting. The one possible opening was seen to be in Pakistan's providing trade concessions to India. That would have given Mr. Vajpayee a way to visit Islamabad in a multilateral economic forum that could lead to a political dialogue. 
But Indian officials say Pakistan negotiated in bad faith, and the trade talks soured last fall. For now, even economic cooperation between the estranged neighbors is at a standstill.

A Specialist in Trompe l'Oeil Is Stirred Anew by Semigloss

BYLINE:  By MARIANNE ROHRLICH 

 BODY:
 Paul Rosenfeld specializes in trompe l'oeil, stenciling, glazing and gilding. But because business has been slow, he said, "I'm getting in touch with my roots as a house painter." Thus his "recession special": hire him to paint the interior of your house, and he will glaze one room (a foyer or a similar space) for free. The cost would usually be $500 more. He charges $1,000 to paint a medium-size living room, 300 square feet, with two coats. He can be consulted on choosing colors, and he works in New York City and its suburbs; (845) 398-8942.
