HEADLINE: Carnegie's Zankel Hall Joins the Competition for Audiences 

BYLINE:  By JOHN ROCKWELL 

 BODY:
After four years of construction, including a year's delay prompted by the Sept. 11 attacks, the Judy and Arthur Zankel Hall at Carnegie Hall is set to open in September. Last week the inaugural season's lavish programming was grandly announced.
 What this new underground hall should mean for Carnegie is clear enough, assuming good acoustics and proper insulation from subway rumbles. But what will its impact be on other New York performing institutions, especially those at Lincoln Center? 
 Carnegie is now a three-hall complex, with the main Isaac Stern Auditorium and the intimate Weill Recital Hall joined by this new, flexible, 644-seat space directly below Stern Auditorium. Starting in September, Carnegie can and will offer music for most every audience taste and size.
The most piquant aspect of Zankel's programming is its range and variety. That variety reflects what is newly popular in noncommercial music today: jazz, world music, frisky new music, some folk and country-rock. There will also be educational programs and spoken-word events, along with more traditional classical music too expansive for Weill but likely to profit from Zankel's intimacy.
But with Carnegie (via Zankel) entering into alternative programming in such a big way, and with its seemingly limitless resources in a time of economic uncertainty, what will this mean for familiar purveyors of such fare? Jane S. Moss, vice president for programming at Lincoln Center, suggested this week that the major negative impact may be on what she called "geographically challenged" institutions, places like the Brooklyn Academy of Music or the Miller Theater at Columbia University that might lose audiences to this new midtown eruption of venturesome programming.
One wonders about that. The Brooklyn Academy is so well established and offers such a range of interesting events that one doubts it will be severely threatened, although it could always benefit from a little shaking up. 
Ditto for Miller, which has its own sharply defined profile under George Steele's direction.
Which shifts the focus back to Carnegie's main midtown rival, Lincoln Center. The center's independent constituents -- the Metropolitan Opera, the New York City Opera (for the nonce), the New York Philharmonic, et al. -- will probably be only slightly affected. Perhaps only the Chamber Music Society will be prompted to expand into more innovative repertory, although it has done some of that already.
As for productions by Lincoln Center Inc., the central entity that serves as a landlord and periodic programmer, the likely impact on the three-week Lincoln Center Festival and Ms. Moss's Mostly Mozart Festival, Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors and Midsummer Night Swing would seem nonexistent. Robert Harth, Carnegie's executive and artistic director, said last week that he had no plans, at least for now, to expand into the summer, thus effectively ceding that season to Lincoln Center.
The real threat would seem to be on Ms. Moss's regular-season Great Performers series, which makes use of Avery Fisher Hall, Alice Tully Hall and off-campus sites like the theater at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice. Over the years Ms. Moss has developed an effective strategy for countering the hegemony of Carnegie and its big-ticket prestige presentations like the Vienna Philharmonic. Stern Auditorium is widely perceived to be an acoustical jewel compared with Fisher Hall, which in any case is often unavailable to Ms. Moss, given the Philharmonic's prior claim.
The two halls can be heard differently, however: Fisher sounds warmly cleaner and clearer for many kinds of music, although it is a visual disaster (those onstage acoustical carbuncles) and a psychological one (its shoe-box length), too. But Carnegie has the cachet, no doubt about it.
To compete with that cachet, Ms. Moss has borrowed from BAM's playbook, or simply reflected the evolution of audience tastes, as Zankel is now doing. She has positioned Great Performers as the innovative alternative to Carnegie's staidness. But now, with Zankel, Carnegie doesn't look so staid anymore.
Ms. Moss put a positive face on her situation, arguing -- with considerable plausibility -- that the market for everyone is ample. But she has reason for optimism for more tangible reasons, too.
One, curiously, is that whatever Lincoln Center and the Philharmonic decide to do about Fisher Hall, it's likely to be closed fairly soon for two seasons. This will free Ms. Moss from some of the more conventional and slightly faded orchestral presentations she is now compelled to present.
What has really distinguished her alternative strategy has been theatrical extensions of typical concert fare: productions like Trisha Brown's choreographed Schubert's "Winterreise" earlier this season. Zankel Hall does not have fly or wing or backstage space; it's not, in any configuration, a real theater.
Ms. Moss has John Jay and occasionally the two theaters in the Fiorello H. La Guardia High School. Should the City Opera decamp downtown, she would have access to the New York State Theater, for better or worse. And as of the fall of 2004 she will have Jazz at Lincoln Center's spaces in the new AOL Time Warner building, especially the Frederick P. Rose Theater. Tuesday's fire seems not likely to delay the opening. 
That theater grew out of an effort by Nathan Leventhal, Lincoln Center's president for 17 years, to build a midsize theater with a full-size stage for Lincoln Center and its constituents.
Churlishly the constituents shot down a carefully planned theater on Broadway at 65th Street. Cleverly Mr. Leventhal and Gordon Davis of Jazz at Lincoln Center (and, briefly, Mr. Leventhal's successor as Lincoln Center president) simply shifted the idea down to Columbus Circle. The Rose Theater is pretty much identical to the one the constituents rejected and will be fully and frequently available for rental by Ms. Moss, the Lincoln Center Festival and constituents and outsiders who choose to make use of it.
In theory of course those outsiders could include Carnegie Hall. But no need to cry for Ms. Moss. One welcomes the advent of Zankel; it should perk up our concert life considerably. But mostly because of the real estate at her disposal and her inherent theatrical instincts, Ms. Moss and her Great Performers should continue to flourish.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Zankel Hall is scheduled to open next September at Carnegie Hall. (Carnegie Hall)(pg. E1); Jane S. Moss of Lincoln Center may face additional programming competition from Carnegie Hall. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)(pg. E5)

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Here's Your Vote; Liberty Can Wait

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. KAPLAN; Robert D. Kaplan is a correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly whose books include "Warrior Politics" and "The Coming Anarchy."

 BODY:
THE FUTURE OF FREEDOM
Illiberal Democracy at Home and Abroad
By Fareed Zakaria
286 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $24.95.
 The triumph of democracy in Central Europe after the collapse of the Soviet empire led to the fatuous assumption that democracy would succeed everywhere else. Many intellectuals brushed aside the advantages that Central Europe had that other regions lacked: high literacy rates, a long bourgeois tradition and exposure to the Western Enlightenment. 
 Thus policymakers were not prepared for elections that helped pave the way to mass killings in the Balkans, to new dictatorships in Central Asia and to chaos in Africa. As Fareed Zakaria explains in "The Future of Freedom: Illiberal Democracy at Home and Abroad," elections are not necessarily synonymous with constitutional liberalism: "Democracy is flourishing; liberty is not." 
Mr. Zakaria, the editor of Newsweek International, defines constitutional liberalism as the "bundle of freedoms" that include the rule of law, the rights of free speech and religion and the protection of minorities. Such freedoms, he writes, require the limitation of power, although democracy can sometimes mean the accumulation of it by an electorate that is little more than a mob. An example is his native India, where Hindu politicians pursue the "rhetoric of hatred," which has led to "the ethnic cleansing of tens of thousands" simply because it appeals to so many anti-Muslim voters. 
Mr. Zakaria's complex argument is particularly relevant today, as the United States is at the apex of its power in the Middle East, facing the decision of whether to democratize Iraq quickly and whether to push for change elsewhere in the region.
He provides this cautionary note: "The Arab rulers of the Middle East are autocratic, corrupt and heavy-handed. But they are still more liberal, tolerant and pluralistic than what would likely replace them. Elections in many Arab countries would produce politicians who espouse views that are closer to Osama bin Laden's than those of Jordan's liberal monarch, King Abdullah." 
Nevertheless, elections in Iraq, particularly in the Shiite areas, might show the world that the United States is bent on the Iraqis' liberation rather than on their subjugation. Elections would also pressure the Shiite regime in neighboring Iran to liberalize. But it is the circumstances of each Middle Eastern country that should dictate how far and how fast we push for democratization, and not our ideological hubris.
Elections often constitute the culmination of liberalization rather than its beginning. The United States will surely be at its best in the Middle East when it promotes the general principles of a free society, rather than when it seeks to interpret those principles too narrowly and legalistically by demanding elections when it is dangerous to do so. In a post-Saddam Hussein Middle East, Mr. Zakaria implies, our truest allies will be patience and endurance. His book, whose target is zealotry and not democracy, could not have been published at a more appropriate time.
Democracy's mixed record in producing liberty is Mr. Zakaria's theme. He writes about Karl Lueger, the rabid anti-Semite who in 1895 was elected mayor of Vienna. The unelected Habsburg emperor, Franz Joseph I, refused to honor the election, an anti-democratic measure that furthered the cause of historic liberalism rather than impeded it. As the author shows, the rise of fascism in the first half of the 20th century was inextricable from the expansion of the democratic franchise: Hitler rose to power through a free and fair democratic election.
Because social and economic conditions in much of the non-Western world now approximate those of Europe between the wars, Mr. Zakaria is able to catalog a vast array of instances in which the electorate's will led to the retrenchment of liberty. In 1994 voters in Belarus overwhelmingly elected the extreme nationalist Aleksandr Lukashenko as their president. The recent crackdown on independent news media by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was sanctioned by the electorate in opinion polls. In 1998 Venezuelans elected as their president Hugo Chavez, the angry populist and cashiered army colonel who then eviscerated the legislature and the judiciary.
And while Americans and Israelis justly despise the misrule of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, the author points out that Mr. Arafat "is the only leader in the entire Arab world who has been chosen through reasonably free elections." 
"The Future of Freedom," however, is no polemic against elections. Rather, it is a calm antidote to the fervency of those who want to force elections down the throat of every society, no matter what its particular circumstances and historical experience. As any foreign correspondent knows, there are all kinds and gradations of dictators. Saddam Hussein cannot be compared to Gen. Pervez Musharraf, whose coup in Pakistan in 1999 led to an attempt at "radical political, social, educational and economic reform" that no elected politician would have dared. Nor can Lee Kuan Yew, who wrought an economic miracle in Singapore, be compared to another dictator, Robert Mugabe, whose thuggery and incompetency have brought Zimbabwe to the brink of famine and bankruptcy. Mr. Zakaria, far from extolling dictatorship, usefully reminds us of a complicated world that cannot be depicted as a Manichean divide between democratic and authoritarian.
"It should surely puzzle these scholars and intellectuals," Mr. Zakaria writes, "that the best-consolidated democracies in Latin America and East Asia -- Chile, South Korea and Taiwan -- were for a long while ruled by military juntas. . . . In almost every case the dictatorships opened the economy slowly and partially, but this process made government more and more liberal." 
Nor did our own democracy spring from completely exalted ground. Mr. Zakaria notes that Western liberty was born of naked struggles for power. The Vatican, though itself reactionary, furthered the cause of individual liberty by competing with the power of the state so that the state lost its monopoly on ideas. There was also the dumb luck of geography: Europe's many rivers, mountains and navigable bays allowed for the growth of feisty, independent countries, in contrast to the flatlands of Asia, easily overrun and thus friendly to despotism. Earned wealth also helped the West. The rise of a bourgeoisie and private businesses weakened the state's centralizing power.
The author nowhere denies moral will as a factor in liberty but writes that people of strong moral will exist in many places that are still not liberal, often because history, geography and economic conditions have not been propitious.
As for Iraq, Mesopotamia's flat geography, so friendly to conquest, as well as its ethnic splits and absence of public opinion (at least as we know it), would not make it seem fertile ground for democracy. Nevertheless, the nation's high level of education and relatively secular tradition should give us some cause for optimism. Who knows? Iraqis may turn out to be wise in the way of Eastern Europeans, who had experienced a similar despotism.

HEADLINE: ARTS BRIEFING 

BYLINE:  By Lawrence Van Gelder 

 BODY:
 HIGHLIGHTS

ECONOMY CITED IN CANCELLATION -- The highly regarded Stuttgart Ballet has canceled a four-performance engagement at City Center this month, attributing slow ticket sales to the war in Iraq's economic impact on the entertainment industry in New York. The company's appearance, scheduled for April 23 through April 26, was to have ended a five-week United States tour. "The ticket sales were slower than anticipated," said Jane Herman, senior vice president and director of dance for ICM Artists, the North American agent for the company. Its tour was described as otherwise unaffected by the war because many tickets elsewhere had been sold by subscription six months to a year in advance. "It is the lack of the subscription that has caused cancellation," Ms. Herman said. The tour began on March 17 in Orange County, Calif., and will now end on April 19, when the company performs in Midland, Mich. The Stuttgart Ballet, founded in 1961 by the renowned choreographer John Cranko, performs traditional and modern ballet under the artistic directorship of Reid Anderson. Refunds for City Center performances will be given at the point of purchase, and tickets bought over the telephone will automatically be credited.

HEALTH THREAT CITED IN CANCELLATION -- The BBC Scottish Symphony has canceled a six-city tour of China next month because of fears of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, known as SARS. The orchestra said the decision was made on the advice of the World Health Organization and other health officials after consultation with the BBC's chief medical officer. The touring party of 100 was to arrive in Beijing on May 21 and finish its tour on May 30 in Guangzhou.

THE IMPACT OF SPLAT! AND POW! -- How have cartoons influenced contemporary art? That is the question addressed by "Splat Boom Pow!," opening on Saturday at the Contemporary Arts Museum Houston. With works by emerging and established artists, including Mel Ramos (with "Captain Midnight," left), Takashi Murakami and Andy Warhol, this exhibition chronicles three generations of visual artists who have used the images and techniques of cartoons to examine issues like the war in Vietnam, race relations and poverty. "Splat Bam Pow!" remains through June 29 and will be seen in September at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Boston.

PROTESTERS DISRUPT CONCERT -- Students and other protesters shouting antiwar slogans disrupted a concert by Riccardo Muti and La Scala Philharmonic Orchestra on Monday night in Rome. The Rome daily La Repubblica reported that about 100 protesters burst into the auditorium as the concert was to begin while hundreds more stood outside with drums and loudspeakers, chanting slogans like "Stop the war, stop the war" and carrying banners reading "No peace -- no party." The concert began after Mr. Muti told the protesters, "The musicians you see here have been touring the world since 1996 in the name of peace." The interlopers sat on the floor, listened to the first part of the concert and left.

TOULOUSE-LAUTREC IN VIENNA -- The Leopold Museum in Vienna may be best known for housing the world's largest collection of paintings by Egon Schiele and great works by Gustav Klimt and Oskar Kokoschka. But beginning tomorrow, Toulouse-Lautrec will be its star attraction. Through Aug. 31, the museum will show 350 of his drawings and posters, above, depicting life in the Montmartre quarter of Paris at the end of the 19th century.

WILDE TRIAL TRANSCRIPT -- Undiscovered for more than a century, the original stenographic transcript of the 1895 libel trial involving Oscar Wilde is going on view at the British Library in London. The account of the events that sent Wilde to Reading prison was found in a bundle of papers lent to the library by an anonymous benefactor two and a half years ago. The BBC reported that historians never knew that the transcript existed. Until now, only heavily abbreviated accounts of the trial have been available, the BBC said. Wilde brought the libel suit against the Marquess of Queensberry, who was angry that his son was having an affair with Wilde and accused him of homosexuality. Evidence of Wilde's homosexuality was brought out at the trial.

TOOLS OF DIPLOMACY -- A Paul Revere engraving of the Boston Massacre of 1770, lush portraits by John Singleton Copley and the silver coffee pot from John and Abigail Adams's presidential silver service are among the items of early American art from the State Department collection that will go on view on Saturday at the Portland Art Museum in Portland, Ore. "Becoming a Nation: Americana From theDiplomatic Reception Rooms, U.S. Department of State," assembles more than 130 examples of decorative objects created by artists and artisans. After its national premiere in Portland, the exhibition is to travel for two years, stopping in Athens, Ga.; Fresno, Calif.; Palm Beach, Fla.; Cincinnati; Huntsville, Ala.; Sioux City, Iowa; and Portland, Me.

FOOTNOTES -- With 100 screenings, discussions and festivities, the Full Frame Documentary Film Festival begins today in Durham, N.C. The six-year-old event, running through Sunday, will show 65 films in competition. The opening night presentation will be the world premiere of "Seabiscuit." The festival's Career Award will go to Charles E. Guggenheim, the Academy Award-winning maker of films like "A Time for Justice" and "RFK Remembered," who died in October.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Cuts Worldwide Forecast To a 3.2% Expansion This Year 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9 

 BODY:
The world economy will grow 3.2 percent this year, hindered by concerns over war and terrorism that may also limit the pace of expansion in 2004 and beyond, the International Monetary Fund said today.
 The forecast contrasts with the 3.7 percent growth predicted in September. 
 The world economy grew 3 percent in 2002 and 2.3 percent a year earlier, the I.M.F. said in its World Economic Outlook, its most comprehensive look at global trends.
Increased oil prices before the United States-led war to topple Saddam Hussein contributed to the revision, as did fallout from a three-year decline in stock prices, the fund said. United States success in Iraq will not undo all the harm from the terrorist attacks 19 months ago on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.
"Perceptions of the global security situation may not return to pre-Sept. 11 levels for decades to come, implying higher costs of insurance, weaker confidence, higher trade costs and a slower pace of global economic integration," Kenneth Rogoff, the fund's chief economist, said. He noted a "partial rollback in the peace dividend of the 1990's."
The fund urged central banks to consider further interest rate cuts to ensure growth. It said deflation might be a threat, especially in Japan, and central banks should let the public know what is an acceptable rate of increase in consumer prices.
Mr. Rogoff described this year's expected growth as tepid and said normal growth would resume "sometime during the first half of 2004."
Concerns about terrorism and war will cut global growth in coming years by a quarter of a percentage point, to 3.75 percent a year from a normal 4 percent, Mr. Rogoff said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Some risks are more manageable than others. Can we design markets to change that?

BYLINE:  By Hal R. Varian; Hal R. Varian is an economics professor and dean of the School of Information Management and Systems at the University of California at Berkeley. E-mail: hal@sims.berkeley.edu.

 BODY:
UNEMPLOYMENT is up. Housing sales are weakening. Oil prices continue to fluctuate, and the stock market remains volatile. There's no doubt we live in risky times, yet our tools for managing risk are limited.
 We can do something about the stock market: those with low tolerance for risk can put their money in investments with more stable returns. There are also ways to manage the risk from oil-price fluctuations: buy or sell oil futures to lock in a particular price. 
 But what about unemployment risk or housing price risk? There are financial markets that help us manage fluctuations in corporate profitability and commodity prices. But there are no markets to help manage risks from fluctuations in labor markets and housing markets, even though these have a much bigger impact on most peoples' financial security.
How could we design markets to help manage such risks?
This challenging problem is examined in Robert J. Shiller's book "The New Financial Order" (Princeton University Press, 2003).
Mr. Shiller, a professor of economics at Yale, is well known for his previous book "Irrational Exuberance," which forecast the demise of the 1990's bull market. In his new book, Mr. Shiller turns to the role of financial institutions in managing risk.
Why is it that I can buy insurance against my house burning down, but not against my house price declining? One difficulty comes from what economists call moral hazard. Suppose I were able to buy "house price insurance." Once I had it, why should I bother to repaint, or fix that hole in the roof?
True, the peeling paint and leaky roof would lower the resale value -- but, hey, I'm insured, why should I care?
One solution to this sort of moral hazard is to base housing insurance on something outside a homeowner's control, like an index of house prices in that ZIP code. This way homeowners can be insured against fluctuations in local prices, but still have incentives to invest in keeping their own house marketable.
Such insurance has been offered, as an experiment, in certain neighborhoods in Chicago and Syracuse. Mr. Shiller, by the way, does not confine himself to ivory tower speculations. He has founded a company with his colleague, Allan Weiss, to offer tools to manage home price risk.
Similar ideas can be used in labor markets. One could sell financial securities linked to average compensation in various occupations. If you wanted to go to dental school, but were worried about the market for dentists when you graduated, you could buy "dentist income insurance," tied to average wages in this profession. Such insurance would protect you against the risk of labor market fluctuations, but still give you an incentive to work hard at your chosen occupation.
Moving from micro to macro risks, Mr. Shiller also offers novel ideas for markets in risks in a given country. Suppose you could buy or sell a security linked to a country's gross domestic product. Now you can buy shares only in stock issued by companies based in particular countries, but stock market growth is only loosely related to G.D.P. growth. Such "macro markets" could be an attractive way of managing risk and financing investment.
This year exports from Argentina are booming, driven by a cheap peso; perhaps this export growth will pull the country out of its three-year slump. Those who think so could buy shares of future G.D.P. in Argentina. Argentine businesses that produce exports could, in turn, sell shares tied to future G.D.P. to raise money for needed investments.
A particularly intriguing section of the book deals with risk sharing in Social Security programs. The current arrangement in most countries offers retirees monthly payments based on lifetime income, age at retirement and the inflation rate; these payments, in turn, come from a payroll tax on those still employed. Retirees get a fixed, inflation-adjusted payment, while all the risk from fluctuations in nominal income is borne by workers.
Suppose that, instead of receiving a fixed amount taken from workers' paychecks, Social Security recipients received a fixed share of those paychecks, where the share was determined by the fraction of the population that was retired. (This is now about 11 percent.)
The risk of fluctuations in nominal labor income would then be shared between workers and retirees. Those who preferred not to bear such risks, whether they were retired or working, could sell off some of that risk using the other markets Mr. Shiller describes.
These are intriguing ideas. They are only partly fleshed out in the book, but Mr. Shiller and his colleagues have investigated these ideas in greater depth in their academic work, some of which is available at www.newfinancialorder.com.
But would these markets really work? Housing equity insurance sounds feasible. Intergenerational risk sharing for Social Security also appears attractive; we would certainly be in a much better position today if the system had been set up in that manner. But Mr. Shiller's proposal faces the same problem all Social Security reforms face: How do we get from here to there?
Occupation insurance seems problematic. It's easy enough to decide the definition of a "dentist," but what, exactly is an "auto worker"? The Department of Labor has been trying to standardize occupational titles for a long time, but they change so rapidly that it's a losing battle. Think about trying to buy occupation insurance for "webmasters" a few years ago, or for "nanotechnician" a few years from now.
If such problems could be solved, occupation insurance would no doubt be a popular wedding present: "Good luck in your marriage to that economist, but here's some occupation insurance, just in case."
It is said that behind every successful man is a surprised mother-in-law. If so, there could be quite a large market for such securities.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Agency managers may look in vain for les bons temps at this year's conference in New Orleans.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE first management conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies to be held in New Orleans is shaping up as neither big nor easy, mostly because of a dearth of les bons temps.
 Amid war anxieties, the worst ad downturn in decades, and even weather woes, the attendance for the conference, which began yesterday afternoon, is being estimated at the lowest level ever. About 250 to 260 people are attending the 2003 Management Conference, as the 85th annual meeting of the association is formally called, compared with the 293 who came for the conference last year and the 450 people who attended during the boom year of 2000. 
 "We're still trying to figure out the most appropriate way to open the meeting, but we won't be playing 'Happy Days Are Here Again,' " said O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the association, which is based in New York. 
Those agency executives who do not let the economy or the war dissuade them from attending the conference, which continues through tomorrow, will hear presentations that are to be concentrated on two subjects -- yes, the economy and the war.
J. Walker Smith, president at Yankelovich, the research company, will describe the results of a survey of consumers and the economy conducted for the association, known as the Four A's. There will be an address by Mel Karmazin, president and chief operating officer at Viacom, the media giant whose revenue and profit are particularly reliant on advertising sales.
And three talking heads from the CBS News division of Viacom -- Ed Bradley, Bob Schieffer and Hannah Storm -- are scheduled to discuss Iraq and other topics in a panel moderated by Andrew Heyward, president of CBS News.
"Obviously, the war is impacting us, but to what degree we can't gauge yet," said Ken Kaess, president and chief executive at DDB Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, who is the 2002-3 chairman of the association. "From what we can see, most advertisers are staying the course."
Though less advertising was canceled or postponed at the start of the attack on Iraq than had been expected, $77 million in ad revenue was lost by American media in the first week of the war, according to estimates by CMR, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres that monitors the major media.
"If you look around, there are people succeeding in this environment," Mr. Kaess said in an interview before the conference began.
"The world is different now, and we'll have to adapt to it being different," he added. 
At a business session that opened the conference, Mr. Kaess was elected to a second term as chairman, serving through 2004. He agreed to stay on another year because the executive who was supposed to succeed him, James R. Heekin, the vice chairman for 2002-3, no longer has a job and was thus ineligible to serve. As part of a management shake-up in February at the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, Mr. Heekin was dismissed as chairman and chief executive of the largest Interpublic unit, the McCann-Erickson World Group.
Ron Berger, chief executive and co-chief creative officer at Euro RSCG MVBMS Partners in New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas, was elected the 2003-4 vice chairman. That places him in line to succeed Mr. Kaess as chairman for 2004-5.
Though Mr. Kaess will be the first chairman to serve two consecutive years, he will not be the last. At the business session, the members of the Four A's also approved changes to the constitution and bylaws that will double the term of the chairman or chairwoman and the other top officers to two years, effective with the election for 2004-5.
"All of our chairmen found that one year was not enough to make progress on their agendas," Mr. Drake said. "By the time they get rolling, they get replaced."
Mr. Kaess said he would use the second year being added to his term to continue his focus on demonstrating the value of advertising on sales.
"The issue of the value of what we do is still important," Mr. Kaess said, particularly when "we say webring value to clients as brand builders and then we close our own brands." His reference was to the shuttering of agencies with familiar names like Ammirati & Puris, N. W. Ayer, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles and Lintas in recent rounds of consolidations.
Those closings are, needless to say, another reason there are usually fewer attendees at each management conference than the one before.

HEADLINE: S.& P. Cuts Ratings for Altria and Kraft 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The credit ratings of the Altria Group, along with those of its Philip Morris USA and Kraft Foods units, were lowered yesterday by Standard & Poor's, which cited increased risk of litigation for tobacco companies.
 Philip Morris has said it may seek bankruptcy protection unless a $12 billion deposit required for it to appeal a $10.1 billion judgment in Illinois is lowered. 
Philip Morris and the lawyer for the plaintiffs in the lawsuit are scheduled to resume talks today. 
 Ratings on $23.3 billion in debt may be cut to a level below investment grade unless progress is seen in the request to lower the requirement, Standard & Poor's said. Judge Nicholas Byron of the Third Circuit in Illinois, who awarded the judgment and is hearing a Philip Morris request to reduce the deposit, indicated on Tuesday that the company might not have to post the entire amount.
"While Altria is a great company that enjoys incredible margins, it will be a constant target for litigation," said Marvin Roffman, president of Roffman Miller Associates, which manages $170 million and owns Altria shares. "It's something that will go on for a long time."
Corporate credit ratings on Altria and Philip Morris Capital were dropped two levels, to BBB+ from A, or three grades above junk bond status. The debt has been rated A since at least 1985. Kraft Foods was dropped to A- from A by Standard & Poor's.
Standard & Poor's raised concern that Philip Morris might seek bankruptcy protection when it said two weeks ago that the ratings might be reduced. Moody's Investors Service and Fitch Ratings lowered the credit ratings on the companies last week.
Altria gained 30 cents, to close at $30.30. Kraft, which trades separately, gained 4 cents, to $29.30.

HEADLINE: Proposal on Pension Conversion Attacked 

BYLINE:  By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH 

 BODY:
Proposed regulations to govern the way companies change to a controversial type of pension plan were assailed yesterday both by workers and corporate officials at a hearing by the Treasury Department.
 Employees said the proposals would not prevent companies from reneging on pension promises and stripping workers of benefits they had been led to expect. 
 Company representatives found another fault, saying the rules failed to give employers enough flexibility to change their compensation practices as the economic climate changes. A number of companies, including R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Holding, also said that if the regulations were adopted as written, pension-plan changes that they completed years ago would be illegal. 
The regulations under discussion try to address conversions of traditional pension plans to what are called cash-balance plans. Cash-balance pensions are hybrids that combine some features of pensions, which provide a defined benefit at retirement, with other features of 401(k) retirement plans. The rules were drafted after an outcry by older employees who said their benefits shrank drastically after their companies made such conversions.
In a traditional pension, workers build up the biggest part of their benefit shortly before they retire. Employees in cash-balance plans build their benefits at a steadier rate.
Kathy Cissna, director of pension benefits for R. J. Reynolds, testified that her company's pension plan would fall into a legal twilight zone under the new rules. The regulations would "push plan design into two limited categories," neither of which applies to the Reynolds design, she said. The company converted in 1993 to a type of hybrid that is not addressed by the proposed regulations.
Ms. Cissna said the rules would cause "extreme disruption" to many companies whose pension plans do not adhere to the standards, citing a study by the Watson Wyatt consulting firm that said about two-thirds of pension plans sponsored by the 100 largest American corporations would fail to comply. Watson Wyatt, which helps companies set up and change pension plans, also testified.
Representative George Miller, one of three legislators to speak on behalf of employees, called on the Treasury to scrap the regulations and replace them with rules that would permit employees going through conversions simply to calculate whether they would be best served by their companies' old plan or the new one, and choose one or the other. He cited a General Accounting Office finding that some workers could lose half their benefits in a cash-balance pension conversion.
The Treasury declined to comment on the testimony, which is to continue today. A spokeswoman said that the Treasury was "carefully considering" all public comments and would take them into account as it prepares the final rules. The department can either withdraw all or part of the rules, or revise and reissue them. If revisions are made, more public comment will then be solicited.
Even before the hearings began, the Bush administration took steps to defuse some of the tension over the rules. On Monday, it scrapped one part of the package, saying it would have undermined separate, existing pension rules that are designed to keep executives from turning pension plans into tax shelters. 
The Treasury said it would rewrite that measure in a way that did not conflict with existing practices. 
In addition, a separate regulation, requiring companies to notify employees clearly of pension-plan reductions, went into effect on Tuesday. In the past, some companies' communications were so impenetrable that the workers had no idea what was going on.
Cash-balance pensions captured the spotlight in 1999 after employees at I.B.M. discovered that a conversion by that company was reducing employees' benefits by tens of thousands of dollars in some cases. The harshest effects befell workers with the most seniority. An age-discrimination lawsuit followed, along with a political uproar.
The Internal Revenue Service, one of three agencies that regulate pension plans, has stopped approving cash-balance conversions while experts sort out the legal issues. The new regulations, issued in December, are the Bush administration's proposal to resolve the age-discrimination issue.

HEADLINE: Pataki Calls for Security Plan To Help Ease Canada Trade 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 9 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and Premier Ernie Eves of Ontario signed an agreement today urging their national governments to create a common North American security perimeter to guarantee the free flow of goods across the border.
 A common North American perimeter could assure that goods and people are checked before they come to North America or at entrance points in North America. That, Mr. Pataki said, would "enhance our security while at the same time allowing that we not build walls between Ontario and New York, and Canada and the United States." 
 Security between the countries, the world's largest trading partners, has been a topic of concern since measures adopted after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks threatened to halt the normally steady movement of goods across the 5,500-mile border.
Each day $1.3 billion worth of goods move across the border, and Ontario Province and New York State share $16 billion in trade annually.
Canadian and United States officials have already introduced some programs to speed the movement of goods, including prescreening programs for companies that regularly ship goods across the border. New York has posted 100 additional police officers at the border to help inspect incoming goods, Mr. Pataki said. 
Canada has increased the number of officers at the border, and, after the war in Iraq began, started checking trucks as they leave the country. 
The two men also proposed using more high-tech devices at the border like magnetic resonance imaging systems that can scan entire trucks.
"Neither Ontario nor New York can afford the economic consequences of building a wall between our two great nations," said Mr. Eves, who has sought to distance himself from the government of Prime Minister Jean Chretien and its refusal to take a strong position on the Iraq war.
Recently, there have been concerns that Canada's lack of support for the war could hurt the countries' economic ties. Mr. Pataki said they would remain strong, despite some tensions. He mentioned the booing of a youth hockey team from the United States during a visit to Montreal.

HEADLINE: Energy Matters Return to Fore On Capitol Hill 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9 

 BODY:
Two years ago, with California suffering from rolling blackouts and oil prices sinking, energy policy was a centerpiece of the Bush administration's domestic agenda. Then the terror attacks intervened and momentum for a wide-ranging new energy program was lost.
 Now the House and Senate are again moving ahead on comprehensive energy measures that sponsors say are needed steps toward stability in the volatile oil and power industries. But critics say they are stuffed with special-interest aid and tax breaks for big energy companies and fail to recognize a changed energy and economic climate. One senior House Democratic aide said the House measure, with its focus on oil and gas production, was the equivalent of wearing 1970's fashions in the 21st century. 
 Backers dismiss the criticism as short-sighted and say new legislation is needed now. "I am not willing to wait for a crisis," said Representative Billy Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana and chairman of the House Energy Committee, one of four House panels involved in the bill. "We ought to have stable markets in energy so we can have stable markets in our economy as well." He estimated the measure could create 700,000 jobs.
Representative Nick J. Rahall II of West Virginia, the senior Democrat on the House Resources Committee, countered that the bills would benefit big business, not consumers. "There is little in the way of relief for Americans at the gas pump in this bill," Mr. Rahall said. "Adding insult to injury, the legislation would gouge them even further through a whole host of taxpayer subsidies to energy producers. This is misguided relief."
As the House prepares to adopt its version of the energy bill as early as Thursday, much of the attention will be focused on disputed high-profile issues like Arctic oil drilling, offshore exploration bans and gasoline additives. But the measure also includes $18.7 billion in tax breaks that opponents of the bill say are geared mainly to oil and gas companies and do little to promote conservation or development of new energy technologies.
"This is really a backward-looking energy bill," said Anna Aurilio, legislative director of the Public Interest Research Group.
Opponents object to numerous parts in the House bill. Among them is a provision that critics say amounts to a $2 billion subsidy for big utilities by allowing them to depreciate the cost of transmission systems more quickly. The critics object to other proposals they say would give two Western coal companies an advantage in mining federal lands, provide tax advantages for power plants that burn garbage, and jeopardize the health benefits of retired mine workers.
They also say relief from royalties for oil and gas drilling on federal land is outdated, because the proposals were drafted two years ago, when oil prices were expected to go as low as $21 a barrel. Today the price was $28.85.
"Most of the incentives were designed at a time when the prices were low and the low prices were used as justification," said John Buckley, chief tax counsel for Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee. "Now prices are high and the high prices are used as the justification."
Authors of the bill say that the tax benefits are half of what was proposed two years ago. And industry representatives said that the royalty relief was necessary to spur domestic production by making it economical to drill marginal wells and attract the capital necessary for costly exploration projects. Most of the breaks also expire within two to four years, preventing them from being abused, a top industry lobbyist said.
"If you look at the nature of the domestic industry, you would have to conclude that these things make sense," said the lobbyist, Lee Fuller, vice president for government relations at the Independent Petroleum Association of America.
Mr. Tauzin, noting some bipartisan support for the energy plan in committees, expects to draw significant Democratic votes for his measure, though Democrats are also pressing to offer major amendments to the bill, including one to revise a proposed restructuring of electricity regulation. In the Senate, the Energy and Natural Resources Committee was drawing up its own, similar bill in hopes of completing it by the end of the month.
The outlook for reconciling them is uncertain, because the House version would open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling while Senate Republicans have indicated they would leave that explosive issue out of their bill. Last month senators rejected Arctic drilling as part of their budget. 
House Republicans plan to press ahead. "The Senate hasn't seen our best offer yet," Mr. Tauzin said.
Opponents of oil drilling are also fighting moves in both the House and Senate to allow the federal government to conduct an "inventory" of national energy resources, including under waters now off limits to exploration. Lawmakers from coastal states who oppose drilling are worried that the resource review could lead to exploratory drilling in protected areas and increase pressure to open them to production.
House Democrats, backed by the United Mine Workers of America, are also fighting a provision that they say could allow coal companies to escape responsibility for health benefits of future retirees by prepaying some of their health costs into a benefit fund.
Cecil E. Roberts, the union president, said it would be difficult to forecast future health costs, and he accused authors of the measure of trying to dismantle benefits for those "who worked hard all their lives to provide the nation's energy needs."
But a spokesman for Representative Eric Cantor, a Virginia Republican who sponsored the measure, said that the intent was to give some flexibility to coal companies that have run into trouble selling some of their subsidiary operations because of the benefits issue. The spokesman added that the workers would be fully protected.

HEADLINE: Behind the A B C's, a Buzz Saw; 
Ambitious Schools Deputy Shakes Up the Curriculum

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
The rumor bounced all over town last month: Diana Lam, the new deputy chancellor with the onerous job of overhauling instruction in New York City's 1,200 schools, had resigned.
 To all who asked, the Education Department denied that Ms. Lam was going anywhere -- yet her colleagues there were as intrigued by the rumor as people who had heard it on the street. Even they seemed not to know the mind of Ms. Lam, a career educator who has hopscotched from one troubled school system to the next and has left legions of critics in her wake. 
 Chancellor Joel I. Klein's choice of Ms. Lam as his deputy for teaching and learning struck some educators as unwise, because she had led only school systems -- Chelsea, Mass.; Dubuque, Iowa; San Antonio; Providence, R.I. -- that were tiny compared with New York's, with mixed results to boot. She had a reputation for pushing through major changes without building consensus, then leaving town when the protest grew deafening. So the rumors of her departure were not altogether shocking. 
Asked about them the other day, while her driver was taking her to a conference in Westchester County, Ms. Lam smiled and shrugged.
"I'm still here," she said in her wispy voice, a striking counterpart to her steely personality. "I mean, I just bought an apartment. I have no plans to leave."
And is she happy?
"Yeah, I am, I am," she said. "It's an adjustment. This position is very different than being superintendent."
Then she turned away, smile widening as she realized the car had reached its destination, and she could wriggle away from the subject: "Are we here already?" 
In the seven months since she came to New York from Providence, Ms. Lam, 55, has largely avoided the public eye, even while initiating some of the biggest changes the school system has seen in decades.
She has already caused a stir: many educators, community leaders and parents find her prickly and unconcerned with their opinions, as do federal and state education officials.
Ms. Lam has also come under attack for her choice of Month by Month Phonics, a little-known program with scant research backing it, to teach rudimentary reading skills, and Everyday Mathematics, which encourages untraditional -- some say bewildering -- methods of problem-solving.
Yet some who have watched Ms. Lam say she is smart and courageous, especially for quickly developing plans for a citywide reading and mathematics curriculum.
"She needs to be given credit for moving us in a sensible direction in a very short period of time," said Eva S. Moskowitz, chairwoman of the City Council's Education Committee and a vocal critic of the Education Department under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Mr. Klein. "There were others who were here for years and years and couldn't manage to do that."
Or, as Kati Haycock, director of the Education Trust, a Washington group that works as an advocate for poor children, put it: "Diana Lam is good for New York, because nicey-nice people never get anything done."
Ms. Lam is quite used to getting things done: as a 3-year-old in Lima, Peru, she said, she taught herself to read the newspapers that her father, a Chinese truck driver, brought home. Though she perfected English at an early age, her thick accent gives away her Latin American roots. Neither her father nor her mother, a Peruvian seamstress, was educated beyond elementary school. She debated social policy in the lunchroom of her Catholic school and won a scholarship to the College of St. Benedict in Minnesota, where she majored in sociology and aspired to be an economist.
She married a Minnesotan, Peter Plattes, and scrapped her dream of attending graduate school in Europe, staying in St. Cloud with him for a few years and teaching middle school. The couple taught children in a Peruvian mining camp in the early 70's, then moved to Boston, which Ms. Lam said she chose because its Roman Catholic cardinal had sent money to the school she attended in Lima.
Over 18 years, Ms. Lam rose from a bilingual teacher in Framingham to a zone superintendent in Boston, responsible for 23 schools and 10,000 students. Her husband, a high school teacher, became a stay-at-home father, caring for their children, Sasha and Tamara.
She had been superintendent of the beleaguered schools in Chelsea, Mass., for only two years when she quit in 1991 to run for mayor of Boston -- a gutsy move in a city whose leaders have virtually all been men of Irish or Italian descent. But her campaign ended three days after it began, when it was revealed that she had filed late tax returns.
Why did she veer into politics?
"It appealed to me because at that time, City Hall was not doing enough for education," Ms. Lam said.
She stirred more controversy in Dubuque, where she was superintendent for two years, and in San Antonio, where she was hired on a split vote by the school board and was forced out after four years, taking an $800,000 buyout.
In both San Antonio and Providence, where she spent three years, test scores generally rose during her tenure but were still low when she left. Her most strident enemies in both cities were the teachers' unions, which complained that she forced too much change too quickly and did not listen to them. Her relationship with Randi Weingarten, president of New York's teachers' union, is chilly.
In New York -- where the $250,000 salary that Ms. Lam negotiated makes her the highest-paid city employee besides Chancellor Klein, who earns the same amount -- Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Klein clearly want to keep Ms. Lam focused on instruction while they handle the politics. They rarely put her on the phone with reporters or have her speak at news conferences or hearings.
When she does appear in public, Ms. Lam's body language -- her arms are often crossed, her chin jutted out -- and brusque manner sometimes put people off.
"The beauty of this position is that as a deputy, Diana can stay totally focused on instructional change and let the chancellor and mayor's office deal with a lot of the other dynamics she had to deal with in past jobs," said Dennis M. Walcott, the deputy mayor in charge of education.
Others suspect that Ms. Lam's limited role is frustrating her.
"To be muzzled would not be very satisfying to her, because she seems like such a strong-minded person," one education official said.
Not that Ms. Lam's lack of spotlight has stopped people from tarring her. In particular, her choice of Month by Month Phonics has galled many experts, who say the program does not have nearly enough structure.
They also say that the overall reading curriculum -- which will provide each classroom with a library of several hundred books and require students to read and write on their own or in small groups -- is too challenging for New York's teachers, many of whom lack experience and grapple with constant behavior problems.
Ms. Lam has compromised by adding a second, more comprehensive phonics program developed by Voyager Expanded Learning, a Texas company. But she flatly rejects the criticism that teachers and students are not up for the overall curriculum she has chosen.
"How I have heard it as part of the debate is, 'Well, we are looking for teacher-proof materials,' " Ms. Lam said. "I don't believe in teacher-proof materials. If a teacher is not a critical thinker, how can we expect our kids to be critical thinkers?"
Ms. Lam said she took the job in New York because she relished challenges and change. Her son, 25 and perhaps weary of controversy, was more wary.
"My son, in his very abrupt way, says, 'If you're going to New York, it's O.K., but don't change things,' " she recalled, laughing. "It's painful on them, the ripple effect and how it impacts our life."
Some educators give Ms. Lam another six months to a year before she ships out of New York, either as the fall guy in a reform plan gone amok or because she will be restless. When asked if she would like to stay in her job over the long term, Ms. Lam was vague.
"It's certainly a theory that there are two kinds of tenure for school administrators -- those that jump-start the system, that do the kind of very difficult and labor-intensive work, and those other educational leaders that can then come and build upon the jump-start," she said. "I'm hoping that in New York we can do both."

HEADLINE: Audit Finds State Agency Mishandled Some Post-9/11 Grants 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The New York State agency overseeing a program of federal grants to businesses hurt by the World Trade Center attack paid too much or too little to several companies, a federal audit has found.
 The agency, the Empire State Development Corporation, made a small number of faulty payments, for relatively small sums, the audit found. But the agency paid millions of dollars to companies without getting details on how they had calculated their losses, a flaw that persisted despite a preliminary audit that flagged the problems. 
 Among the problems the audit found was the fact that the agency had failed to install appropriate administrative controls, including measures to ensure that businesses could not apply for and receive the same grant twice. 
The deficiencies in Empire State Development's procedures were detailed in a federal report released two weeks ago by the Office of the Inspector General of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The department was designated by Congress to oversee $2.7 billion in Community Development Block Grants to businesses and individuals in Lower Manhattan as part of the $21 billion in federal aid pledged to New York City after the 9/11 attack.
Overall, the audit report said, Empire State Development has disbursed the disaster-relief money quickly and in accordance with federal rules, and its financial system "is capable of safeguarding the funds." And the inspector general acknowledged that Empire State Development was under pressure to quickly plan and put in place a system to aid companies that were in danger of going out of business.
But the report notes that the state agency failed to put into effect several changes it had promised to make after a preliminary audit report released last May, including a requirement for grant applicants to provide details on how their economic losses were determined.
Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of Empire State Development, said yesterday that the agency believed the results of the audit showed a successful grant program had been put in place.
"There are always some findings in any audit," Mr. Gargano said. "We'll do whatever we have to do to address the issues that were outlined for improvement." He noted that both its initial procedures and the revised May regulations were approved by the Housing and Urban Development staff, and that any company submitting false estimates of its losses was subject to prosecution for fraud.
The audit focused on two of the largest 9/11-related programs overseen by the agency: the $481 million World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program and a $155 million Small Firm Attraction and Retention Grant Program.
The Business Recovery and Small Firm Attraction programs are designed to compensate small companies -- defined as those with fewer than 500 employees -- that suffered physical damage, were shut or lost business after the attack on the trade center, or to attract companies to the area or keep them there.
By the middle of March, grants totaling $580 million had been approved under the two programs for more than 15,000 small companies. The audit raises significant questions about whether the money is going where it was intended, and makes clear that this is not the first time the questions have been raised.
Nearly a year ago, the inspector general warned Empire State Development that it should begin requiring companies to verify the losses they claimed after 9/11. As a result, the agency changed its application forms to include a request for details on losses.
But the audit found that more than half of the applications sampled -- including many turned in after the new forms were in use -- did not include details on how a company calculated its losses.
"As a result," the audit report said, "we cannot be assured that the Empire State Development Corporation is obtaining the details from applicants to support the amounts of their estimated economic losses."
The audit also found instances in which Empire State Development incorrectly calculated grants, most often resulting in an overpayment to companies. The inspector general estimated that in approving the first 10,000 grant applications, the agency made net overpayments of more than $1 million.

HEADLINE: FleetBoston, Rocked by Bad Loans, SeeksStability as a Consumer Bank 

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
Charles K. Gifford, chief executive of FleetBoston, is struggling to overcome his bank's past.
 Mr. Gifford, 60, has spent tens of millions of dollars since he took control at the end of 2001 trying to revive the long-neglected consumer business at Fleet, the nation's seventh-largest bank. He has hired 500 tellers and added 26 branches and 126 automated teller machines. Fleet's deposits are now rising at rates competitive with other big banks, which have been aggressively marketing their checking and savings accounts to consumers for some time. 
 But his progress has been overshadowed quarter after quarter by unexpected write-downs and losses in other businesses where he has been desperately trying to scale back. 
All told, the bank has taken more than $1 billion in charges related to losses in Argentina since the government defaulted on its debt in late 2001. Last quarter, Fleet had to bolster reserves against risky corporate loans and write off loans to bankrupt entities like Enron, United Airlines and a division of TXU, an energy services company.
Mr. Gifford said in a recent interview that the first-quarter results, to be announced on Monday, would be in line with estimates. But if he is unable to string together enough convincing signs of stability, analysts say, Mr. Gifford could wind up in the awkwardly familiar situation of having to look for a merger partner after his company has failed to produce the expected results. 
When Mr. Gifford was chief executive of BankBoston in the late 1990's, the company was stung by a series of losses in Latin America. He had spent 33 years at BankBoston, whose charter dates back to 1784, and insisted in 1999 that he felt no pressure to make a deal. But within weeks, he relented and agreed to a merger with Fleet Financial, a much scrappier institution with headquarters just across the street.
At the time of the merger, Fleet was led by Terrence Murray, who built the company from a tiny Rhode Island bank into one of the nation's largest financial institutions, through more than 50 bank mergers over two decades.
Defying skeptics who wondered if Mr. Murray would ever retire, Mr. Gifford succeeded him at the end of 2001. Whether Mr. Gifford will again defy skeptics is the question. Fleet's stock has fallen 24.6 percent in the last 12 months, compared with a 17.8 percent decline in the Philadelphia Stock Exchange/KBW Banks Index. 
"If Fleet continues to deliver results similar to last year, their ability to stay independent will be greatly reduced," said Gerard Cassidy, a banking analyst with RBC Capital Markets in Portland, Me.
With the economy still weak, many analysts are expecting Fleet, in line with other big banks, to lower its profit forecast for the year on Monday, from the $2.50 a share that the company predicted just three months ago.
"I do not see how they do $2.50 this year," said Nancy Bush, an independent analyst with NAB Research. "There's just not enough growth."
Mr. Gifford told analysts in August that if Fleet's results did not improve, he would reconsider his strategy. Many took that to mean he would consider a sale or merger.
The most likely candidate, bankers say, is another giant institution known for deal-making: Citigroup, whose chairman, Sanford I. Weill, met with Mr. Murray two years ago.
Still, in recent interviews, Mr. Gifford said he expected Fleet would go it alone. "It is not our intention to sell the company," he said.
In fact, Mr. Gifford predicted that once the economy recovers, Fleet would be making acquisitions, possibly in the consumer-banking business, where deposits have risen 10 percent in the last year.
"This is as uncertain an economic environment as I've ever seen," he said, adding that Fleet's stock would also have to strengthen before the company could do deals. Unlike Mr. Murray, who combined back offices of many banks to cut costs, Mr. Gifford says the new Fleet will also focus on revenue growth.
Terrence Laughlin, director of corporate strategy at the bank, said that it would probably look for acquisitions "in contiguous geographic areas," citing Fleet's purchase of Summit Bancorp of New Jersey in 2001. Fleet has lost some Summit customers by refusing to pay top rates on low-margin products like certificates of deposit, but has been selling more mutual funds and credit cards to these customers.
The overall weakness in the financial markets has dragged down competitors, as well as Fleet. Most big banks are still posting poor results from businesses tied to the capital markets, like lending or private equity investments. Those areas account for nearly half of Fleet's profits.
"It's a difficult environment for all banks," said Steven Wharton, a stock analyst at Loomis, Sayles & Company, which owns Fleet shares.
Thomas Finucane, a banking analyst at State Street Research, said that only some of Fleet's problems are Mr. Gifford's doing.
On Mr. Gifford's watch, at the peak of the Internet boom, BankBoston acquired Robertson Stephens, an investment bank specializing in technology companies. But he could not have anticipated the problems in Argentina, Mr. Finucane said. The old Fleet, under Mr. Murray, expanded more rapidly in corporate lending than BankBoston did.
Fleet has been pulling back from these money-losing businesses. The bank closed Robertson Stephens, and reduced by 14 percent the amount of corporate loans on its books. It has cut its exposure to Argentina and private equity investments.
"Chad has done a decent job given the cards dealt him," said Mr. Finucane, using Mr. Gifford's nickname.
In a nod to the weak performance, Fleet said Mr. Gifford and other top executives would forgo bonuses for 2002. Mr. Gifford, who received a bonus of $2.25 million in 2001, still made a total of $1.27 million last year, in addition to getting option grants worth an estimated $1.2 million.
Some investors remain bitter over the bank's decision in 2001 to increase Mr. Murray's retirement package to an estimated $5.8 million annually from $2.7 million. Mr. Murray said the package was based on what chief executives at other large banks were offered at the time.
In his time as chief executive, Mr. Gifford has emphasized consumer banking, a bright spot for the industry in the last few years, though one some fear may be losing its bloom.
Fleet has had to overcome a poor reputation among consumers. A survey released three years ago by Consumer Reports gave Fleet the second-lowest overall rating. The magazine has not done a similar study since, although Fleet says other surveys show it registering a 30 percent improvement in its ratings.
As other banks are cutting costs, Fleet is spending heavily to improve its performance.
Last year, it announced plans to invest about $100 million over two years adding tellers and remodeling branches, among other improvements. It also wooed a top consumer strategist from Wells Fargo, Lynn Pike, to oversee its 1,500 branches.
Later this month, Fleet will unveil a $70 million advertising campaign focused, in part, on its personal financial services division.
There are some indications that Fleet's effort is paying off, with checking account sales up 4 percent last year and profits for the consumer businesses over all up 7 percent, adjusted to exclude one-time gains in 2001.
But some analysts are skeptical that Fleet can strengthen earnings quickly enough in this area, which accounts for an estimated 40 percent of its profits.
"They may be able to stop losing market share, but to grow very fast will be difficult," Mr. Wharton said. The bank already has a dominant share in many of the states in which it has branches, he said.
Mr. Finucane, speaking of Fleet's branches, said, "Their deposits are up, but so are every bank's."
In chasing consumer financial services, Mr. Gifford is copying a strategy successfully adopted by two other large banks -- Bank of America and First Union, now known as Wachovia.
Both banks turned to the consumer business a few years ago after stumbling, much as Fleet has, following big mergers, said H. Jay Sarles, a Fleet vice chairman. These banks' stocks have been among the industry's strongest performers.
Some analysts wonder if Fleet is simply too late to that strategy.
"Over the years the banking industry has gotten into trouble when everyone is chasing the business to be in," Mr. Cassidy said. "That is retail banking today. What happens when the pie stops expanding?"
Particularly noteworthy is the rapid growth in home equity lending at Fleet. Such loans rose 63 percent last year, but could lose their consumer appeal when interest rates rise. 
A stronger stock market could also cause people to return there, and shift investments away from savings and checking accounts.
If Fleet's deposit growth slows, Mr. Gifford said, he hopes he can entice customers to buy mutual funds or open brokerage accounts.
Despite the slump in the stock market, Fleet's Quick & Reilly division hired more brokers, ending last year with 890, compared with 600 just two years earlier.
Perhaps the most important wild card remains South America. Fleet's businesses in Argentina, Brazil and neighboring countries account for less than 5 percent of revenues. Fleet's business, which depends on government policy, worries investors, the bank's executives concede.
"Not only do we have the problems that hit all banks, but we have Latin America on top of it," said Mr. Murray, who is still on the board.
Ms. Bush, the independent research analyst, said of the Latin American investments: "That business, which dominated BankBoston's stock performance, has come to dominate Fleet's as well. It's a bottomless pit."
The Argentine Supreme Court ruled last month that it was unconstitutional for the government to force conversion of bank dollar deposits into pesos at a fixed rate, and that decision could make it more expensive for Fleet to pay its depositors.
The cost to Fleet could be $300 million, or possibly nothing, if the government agrees to assume the losses, analysts said. But Fleet's stock fell nearly 10 percent in the days after the decision, which reminded investors that Argentina's unstable political situation made the bank's losses there hard to predict.
Fleet's stock has since rebounded, and its shares are up 3 percent this year, partly on takeover speculation.
Oddly enough, some bankers said the uncertainty of Fleet's losses in the region could prove to be Mr. Gifford's best defense against an unwanted merger, since no acquirer would want to take on the risk.
"It's Chad's poison pill," one banker said.

HEADLINE: The PC Generation, Back to the Board 

BYLINE:  By By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
JUST two years ago, Michael Megalli, a 32-year-old marketing executive in Manhattan, seemed like a paragon of the digital generation. After spending all day on his office PC, he would spend his free time exploring the virtual worlds inside his computer at home.
 "There was a time when I was at the office for 12 hours and then I would go home, have dinner and then spend nine hours playing Age of Empires," he recalls, referring to a popular computer strategy game set in various historical civilizations. 
 But Mr. Megalli has hardly touched a computer game in months. After work and on weekends, he is more likely to be found playing a board game called Settlers of Catan with his wife and friends. 
He is not alone. What was once known as Generation X -- the first generation raised in the PC age -- was supposed to have left the anachronistic board game in the old-world dust of the 20th century. In the 1990's, playing board games was about as cool as carrying a Filofax.
But as the dot-com generation experiences the first pangs of middle age, board games are back. With budding families and increasing work commitments, many young adults now prefer to spend scarce free time with real people rather than in cyberspace.
"This is really a return to how people can be social rather than staring at a screen," Mr. Megalli said. "Even when you're playing against people on the Internet, the human factor, the social interaction, is really minimized. With work and family, it gets harder to see friends as you get older, and the games are a great way to get people together who otherwise have really busy lives."
The video game industry is hardly in trouble. Yet the Game Manufacturers Association, a trade group, estimates that sales of nonelectronic "hobby games," which do not include mass-market stalwarts like Monopoly and Scrabble, have more than tripled since 1994, from $720 million to roughly $2.6 billion. (Some of that increase is a result of the popularity of youth-oriented trading card games like Pokemon.) Instead of old standbys like Monopoly, the new generation of postcollegiate gamers is gravitating toward more complex games of exploration and trade with names like Settlers of Catan, Puerto Rico and Carcassone.
Mike Kilbert, a co-owner of a New York-based chain of hobby game stores called the Compleat Strategist, estimates that the average age of people buying board games at his stores has declined to the early 30's from the mid-40's in recent years. 
"A lot more people are college-educated now, especially women, and with that there is a desire to use some of that education outside of the office," he said. "People in their late 20's and 30's are coming in and asking for games that they can play with a group instead of alone on a machine."
Mr. Kilbert said that at least 90 percent of his customers were men, but that women seemed to be growing more comfortable with the newer generation of games, which often require players to cooperate and negotiate with one another. Some of the newly popular games can be played with only two people, but most generally require at least three players and can support up to perhaps six.
Many of the newly popular board games focus on competitive exploration and development rather than on overt conflict. In Settlers of Catan, for instance, players compete in building cities and roads to populate a virgin island but must exchange resources if they are to succeed, adding a level of diplomacy to the game. 
Francesca Basilico, 38, a children's clothing designer in Los Angeles, discovered Settlers of Catan in December during a holiday trip to New York.
"I have three kids, ranging from three to five, and so any games that we play at home are more geared to children," she said. "I liked the fact that when I was in New York we were able to play a game where you could spend time with your friends and where I actually had to think. It was for adults and was a bit higher level than Candyland, which is sort of what I'm used to."
Mr. Kilbert said that the new games were often designed to allow as many players as possible to remain in contention throughout the contest, perhaps reflecting a broader shift in the nation's culture.
"The mentality in the late 1950's and early 60's was that games should be played to the bloody death," said Mr. Kilbert,56, whose father founded the original Compleat Strategist store on East 33rd Street in Manhattan in 1973. "Scrabble has its aficionados, but it's the kind of game where one person can blow everyone else out of the water. In Monopoly, if you get the right properties and get hotels you will clobber everyone else. The people in their 30's today don't want that kind of game, they don't have that mentality. They want games where everyone can stay involved."
But the young adults in today's board game vanguard are thinking less about sociology than how physical games compare with their electronic counterparts.
Phil Potter, 30, a financial technology executive in New York, said that he enjoyed playing backgammon, bridge and occasionally chess on the Internet because a game can be completed in 10 or 15 minutes.
"But most of the really involved computer games can require 80, 100 hours to complete," he said. "I haven't really engaged in one of those for probably six months. When you're a kid and have endless time and no responsibilities, of course you play a lot of computer games. The great thing about strategic board games is they are a great opportunity to get people together and do something social."
Firm figures are not available, but Settlers of Catan, developed in Germany in the mid-1990's, may be the most successful of the new breed of board games. Robert T. Carty Jr., director of sales for Mayfair Games, a company based in Skokie, Ill., that is the game's English-language publisher, estimated that more than 10 million copies of the basic game and its expansion sets had been sold worldwide.
Mr. Carty declined to say how many copies have been sold in the United States but said that sales had risen by about 20 percent in each of the last few years. "All of the sales increases have been generated at the grass-roots level, which is people telling other people about it," he said.
At the moment, some of the renewed popularity of non-electronic games may even be rooted in economic conditions.
"In times of economic uncertainty, like now, we get a resurgence in people playing board games," said Rick F. Loomis, president of the Game Manufacturers Association. "When times get a little bit tight, people realize they can take out a game every Saturday night and play it instead of going out."
Most of the newer board games cost around $30, roughly the price of a new video game.
"Most people realize that they go buy a video game, they play it for a while and then it's done forever," said Mr. Loomis, who is also president of the game publisher Flying Buffalo. "With a board game you can play it for years. You can even put it in the closet for 10 years and then take it back out and play it. Video games get obsolete."
Paradoxically, perhaps, some of the new board games are themselves being translated into noncommercial Internet versions. They are even attracting the attention of video game companies. The video game company Capcom is developing an "official" Web version of Settlers of Catan and may soon try to shut down the unlicensed sites, Mr. Carty said.
But the online politics will not matter much to many of the young adults who are fueling the board game renaissance. Jonathan Fried, 35, a lawyer who invites friends to his home in Brooklyn for a game night every Tuesday, never seriously engaged in computer games. For him and some other members of his regular group, board gaming is essentially a return to earlier days.
"We played a lot of games all through junior high school," he recalled. "Then it stopped being cool. In high school you want to socialize, and the people who are playing these games in high school are not necessarily the people you want to be hanging out with. Either that or you are so insecure at that age that you don't think you can play games and be cool at the same time."
Lev J. Fruchter, 36, an old friend of Mr. Fried's who is now a Tuesday night regular, said that even after college, he had other things on his mind.
"We could have been playing games but we weren't because we were meeting people and getting drunk and staying out late and having real-world fun rather than simulation-imagination fun," he said. "Now you're at home and the kids are asleep upstairs and games are the perfect way to spend the evening."
Mr. Fruchter has two young daughters, and he plays a simplified version of the board game Carcassone with his 3-year-old.
Doesn't he want her to start learning about computers?
"Look at the world today," he said. "She is going to be spending enough time playing computer games. I am in no hurry to get her spending more time in front of the screen."
