HEADLINE: It Adds Up (and Up, and Up) 

BYLINE:  By ROB FIXMER 

 BODY:
WHEN Jon Green was growing up in rural Massachusetts in the 1970's, his family's phone service consisted of a party line shared with several neighbors. A simple rabbit-ears antenna captured all of seven television channels.
 Today, like many middle-class Americans, Mr. Green and his wife, Stacie, carry cellphones, and their home in Maynard, Mass., has a land-line phone, cable television and a high-speed connection to the Internet, each offering an array of extra services. The connections they have come to consider necessities are discreet if not invisible. The tangible reminder is the stack of bills the Greens must pay each month. 
 When technology executives and marketers talk about the value of their products, they tend to focus on computer chips, which are 350 times more powerful today than they were 20 years ago and cost about a third as much. 
But it is not the cost of the machines that has most altered household budgets. Instead, all that cheap computing power embedded in scores of new gadgets and married to communications networks has resulted in a growing number of subscription services that most consumers cannot resist -- and continuing charges that they cannot escape.
 The party line phone service they had in 1974 probably cost Mr. Green's family about $19 a month, the equivalent of about $70 today when adjusted for inflation. Long-distance calls were thought of as expensive, infrequent luxuries. Watching television was free, and access to the Internet would not be generally available or billable for two decades. 
 Today the Greens pay more than $225 a month for services that enable them to watch television, make phone calls and communicate over the Internet. That is more than a threefold increase, in today's dollars, for communications and home entertainment.
 Research at Columbia University in the late 1990's suggests that like the Greens, most other American households have spent an increasing percentage of their disposable income over the last decade to link themselves to the outside world. Other research, done at Rutgers University, suggests that the appetite for such services has not reached its limit: American families are spending only about half as much as they say they would be willing to pay for technologies that would perfectly meet their needs. That is heartening news for the companies that are trying to convince consumers of the virtues of high-speed Internet connections or digital cable or satellite television services. 
 Not everyone, to be sure, is happy about that continuing evolution. Some consumers say they resent the addictive nature of such offerings.
 "They get you hooked, and then you can't let go," said Sari Boren, a designer of museum exhibits from Cambridge, Mass. "A big part of what bothers me about the monthly payment thing is that no matter which of these services you subscribe to, you know they're going to keep raising the rates."
 Of course, the mix of services differs from household to household. 
 Many families consider extensive cable television access or unlimited cellphone use to be a greater priority than access to the Internet. Music lovers might tend to spend more for subscriptions to online jukeboxes or satellite radio systems. Frequent business travelers are likely to spend more than others for access to mobile wireless Internet services.
 "I know a lot of people who pay over $100 just for cable TV," said Tyrone Chee, a 42-year-old senior hardware engineer for R.R. Donnelly & Sons, a Manhattan-based printing concern. "Television isn't that important to me. We just have basic cable."
 But that does not mean Mr. Chee is not paying in other ways for his family's mix of technologies. His outlay for various communications services at his home in Maplewood, N.J., is about $400 a month -- if his 15-year-old daughter stays within the allotted minutes on her cellphone plan. "Last month, I ended up with a $600 cellphone bill because one of us talked way too much," he said.
 While Mr. Chee described his daughter's cellphone bill as "clearly excessive," he added that for himself and his wife, Dana, "the cellphone is an absolute necessity."
 The notion of what constitutes a necessity varies from one household to another, but some services tend to become ingrained and all but indispensable. Both the telephone and television have achieved this status, with a presence in more than 90 percent of American households. While only 54 percent of homes have Internet access and about 56 percent subscribe to a wireless phone service, the Internet and the cellphone service are considered essential by many people.
 An analysis of government data by academic researchers over the last 25 years shows that from the 1920's through the 80's, the average household spent about 6 percent of its disposable income on "information and entertainment," a category embracing everything from newspapers and movies to telephone service, radios and television sets.
 In the 1990's that figure jumped to 8 percent. Today, "it looks like it's more than 10 percent," said John Carey, who teaches courses in new media at Columbia University's graduate school of business. Clearly, Mr. Carey said, the increase in consumer spending on information and entertainment coincided with widespread expansion of cable and satellite TV and with the rapid growth of the public Internet.
 "The so-called information age and information economy are reaching down to the household level," said Mr. Carey, who has tracked consumer spending on communications media since 1990.
 And the effects go far beyond the so-called early adopters, those people who are first to embrace a new form of technology. Gary Kemp, a trademark lawyer in Boston, described himself and his wife, Jayne, a book editor, as "techno-minimalists." Nonetheless, he said, "We pay about $140 for basic cable, low-level local and long-distance service for one land line, the cheapest possible cellphone plan, and a basic modem-based Internet connection," he said. "The sheer number of bills is driving me nuts."
 Mr. Kemp is resigned to the idea that he will probably have to add network services as his 3-year-old daughter grows up. "When Susanna's old enough to spend too much time either on the phone or the Internet, I'll probably get a package service," he said.
 But by the time his daughter is old enough to commandeer the family's phone or computer, there are sure to be many more network services vying to entice the Kemps into tacking another monthly payment or two onto the family budget.
 As for his idea of a consumer-friendly package of services, that turns out to be something many consumers say they want, said James E. Katz, a professor of communications at Rutgers University. But, he is quick to add, "there's a fundamental difference between what people say and what they do." 
 When AT&T bundled a number of services into one monthly bill, he said, consumers went into sticker shock and cut back their expenditures.
 "If you're getting pelted monthly by a lot of little bills, it's irritating, but you don't tend to realize how much all that adds up to," Professor Katz said. "Whereas when they get all those items in one bill, people get horrified at how much they're spending. They start looking for ways to make the total dollar amount go down."
 Mr. Katz said his research suggested that if subscription costs were billed discretely, American consumers would continue to pay more for new gadgets and ways to connect with each other.
 Certainly there will be no shortage of new subscription services from which to choose. Companies are already aggressively marketing satellite radio, mobile wireless Internet broadband and myriad new online services. Networks that connect hand-held devices to the Internet are beginning seem essential to business travelers. Cable and satellite operators continue to add new products like digital broadcasts, high-definition content and video on demand. Wireless phone companies, which are already promoting cellphones that can take and transmit photos, plan to introduce dozens of other new Internet-based products over the next five years.
 Many market analysts predict that the surging popularity of TiVo, the digital television recorder, will inspire new home video servers that capture signals from multiple Internet, cable and satellite networks and feed them to computers, televisions and other devices around the house.
 What all these emerging services have in common is a business model based on subscriptions that are billed monthly or yearly. What the most successful services will share is an appeal that will quickly evolve from intriguing to compelling to essential.
 "These things always start out as somewhat exotic luxuries," said Professor Katz. "But it's surprising how quickly, by historical standards, they come to be perceived as necessities." 
 For example, for the first 40 years of its existence, the telephone was considered something of a luxury, or perhaps a dispensable convenience, he said. But by the 1960's, welfare agencies throughout the United States were incorporating phone costs into their calculations of welfare benefits as an essential commodity, like heat and electricity.
 At his home in Massachusetts, Mr. Green, a 37-year-old computer-systems specialist, discovered how irresistible communication services can be when he was laid off last year. "I looked carefully to see if there was any way we could reduce the level of service and save money," he recalled. "Unfortunately, I wasn't able to find any."
 Not without pain, anyway. He could have saved $65 a month by dropping the high-speed Internet service he gets over his phone line, but he said: "I'd have to be incredibly desperate before I gave up broadband. I don't even want to think about that."
 Similarly, Ms. Boren, the museum-exhibit designer, finds it "insane that I spend $46 a month for broadband when I'm online at home a total of about four hours a week." Yet, she said, "I would have to be facing extreme economic hardship before I would give it up. In fact, I would first cut out cable TV, even though I use cable multiple hours more than I use broadband."
 Ms. Boren, who is 38 and single, pays $128 a month for her combined cable television and cable modem services. Her personal line of resistance is the cellphone -- she has refused to get one, which she said made her "practically a social pariah."
 "But why should it?" she said. "It's not like I have a husband or kids that need to reach me all the time."
 Still, Ms. Boren acknowledged a limit to her resistance. "Twenty dollars is my breaking point," she said. "If I could find a plan for $20 a month, I would have a cellphone."
 Not surprisingly, research shows that price is an important factor in most consumer decisions about whether and when to subscribe to a new service. But research by Professor Katz suggests that the typical American household is nowhere near its limit -- that the average family would be willing to spend as much as $500 a month for the right combination of subscription services.
 "It isn't really all that much money given the value of the services," he said. "Consider that they get all the pleasures of fabulous sound, rich pictures, entertainment, multimillion-dollar films brought into their homes, highly individualized communications networks with which they can visit with their friends in an unlimited way any time. That takes the place of a lot of trips on the Concorde a generation ago, or, in generations before that, a trip on a luxury liner."
 "Network creep," as Professor Katz calls the proliferation of subscription services, has already had a significant impact on household budgets in the United States, he said, but because of the perceived value of the new services and because the phenomenon took place gradually over two prosperous decades, it has gone unnoticed by many consumers.
 Now that times are leaner, however, many households are re-evaluating monthly expenses and reassessing priorities. Some analysts are pessimistic about consumers' willingness to take on new services at a time of high unemployment and record consumer debt.
 Allan Tumolillo, the chief operating officer of Probe Research, a consulting firm in Cedar Knolls, N.J., that specializes in the telecommunications sector, said his biggest concern was consumer debt, which is now more than $1.7 trillion. Measured as a percentage of the nation's gross domestic product, that is the highest consumer debt level since the beginning of the Great Depression, according to government data.
 "This new-economy thing of subscribe to this, subscribe to that gets to be a lot of money," Mr. Tumolillo said. "You end up with some people paying $500 to $1,000 a month between their cable service, their cellphones, their phone lines, their long distance, their Internet service provider, two or three information services, music videos, what have you."
 Writing in an advisory for his clients in the telecommunications sector recently, Mr. Tumolillo suggested that baby boomers who are approaching retirement age during an economic downturn might change their habits.
 "Where will consumers put their dollars?" he wrote. "On services like D.S.L., cable modems, multiple cellular lines, I.S.P. accounts, online gaming, other subscriber-based services? Or will they shift spending toward more home improvement, toward health care, savings, paying off debt? This is extraordinarily difficult to predict."
 Ms. Boren suggested that perhaps the biggest cost of network creep was not in dollars but in the lost opportunities, amid the unrelenting buzz of a hyper-connected culture, to reflect quietly on the day's events or life in general. "The lack of a cellphone allows me to have unproductive moments," she said.
 In an ever more connected world, unproductive moments, not the hottest new service, could prove to be the ultimate luxury.

HEADLINE: U.S. Plan for Wall St. Firms Drops Provision for a Move 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Federal regulators have recommended that companies critical to the nation's financial system should try to resume operations within hours of a disaster or terrorist attack. The regulators did not require that Wall Street firms move their operations out of Manhattan, as many executives and city officials had feared.
 A white paper issued jointly Tuesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve said financial firms involved in processing market transactions should establish separate backup operations to help prevent wide-scale disruption of financial markets. 
 Tuesday's report, and an earlier version, were issued for the first time after Sept. 11, when the terror attack on the World Trade Center disrupted financial transactions for days. 
Industry executives and city officials said yesterdaythat they were heartened that the federal agencies did not think it necessary that backup operations be a minimum distance from main offices. An earlier version suggested that backup sites be as much as 300 miles away. City officials had feared that such a requirement would encourage the flight of financial jobs from New York.
"It seemed to me to be a much better result for New York City than what they started with," said Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff. "The reality is that securities firms like Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs already have backup facilities at their other offices."
Donald Kittell, executive vice president of the Securities Industry Association, said some Wall Street companies had resisted efforts by regulators to establish distance requirements for satellite offices.
"You had firms that had just invested millions of dollars in backup sites that were within 300 miles of New York," Mr. Kittell said. "They were afraid that there would be some heavy-handed requirement that they build it somewhere else."
As a result of a sluggish economy and the terrorist attack, the financial industry in New York City has lost 37,100 jobs over the past 25 months. City officials did not want the regulators to cause another exodus.
The federal agencies did recommend, however, that backup sites be in locations that did not use the same transportation network, telecommunications system or water as the main offices. Mr. Doctoroff said it was unclear whether that would preclude the Bank of New York's plan to move some operations to Brooklyn from Lower Manhattan, or Morgan Stanley's decision to move some offices to Westchester County. 
The agencies are also expected to issue recommendations concerning trading operations by the New York Stock Exchange, the National Association of Securities Dealers and financial services firms. Executives said they wondered whether those companies would be required to build backup operations elsewhere. The stock exchange announced earlier this week that it had decided against building a parallel trading operation in Westchester.
"Everyone is waiting for a second white paper to drop," Mr. Kittell said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
U.S. Companies Compete For Work in Postwar Iraq
The roster of United States companies that have received potentially lucrative contracts for work in the Iraq region continues to grow despite a demand by Democrats in Congress for an independent review of the process for awarding such deals.
 There is still no word on what company will win the grand prize in the bidding: a $600 million reconstruction contract. Page C2. 

Strong Ad Sales Lift Yahoo Profit
Strong advertising sales along with steady growth of its fee-based businesses, helped Yahoo earn $46.7 million in the quarter, exceeding the expectation of analysts. In the period last year, Yahoo lost $53.6 million, including a $64.1 million charge related to changes in accounting rules for acquisitions. C7.

American Offers Union a Pay Raise
American Airlines agreed to give members of the Transport Workers Union a short-term wage increase if they voted in favor of $620 million in concessions, and if the credit rating of the company improved. C8.

Tobacco Crisis Hits Governments
Only three months ago, governors across the nation were seeing the billions of dollars in payouts from cigarette makers as a magic elixir to solve their expanding financial crises. But bonds backed by the tobacco payments have suddenly become tainted on Wall Street and governments are rethinking their plans to borrow against future payments. A18.

The credit ratings of the Altria Group, along with those of its Philip Morris USA and Kraft Foods units, were lowered by Standard & Poor's, which cited increased litigation risk for tobacco companies. C8.

Clear Channel Blocks Promoters
Clear Channel Communications is cutting ties with music promoters who are paid by record labels to push songs to radio stations. C3.

After months of declining ratings as an all-talk station, WNEW (102.7, FM) is switching to a free-form music format. D4.

Microsoft Opens Door to Codes a Bit
Microsoft announced that it would allow industry partners the right to modify and then redistribute its underlying programming code used in cellphones, hand-helds, television set-top boxes and other devices. C7.

The Internet via the Power Grid
As cable, telephone and wireless companies compete to provide high-speed Internet access to homes, a new challenger is emerging based on a decidedly old technology. The idea is to send Internet data over power lines. C7.

Shares Drop on Earnings Worries
Stocks fell on earnings concerns. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 12.30 points, or 1.4 percent, to 865.99. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 100.98 points, or 1.2 percent, to 8,197.94. The Nasdaq composite index lost 26.20 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,356.74. C8.

Chief Quits Chemical Maker
Imperial Chemical Industries, the British specialty chemical and paint company, said that its chief executive, Brendan O'Neill, left, had resigned. His departure comes two weeks after the company surprised investors with a profit warning. Imperial Chemical, known as I.C.I., named John McAdam, 54, to succeed Mr. O'Neill. World Business, Section W.

Novel Ideas for a Risky World
In an age when risks abound, some risks can be managed -- with fire insurance, say. But what about housing price insurance? Or perhaps securities tied to a nation's economy?
Hal R. Varian: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: Shift in Bonds Has States Rethinking Tobacco Plans 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER and JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
State governments from New York to Oregon are pulling back from their plans to borrow directly against future payments of tobacco settlements and are scrambling to find other ways to use the payments to ease their expanding financial problems.
 An Illinois judgment last month against Philip Morris, the nation's largest cigarette maker, prompted investors to demand higher interest rates on bonds backed by the tobacco payments. 
 As a result, some states, like California, have delayed their plans to enter the tobacco bond market. Others, like New York, which saw tobacco borrowing as central to closing its budget gap, are finding other ways to borrow using the tobacco payments. In those cases, the states are paying less to borrow but are taking on more long-range risk. 
Only three months ago, governors saw the billions of dollars in payouts from the nation's cigarette makers as a magic elixir for various financial crises.
Turning the revenue from a 1998 settlement into immediate cash was accepted by Democrats and Republicans alike as a palatable alternative to less popular budget fixes, like tax increases or service cuts.
But Philip Morris's warning that it might forgo its next payment to the states next week and could face bankruptcy if it has to post a $12 billion bond to appeal the Illinois judgment, has taken the shine off the pot of tobacco gold. Even if the Philip Morris situation is resolved, the tobacco bonds are still tainted.
States are now coming up with new ways to tap a combined $206 billion in tobacco payments they are owed over 25 years.
"The risk of these bonds has obviously been raised," said Lee Dixon, director of the health policy tracking service at the National Conference of State Legislatures. "It is certainly chilling the states' actions. How long it stalls it, I really could not predict."
The states' responses run the gamut. Virginia canceled its $767 million tobacco bond sale April 1. California has put off its $2.3 billion issue scheduled for next week and paused to consider its options. Oregon and Missouri are turning to alternative bonds, freer of the tobacco taint. Colorado, Illinois, Indiana and Kansas are mulling their options.
And in New York, officials are still thrashing out exactly what to do. Even before the Philip Morris crisis, state leaders were bickering over how to structure a tobacco borrowing deal. Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, wanted the Legislature to approve $4.2 billion in tobacco borrowing to help plug a nearly $12 billion gap in the $90 billion budget.
Mr. Pataki's plans have, however, veered off script, and he is insisting on a new deal that will not transfer the financial risk to investors, as he had intended, but will keep it squarely in the state's lap. It was the effort to shed that risk that originally made the so-called tobacco bonds so popular with New York and other states.
"What's the right choice?" asked Bill O'Keefe, head of municipal bonds at Morgan Stanley, echoing the states' quandary. "Do you wait until the market for tobacco bonds settles down and sell tobacco bonds that transfer the risk of nonpayment to the bondholders? Or do you go for lower interest costs and take the risk into the state?"
It is a question states are increasingly struggling with as they realize that the tobacco windfalls might be less reliable than they thought.
Since the 1998 settlement with 46 states (and earlier ones with Florida, Minnesota, Mississippi and Texas), many governors have dedicated a bulk of their tobacco cash for health care and research, smoking cessation or education, in line with the spirit of the settlement. 
States, however, are facing a combined deficit of $27 billion in 2003 and as much as $70 billion in 2004. 
So far, Mr. Dixon said, 17 states have used tobacco settlement revenue as a vehicle for borrowing, 6 of them to address revenue shortfalls.
But even as more states queued up to the enter the market, that market effectively closed soon after March 21, when Judge Nicholas Byron of Madison County Circuit Court in Illinois awarded a $10.1 billion judgment against Philip Morris and required the company to put up a $12 billion deposit by April 21 to appeal the verdict. Philip Morris, with the help of attorneys general from 37 states and territories, is trying to get that requirement lowered.
The company's credit rating, as well as that of its parent, Altria, has since been reduced. The ratings on about $18 billion of tobacco bonds have also been lowered, with yields on some trading in the secondary market now up to 7.8 percent, from 6.2 percent before the Illinois court decision. When the yields rise, so do the costs of borrowing to the states.
As a result, Oregon and Missouri have been forced to drop plans to sell tobacco bonds. Instead, the states plan this week to enter the bond market, but they would back the bonds with their general fund and use the annual tobacco settlement revenue indirectly to pay the principle and interest.
"They can take the money into the general fund and with their own internal accounting pay the principle and interest with the tobacco money," said Robert A. Kurtter, senior vice president for state ratings at Moody's Investors Service. "But for the investor, it is the general fund."
That new approach means that those two states, and others that follow, could save millions of dollars in interest over the next 20 to 30 years. But to get the lower rates, the states have to take on the risk, not unsubstantial, that the cigarette companies will fail to make payments.
On the plus side, the interest rate for those kinds of bonds is based on the state's credit rating, which is high for Oregon and Missouri. Thus,the new deal is less expensive for those states.
Jim Carder, director of Missouri's division of accounting, said the state expects to pay around 5 percent on its bonds, instead of 7 percent or more for the tobacco bonds. Mr. Carder said the idea to switch from tobacco was elementary. 
It was not so easy for New York to choose the path of Oregon or Missouri because New York's debt reform act of 2000 barred the issuance of state debt to pay operating costs and is something Mr. Pataki worked for years to achieve. State budget officials say the tobacco bonds do not qualify as state debt. 
Democratic opponents of Mr. Pataki's plan disagree, arguing that the tobacco money is a recurring revenue source and that to consider it off budget is a fiction or accounting gimmick.
Nonetheless, a deal appears to be moving forward. The Pataki administration has now zeroed in on a so-called hybrid alternative tobacco bond, unlike any other and perhaps a model for other states.
Under the plan, which would require legislative approval, New York would borrow $4.2 billion against the $10.4 billion in tobacco payments the state is due over the next 20 years, using part of the annual tobacco payments to cover the principle and interest on the bonds. 
But the bonds would include a backup source for debt service payments if the tobacco settlement payments evaporate. This would come in a separate appropriation each year from the state's general fund that would be set aside for the payment of the principle and interest. Should the tobacco money not materialize, this pot of money would be available.
Pataki administration officials do not believe the appropriation, which will not be included in the state's regular budget, would ever be spent. 
And while they admit a risk to the state remains, they also cite an advantage: the interest paid on the hybrid bonds will be about 4 or 5 percent, akin to what the state pays for the rest of its debt.
New York officials will most likely wait to sell the state's hybrid tobacco bonds until, as one budget analyst put it, the problems with the tobacco industry, "settle out." By then, the decision will probably be part of an overall budget solution for the state.

HEADLINE: In Los Angeles, It's South-Central No More 

BYLINE:  By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 9 

 BODY:
South-Central Los Angeles, the neighborhood that became infamous in recent years for riots, gang violence and poverty, is no more -- at least according to the Los Angeles City Council.
 The council voted unanimously today to rename this 16-square-mile district South Los Angeles as part of an effort to erase the image of South-Central as the scene of race riots in 1965 and 1992 and the setting for films featuring gangs and drug dealers like "Training Day," "Colors" and "Boyz 'n the Hood." 
 From now on South-Central will start disappearing from maps, and the area will be called South Los Angeles in city documents, correspondence, maps and community plans.
The South-Central neighborhood had long been predominantly black, but in recent years became more ethnically diverse as Hispanics, Aisans and whites moved in. 
Supporters of the name change said that while South-Central is defined on city maps as a 16-square-mile rectangle with two prongs at the south end, the name had become a racially charged shorthand applied to other areas of Los Angeles that have predominantly black populations.
Residents of solidly middle-class neighborhoods have long complained that they were being unfairly stigmatized and lobbied the city to get rid of the name.
"We believe this action will go a long way toward changing attitudes and how people view this community," Councilwoman Jan Perry, an author of the motion, said. "We still need more jobs, better schools, health care and recreational activities, but we hope this change will help communities discover their cultural and historical significance."
Although there was no organized opposition to the name change, some residents said that they were proud to be from South-Central and that they found the council's action offensive.
At the intersection of Florence and Normandie Avenues in South-Central, the flash point of the 1992 riot, Evann Tavares, manager of Art's World Famous Chili Dogs, which was founded in 1939, said: "There's nothing wrong with being from the 'hood. You should be proud of your roots. It's nothing to be ashamed of."
Maria Mendoza, a 17-year-old student who was born in South-Central, said: "This is ridiculous. It's still going to be the same neighborhood with the same problems. Nothing will change."
Ms. Mendoza said that instead of "wasting time making silly motions to change names" the council "should work harder to reduce crime and create opportunities for poor people."
But some businesses in South-Central said the new name was a good idea. "I think the change will be very positive because a lot of people hear the name South-Central and they are afraid to patronize businesses here," Juan Vaca, manager of Auto Zone, an automobile-parts store built shortly after the riots, said. "Image is important when it comes to business, so being located in South L.A. versus South-Central L.A. certainly won't hurt us."
Rojellio Martinez sells oranges, peanuts and ice-cold coconuts on the corner where television cameras captured a gang of black men beating Reginald O. Denny, a white truck driver, during the riots 11 years ago after the acquittal of four police officers over the beating of Rodney G. King, the black motorist.
"It's great that they are trying to improve the image of this barrio," Mr. Martinez said in Spanish.
Supporters of the change said South-Central had derived its name from South-Central Avenue, which during the last century was the business and professional hub of the city's black residents. Over time, however, the black population shifted west toward Crenshaw Boulevard, and the area known as South-Central became increasingly Latino. Because of its inexpensive housing, it has been home to many new immigrants.
For several years now, many neighborhoods in Los Angeles and nearby cities have changed their names to distance themselves from areas with bad reputations. Sepulveda, a neighborhood in the San Fernando Valley, recently became Panorama City and North Hills. In Compton, a Los Angeles suburb infested with crime and gangs, the Crystal Park Hotel and Casino has marketed itself as being in Crystal City to attract tour groups.
"I think there's a lot to be said for renaming South-Central, a moniker that tends to stigmatize rather than uplift," Mark Ridley-Thomas, a California Assembly member and former city councilman representing the area, said. "The bottom line is that no one wants to be stigmatized."
The assemblyman said that many neighborhoods like Green Meadows, Chesterfield Square and Morningside Heights that were generically described as South-Central have their own identities and character that should be recognized.
One councilman who voted in favor of the name change said the move was cosmetic and would have no impact on the community. "It's meaningless and won't really change a thing," Councilman Nate Holden said. "What is really needed is a comprehensive program to address crime, unemployment, education and drug abuse."
Mr. Holden said that the ethnic makeup of South-Central and much of Los Angeles was shifting rapidly, as the number of Latinos and Asians in the city increases and the black population declines. This demographic shift, he said, will have profound consequences for the political process.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: THE RECOVERY; 
Relief Agencies Are Forced to Wait as Chaos Reigns

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

 BODY:
Lawlessness in Iraq is preventing international relief organizations from entering the country with emergency shipments of medicine, food and water, blankets and other supplies, relief officials said yesterday.
 The lack of security also has led the International Committee of the Red Cross to suspend its Iraqi relief program, the only one that has been operating in the country throughout the war. The organization suspended its program after Vatche Arslanian, a 48-year-old Canadian who was in charge of logistics for the Red Cross in Iraq, was killed in a crossfire in Baghdad on Tuesday. 
 "We're taking it day by day, but the situation must be stabilized," said Amanda Williamson, a Red Cross spokeswoman in Washington. "We know from long experience that there is often a vacuum when a war is ending and lawlessness can be a real factor with immediate consequences for the population." 
The death of Mr. Arslanian underlined the precariousness of any planning for relief work while fighting continues. Kenneth Bacon, president of Refugees International, said he wished that American military forces would concentrate on securing hospitals and food stores and not on pulling down statues of Saddam Hussein.
While American and British troops have handed out food parcels to Iraqi civilians and military doctors have bandaged their wounds, the full relief effort -- which some officials said would be the largest in years -- will be carried out by the United States civilian agencies led by the United States Agency for International Development, by agencies from the United Nations and other international and private relief groups.
By charter these organizations are unable to work under the authority of any military force, including the Pentagon's civilian team headed by a retired general, Jay Garner, which will initially administer the country. Instead, the international and private aid organizations will coordinate their activities with General Garner and the military to ensure that the relief programs are as effective as possible.
Aid organizations said they have been stockpiling supplies in neighboring countries and preparing staff in the weeks leading up to the war, but have had little idea what they will find when they get inside Iraq and begin assessing the condition of the water and sanitation system, the size of the food stocks and the state of the medical system.
"It is very very difficult to give a picture of the needs of the Iraqis," said Oliver Ulich, of the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. "We know the generalities -- running out of medical supplies, of water -- but without a proper assessment we cannot make any predictions."
One of the few situations that is relatively clear is the amount of food that will be needed. The relief organizations will inherit the oil for food program begun by the United Nations in 1996 to offset health problems created by the sanctions program. The Iraqi government set up a nationwide food distribution system that relief experts hope will be in good enough shape to be reassembled.
"We know we will need to feed 27 million Iraqis at the beginning -- the largest operation in our history -- but we don't know how we will be able to revive the distribution system, what will be left, who will do it," said Jordan Day, spokesman for the United Nations World Food Program.
That effort will require 480,000 tons of food every month. It will also cost nearly $2 billion. The United States has already contributed more than 600,000 tons of grain and $200 million, but the agency said it needs an additional $1.3 billion.
Working with the United States Agency for International Development, the U.N. food program has begun buying and shipping enough food for the next four months. But at the start, the agency is counting local food stocks inside Iraq. Grain purchased from neighboring Syria and other countries in the region will be a stopgap while food from the United States begins to arrive.
The far more crucial problems are water and medical supplies.
Already, children are lining the highways from the southern port of Um Qasr to Basra, begging westerners to slow their cars and share their water. Mohammed Hussein, a 30-year-old barber in Basra, said yesterday that while he appreciated the defeat of the Saddam Hussein government, he was upset that it has not been replaced. "For three weeks, there is no water, no electricity," he said. "The British are kind to us but we need water."
The Hussein government did operate these delivery systems to ensure there was food and water throughout the country. That system, however meager, disappeared in the last days and until the American-led military force establishes order it will not be replaced.
At the same time, much of that water was filthy, delivered in rusty pipes with little concern for the health problems it caused. Roughly one in five of Iraq's young children are malnourished because of diseases caused by the water, said Mr. Day of the World Food Program.
The United Nations Development Program has warehouses in northern Iraq with $60 million worth of equipment and spare parts needed to repair the electrical system , which powered water and sanitation plants that were either destroyed or crippled in the fighting.
"Because we don't know nearly enough about the situation in south and central Iraq we can't say what will be needed when we finally are able to assess the damage," said William Orme, the spokesman for the U.N. program.
The Red Cross has already warned that hospitals are running out of supplies to treat the war wounded.

HEADLINE: Suit Accuses Toyota Of Bias in Lending 

 BODY:
A lawsuit was filed in San Francisco yesterday accusing the financing unit of Toyota Motor of discriminating against black and Hispanic car buyers in setting the interest rates on their dealer-arranged loans.
 The suit was filed in California Superior Court by a team of lawyers that includes Bill Lann Lee, who ran the Justice Department's civil rights division during the Clinton administration. 
He is now a partner at Lieff Cabraser Heimann & Bernstein in San Francisco. 
 In recent weeks, the legal team has quietly filed similar cases against the financing arm of Honda Motor and WFS Financial, the auto credit unit of Westcorp.
All the cases contend that the auto finance companies have allowed their dealers to discriminate against blacks and Hispanics by adding extra points -- called dealer markup -- to the interest rates that the finance companies established for borrowers based on credit histories. 
A result, the lawsuits say, is that blacks and Hispanics paid higher interest rates than whites with similar credit ratings.
The lawsuits, like similar cases filed in recent years against other auto dealers, ask the courts to bar the dealer markup practice and reimburse consumers for discriminatory practices in the past.
A Toyota representative said last night that the company was committed to fair lending and permitted its dealers to add no more than 3 points to their loans.
A spokesman for Honda declined to comment. WFS Financial did not respond to a phone call made to its corporate office last night.

HEADLINE: U.S. Left Out of Emissions Trading 

BYLINE:  By OTTO POHL 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
During negotiations over the Kyoto Protocol, the United States preached the importance of market solutions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Few countries listened. 
 Now, with the Americans no longer at the table, the former free-market opposition has taken over the pulpit. Canada ratified the treaty in December, meaning the plan to reduce greenhouse gases is just one nation shy of becoming law in more than 100 countries. And the heart of the treaty is an emissions-trading plan that closely resembles what the United States originally proposed. 
 "When Bush pulled out in the cavalier way he did, he galvanized everyone around the world to make it work," said David Doniger, a former Kyoto treaty negotiator under President Bill Clinton and now policy director of the Climate Center at the Natural Resources Defense Council. "The system is made in America, and the Americans aren't part of it."
Other countries see opportunity in America's retreat. 
"Now that the Americans are out, Europe can dominate the emissions trading market," says Steve Drummond, managing director of a greenhouse gas brokerage in London called CO2e.com. "It entitles the Europeans to write the rules for global trading."
And Europe has indeed been busy writing. Britain introduced the world's first organized trading system two years ago. Denmark has begun a smaller plan, and in December the European Union issued plans to begin full-scale trading in 2005. With Kyoto shaping a multibillion-dollar commodities exchange, companies are already trading emissions reductions, which are expected to become increasingly valuable as other companies enter the market.
The idea behind what are called cap-and-trade arrangements is to issue a limited number of pollution permits and then allow companies to buy and sell them. Whoever can reduce emissions cheaply can sell unused permits to others, making creative ideas for pollution reduction a profit opportunity. As overall reductions are realized, governments can slowly reduce the number of outstanding permits to keep both the price of permits and interest in further reductions high.
It is hard to quantify the benefit or loss to American businesses for not being part of the global market. Certainly, heavy polluters are better off because they do not have to buy pollution permits or invest in new technology. Companies that could achieve low-cost reductions, however, cannot realize the profits by making those reductions, and the market infrastructure of brokers and trading experience is developing abroad.
American multinational corporations are also forced to put in place two ways of accounting for carbon dioxide emissions, one for emissions inside the United States and one for emissions in nations that signed on to Kyoto. And with various proposals before Congress to regulate greenhouse gas emissions, companies contemplating equipment upgradings in their American plants are unsure what kind of regulatory environment they face.
So far, regulation is strictly self-imposed. Trading at the Chicago Climate Exchange, a market based on voluntary compliance, is set to begin in June. The chairman and chief executive of the exchange, Richard Sandor, says that even voluntary markets can allow the United States to be competitive internationally. "This will squarely put the U.S. in a very good position to lead efforts in developing market-based solutions to environmental problems," he said. "Carbon is only the beginning."
Outside experts are not as hopeful for voluntary measures. "Mandatory programs can force behavior from inefficient firms," says Thomas P. Lyon, a visiting fellow at Resources for the Future, a Washington research center. "A voluntary program simply can't touch those."
One reason companies are involved with the climate exchange is to prepare for mandatory requirements they foresee. "It's an insurance policy," said Bruce Braine, vice president for strategic planning and analysis at American Electric Power, the nation's largest power generator and biggest emitter of carbon dioxide. "If you ultimately have mandatory requirements, then this gives us first-mover advantages."
So far, the right to emit an estimated 200 million tons of greenhouse gases has changed hands, and trading volumes are growing rapidly. According to Natsource, a large environmental gas brokerage firm, volumes last year matched the volume for the previous five years. Most of the volume is driven by the desire to get low prices on emissions reductions that companies expect will be valid under the Kyoto agreement. 
The right to emit the equivalent of one metric ton of carbon dioxide now sells for $3 to $8, said Jack D. Cogen, chief executive of Natsource. When Kyoto takes effect in those countries that have ratified it -- Russia, for one, is still to act -- that price is expected to rise sharply. Estimates for the size of the greenhouse gas market vary widely, but everyone agrees it will be a major commodities market. "Every time you burn fossil fuels you create carbon," Mr. Sandor of the climate exchange said. "This market could be as big as the energy market."
The Dutch government is now one of the largest buyers on the market. Canadian corporations, which had been buying large volumes of American emissions reductions in recent years, have scaled back since it became clear the American reductions would not be compliant with Kyoto.
Brokers are still waiting for precise Kyoto rules to be published, which will allow trading to develop similar to that for stocks and bonds. For now, each deal is based on an estimate about whether the reductions will comply. "It's like selling real estate," said Frank Joshua, managing director of Natsource Tullett (Europe) Ltd. 
Today at CO2e.com, a subsidiary of Cantor Fitzgerald, just a few employees sit in offices next to Cantor's trading floor, where billions of dollars of bonds change hands daily. Mr. Drummond of CO2e.com looks forward to the day when his brokers join the brokers working the bond market a few feet from his desk. "The emissions market closely resembles the bond market," he said. "This is a serious business opportunity."
The idea of trading pollution credits first came up in a significant way in the Clean Air Act of 1990. It was intended to reduce pollutants responsible for acid rain and was signed into law by President George H. W. Bush. 
The Clean Air Act reduced dangerous pollutants like sulphur dioxide for a fraction of what it had cost before. The Environmental Protection Agency estimates that for a cost of $1 billion, the legislation has saved the United States at least $50 billion in health costs alone.
By not putting in place similar legislation for greenhouse gases, critics fear, the United States allows other countries to gain experience and win business in the field. "All we're doing now is giving other countries a chance for remedial education," said Mr. Doniger of the Natural Resources Defense Council, "and it will cost us in the end."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Now that the Americans are out, Europe can dominate the emissions trading market," said Steve Drummond of C02e.com. (Otto Pohl for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Furniture Forecast: Thawing Prices 

BYLINE:  By LIZ SEYMOUR 

DATELINE: HIGH POINT, N.C. 

 BODY:
SPIRITS were surprisingly good at the International Home Furnishings Market, the largest wholesale furniture expo in the world. Under budding dogwood trees, international news faded to a whisper. A headline in Furniture Today read "War Causes Rug Delays," and analysts reminded retailers and buyers that despite a three-year slump in furniture sales, housing starts and existing home sales were up and interest rates were down, traditionally good signs for the furniture industry. "We've got to get this war behind us so we can go out there and furnish those hundreds of thousands of new homes," Pat Norton, chairman of La-Z-Boy, said. 
 At the spring show, which ended yesterday, the war more often discussed was the price war raging between importers and domestic producers. Imports represented $14.2 billion of the industry's $44 billion sales in wholesale furniture in 2002, and China's furniture exports to the United States alone increased 37 percent between 2001 and 2002. 
 In a sign of increased attention to prices, Henrendon introduced a line of licensed Ralph Lauren furniture that will sell for slightly less than an existing Ralph Lauren Polo line. 
Other furniture being introduced was generally a little warmer, maybe even a little cozier, than in past years. "Consumers want to feel good in the only environment they can control right now," said Michelle Lamb, chairman of Marketing Directions, which forecasts colors and trends for the home furnishings industry. 
Designers delivered smaller pieces in upbeat colors and playful stripes and checks. Shades of red, from lipstick to chili powder, were everywhere; Mitchell Gold reported brisk sales in recent months of anything upholstered in red leather. A vibrant blue, somewhere between robin's egg and swimming pool, also appeared in many showrooms.
Demand for psychic comfort may be driving a resurgence of wing chairs, high-backed sofas and high-armed settees, which stood around showrooms like little upholstered isolation booths. Thayer Coggin introduced a streamlined wing chair, while Mitchell Gold went more traditional with Grace, a bright-red wing chair with a tall back. Chris Madden's new collection for Bassett included a curved and button-tufted wing chair in buttery leather. 
Other curvy pieces included Weiman's kidney-shape Infinity sofa; a two-piece sofa from La-Z-Boy; and a small armless sofa from Baker, which it paired with a curved mahogany table.
In many showrooms, "it's smaller or it's longer or it's taller, but it's not fatter and lower," said Larry Laslo, on hand to introduce his new collection for Directional.
Six months ago, concerns about the economy and the world situation were nearly drowned out by the hoopla surrounding big-name licensed furniture collections, among them Martha Stewart at Bernhardt, Jaclyn Smith at Largo and Humphrey Bogart at Thomasville. Early returns suggest that the Martha Stewart and Bogart collections are connecting well with consumers. "If you have something good and it's solid and branded right, people are going to buy no matter what," said Judy George, chief executive of the furniture chain Domain. 
The celebrity licensees at this market were of smaller caliber. Steve Tyrell, the Grammy-winning jazz musician, sang a few riffs to piped-in music as he led visitors around New Standards: the Steve Tyrell Collection, 72 pieces for Pennsylvania House. 
The wisdom of keeping celebrities away from the drafting board was demonstrated at La-Z-Boy, which showcased some ungainly recliners designed for a charity auction by members of the cast of "Friends."

HEADLINE: Success for Brazil Despite Naysayers 

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 9 

 BODY:
As the government of President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva passed its 100th day in office this week, the specters of economic calamity that his election had raised for foreign investors -- debt default, a sinking currency and economic mismanagement -- seemed to be just that, shadows.
 Mr. da Silva and his team could -- and did -- congratulate themselves that, because they committed themselves to a policy of tight money and painful spending cuts after taking office on Jan. 1, the economic signs are mainly pointing in positive directions. 
 The Brazilian currency, the real, has recovered from its swoon during the election. Government bonds are trading at their highest prices -- and lowest yields -- in years. The spreads between government bond rates here and in the United States, widely watched guages of investors' confidence in the government, are as narrow as they were a year ago, before the election. 
Still, analysts say, Brazil must be careful not to veer off the path to solid economic growth by postponing important reforms or permitting the real to become too strong. 
A strong currency cuts two ways. It makes imported goods cheaper for consumers, and it makes repayment of the government's extensive dollar debts easier. But it also makes Brazilian goods more expensive abroad. That could sap momentum from the boom in exports, which gave Brazil a $13.1 billion trade surplus last year and could help the country bring its current account, which also includes monetary flows, into balance this year.
Analysts said the government also needs to move quickly on important tax and pension programs while Mr. da Silva's approval rating remains high: recent polls put it at 64 percent, higher even than his 61 percent share of the vote in the runoff that gave him the presidency.
Speaking on Monday to the nation on television, Mr. da Silva acknowledged that he had "lost a few nights' sleep" over the "bitter medicine" that his government had applied economically since he became Brazil's first working-class president.
But he said the medicine, which included raising short-term interest rates to 26.5 percent for a time, freezing nearly $4 billion in public spending and aiming for a budget surplus equal to 4.25 percent of gross domestic product -- was already taking effect and had restored market confidence in the country.
"The world believes in Brazil again," Mr. da Silva said. "Now we must go forward cautiously, without exaggerated optimism and with our feet firmly on the ground, but sure that better days will come." 
Market analysts are looking at Mr. da Silva, a former lathe operator and union leader from a hardscrabble background, with fresh eyes, even those who predicted before the election that his government would soon default on the country's $250 billion debt.
"They've done much better than the pessimists predicted, including myself," said Maurice Goldstein at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "I don't think the finance team has made a serious mistake yet."
Others, who put more faith in the genuineness of the shift Mr. da Silva and the Workers' Party have made toward the political center, are now able to tell investors, "I told you so." 
When he last visited American and European investors in November, John Welch, the chief Latin America economist at West LB, said most of them "were very, very scared we'd have another Argentina on our hands in Brazil." But on the trip he just finished, investors were "reacting more and more positively to Brazil," he said.
"The best word to describe Lula's administration so far is 'constructive,' in all senses of the word," Mr. Welch said. "They are moving forward and they are trying to build a structure for growth."
Mr. da Silva has turned economic policy over to three market-minded advisers: the finance minister, Antonio Palocci; Luiz Furlan, a top executive at the Development, Trade and Industry Ministry; and Roberto Rodrigues, the agriculture minister, who came from Brazil's booming agribusiness sector.
But responsibility for other important industries has been given to politicians who have questioned privatization plans like those for the electric power and telecommunications companies, to the consternation of investors. And the national development bank, a longtime conduit for foreign capital, is under the control of politicians who have been hostile to foreign financial interests.
Mr. Palocci, a medical doctor who has led policymaking so far, warned Brazilians this week against "an excess of optimism."
"We cannot afford to neglect our agenda by thinking, for example, that we can ignore the tax and pension reforms," Mr. Palocci said in an interview with Valor Economico, a business daily. 
Mr. Furlan joined in, saying that "alarm bells would ring" in the export sector if the real were to rise above three to the dollar. Analysts, however, say the central bank is using the real's strength to reinforce its reserves, which fell about one-third last year, to $17 billion. The consensus forecast is for the real to level off at 3.20 to the dollar. 
"The thing is, this is not a 100-yard dash. It's a long race," said Mr. Goldstein. "The crucial question is whether they can keep it up -- whether they can deliver over the next six months to a year."

HEADLINE: Fears in Turkey That Its Cyprus Problem Is Alienating Europe 

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, April 9 

 BODY:
Remarks by Turkey's president and prime minister provided fresh signs today of the frustration many Turkish leaders feel over the divided status of Cyprus and, more specifically, over the degree to which it may hamper Turkey's bid to join the European Union.
 President Ahmet Necdet Sezer lashed out at European Union officials for repeatedly suggesting that Turkey would never get into the union until negotiations to reunite the Turkish and Greek sectors of Cyprus succeeded. 
 Mr. Sezer said Turkey was weary and suspicious of "some circles using the Cyprus and northern Iraq issues as elements of threat and blackmail," according to a written statement released by his office. 
Mr. Sezer was referring not only to the widespread European conviction that Turkey is to blame for the continued division of Cyprus but also to statements by European leaders that if Turkish troops crossed the border into northern Iraq, Turkey's entry into the union could be doomed.
As Mr. Sezer made his comments, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey and Prime Minister Costas Simitis of Greece met in Belgrade, Serbia, to discuss the Balkans. It was their first face-to-face discussion since the collapse last month of Cyprus peace talks that were mediated by the United Nations.
"Both our governments have to push," Mr. Erdogan told reporters in Belgrade. "We are in favor of a continuation of negotiations."
Mr. Erdogan had announced last week that his government would be redoubling efforts for the reunification of Cyprus, but he did not provide any kind of detailed proposal. He did not do that today, either.
Rather, the comments by Mr. Erdogan and Mr. Sezer signaled a general and apparently growing distress among Turkish leaders with the way in which Turkey is perceived and treated as the country responsible for the situation in Cyprus, which has been partitioned since 1974. Turkish leaders clearly want to change that.
Next week, the Greek sector of Cyprus is scheduled to sign an accession treaty as one of 10 new countries joining the European Union in 2004. In the absence of a reunification agreement for Cyprus, the Turkish sector of the island would be left out of the union.
"It comes as no surprise that the Turkish side is squirming," said John Sitilides, executive director of the Western Policy Center, a Washington research and education group that analyzes American policy in southeastern Europe.
"Turks are just beginning to come to grips, again at the last minute, with Cyprus crossing the next-to-last threshold toward full E.U. membership while Turkey's own accession program seems to be at a standstill," Mr. Sitilides said.
Turkish officials have also seen their country's alliance with the United States badly strained by the war in Iraq, and many of them do not want Turkey to drift away from Western Europe at the same time.
But Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriot leader, emphasized again today that the Turkish sector would resist any plan that seemed to put it under the control of the Greek sector.
"We are in favor of a good partnership, but we will never give up our sovereignty and state," Mr. Denktash said in Lefkosa, Cyprus, according to the Turkish state-run news agency.
European Union officials have long complained about Turkey's record on human rights, especially its treatment of ethnic Kurds, and are watching closely for any movement by Turkish troops into the Kurdish region of Iraq.

HEADLINE: New Kenyan President Vows to Deliver on Economic Promises 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, April 9 

 BODY:
Kenya's president, Mwai Kibaki, in a speech marking his first 100 days in office, said today that he would put into effect the election pledges that won him the top job, answering critics who say he has not yet delivered.
 Promising to revamp east Africa's biggest economy, Mr. Kibaki's party, the National Rainbow Coalition, defeated the Kenya African National Union, which had ruled Kenya for nearly 40 years. Kenya's economic performance had lagged badly in recent years, dragged down by years of corruption and mismanagement under the country's former ruler, Daniel arap Moi. 
 Mr. Kibaki won the December election on a platform of free primary education, a new constitution, zero tolerance of corruption and the creation of 500,000 new jobs every year in a bid to revive an economy that grew by only 0.9 percent in 2002.
Opinion polls published in Kenyan newspapers on Tuesday showed that a majority of respondents said they believed the country was headed in the right direction. Many more Kenyans have cheered the start of free primary education. But Mr. Kibaki's critics say that he has not delivered on his promise of new jobs.
Internal power wrangles in Mr. Kibaki's coalition have also sown widespread public doubts that the party is sincere in implementing its election pledges.
"We have made promises and are in the process of keeping them," Mr. Kibaki said in a taped speech that isto be broadcast later on radio and television. "Where there are delays, these are sincere. We are not a government that makes promises it does not intend to keep."
Mr. Kibaki took credit for reforms already introduced by his administration, especially the start of free primary education. He said this had added 1.6 million new pupils to the national school system, bringing the total to 7.5 million.
He said that institutions that had been dogged by allegations of corruption during the Moi era, particularly the judiciary, were also being cleaned up.
Mr. Kibaki stressed that the greatest changes so far had been in public attitudes. "The most important transformation in Kenya over the last one hundred days has been in the minds and hearts of the Kenyan people," he said. "We have seen a renewal of their confidence in the future."
Mr. Kibaki said he had established an important precedent by allowing his cabinet ministers to work without undue interference. Most Kenyans had criticized Mr. Moi for overruling his ministers on key issues, undermining their authority.
On employment, Mr. Kibaki said 4,000 new jobs had been created so far under the African Growth and Opportunity Act, which provides duty free access to the United States for a wide range of export products from 38 eligible African states.
Another 3,000 jobs had been created in the economy at large, Mr. Kibaki said. But that was a far cry from the 500,000 jobs he said he would create in his first year.
"Quite honestly, the promise for 500,000 jobs was a nice thought but totally unrealistic and unattainable in this economy for now," said Robert Shaw, a Nairobi businessman and columnist.
There was little prospect of widespread job creation in the immediate future, economic observers said. "So far there is no change on the ground, economic growth is hardly visible and people's purchasing power is still very low," said Manga Mugwe, chairman of the Kenya Association of Manufacturers.

HEADLINE: Cuba Confirms Sentencing Dozens of Pro-Democracy Dissidents 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: HAVANA, April 9 

 BODY:
Cuba confirmed today that dozens of dissidents who were arrested last month had been sentenced to prison terms of up to 28 years.
 In the first official statement on the trials of 78 opponents of President Fidel Castro rounded up since March 18, the Justice Ministry said the sentences ranged from 6 to 28 years. 
 The dissidents were convicted of "mercenary activities and other acts against the independence and territorial integrity of the Cuban state," said a ministry statement published on the front page of Granma, the Communist Party daily. 
After the largest wave of arrests in decades in Cuba, the authorities charged the dissidents with plotting with United States diplomats to subvert Cuba's government. Leading dissidents, democracy and rights activists and opposition journalists were arrested in their homes. The houses were searched by the police, who seized computers, typewriters, fax machines and books.
Many of the dissidents had attended meetings at the residence of the top United States diplomat in Havana, James Cason, who had increased support for the island's small but growing opposition movement, in line with the Bush administration's harder push for political change in Cuba.
A White House spokesman denounced the crackdown today.
"The president remains deeply troubled by the wave of repression and the long prison sentences handed down to Cuba's pro-democracy and human rights activists," said Michael Anton, a spokesman for the National Security Council.
"The Castro regime's arrest, prosecution and sentencing of these brave and peaceful activists are repugnant reminders that the Castro regime remains a totalitarian blight in an otherwise peaceful and democratic hemisphere."
The toughest sentences were for independent journalists -- 28 were arrested -- and organizers of the Varela Project, a petition for democratic reforms that gathered more than 11,000 signatures last year.
The initiative's leader, Oswaldo Paya, who won the European Union's top human rights award, the Sakharov Prize, in December, was not arrested, but his organization, the first nationwide opposition network, was dismembered in the roundup.
Luis Enrique Ferrer, a local coordinator in the city of Las Tunas for the Varela Project, was sentenced to 28 years in prison, the stiffest sentence, the Cuban Human Rights Commission said.
Cuba's best-known dissident poet, writer and journalist, Raul Rivero, 57, and the economist Martha Beatriz Roque, the only woman put on trial, received 20-year sentences.
International rights groups said the sentences given after one-day trials by improvised courts, where undercover agents who had infiltrated the dissident groups were produced as witnesses, was a throwback to Stalin-era proceedings.
Amnesty International called the jailings appalling and "a giant step backwards for human rights" in Cuba.
The Castro government was undeterred by an outpouring of criticism from foreign governments and rights groups and insisted that the dissidents were a tool of its longtime ideological foe, the United States.
The wives of jailed dissidents said they had three days to appeal, but they were not hopeful the sentences could be changed. "These terms were dictated by President Castro," Mr. Rivero's wife, Blanca Reyes, said after hearing his sentence on Monday. "In Cuba there is only one voice. This is like a Roman circus."

PERSON: Dwight C. Johnson 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
A Fund-Raiser Who Bridges Racial Borders

BYLINE:  By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
A CLOSE friend of Dwight C. Johnson's told him recently that she finally gets him, how he manages to assemble people like George Lucas, Martin Scorsese and David N. Dinkins under one roof, as he did Monday night. He is the president of the Black Alumni of Pratt Institute, which raises money for low-income black and Latino students.
 "She says, 'Dwight, you make people want to be a part of what you're involved in, then you make them empty their pockets,' " recalls Mr. Johnson, a graphic designer, from a cramped apartment on Lexington Avenue near 31st Street that doubles as his office. 
 Then again, maybe the light sabers figure into the equation. More than 70 boxes of the Star Wars sabers were piled high in Mr. Johnson's apartment on the eve of the alumni group's 12th annual scholarship benefit Monday at the Waldorf-Astoria. There were so many sabers, donated for the 250 guests by the maker of the toy, Hasbro, that some were stacked in Mr. Johnson's bathtub.
At a time of challenges to affirmative action on college campuses, when the economic climate is frightful, Mr. Johnson has quietly built a reputation for crossing racial and economic borders to diversify his alma mater.
In Monday's slush and snow, Mr. Johnson, who is 53, raised $260,000 at the black-tie affair, in which James Earl Jones was the M.C. Brooke Astor, who is a major benefactor for the group, did not brave the weather, but Mr. Johnson lunched with her last month at the Four Seasons restaurant in honor of her 101st birthday. An annual award, which she presented at last year's benefit, is given in her name.
So how does Mr. Johnson do it? He's corralling people who tend not to be straphangers on the G train to Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, where Pratt, the private art and design school, has its main campus.
Mr. Johnson seems a bit taken aback. He says he merely writes a note or reaches out. "It seems they are waiting to be brought in," he says. He got in touch with Mr. Lucas, who was honored on Monday, through a Web site, then e-mailed his office.
"Everybody thought I was out of my mind," Mr. Johnson says. "I do it from the heart. If this was something for myself, I couldn't do it."
As Mr. Johnson tells it, he had his first meeting about five years ago with Mrs. Astor after she wrote him on blue Tiffany note paper, suggesting a meeting. He says she was on his group's mailing list. He took a bouquet of flowers to her office and asked her to read one of her poems. (He says Osborn Elliott, the chairman of the Citizens Committee for New York City and former editor of Newsweek, had told him she wrote poetry, and that he would be wise to ask her to read one.) 
When Mrs. Astor finished, Mr. Johnson says he stood, applauding with two hearty bravos. She asked how much his group needed. He told her that $50,000 would be nice. Thus started the alumni group's endowment, now at $1 million.
On a recent day, Mr. Johnson's apartment is packed with 10 young volunteers, mostly Pratt students and graduates. They are labeling boxes of giveaways for the fund-raiser, confirming reservations, revising table listings on computers. Mr. Johnson goes to a back room that looks like an office. Up high, above a wall of closets, are two fluffy pillows. Mr. Johnson, who is single, sleeps on a Murphy bed.
He says he took a sabbatical two years ago from Pratt, where he is a full-time professor in the School of Art and Design, to start his own design and marketing business. He volunteers for the alumni group.
Trimly built with a light mustache, Mr. Johnson has a big gusty laugh and old-fashioned manners as he serves tea. He is dressed in a three-button Jil Sander suit and a blue shirt with gold cuff links.
He is relaxed even when a nerve-racking call comes in from the Waldorf, informing him that lunch will cost $50 a sandwich for the technical crew putting up the stage. He takes in the information, calmly, then says the crew will grab lunch outside the hotel. He hangs up, chuckling.
MR. JOHNSON grew up in Detroit, the son of a Chrysler factory worker. His mother worked as a secretary in a synagogue. "I can remember we were on public assistance and we always had to make do with what we had," he says. He says he was a quiet, shy youth, always drawing and making sculptures. He was desperate to attend Cass Technical High School, a revered institution in Detroit that was attended by Diana Ross, but failed its entrance exam on his first try.
"I'm not a multiple-choice person," Mr. Johnson says.
He says his mother found him a tutor through the synagogue where she worked, and he surreptitiously got a copy of the exam. As it turns out, he was tested on a different version of the exam. "I was scared to death." Still, he passed and went to Cass, then received a one-year scholarship to Pratt from Scholastic magazine.
He says he thinks of his own struggles when he is asked why he devotes his free time to the alumni group, which has supported more than 300 students. 
"These students are me," he says. "I know how hard it was for me to go to Pratt. I came up here with a scholarship and I did maintenance work in the evenings and sold women's shoes. I had to struggle. I'm willing to help others. It's my responsibility. It's our responsibility. And if I'm an example, let it be."

HEADLINE: Competing for Work in Postwar Iraq 

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
The roster of United States companies that have received potentially lucrative contracts for work in the Iraq region continues to grow despite a demand this week by Democrats in Congress for an independent review of the process for awarding such deals.
 The most recent winners, for work that could total as much as $300 million, are the Fluor Corporation, based in Aliso Viejo, Calif.; Washington Group International, in Boise, Idaho; and the Parini Corporation, in Framingham, Mass. Last week, each company received a contract from the Army Corps of Engineers to provide up to $100 million worth of work to the military in the region. The tasks could include repairing roads and bridges, replacing damaged windows and doors and building barracks for military personnel. 
 According to unsuccessful bidders, the Raytheon Corporation in Lexington, Mass., and the Kellogg, Brown & Root unit of the Halliburton Corporation in Houston have received a $30 million contract from the Defense Threat Reduction Agency to dismantle and neutralize any chemical or nuclear weapons found in the region. Neither Raytheon nor the agency would confirm any contract.
But there is still no word on who will win the grand prize in the current round of bidding: a wide-ranging $600 million reconstruction contract that will be awarded by the United States Agency for International Development. The contract will cover early work on rebuilding Iraq's essential infrastructure, including airports, roads, water and power systems, schools and hospitals. The agency previously said it had narrowed the bidders to two finalists and would announce a decision by the end of last week.
The Bechtel Group of San Francisco and Fluor have both been mentioned as finalists, although neither the companies nor the agency would confirm that status. But an executive of the Parsons Corporation in Pasadena, Calif., said that her company had not been eliminated from consideration.
And although Halliburton announced publicly last week that it had not bid to be the lead contractor on the work, other bidders say that Halliburton is named in procurement documents as an integral subcontractor in the Parsons bid. Neither company would confirm that arrangement, but Halliburton's latest public statement on the contract noted that the company remained "a potential subcontractor."
Last month, Halliburton received an open-ended contract from the government to extinguish oil well fires in southern Iraq, along with subcontractors Boots & Coots and Wild Well Control.
That contract was specifically cited in the Congressional request this week for an independent review of the procurement process by which as much as $25 billion could ultimately be awarded for reconstruction in Iraq.
On Tuesday, Representatives Henry A. Waxman of California and John D. Dingell of Michigan, both Democrats, asked the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, to investigate whether Halliburton "has received special treatment from the administration over the past two years in the awarding of Defense Department contracts," including the oil fire contract.
They noted that Vice President Dick Cheney served as chief executive of Halliburton from 1995 until 2000 and is still eligible for some deferred compensation from the company. But they also cited numerous government investigations of Halliburton's work on previous government projects and its accounting for cost overruns on some of its long-term contracts.
The congressmen also asked the accounting office to conduct a more wide-ranging investigation of how the aid agency and the Pentagon have handled the bidding process so far. They specifically expressed concern about how specific companies were invited to submit bids without public notice, what information was provided to Congress about the process and whether the details of the bidding process were "properly kept secret." 
The aid agency has defended its procedures, saying that some degree of secrecy and selectivity was necessary because of the military situation in Iraq.
It is not clear whether the investigation will further delay the award of the pending reconstruction contract. The agency has already awarded two other small contracts for work in Iraq, a $4.8 million award to Stevedoring Services of America to operate the important port of Umm Qasr in southern Iraq, and a $7.1 million contract to the International Resources Group to provide coordination and monitoring services to the agency as it oversees the work in Iraq.
