HEADLINE: Must What Goes Up Also Come Down? 

BYLINE:  By Solomon Volkov; Solomon Volkov is author of "St. Petersburg: A Cultural History."

 BODY:
It is almost certain that the toppling yesterday of Saddam Hussein's giant statue in the center of Baghdad will be considered in retrospect as one of the iconic images of the present war in Iraq. As I watched this scene unfolding on television, similar episodes from the not-so-distant yet already faintly hazy past, sprang to my mind.
 First, of course, there was the 1989 demolition of the Berlin Wall, which for years divided Germany into the socialist East and the capitalist West. Watching that evening unfold on TV, one could feel the almost palpable physical excitement as youthful drunks madly clawed and hammered away at the hated symbol of this enforced division. 
 Then, on an August night in 1991, another statue came down. This time it was a bronze of Feliks Dzerzhinsky, the founderof the Soviet secret police, which had presided over central Moscow since 1958. One saw the same excitement but markedly less merriment, and the crowd looked more mature, even sober. They had thought ahead, going to the trouble of bringing along five cranes for the job. These people were exacting what felt like an intellectual revenge for the years of living in fear, of being able to talk candidly only with trusted friends -- and then only in a whisper. 
A parenthetical thought: lately, parallels have been drawn in the press between Saddam Hussein's Iraq and the repressive Communists who ruled Russia. I think an important difference between the two regimes was revealed when the solidity of the comparative statues was tested. The Soviet one had to be dragged away with much effort, exertion, etc. And when it came down, it came down in one piece. In contrast, the Iraqi monument toppled quite easily. And when it did, it broke apart, leaving the hollow boots of the dictator on the pedestal. Of course, the statue's quick demise could be attributed to the superiority of American equipment and expertise, which seem to be in plentiful supply in Baghdad these days.
Compared to the events in Berlin and Moscow, the crashing of Mr. Hussein's statue was a much more modest affair. One got the feeling that the dancing, shirtless men didn't extend too far beyond the camera's eye. This is probably not such a bad thing, because big symbolic gestures, while immensely satisfying at the time, rarely live up to their promise. This is certainly true with regard to Germany, where almost 14 years after the fall of the wall, the economic and psychological division between East and West endures.
As for Russia, there is now persistent talk coming from Moscow's conservative mayor, Yuri Luzhkov, that the statue of Dzerzhinsky (which conveniently survived intact and has been living a quiet life in a Moscow park) should be returned to its former home -- a traffic island in front of the headquarters of the former K.G.B. and its successor, the Federal Security Services. The liberal intelligentsia, of course, vehemently objects to the resurrection. But with polls showing that more and more Russians are looking on the Soviet past with fondness, there is a distinct possibility that one day we will see the once-toppled monument back at the heart of Moscow, gazing imperiously at passers-by.
And if this happened, one question in particular would gnaw at me: is it possible that among those who restored the statue, there were also some who helped to bring it down?

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Sues 4 Countries, Saying They Owe City $100 Million 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Turning from a budget crisis to the troubled world of international diplomacy, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city was suing four foreign governments that own Manhattan property for failure to pay real estate taxes.
 The suits seek more than $100 million in back taxes, interest and other charges from Turkey, the Philippines, India and Mongolia, claiming that for years they have used properties for housing or commercial enterprises that make them fully taxable. 
 City law stipulates that foreign governments are exempt from real estate taxes only on property used as missions or consulates. 
While Mayor Bloomberg has sought to foster warm relations with the United Nations because of its huge contribution to the city's economy and prestige, the legal actions announced yesterday make clear that City Hall will not pass up potential windfalls.
"Although we are proud to be the host of the United Nations, one thing we simply cannot afford is to be taken advantage of by our guests," Mr. Bloomberg said. 
Officials of the four governments either refused to comment or did not respond to telephone messages.
"Ask me about what is happening in northern Iraq, and I will have a response," said one Turkish diplomat at the United Nations. "Taxes are not my responsibility." 
Aides to the mayor said the lawsuits, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, follow months of discussions in which the city hoped to collect the back taxes without lawsuits.
They described the lawsuits as the first in which the city challenged the use of foreign government real estate for business or housing purposes.
The lawsuits seek the largest amount, $70 million, from Turkey, which the city claims is in arrears for more than 20 years of taxes on 821 United Nations Plaza, which it says is used for commercial purposes.
The complaint against the Philippines seeks $17.7 for use of a building at 556 Fifth Avenue from 1974 to 1996 by Philippine National Bank, Philippine Airlines and a restaurant.
The city is seeking $16.4 million from India for 235 East 43rd Street, which the city says was used for living quarters for people other than the head of India's mission or consulate. A similar claim is made against Mongolia for $2.1 million in taxes for a building at 6 East 77th Street.

HEADLINE: Jubilant V-I Day 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE; E-mail: safire@nytimes.com

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Like newly freed Parisians tossing flowers at Allied tanks; like newly freed Germans tearing down the Berlin Wall; like newly freed Russians pulling down the statue of the hated secret police chief in Dzerzhinsky Square, the newly freed Iraqis toppled the figure of their tyrant and ground their shoes into the face of Saddam Hussein. 
 All these pictures flow together in the farrago of freedom's victories over despotism in the past two generations. Just as video of human suffering understandably triggers demonstrations against any war, unforgettable images of the jubilation of enslaved people tasting liberty drive home the wisdom of just wars. 
 Even in the flush of triumph, doubts will be raised. Where are the supplies of germs and poison gas and plans for nukes to justify pre-emption? (Freed scientists will lead us to caches no inspectors could find.) What about remaining danger from Baathist torturers and war criminals forming pockets of resistance and plotting vengeance? (Their death wish is our command.) 
The most insulting question is this: Considering their Islamist religious schisms and tribal hatreds, their tradition of monarchy and obedience to dictatorial regimes, their turbulent "street" easily inflamed by demagogues -- how can any population of Arabs be entrusted with democracy?
The answer to that is the experiment on which Iraq is now embarked. Iraqis start with the advantages of being literate and extravagantly oil-rich, and most aren't fundamentalist.
If Iraqis are able to adopt a system of free enterprise and representative government, they will become the center of an arc of freedom from Turkey in the north to Israel in the south (with Lebanon freed from Syrian occupation, if France will liberate the state it created). Egypt, the largest Arab nation, could not long resist such a tidal wave of liberty.
A parade of former U.S. ambassadors to Arab nations pooh-poohs this vision, deriding the Bush-Cheney-Rumsfeld-Wolfowitz idealists as the four horsemen of hubris.
But consider one example of a big segment of Iraq's population that proved willing to ally itself wholeheartedly with the coalition, and showed under fire its eagerness to make sacrifices for its freedom.
Nobody came out of this war more nobly than the 3.5 million long-suffering Kurds of Iraq. After Gulf War I, we at first left them to the poison-gas savagery of Saddam, then expiated that sin by providing them air cover for the next decade. In that time, this ethnic group built a model state: a lively parliament, schools, hospitals, a thriving economy built on farming and a little smuggling on the side.
Their rival leaders, Massoud Barzani and Jalal Talabani, realized that what they call "our friends to the north" -- the Turks -- suspected a plot to declare an independent Kurdistan, which might encourage Turkey's Kurdish minority to break away. 
Because the U.S. believed that we would get Turkey's cooperation against Saddam, we refused to arm the Kurds, even though they were under attack from terrorists affiliated with Al Qaeda. Despite this, when we launched our invasion, the 70,000 Kurdish pesh merga troops volunteered to serve in the coalition under the command of our small airborne units in the north. The Kurds were and still are the only indigenous force fighting against Saddam's regime.
One tragic test of loyalty came last week when one of our aircraft mistakenly bombed a convoy carrying pesh merga to engage Saddam's troops. Nineteen Kurds died, with two of the Barzani clan wounded. A Barzani aide, Hoshyar Zabari, told me by cellphone afterward: "We do not blame anyone. This happens in war. We are fighting together for our freedom."
That's an ally. The Kurds have decided their cultural autonomy -- and their future safety -- lies not in independence but as part of Iraq's new confederation, with its capital Baghdad. "We will always retain our Kurdish identity, but we are Iraqis," emphasized Barham Salih, Mr. Talabani's prime minister.
My guess is that the urbane Mr. Talabani will serve in Iraq's national government, with the locally rooted Mr. Barzani in its regional capital in the north. They have learned how democracy works, and have earned a seat at the governing table. They also know, and will bear witness to their Iraqi compatriots in this great experiment, that the U.S. and Britain are freedom's best friends.

HEADLINE: A SATELLITE EMPIRE: THE DEAL; 
NewsCorp. Adds to Empire With Control of DirecTV

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
Completing the final piece in Rupert Murdoch's global satellite empire, the News Corporation agreed yesterday to buy control of Hughes Electronics and its DirecTV satellite operation from General Motors in a deal valued at $6.6 billion.
 The deal will give Mr. Murdoch even more power in determining what programs are beamed to television sets across the United States and how much consumers pay for them. 
 With the addition of DirecTV, the nation's largest satellite operator with 11 million subscribers, the News Corporation will become one of only a few media companies in the nation, among them AOL Time Warner, that both create television programs and distribute them. The News Corporation owns the Fox Network and dozens of local affiliates as well as the increasingly powerful Fox News Channel and a clutch of heavily watched regional Fox Sports networks. 
Mr. Murdoch, the chairman and controlling shareholder of the News Corporation, is expected to start a pricing war with cable companies that could benefit consumers. His control of DirecTV will also give him substantial leverage to defend his programming business against pressure from a consolidating cable industry and, critics contend, possibly even squeeze his cable rivals by raising the prices they pay for his programs.
"We can help make satellite TV a viable competitor to cable," Mr. Murdoch said on a conference call last night. "More programming options, richer content and compelling new technologies will give satellite TV the best chance to break cable's hold on viewers."
The deal ends nearly three years of bidding wars, changing alliances and regulatory jockeying as Mr. Murdoch has sought to take over DirecTV in an effort to make the News Corporation the dominant television distributor in the world, with satellite operations serving more than 100 million households in the United States, Europe, Asia and Latin America.
"I've always felt for years that if you're in the content creation business, you must be somewhere in the distribution business to make sure you're not wasting your efforts and your money," Mr. Murdoch said on Fox News.
In 2001, Mr. Murdoch lost a bidding contest for control of Hughes to EchoStar Communications, the nation's second-largest satellite operator. That deal was rejected by regulators late last year after Mr. Murdoch waged a behind-the-scenes lobbying campaign -- circulating a 123-page volume opposing the deal called "The Essential Guide to the EchoStar/DirecTV Deal" around Washington -- to block the agreement, giving him a second chance.
Of course, the News Corporation's deal for Hughes will also require the approval of regulators, including the Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission, and some consumer groups are already calling for this deal to be blocked as well. But unlike the deal with EchoStar, which would have combined the nation's two largest satellite television companies, legal experts suggest that the deal with the News Corporation will be approved because the company does not already compete in the satellite distribution business in the United States.
The News Corporation's offer for Hughes is significantly lower than the amount it offered in the 2001 bidding war -- a deal worth about $22.5 billion -- calling into question the decision by General Motors, which controlled Hughes, to accept EchoStar's offer when it knew the chances of that deal's being blocked were high. This time around, there was only one bidder.
Rick Wagoner Jr., chief exective of G.M., contended in a conference call yesterday that "the economic value is roughly the same" from this deal with the News Corporation, compared with its offer in 2001, but he declined to explain his math. A banker who worked on the transaction laughed when he heard of Mr. Wagoner's comments.
Under the terms of the deal, which must be approved by Hughes shareholders, the News Corporation would buy G.M.'s 19.9 percent stake in Hughes for $14 a share, or $3.8 billion. Of that amount, at least $3.1 billion would be paid in cash, with the rest in News Corporation publicly traded securities.
The company would then make a tender offer for 14.1 percent of the publicly traded Hughes shares for $14 a share in cash or News Corporation securities.
The price represents a 22 percent premium over Hughes's stock price, which closed yesterday at $11.48, down 2 cents, before the deal was formally announced. The shares, which trade as a G.M. tracking stock, edged up to $11.60 after hours. The News Corporation's American depository receipts ended regular trading down 66 cents, at $27.22. G.M. closed down 25 cents, at $34.48. 
G.M. is planning to use the cash it receives from the deal to reduce its debt and strengthen its balance sheet.
The News Corporation would end up controlling 34 percent of Hughes, while the General Motors Pension Trust, which is separate from G.M., would continue to own 21 percent and the public would own the remaining 45 percent. Hughes will eventually be folded into the Fox Entertainment Group.
It is unclear what the effect of the deal will be on consumers, but some are crying foul.
"Hold on to your wallet," said Gene Kimmelman, co-director of the Consumers Union, a consumer advocacy group that supported the EchoStar-Hughes deal. "Prices will go through the roof." 
Mr. Kimmelman said he was worried that the News Corporation would raise programming fees for cable operators by threatening to pull his networks off their systems, pushing cable prices for subscribers even higher.
"He has no incentive to price-compete against cable as long they pay a hefty fee for his programming," Mr. Kimmelman said.
The News Corporation disputes that contention and says that any price increases will have to be passed on to DirecTV as well, making higher programming prices less attractive.
"We have every intention of being a fair player," Mr. Murdoch said.
The News Corporation already owns satellite networks around the world, giving it considerably more influence when negotiating to buy satellite-receiving dishes, set-top boxes and other gear. That could enable DirecTV to substantially lower the average cost of acquiring each new customer, now estimated at more than $500 a household. 
Mr. Murdoch also expects to expand the DirecTV subscriber base by aggressively marketing the service through his Fox TV outlets. And he will be able to eliminate Hughes's middleman status and reap the revenue directly each time a DirecTV viewer watches one of the News Corporation's 20th Century Fox films on pay per view.
Mr. Murdoch is hoping to repeat the success he has had with British Sky Broadcasting with DirecTV. He has turned BSkyB into the largest pay television operator in Britain by offering exclusive programming, like soccer matches, and has led the field in offering interactive services, like different camera angles for sporting events. It also offers programmable video recorders like the popular TiVo service.
G.M. said that Mr. Murdoch would become chairman of Hughes and that Chase Carey, the News Corporation's former co-chief operating officer, would be president and chief executive. Eddy Hartenstein, senior executive vice president of Hughes, will be vice chairman of Hughes. 
An army of investment bankers and lawyers worked on the deal, many for more than three years. Indeed, half a dozen investment banks have worked on the transaction for little or no money because they are paid only after a deal is completed. Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. acted as financial advisers to the News Corporation, while Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom; Hogan & Hartson and Harris, Wiltshire & Grannis provided legal advice.
Merrill Lynch and Bear Stearns acted as financial advisers to G.M., and Jenner & Block; Kirkland & Ellis; and Richards, Layton & Finger provided legal advice.
Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse First Boston acted as financial advisers to Hughes Electronics and Weil, Gotshal & Manges; Latham & Watkins; Wiley, Rein & Fielding; and Jones Day provided legal advice.

HEADLINE: Welfare Veto Is Overridden By Council 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN and NICHOLE M. CHRISTIAN 

 BODY:
Over the veto of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the City Council passed legislation yesterday that would significantly soften the welfare-to-work policies that became New York City's trademark during the Giuliani administration.
 The legislation, which passed 46 to 5 yesterday, has long been on the wish list of advocates for the poor who say the work requirements in the city's welfare programs are too harsh, particularly in a weak economy. And the Council's ability to override Mayor Bloomberg's veto so easily suggests that he does not wield the same influence over the Council as his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, who made overhaul of welfare a signature issue. 
 The broadly drawn legislation, first passed in February, would give almost everyone on the welfare rolls a right to at least some education and training -- something that is now largely at the discretion of the Human Resources Administration. The law would also greatly increase the number of hours of education that recipients could count toward federal and state work requirements. In the case of recipients approved for college programs, it could be as high as 35 hours a week. 
Mr. Bloomberg, who vetoed the bill on March 14, criticized the override yesterday. He said the bill would cost the city millions of dollars it could ill afford in the midst of a budget crisis, because it would lead to federal penalties tied to minimum work requirements. He vowed to challenge the law in court, meaning that it could be some time before the law takes effect.
"Their actions fly in the face of research, experience and common sense," Mr. Bloomberg said in astatement. "The requirement to work is an indispensable component of welfare reform. It ends the cycle of dependency, which ruins too many lives and creates self-sufficiency in its place." 
He said the Council had chosen "to turn back the clock on welfare reform, reviving a dated, discredited policy that we long ago learned was a failure."
The bill would seem to put the City Council on an ideological collision course with the Bush administration and Congress, which is expected to pass legislation this year tightening federal work requirements further. 
In 1996, after the federal government made historical changes to welfare laws, giving local governments more power over disbursing funds, the Giuliani administration started an aggressive policy of forcing able-bodied recipients to work for their checks. The results were stunning. In subsequent years, the rolls dropped by almost 800,000 people.
Many experts viewed New York's law as a success. Child poverty decreased, income of women who left the rolls increased, and even after the economy soured in 2000 the rolls continued to shrink.
Advocates of the poor, however, have long insisted that the work requirements could be punitive. Welfare recipients who were illiterate or just weeks short of finishing high school degrees were forced to sweep parks and pick up litter, instead of finishing training that would give them higher paying jobs, the advocates said.
They argued that the best chance for welfare recipients to stay employed and to be employed at a decent wage was more education and training.
"We've achieved a lot, but one of the weakest parts of the city's program remains the fact that most welfare recipients get very little preparation for the realities of the private sector economy," said Bill de Blasio, a Brooklyn councilman who was a prime sponsor of the bill.
Mr. de Blasio said he expected the new law to complement current policy. "Most people will continue to do the type of workfare and other programs that already exist," he said. "But some will show initiative to pursue training and education, and those who can find the funding to do that should have the right to do so."
The bill allows almost any recipient on the rolls to demand that some kind of education be part of a work plan, eliminating the administration's discretion. The bill also eliminates a 20-hour work requirement, the cornerstone of the current program, and instead allows an individualized mixture of work and education to equal 35 hours a week. Those seeking college degrees would also be allowed to count study time.
Citing its own academic experts and reports, the Bloomberg administration said that education and training worked best to improve the economic potential of recipients if they were in conjunction with concrete work requirements. "The concurrent model is the best approach to get people on the road to self-sufficiency," said Frank Sobrino, a Human Resources spokesman. "This is not mean-spirited or arbitrary -- it is what works."
Former officials of the Giuliani administration said the new law was reminiscent of days when welfare recipients would enroll in education classes but not attend them or ever enter the work force.
"If they aren't confrontational and actually implement it, there is significant risk that people won't work and we will see the welfare roles begin to climb again," said Mark Hoover, a deputy commissioner under Mr. Giuliani.
The bill contains measures meant to prevent such an outcome, including attendance requirements and a demand that recipients keep up at least a C average.
Those requirements, combined with the fact that the Council allocated no new money for the training and education it was permitting, led council members to predict that only a small percentage of those on the rolls would actually seek to take advantage of its provisions.
In addition to the work training bill, the Council also overrode Mr. Bloomberg's vetoes of three other bills. Two will provide women greater access to emergency contraceptives.
The third will require the city's schools chancellor to provide detailed quarterly reports on the status of all school construction projects, a sore subject with council members who have tried to track long-delayed projects and cost overruns. 
Legislators said the law would provide much-needed oversight. "The message is you can't take the public out of public education," said Councilwoman Eva S. Moskowitz, the chairwoman of the Education Committee.
But the welfare debate stirred the strongest emotions. An opponent of the bill, Councilwoman Madeline Provenzano of the Bronx, was booed by welfare advocates in the balcony of the Council chamber. Speaking into a microphone that suddenly stopped working, Ms. Provenzano, who is white, was heard to say, "You people need to get jobs, not be in school." She later insisted to reporters that she did not use the phrase "you people," which some of her colleagues said was racially insensitive.
She said, "I am sure that I did not say it. If it was interpreted that way, if someone thought they heard me say that, yes, I'm sorry. But I know I would never use that."
But Councilman Leroy Comrie, the deputy majority whip, who was sitting next to her, said that she did. Mr. Comrie, who is black, said he heard her say, "You people should be at work and not at City Hall." But he added that Ms. Provenzano, who as a single mother put herself through college while raising four children, was frustrated by the passage of the bill. "Madeline was having a bad day," he said. "I don't think she meant it racially."

GRAPHIC: Photo: City Councilwoman Eva S. Moskowitz and Speaker Gifford Miller, right, at a news conference yesterday, discussing the override of a mayoral veto. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)(pg. D6)

HEADLINE: Pressure Building on State To Close City's Budget Gap 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
For weeks, budget experts, lawmakers and the state's fiscal monitor have been urging Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to get his fiscal house in order, warning that his proposed budget for the next fiscal year was too reliant on help from Albany that was never going to come through.
 But now, the criticism, and the call for ideas to assist the city in its climb out of a $3.4 billion budget hole, has begun to focus on Albany. In just the last week, some business leaders in the city drafted a letter to Gov. George E. Pataki urging him to consider imposing a commuter tax, the proposal at the heart of Mr. Bloomberg's budget plan. 
 City labor leaders have scurried to Albany to plead their case. And plans for demonstrations in the state capital -- street theater often reserved for the steps of City Hall -- are well under way. 
In many ways, the shift of the focus from New York to Albany is a return to familiar budget territory. But it also appears that some groups are beginning to cotton to what Mr. Bloomberg has been saying for weeks: that the city has done all that it can within its control to manage its fiscal crisis -- raising property taxes, cutting agencies and laying off workers. Others want to block more dire consequences, and see the state as the obvious mitigator.
Indeed, it is self-interest, rather than an affinity for Mr. Bloomberg, that is driving the process. Labor leaders are faced with layoffs -- more than 5,000, according to a recent announcement from City Hall. Schools and health care systems are facing drastic cuts in state aid, and business leaders are fretting that Albany's inaction will mean further local tax increases, driving business out of the city.
"I think people have figured out that the state can solve its budget problems by pushing them down to localities," said Kathryn S. Wylde, the president of the Partnership for New York City, a consortium of business leaders. 
Members of the partnership wrote the letter to the governor that strongly supported reinstating a commuter tax. The members had planned to publish the letter but refrained at Mr. Pataki's request. 
Many former pleas are morphing into angry demands. This week, the City Council came up with its own commuter tax proposal, and argued vehemently that New York should hold off on cutting services until Albany gives it more money.
And Mr. Bloomberg, whose usual budget discourse consists of saying over and over again how helpful he knows Albany will be, has subtly ratcheted up his own language, standing firm as the governor tried to get a large portion of security money working its way through Congress for New York's security costs. 
Yesterday, the mayor sent a letter to Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders stating, in blunt language, that draconian cuts would be the result of a failure to get a "mutually acceptable program of revenue and aid relief from Albany."
Mr. Bloomberg is expected to lay the onus on Albany once again in his budget address next week. 
"The city from Day 1 has been talking about how big the problem is," Deputy Mayor Marc V. Shaw said yesterday in an interview. "We did the labor part and the property tax part. The stuff that didn't need state action has been done. State help is the only part that is not done yet."
New York City is extremely limited in what it can do with its own budget. The only tax it can raise without legislative approval is the property tax -- which already was raised 18.5 percent -- and much of its expenditures are state or federally mandated. Even federal aid that is earmarked for the city goes through Albany, which often helps itself to some before the rest makes its way into local government coffers. 
What Mr. Bloomberg wants is for Albany to allow him to tax commuters at the same rates that city residents would pay, with a top rate of 2.7 percent. He also wants Mr. Pataki to abandon plans to cut more than $700 million in education aid to the city.
A protest against education cuts in Albany is planned for May 3.
Part of the stepped-up call for Albany's help stems from timing. Both the city and state are at the same time furiously trying to agree on budgets, and quickly, that close enormous gaps. The mayor sees his deadline as next week, when he gives his budget address. State leaders also see next week as crucial, hoping to make a deal before localities must bring their school budgets to a vote.
The state's two top legislative leaders are still matching up priorities on how to restore billions of dollars in cuts to education and health care the governor wants. 
"
If real progress is not made soon, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said, he is willing to work out a budget solely with Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader. The governor is likely to veto that product and spark a fierce fight for override votes.
Yesterday, after an hourlong meeting with Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver, Mr. Pataki emerged with no budget progress to report but said he thought a budget needed to be in place by April 25. If it is not, he said, he will continue to run the state, using emergency bills.
The governor, asked about city aid, said he recognized the city's plight but that there were alternatives to tax increases, some of which he said he endorses, others not.
"Well, all of us, the Senate, the Assembly, and certainly myself understand that it is not just the state that has a fiscal problem, the city does, too," Mr. Pataki said. "And we are working to try to come up with ways to help the city deal with that fiscal problem. We are looking at ideas, some of which come from the city, some of which come from the Assembly, some of which come from the Senate, some of which come from me, some of which come from outside sources, to see how we can, without having the commuter tax, help the mayor." A memo from Pataki officials outlined some of the alternative proposals that have been floated as ways to help the city raise money, including a plan to transfer private bus operations to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority -- which is already in the city budget. Another idea was to extend the mortgage-recording tax to co-ops.
In recent weeks, labor leaders have increased their visits to Albany to press their case with lawmakers, arguing that cuts to the labor force, particularly in areas of public safety, would damage New York City, with economic ramifications for upstate.
"I have to avert these layoffs at my front door," said Norman Seabrook, president of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association. "I think it is a matter of people using all of their options now and not just concentrating on the city."

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: COMBAT TECHNOLOGY; 
A War Like No Other Uses New 21st-Century Methods To Disable Enemy Forces

BYLINE:  By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. and THOM SHANKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9 

 BODY:
The march on Baghdad exemplifies 21st-century warfare, allied commanders and outside military experts say: swift, agile and decisive, employing overpowering technology to bring relentless violence to bear in many places at once.
 "The superior technology we now possess is, perhaps, the most obvious difference between the gulf war and the present conflict," Vice President Dick Cheney, who was the secretary of defense 12 years ago, said today. 
 In the 1991 Persian Gulf war, only one combat aircraft in five could drop a bomb on a target sighted by a laser; today they all can, Mr. Cheney said.
Only 9 percent of the weapons dropped in the 1991 war were precision-guided; for this war, air combat officials based in Saudi Arabia said today that a total of 15,000 precision-guided munitions and 7,500 unguided bombs had been dropped thus far. When added to more than 750 cruise missiles, the percentage of precision munitions used in the war is 68 percent. 
Then, a strike might happen two days after a reconnaissance plane photographed a target; now it sometimes happens in an instant.
Commanders, Mr. Cheney said, then used "maps, grease pencils and radio reports" to plot movements. Now, even in combat vehicles, they click with mouses and watch the war unfold on video displays.
But the most important element that technology offered the war's planners was an entirely new way of thinking about modern warfare.
Strikingly, top commanders appear to have vanquished the idea that generals always fight the last war. They took only small pieces from the lessons learned from wars as recent as the victory in Afghanistan, as celebrated as the first gulf war, as odious as Vietnam or as defining as World War II.
Air Marshal Brian K. Burridge, the commander of British forces in the American-led coalition, called this three-week campaign "something that military historians and academics will pore over in great detail for many years to come."
Even as senior Pentagon officials warned today that tough fighting lies ahead -- and the specter of unexpected chemical attack lingers -- they could not disguise their glee at the way things were playing out.
"It's not a matter for me to be vindicated," Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today, crediting his generals for developing a plan that was criticized during the past few weeks by armchair generals -- and even by anonymous officials inside the military. "The outcome is in the process of speaking for itself."
The technological advantage at the heart of the American advance was not just a matter of smarter bombs and stronger armor, officials said, though these cannot be discounted -- nor can the training of the troops.
New surveillance methods -- whether using drones, spy planes, or satellites -- were used only by one side in this war, feeding round-the-clock intelligence back day and night, through smoke and sandstorms. And intelligence about the enemy and its leadership, though still imperfect, was impressive.
Dr. Stephen A. Cambone, recently confirmed by the Senate to a newly created post managing all Pentagon intelligence, said in an interview that the tight coupling of intelligence with an increasingly agile military has become more decisive than ever, on a par with traditional skills like artillery, close air support, urban warfare or airborne assault.
"It may be that it's a melding of the intelligence and the operational arts into a new mission area, not much different than suppression of enemy air defenses or air superiority or undersea warfare," Dr. Cambone said. "It is beginning to emerge as a new mission area in its own right."
The example that may stick best in the public's mind is the night raid to rescue Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch, a mission planned and carried out within hours of the tip that revealed her location.
American intelligence was also able on at least two occasions to suggest precise locations where President Saddam Hussein was believed to be in seclusion.
The tenacious guerrilla campaign in southern Iraq, though, appears to have surprised allied forces. Senior Pentagon officials said they were well aware that paramilitary units loyal to Mr. Hussein and his Baath Party were unlikely to fold quickly, but they assumed that these guerrillas would make their stand in Baghdad, not against the allies' rear echelon in the south.
Another big question remains, about why Iraqi forces have not used chemical weapons. A number of air attacks, Special Operations raids and psychologicial operations were intended to prevent the launching of unconventional weapons, and they might have succeeded in eroding command over these arsenals. But that is still unknown.
At the strategic level, the campaign was directed at the Iraqi government's ability to govern and the Iraqi army's will to fight -- not at reducing cities to rubble, smashing the economy or waging total war against the population, in the style of Gen. William T. Sherman in the Civil War.
The basic concept of the war plan, which Pentagon officials said was called 1003 Victor, differed radically from traditional military campaigns to capture a country or a capital. It required neither seizing and holding territory mile by mile, nor fighting block by block through city streets.
In the Pentagon, the war plan's mottos of "inside out" and "Baghdad first" captured its central ambition -- to take down the pillars of power as quickly and violently as possible.
The public's perception at the outset -- that the bombing of the regime's palaces and compounds in Baghdad fell short of what had been threatened -- may have missed the point.
The overwrought expression, "Shock and Awe," that some used to describe the initial air campaign was, in fact, taken from an obscure but far-reaching monograph published in 1996 by expert consultants working for the National Defense University in Washington.
Its authors described a theory of "rapid dominance" that they said would move beyond the accepted doctrine of the time, which merely called for the kind of overwhelming force that the generals of the first gulf war employed.
The new doctrine's goal, confounding the foe's will to resist, would require defeating and disarming enemy combat forces and, usually, taking territory by force, they said. But it also meant to move so swiftly and to control the situation so totally as to "control what the adversary perceives, understands and knows." And it all hinged on technologies that were just then emerging, they said.
As it turns out, the invasion of Iraq was remarkably different from the first gulf war, in which a much larger ground force was used after a 43-day bombardment to push Iraqi invaders back from Kuwait. In that war, United States casualties included 148 killed in combat, 151 killed outside of combat and 467 wounded.
So far in this war, the Pentagon said today, the total American losses have included 102 dead, 11 missing and 7 prisoners of war, with the British forces listing 30 killed.
The comparably swift victory over the Taliban and Al Qaeda in Afghanistan offered one template for warfare in transformation, and was a battle laboratory for Predator reconaissance vehicles and showcased the skills of Special Forces working with local allies to call in withering air attacks. But the campaign in Iraq was substantially different.
While technology allowed the American military to leverage its power day and night and in all weather, the swift offensive that led today to downtown Baghdad required substantially more ground troops -- though not as many divisions as some officers had thought necessary. Today there are at least 125,000 coalition troops inside Iraq, and more are arriving every day.
The set-piece battles of this war, in which the Republican Guard's divisions were smashed and their remnants scattered in a few brief days, bore no resemblance to the collisions in Europe, Africa and Asia of World War II. As far as is known, no Iraqi tank destroyed an American tank; no allied warplane faced an opponent in a dogfight. In the brief strategic bombings this time, no city was reduced to rubble in the fashion of Dresden, Berlin or Hiroshima.
Instead, as Air Marshal Burridge said, "the tactics are armored raids and then exploit success, exploit opportunity. And it's very much a tactical battle."

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: ON THE CONTINENT; 
In Europe, a Mixed Reaction: Some Rejoice, but Others Balk

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: PARIS, April 9 

 BODY:
As American forces seized the heart of Baghdad, some voices from European capitals were unwilling to declare victory, while others rejoiced. Some predicted an increase in terrorist activity, while others demanded an urgent initiative to make peace between Israelis and Palestinians.
 With fighting continuing and the fate of President Saddam Hussein still unclear, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain had this warning from London, "It's not over yet." 
 Asked in the House of Commons when the moment of victory might come, he replied, "I think we will know that moment when we see it." 
Mr. Blair explained that it was still "extremely difficult" to say which remnants of the Hussein goverrment remained and which of its representatives would surrender to American and British troops. Later today, however, Mr. Blair and his staff were said by a spokesman to be watching live television reports from Baghdad "and are delighted at what we see in the reaction of people on the ground."
But the need for caution was echoed by Daniel Gros, director of the Center for European Policy Studies in Brussels, who said: "The popular mood in Iraq can change quickly and very profoundly. I think we have to see how the people of Iraq react to one year of American occupation."
In Berlin, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, a staunch opponent of the war, told reporters today: "There are welcome signs that the war in Iraq could be coming to an end. That is, of course, our hope. Every day earlier that the war ends is a better day."
Mr. Schroder emphasized the need for the Iraqi people to decide on their political and economic fate and for a central role for the United Nations in the rebuilding of the country.
"The important thing now is to make a political profit out of a probable and welcome victory," Mr. Schroder said. "Of course, that also means that the United Nations must play a central role in the process of bringing peace and stabilization that is now beginning."
His interior minister, Otto Schily, warned that Germany was under increased risk of attacks because of the war in Iraq and that Al Qaeda, the terrorist network, could be planning more operations.
At the Vatican, there were signs of relief that the war against Iraq might be coming to an end.
"Naturally we are all happy," said Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, one of the Vatican's most senior officials. "It could have gone badly and you could never predict what could have happened because with chemical weapons everything was possible." He added, "We thank the Lord, it seems that everything has gone well."
In Paris today, the foreign ministers of France and Britain, two countries on opposite sides of the European schism over whether to go to war, tried to look beyond the Iraq crisis, agreeing on the urgent need for a new diplomatic initiative to end the confrontation between Israel and the Palestinians.
Exchanging broad smiles and big compliments, Foreign Secretary Jack Straw of Britain and Foreign Minister Dominique de Villepin of France focused on areas of common interest. Most notable was their agreement on the need to end the cycle of violence in the Middle East as the only way to bring stability to the world.
"Dominique was saying to me upstairs, and I agree with him, that the thing that has caused the greatest degree of anger in the Arab and Islamic world has not actually been Iraq, but it's been this profound sense of injustice felt by the Palestinians," Mr. Straw said.
Mr. Straw and Mr. de Villepin both emphasized the need for the United Nations to play a role in Iraq's reconstruction, although neither gave any indication that they agree on when or how that might happen. France opposes a postwar reconstruction for Iraq that is is determined by the United States.
Mr. Straw and Mr. de Villepin gave the impression today that they were dear old friends who had merely engaged in a lively debate. "Life would be very boring if friends always agreed," Mr. Straw said. "This is a grown-up relationship."
Some French politicians said today that now was the time for Prime Minister Jacques Chirac to mend fences with Washington. In a prepared statement, Jacques Barrot, the president of the center-right UMP party in the National Assembly, advised Mr. Chirac to "rejoice at the end of Saddam Hussein's dictatorship, acknowledge the American and English courage, even if this might have been achieved by other means."
In Russia, another leader of the antiwar bloc, television news shows that had focused on setbacks in the allied campaign in Iraq, warning of brutal urban warfare to come and condemning American aggression, reported tonight that Iraqis cheered American troops in the center of Baghdad.
"There are too many questions," the international affairs commentator Maksim Yusin wrote in Thursday's Izvestia. "It's too hard to find answers to them. And there's no certainty that today's triumph won't result in even greater blood tomorrow, even more frightening wars. But about that later. Today isn't the time for unpleasant questions. Today Washington and London are rejoicing. They've won the war against Saddam."
Iraqi expatriate groups and European Muslims had a similar range of reaction. In one neighborhood of northern London, where there are Iraqi cafes and restaurants, small groups of Iraqis danced in the streets and waved Iraqi and American flags. Two dozen Iraqis were arrested after they broke into the Iraqi interests section in the Jordanian Embassy in London, removed pictures of Mr. Hussein and ripped them up on the street in celebration.
But at the Evry Courcouronnes mosque in a poor suburb of Paris, Khalil Merroun, the director, was not rejoicing. "I don't think they won the war, they erased the dictatorship, they ousted the dictator they themselves put there in the past," he said. "Just because the Iraqis hate Saddam doesn't mean they will accept the American nationalism the United States wants to impose on their country."

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: THE VICE PRESIDENT; 
After Weeks of Criticism, Cheney Claims Vindication as Iraqis Hail Outcome of War

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9 

 BODY:
After weeks of criticism that he had underestimated the difficulty of toppling Saddam Hussein and overpromised in suggesting that American troops would be greeted in Iraq as liberators, Vice President Dick Cheney spoke publicly today for the first time since the start of the war, and in his understated way said: I told you so.
 The conclusion of the war "will mark one of the most extraordinary military campaigns ever conducted," Mr. Cheney told the American Society of Newspaper Editors conference in New Orleans this morning, while television screens were showing jubilant Iraqis pulling down statues of Mr. Hussein in Baghdad less than three weeks after the start of the American-led offensive. 
 "In the early days of the war, the plan was criticized by some retired military officers embedded in TV studios," Mr. Cheney said in a dig at cable pundits. "With every day and every advance by our coalition forces the wisdom of that plan becomes more apparent." 
Careful not to sound boastful, Mr. Cheney heaped praise on Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and his top military commanders. But with the war seeming to be in its final stages, it appeared that the vice president's optimistic, even cocky prewar pronouncements and the policy advice behind them have been largely proved correct.
While he remains a polarizing figure in American politics and the personification to critics around the world of an oil-driven, trigger-happy foreign policy, Mr. Cheney is emerging from the war with no diminution in his status as President Bush's chief counselor. And he is sure to be an influential voice largely behind the scenes as the White House turns its attention to rebuilding Iraq and confronting North Korea, Iran and other nations it sees as threats.
Today, Mr. Cheney weighed in on how he wanted to see postwar Iraq put back together, making clear his disdain for giving the United Nations and through it, France, Germany and Russia, a pivotal role.
"The French and the Germans, in particular, did everything they could to prevent us from going forward and enforcing the U.N. Security Council resolutions," he said. 
Mr. Cheney implied that he would like those countries to stew awhile now that oil contracts and other lucrative rebuilding jobs are on the line. "Perhaps time will help in terms of improving their outlook," Mr. Cheney said, adding pointedly that perhaps France, Russia and Germany might start by providing humanitarian aid. 
Throughout the war, his aides said, Mr. Cheney has ignored or shrugged off the criticism that he had oversold the ease with which American and British forces would prevail. He showed little reaction, they said, to protests around the world in which he was portrayed as the instigator of a "blood for oil" war and was accused of using the conflict to benefit his former employer, Halliburton, the oil field services firm.
"We have no interest in the oil," he said today.
But the vice president also displayed a detailed knowledge of Iraq's oil fields and of planning for putting the country's reserves to use to pay for reconstruction and get Iraq back on its feet economically. He said Iraqi oil production could generate $20 billion a year for the Iraqi people, and that some outside investment in the country's oil fields could allow production of as much as three million barrels a day by the end of the year.
In his usual taciturn way, Mr. Cheney has spent the war concentrating on what he sees as his primary role, helping Mr. Bush sort out the competing institutional views brought to him by the sometimes opposing camps within his war council, especially those led by Mr. Rumsfeld and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell.
Although Mr. Cheney is typically viewed as a charter member of the hawkish neoconservatives on Mr. Bush's team and as temperamentally more inclined to support Mr. Rumsfeld's hard-line views than Mr. Powell's internationalism, his aides said he is less ideological than pragmatically focused on protecting the United States from terrorist threats.
"The president expects Rumsfeld and Powell to come with perspectives that reflect their responsibilities," said Mary Matalin, Mr. Cheney's former senior political counselor who is still an informal adviser. "The vice president's responsibility is to help the president sort through all that. He pushes the conversation along by asking pointed questions."
Mr. Cheney, Ms. Matalin said, has the leeway and the background to get involved in almost any issue, but usually weighs in only when it is really important, whether a key vote in Congress or mediating an internal Republican Party dispute or making the president's case one last time before attacking Iraq.
"He keeps his fingers in everything," Ms. Matalin said, "but he's utilized for trigger pulling when something hits the fan, from calling world regional leaders to a key senator." 
After Sept. 11, 2001, Mr. Cheney all but disappeared for days or weeks at a time, secure at an undislosed location. During the last three weeks, Mr. Cheney has stuck more or less to his normal routine, riding his stationary bike at home early in the morning, receiving intelligence briefings, attending war council meetings and lunching once a week in private with Mr. Bush. He joined Mr. Rumsfeld at the Pentagon on Monday for the morning operational update and video teleconference with Gen. Tommy R. Franks, the theater commander. 
He watches coverage of the war on television in his office -- he is partial to Fox News and Brit Hume and sometimes leafs through a historical atlas given to him by his staff on Jan. 30 for his 62nd birthday, his aides say. He attends weekly lunches with Senate Republicans, where he says little -- "stay the course" was his only statement to them a few weeks ago, said someone at the meeting. He also receives many of them at his table, godfatherlike, for a word or a favor when the meal ends.
"He understands that government in our constitutional system is always very hard and very, very frustrating," said Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, who is an old friend. 
"He sees himself as a strategic planner, which fits the Bush style," Mr. Gingrich said. "And he sees himself as an implementer, dealing with key problems that are not getting solved."
Reflecting Mr. Cheney's reputation as far more than a typical funeral-attending vice president, his office has become a required stop for visiting foreign dignitaries. In the past few weeks, Mr. Cheney has met with top ministers from South Korea, Australia and Israel. "When our big shots come into town, we always try to have a meeting with the vice president," said one foreign diplomat in Washington.
Ever the laconic westerner, Mr. Cheney is typically the soul of discretion. But in answering questions today after his speech in New Orleans, he committed a rare gaffe by saying that the United States had scheduled a meeting for this Saturday near Nasiriya of Iraqi groups to begin planning for the interim civil authority. 
But his aides quickly put out word that Mr. Cheney had jumped the gun and that no date had been set for the meeting. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vice President Dick Cheney spoke yesterday to newspaper editors. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Senate Passes Version of Religion Initiative 

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9 

 BODY:
A pared version of President Bush's religion-based initiative passed the Senate today by an overwhelming margin, but Republicans are already using other legislation to press the White House's agenda of expanding government grants to religious groups.
 The measure approved today began as an effort to allow churches, synagogues and other religious organizations to participate in taxpayer-financed programs for the poor. But it wound up as a bill that provides tax incentives to spur donations to all kinds of charitable groups, religious or not. 
 The measure passed by a vote of 95 to 5, an unusual show of bipartisanship in a Senate that has been sharply divided on most issues, including judicial nominations and tax cuts. When it was over, the chief sponsors, Senator Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania, and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, seemed greatly relieved. 
"Praise the Lord and praise Congress," Senator Lieberman said.
Senator Santorum said, "Today is a great day for the armies of compassion." 
As passed by the Senate, the bill offers tax advantages intended to benefit soup kitchens, homeless shelters and other community groups. It would provide technical assistance to small groups, including black and Hispanic churches that need help competing for federal financing and would authorize $33 million to establish group maternity homes for young mothers.
The measure also provides an increase of $1.3 billion for a program that provides social service money, in the form of block grants, to the states. But the White House, while commending the Senate for passing the legislation, said today it would "strongly oppose" the block grant provision because it exceeds the president's budget request.
"America's charities face tough times, and we can do more to support their efforts," Mr. Bush said in a statement, adding, "I continue to urge Congress to take additional steps to end discrimination against faith-based organizations."
The bill now goes to the House. Passage there is likely, but it is also likely that House Republicans will strip out the block grant provision, a prospect that greatly irritated Senator Lieberman.
"I cannot understand why the administration would do such a divisive thing and undermine the harmony we achieved," he said.
Mr. Bush's religion-based initiative has been caught up in controversy from the moment he announced it, early in his presidency. The White House had hoped to use the bill passed today, called the Charity, Aid, Recovery and Empowerment Act, or CARE, as a vehicle to carry the initiative into law.
The original bill included language, sought by the White House, that offered explicit protections for groups with religious names or religious icons in their literature. Under this "equal treatment" provision, such groups would have been eligible to participate in federally financed programs to aid the poor.
But because federal civil rights law permits religious organizations to discriminate in hiring, Democrats argued that the legislation would allow the groups to discriminate using taxpayer money. After Senators Richard J. Durbin of Illinois and Jack Reed of Rhode Island, both Democrats, threatened to amend the bill and delay its passage, Mr. Santorum decided to strip out the equal-treatment language.
But House Republicans have already inserted a similar provision in a job-training bill. That effort has drawn sharp criticism from some Democrats, like Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts. Mr. Frank also complained that the Bush administration is trying to achieve the changes through regulations, including those governing housing programs.
"The current law says if you take federal money you are under a heavy obligation not to discriminate," Mr. Frank said. "They want to turn it around and say if you take federal money you have a license to discriminate on religious grounds."
Mr. Santorum, meanwhile, vowed to insert the equal-treatment language into other measures, including the reauthorization of the 1996 welfare reform legislation.
"There are some who want to roll back the clock on religious freedoms," he said, "and I'm not going to be a part of that."
Despite the controversy, the bill passed today had especially broad support from charitable groups, who have suffered greatly with the downturn in the economy.
"This has been a terrible, tough fight," said Sharon M. Daly, vice president for social policy for Catholic Charities-U.S.A. While Ms. Daly said she was disappointed that the equal-treatment language was dropped, she added, "The bill is still worth fighting for."
