HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "MATTHEW BARNEY: THE CREMASTER CYCLE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through June 11). The most anticipated show by any American artist to emerge in a decade or more. "Cremaster," Mr. Barney's nine-year, five-film project, here presented whole for the first time, is an inspired benchmark of ambition, scope and forthright provocation for art in the new century. I recall Elizabeth Murray's describing how Philip Guston's crazy late works gave her heart to do her own mature paintings. Mr. Barney hasbrought to the art world a new freedom to explore narrative. He has introduced a new repertory of materials, gooey, strange, malleable and synthetic, which nobody thought of as germane before. Never mind that the films and many (not all) of his related sculptures, installations and photographs are very beautiful. The show, an installation itself, brings them together. The earliest "Cremaster" sculptures are film props, cobbled into installations that don't jell. But the latest are better: twin steel towers framed in plastic, a suite of abstract sculptures derived from automobile chassis. Vaseline and plastic combine with cement and steel -- pink and gray, rough and smooth, hard and soft -- the materials sustaining a narrative of formal eloquence. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $15; $10 for students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

"BEALS, HERVEY AND HEWITT: WOMEN PIONEERS OF ARCHITECTURE AND DESIGN PHOTOGRAPHY," New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, (212) 873-3400 (through July 13). Three women photographers, saluted for their successes in early-20th-century New York. The artistic oddball was Antoinette Bryant Hervey (1857-1945) who carried out an obsessive 40-year photographic documentation of the construction of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and produced an epic of great artistry as well as historical value. Greenwich Village was the stamping ground of Jessie Tarbox Beals (1870-1942), the best known of the three, who engagingly turned her lens on Village haunts, architecture and personalities. Mattie Edwards Hewitt (circa 1870-1956) did homes and gardens designed for the era's rich and famous, like Conde Nast and Margaret Bourke-White. Although this mix is a little forced, individually each woman is worth a salute. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for students and 65+ (Grace Glueck).

WENDY EWALD, "Secret Games," Queens Museum of Art, Flushing Meadows Corona Park, (718) 529-9700 (through June 8). For three decades, Ms. Ewald has been teaching and collaborating with children in some of the world's more remote and impoverished places, including the Kentucky Appalachians, the mountains of Columbia and villages in India, South Africa and the Netherlands. Ms. Ewald herself is a capable photojournalist, but the best parts of this retrospective are the photographs taken by children. Many are as beautiful, strange and heartbreaking as anything by Diane Arbus, Nan Goldin or other chroniclers of the rough poetry of real life. (A smaller show is at Scalo, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 334-9393, through May 10. It focuses on works produced by Ms. Ewald and her students in Morocco in 1995.) Museum hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50, students and 55+ (Ken Johnson).

* "MANET/VELAZQUEZ: THE FRENCH TASTE FOR SPANISH PAINTING," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through June 8). The Met has clearly called in every chip to make this show spectacular. The first rooms are a virtual survey of great Spanish painting of the 17th and 18th centuries; after that comes a virtual Manet retrospective, with some Degas and Courbet thrown in for good measure; then a virtual 19th-century American overview of the most gifted portraitists influenced by Spanish painting via Manet, Degas and Courbet: Eakins, Chase, Sargent and Whistler. The thesis of Spanish influence on French art is hardly new, but it is explored in such precise and fresh detail, discreetly, without pushing comparisons (in that respect it's not like "Matisse Picasso" at the Modern, notwithstanding the coincidental titled pairings) that you would have to be churlish not to leave edified and amazed. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7 for students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "MATISSE PICASSO," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 33rd Street at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through May 19). If you're thinking of skipping it because of the crowds, that's not a good enough excuse. This is one for the ages: an eye-educating, often revelatory parlor game, with the fate of modern art as the stakes. The premise is a little dubious -- the two of them competing as if in stately isolation from everything else going on in art -- but the results look great. Choosing a winner is the sport of the event and the inevitable outcome of pitting titans mano a mano. Matisse comes out looking consistently good. To grasp 20th-century art, Picasso once said, "You ought to see side by side everything Matisse and I were doing." He was right about that. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; to 9 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays. Admission: $20; $15.50, students and 65+; under 16 with an adult, free. Reserved tickets: Ticketmaster, (212) 307-5577; or toll free, (866) 879-6662, with Ticketmaster surcharges (Kimmelman).

"ELIE NADELMAN: SCULPTOR OF MODERN LIFE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through July 20). Despite the clarion title, this exhibition is too monotonous, stiffly installed and short on drawings to do full justice to the erudite, polymorphous achievement of the Polish-born American sculptor Nadelman (1882-1946). Still, don't miss this opportunity to see his work in quantity, especially the streamlined wood figures from the 1920's and the small truculent plaster figurines, which were found in his studio after his death. Their suave economy, ineffable stillness, delicate gestures and seamless blend of historical and popular sources make them among the most complex, fully visual sculptures in Western art. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+ (Roberta Smith).

* "SCANNING: THE ABERRANT ARCHITECTURES OF DILLER & SCOFIDIO," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through June 1). This retrospective of the work of Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio, New York's brainiest architectural team, surveys 21 projects in a variety of mediums, including buildings, building additions, product designs, temporary museum installations, commercial interiors, public art and theater design. Aberrance is the last label I would slap on Diller & Scofidio, even in ironic jest. Their typical procedure is to slam opposite concepts together -- outside-inside, public-private, transparent-opaque -- and then explore the richly nuanced terrain that emerges from the overlap. Holding opposites together is a primary function of classical art, and Ms. Diller and Mr. Scofidio are classicists in this dialectical sense. The good, the true and the satirical are their stock in trade. Beauty slips in, too. "Scanning" is a show in which many New York architects will take pride as well as pleasure. Hours and admission: See above (Herbert Muschamp).

* "CHRISTIAN SCHAD AND THE NEUE SACHLICHKEIT," Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200 (through June 9). Schad's career effectively lasted only 15 years, from around 1915 to 1930, and for just two or three of those years was he doing what deserves to be remembered now. Not much time. But just enough. Schad at his mordant best precisely captured an anxious culture affected by war and the threat of it: his bloodless portraits in Vienna and Berlin suggest deep unease and foreboding beneath porcelain surfaces. They are explicitly unemotional, even when they are frankly erotic, as they frequently are. To the end, Schad remained aloof. Hours: Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7 for students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

Galleries: Uptown

"LUXURIOUS ESSENTIALS," Kaikodo, 164 East 64th Street, (212) 223-0121 (through April 28). This show is composed primarily of dozens of painted paper fans, representing a minor but flourishing medium in Chinese art. Such respected Ming and Qing period artists as Qiu Ying, Tang Yin, Wen Zhengming, Yun Shouping and Wang Yuanqi are represented in an art that is intimate, affordable and portable (Holland Cotter).

* AGNES MARTIN, "Five Decades," Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through April 26). We're used to expecting nuances rather than revolutions in Ms. Martin's art. But this 10-painting capsule survey gives a sense of how varied she can be and has been. It also proves how right she is in referring to herself as an an Abstract Expressionist when everyone else has been calling her a Minimalist all these years. She's an engaged, passionate gestural painter with a classicist's emotional tact, a reticent Abstract Expressionist, the way Philip Guston was (Cotter).

* "WEAVING CHINA'S PAST: THE AMY S. CLAUGUE COLLECTION OF CHINESE TEXTILES," China Institute Gallery, 125 East 65th Street, (212) 744-8181 (through June 7). This gallery has a sterling record in presenting small, fine-tuned scholarly shows and this one, imported from the Phoenix Art Museum, exactly fits the description. With precious examples of silk brocades, tapestries and embroideries, including Buddhist ritual pieces, dating from the Jin to Qing dynasty, it gives a vivid sense of the material past in a powerful imperial culture (Cotter).

Galleries: 57th Street

VIJA CELMINS, Susan Sheehan, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 489-3331 (through May 31). Unlike the many painters and sculptors for whom printmaking is a more or less casual diversion, Ms. Celmins invests as much painstaking concentration in it as she does in her paintings. This selection from three decades includes misty etchings of spider webs, rippling waters made in lithography and wood engraving, mezzo-tinted starry night skies and lithographs of desert fields (Johnson).

LYNN DAVIS, "China," Edwynn Houk, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 750-7070 (through May 3). A photographer known for her spectacular pictures of icebergs and Egyptian pyramids, takes on China. Towering pagodas, a giant Buddha in a cave, ancient stairs partially submerged in sand, a beautiful minaret with a surface of intricate brickwork: these and other subjects are rendered in large, smooth black-and-white prints. Her relentless monumentalism can make you wonder whether Ms. Davis has a more intimate side (Johnson).

* BILL JENSEN, Mary Boone, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 752-2929 (through April 26). Where once it was biomorphic-bristly, Mr. Jensen's compositions seem to have mellowed over the years into softer, less defined forms, his surfaces more grounds for colors than for shapes. The forms in these latest works are really markings, sprawly scrawls and calligraphic gestures that play splashily over contrasting or close-valued grounds, sometimes to gorgeous effect. The star of the show is "Untitled (Ochre and Red)," in which a more definite form, that of a red partial cross, occupies the top half of a glowing field brushed thinly enough to show glints of red beneath it. Harking back to medieval and Byzantine sources, it is a mini-cathedral (Glueck).

Galleries: Chelsea

FERNANDO BERMEJO, "Lights," Generous Miracles, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 352-2858 (through May 13). The light box is popular with photographers but rarely used to illuminate hand-made pictures. Black-and-white paintings on paper mounted on light boxes by this Spanish artist suggest possibilities worth exploring. Lighted from behind, his small, brushy pastoral landscapes have a remarkable naturalistic luminosity and his surrealistic visions of trees growing from small boats have a dusky, melancholy poetry (Johnson).

"FLESH TONES: 100 YEARS OF THE NUDE," Robert Mann, 210 11th Avenue, at 24th Street, (212) 989-7600 (through April 19). From Edward Steichen's blurry Pictorialism to Nan Goldin's diaristic intimism, this selection of photographs of people without clothes is wonderfully diverse. The Village Voice photography critic Vince Aletti selected the 79 images, and there may not be a bad one in the bunch. Neither is there anything so transgressive that parents need beware. Still, the nonchronological, salon-style installation cries out to be more illuminatingly sorted (Johnson).

CHEMA MADOZ, "Objects," Yossi Milo, 552 West 24th Street, (212) 414-0370 (through April 19). Mr. Madoz deals in modest surrealistic illusions, like a little puddle of water made to resemble a cartoon cloud raining tiny droplets. Or he transforms objects: a potted shrub blooms butterflies instead of blossoms and a spoon casts the shadow of a fork. The slickly produced prints border on the commercial, but the imagery is amusing nevertheless (Johnson).

KIRSTEN MOSHER, Ten in One Gallery, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 604-9660 (through April 19). Ms. Mosher, who is known for socially subversive public sculpture, here presents a series of playful small paintings that envision a futuristic mix of the pastoral and the post-apocalyptic. Made with colorful, busy, fine brushwork, it looks like faux-folk art by a promising grad student (Johnson).

* ELIZABETH MURRAY, PaceWildenstein, 534 West 25th Street, (212) 929-7000 (through April 26). A life lived the way Ms. Murray paints would be nirvana. Her recent works are airy constructions in low relief: ad-hoc jigsaw puzzles of freewheeling shapes that lean, nuzzle and jostle each other to make unlikely harmonies of pungent color and abstract pattern. Compositional equilibrium, laboriously achieved but seemingly effortless, looks fleeting: there's always the sense that these improvisatory jumbles might break apart and out of their frames. Ms. Murray loves to paint. That's still the bottom line. It is useful to be reminded that there are still veterans like her, steeped in the medium, its difficulties and pleasures, who work so hard and make such beautiful art (Kimmelman).

ASHLEY PRINE, Clementine, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 243-5937 (through April 19). From a distance Ms. Prine's lusciously candy-colored paintings look like hazy, overly simplified abstractions of plants, animals and landscapes. Up close you find that off-register layers of translucent glazing gives the edges of her shapes alacy, fluttering quality. The effect is oddly erotic, like sexy lingerie under sensible outerwear (Johnson).

ALEXIS ROCKMAN, Gorney Bravin and Lee, 534 West 26th Street, (212) 352-8372 (through April 19). With the meticulous care of a popular science illustrator, Mr. Rockman continues to paint nature under stress. Each glossy, medium-size picture focuses on a particular ecosystem, with in most cases some kind of volcanic activity in the background. Deep sea creatures hover around glowing hyperthermal vents; insects flee a smoke-belching mountain; prairie animals seek subterranean shelter before a river of incandescent lava (Johnson).

GARY SCHNEIDER, Julie Saul, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-2410, (through April 19). Mr. Schneider's latest parsing of the photographic process involves extended exposures, people who lie down rather than sit for their portraits, an overhead camera and light from a single pin-point source. Illuminated in a process that resembles drawing, or a gentle touching, the faces glimmer almost lividly beneath dustings of shadows. They could be coalminers getting off work, or lost souls brought back from the dead and freshly made up (Smith).

BEVERLY SEMMES, "In the O," Leslie Tonkonow, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-8540 (through April 19). What can one say in the face of this largesse, which has charged undertones of feminist meaning as well as overtones of female underwear? The entire gallery is clad in hundreds of yards of tangerine-colored chiffon that Niagaras from ceiling to floor to form pools of delicate ruffles. Quirky red pottery vessels handmade by Ms. Semmes, stand around like exclamation points. A huge ovoid bathmat is put together entirely of flesh-colored Band-Aids. Ms. Semmes proves herself once again to be an engaging fantasist as well as a clever manipulator of architectural space (Glueck).

Galleries: SoHo

TONY BERLANT, "What You See Is Who You Are," Lennon, Weinberg, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 941-0012 (through April 19). A spectacular 60-foot mural representing the four seasons is the main attraction here. This visually ravishing, bucolic landscape was made by Mr. Berlant's signature technique: with zillions of finishing nails that remain visible on the surface, he attaches countless cut-up pieces of preprinted and painted tin to wood panels, puzzling together a giant, vividly colorful picture that is as absorbing to study up close as from a distance. (Johnson).

MEG CRANSTON, "Magical Death," Leo Koenig, 249 Centre Street, (212) 334-9255 (through April 22). This California Conceptualist presents five life-size whole-figure portraits of herself as a pinata. The papier-mache effigies are molded from the artist's trim body, dressed in fashionable paper clothes and hung by ropes from the ceiling. As the pinata is a sacrificial object, to be beaten with a stick, the artist becomes a martyr; the idea is more interesting than the nondescriptly made mannequins that represent it (Johnson).

HEIDE FASNACHT, Kent, 67 Prince Street, (212) 966-4500 (through May 3). A sculptor known for her interest in explosions offers a bursting Champagne bottle and splashy puddles, both in cast blue resin, and a sneeze represented by perforations in paper. A big colored pencil drawing of a window glass washed by rain, made with crisp gray and blue hatchmarks, reveals on close inspection an absorbing, crystalline topography; from a distance it resolves into a magically luminous illusion of watery translucency (Johnson).

GEORGE McNEIL, "FE = Form/Energy," Luise Ross, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 343-2161 (through May 3). McNeil, who died in 1995 an underrecognized member of the Abstract Expressionist generation, merged painterly abstraction and primitivistic symbolism with sensuous buoyancy. This small selection of works from four decades includes colorful, transcendentally exuberant landscapes and pictures of scary masklike faces embedded in luxuriantly scabrous surfaces (Johnson).

ALEXANDER VINOGRADOV AND VLADIMIR DUBOSSARSKY, "Our Best World," Deitch Projects, 76 Grand Street, (212) 343-7300 (though April 19). This young Russian duo presents 38 panels of a single endless painting. Wrapping around the gallery is a giddy confectionery parade of fashion models, pop stars, the artists themselves, their wives and friends, animals, candy and toys -- in settings that morph from Red Square in Moscow to a Disney-like pastoral landscape to New York City. Whether a satire or a loving embrace of Western popular culture, it is exhilarating (Johnson).

Other Galleries

DAVID HENDERSON, Kristen Frederickson, 149 Reade Street, TriBeCa, (212) 566-7787 (through April 19). Mr. Henderson works laminated plywood into smooth convex or concave shells animated by tension between the geometric and the organic. Looking at his sculptures you can almost hear the roar of industrial sanding machinery. You might also hear a more colorfully imaginative feminine side crying to get out from under the handsome masculine reserve (Johnson).

NAVJOT, Talwar, 108 East 16th Street, (212) 673-3096 (through April 19). This Indian artist is based in Bombay but has spent extensive time working with village artists. One result is the striking installation of figures of nude women and men carved from teakwood and painted a deep, rich blue. Inspired by both religious icons and tribal art, the tableau suggests the social and sexual tensions at work in a country where women are still subject to indiscriminate abuse (Cotter).

* "PEACE AND LINE," Ethan Cohen, 37 Walker Street, TriBeCa, (212) 625-1250, (through April 26). This is among the few New York dealers to consistently and persuasively present new art from China, often in group shows like this one, which includes calligraphy by the venerable painter C. C. Wang, now 97, done on pages of New York City telephone books; calligraphic paintings from 1986 by Wenda Gu; and experimental work by three young Chinese-based artists Pan Xinglei, Xing Fei and Zhou Hongxiang (Cotter).

ANN SPERRY, "30 Pieces/30 Years," Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion Museum, 1 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 824-2205 (through June 26); "My Piano," Kraushaar, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 307-5730 (through April 12). Since the early 70's, Ms. Sperry has been bending, shaping and welding metal into metaphorically suggestive abstractions. The best works in her Hebrew Union retrospective have an industrial surrealism similar to, though not as surprising as, that of Donald Lipski. Her new assemblages at Kraushaar include cut-up parts of her old piano, a beloved but defunct family heirloom (Johnson).

EDWARD WESTON AND MARGRETHE MATHER, "A Passionate Collaboration," AXA Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, (212) 554-2456 (through April 19). Although Mather (1886-1952), a photographer of considerable accomplishment, was important to the early life and career of Weston (1886-1958), she vanished into obscurity as his reputation advanced. This show calls attention to her achievements alongside Weston's during their 12-year relationship, which ended in 1925. Each taught and learned from the other; Mather helped turn Weston's work in a more experimental direction. By 1921 they had agreed to an equal partnership in which photographs were signed by both. This well-chosen show does make a case for her influence on Weston (and vice versa), and she deserves recognition for her endeavors. Her career, however, was not sustained enough to be compared with his; her impact on one of the 20th century's most influential photographers seems today a relatively small one (Glueck).

Last Chance

* "BRONZE AND GOLD IN ANCIENT CHINA," J. J. Lally, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 371-3380 (through tomorrow). Exhibitions here are always something to look forward to and this one is no exception. It opens with a gilt bronze plaque in the form of a vivacious phoenix. And this image, like almost everything on view -- including a superb lamp in the form of a gold-robed sentry and a set of extraordinary carved narrative titles -- was created to amuse, instruct or protect the dead, in a culture as fixated on the afterlife as our own is caught up in the here-and-now (Cotter).

* EDWIN DICKINSON, "Dreams and Realities," National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Sunday). Revered in his own lifetime, Dickinson (1891-1978) now haunts the margins of art-world consciousness. He was a painter and draftsman of extraordinary skill and subtlety, an artist's artist admired by traditionalists and the avant-garde alike. This fascinating exhibition centers on his monumentally gloomy "symbolical paintings," Surrealistic, old-masterish montages of figures and metaphorical objects. They still cast a spell, especially the hallucinatory unfinished masterpiece "Ruin at Daphne." But it is his less ambitious work, his quickly painted landscapes, his self-portraits and, above all, his exquisitely delicate drawings that feel most alive today. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $4.50 for students and 65+ (Johnson).

* "GENESIS: IDEAS OF ORIGIN IN AFRICAN SCULPTURE," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 570-3951 (through Sunday). This splendid show, installed in the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing, examines African myths about the creation of the world, the foundations of kingship and the formation of the family as told in the art of more than a dozen sub-Saharan cultures. The images range from naturalistic figures to fantastic animals and culminate in a coup de theatre display of some 40 Bamana headdresses. The dynamic is one of ethical persuasion, physical and psychological healing and a holistic connection to the world through objects of irrepressible energy and beauty. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7 for students and 65+ (Cotter).

PAT LIPSKY, Elizabeth Harris, 529 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 463-9666 (through tomorrow) and L.I.C.K., 46-44 11th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (through April 17). This veteran abstractionist presents a series of deceptively plain-spoken canvases. Vertical columns divided at different heights push up and down like valves in a machine, while muted colors alternating warm and cool pulse in and out, setting up a polyrhythmic complexity. The compositions vaguely evoke keyboards, enhancing the feeling of Bach-like musicality (Johnson).

ADI NES, Jack Shainman Gallery, 513 W. 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 645-1701 (through tomorrow). Pictures by this Israeli photographer are mostly of handsome young soldiers napping together, nursing wounded comrades,and celebrating victories. But all the scenes have been staged for the camera with actor-models to create a homoerotic dream of army life. In part, the results reflect Mr. Nes's own outsider status in Israel, as a child of Kurdish and Iranian immigrants, and a gay man (Cotter).

* YUN-FEI JI, "The Old One Hundred Names," Pratt Manhattan Gallery, 144 West 14th Street, (212) 647-7778 (through tomorrow). On wide expanses of rice paper a Beijing-born New Yorker paints a rich mix of classical Chinese-style landscape and modern satire with extraordinary skill and novelistic imagination. Mountainous wilds are populated by doll-scale human, semi-human and nonhuman creatures rendered with delicate, linear brushwork: soldiers, politicians, grotesque old men and women, nubile girls, murderous thugs in masks or with animal heads, goats, pigs, cars and trucks -- evoking a catastrophic human comedy (Johnson).

HEADLINE: Power Company Stresses Its Commitment to Brazil 

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 10 

 BODY:
"Nobody invests $4 billion to change their mind later," read the advertisements in leading Brazilian newspapers. The ads are meant to deliver a clear message from the AES Corporation to its customers, the markets and the government. 
 "We're absolutely here to stay," said Steven Clancy, president of Eletropaulo, Latin America's biggest power distributor and AES's main Brazilian unit. 
 That there should be any doubt about AES's commitment to Brazil may seem strange. The $4 billion that AES, based in Arlington, Va., has sunk into Brazil since 1996 makes it the largest private investor in the country's electric power industry. And AES gets a quarter of its worldwide revenue from Brazil, more than it gets from North America. 
But since January, when AES defaulted on part of the $1.2 billion it borrowed in 1998 from Brazil's national development bank to buy Eletropaulo, there has been mounting speculation that the company is preparing to leave the country.
AES says that is not so -- hence the ad campaign. 
But if the company were to depart, analysts say, it could lead to an exodus by other foreign utilities, especially now that the new left-leaning government appears to be favoring the public sector over private investors in the industry. 
Mr. Clancy said that for the moment he was concentrating on renegotiating AES's Brazilian debt with commercial banks, holders of the company's debentures, and BNDES, the state development bank. 
He must also strive to cut costs and improve a sagging cash flow, while keeping customers happy and persuading shareholders around the globe that the Brazilian operation is worth keeping. 
None of these tasks will be easy. AES lost $2.77 billion in the fourth quarter of 2002, mainly because of failed investments overseas, and it has sold off units scattered from California to the Middle East to raise cash and reduce the likelihood of any more defaults in Brazil.
Talks with BNDES over the company's obligations were already difficult last year; since the Workers' Party government was sworn in Jan. 1, they have all but stalled completely. The new administration named left-leaning executives with a nationalist penchant to run BNDES, and the bank has hardened its negotiating line, saying AES must repay all its creditors or hand Eletropaulo back to the state. 
"The only deal we'll do with AES is one in which they pay their debt," Darc Costa, the bank's No. 2 executive, said in a recent interview. "Either they pay cash or they pay in assets. But they have to pay." 
On a recent trip to Brasilia, the United States assistant secretary of commerce, William Lash, fired back, saying that AES could not pay because it was itself owed more than $300 million by local governments. 
But analysts said that hard words and brinkmanship on both sides could damage the negotiating atmosphere beyond repair. 
"I have a feeling it could be tough for AES to keep hold of Eletropaulo," said Armando Franco, energy analyst at Tendencias, a consulting firm based in Sao Paulo. "These negotiations are not going on in heaven. There are no angels on either side." 
According to one Eletropaulo executive, Mr. Clancy is adopting a more diplomatic approach in Brazil than AES representatives have in the past. Mr. Clancy arrived in Sao Paulo last September and formally took over as president in February.
"Previously, there was sometimes a 'Me Tarzan, you Cheetah' approach," said the executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "But up a tree in Brazil, very often Cheetah turns out to be more agile than Tarzan." 
Mr. Clancy, striking a conciliatory tone, seemed confident that he could reach a deal with BNDES. "Whenever you're in negotiations with someone with whom you have a $1 billion debt and you're not paying, it's bound to be strained," he said. "There's no easy solution for either side. But I'm optimistic we could have something by the end of May." 
Mr. Clancy laid the blame for AES's default -- two missed payments totaling more than $400 million -- on "a perfect storm" of negative factors that have plunged nearly all of Brazil's privatized utilities into crises, and have transformed AES into "a poster child for the energy sector's woes." 
There is no doubt that the whole sector is hurting. Electricite de France had to inject $1 billion of fresh capital last year into Light, the debt-ridden power distributor in Rio de Janeiro. The PPL Corporation wrote off its entire $317 million investment in a controlling stake in Cemar, a Brazilian utility that filed for bankruptcy protection early this year. Enersis, the Latin American investment arm of Spain's Endesa, recently refinanced $2.3 billion of its debt because of the economic crises in Brazil and Argentina. 
"Nobody is in great shape," said Claudio Sales, head of the Brazilian Chamber of Investors in Electricity.
Mr. Sales said that all of Brazil's privatized utilities were suffering from three main problems. 
First, years of drought and a lack of investment culminated in a nationwide energy crisis in 2001. Facing blackouts and rationing, Brazilians slashed consumption by 20 percent or more, and demand has not rebounded.
Second is the fall in the value of the Brazilian currency, the real, which has fallen by almost 60 percent against the dollar since 1998, eroding the value of the utilities' assets while making their dollar-denominated debts harder to repay. 
Third, regulation of the industry appears to be in flux under the new government, which has publicly wondered whether Brazil may have become too dependent on foreign companies for its energy. 
Elected on promises to improve the lot of millions of poor Brazilians, the government so far has frowned on utilities' requests to raise prices, one way of replacing lost revenue.
This week, the mines and energy minister, Dilma Rousseff, said she was effectively altering the distributors' contracts, putting off for a year the reimbursements that they get for costs like exchange rate fluctuations. The decree could cost the sector $480 million to $650 million this year, analysts said. 
For Eletropaulo, these factors have added up to disaster. The 2001 power crisis cut its revenue by $450 million, and consumers used less power last year than in 2001 even though rationing had ended, leaving the company with a $260 million loss for the year. Ms. Rousseff's decree this week could cost it another $145 million, analysts said. 
With AES's $4 billion investment so far having returned only $310 million in profit, and Brazil's regulatory environment still unclear, AES's chief executive, Paul Hanrahan, said last fall that he would sink no more fresh money into the country. 
The departure of PPL, and of Reliant Energy before it, "make you wonder if there won't be others leaving soon," Mr. Clancy said then.
That is why all eyes here are on AES. 
"AES is definitely a barometer for the sector," Mr. Franco of Tendencias said this week. "If they have to hand the keys to Eletropaulo back to the government, there will be a line of other investors waiting to do the same, and the Brazilian state will end up with a herd of white elephants." 
That is basically what Brazil had before its privatization program began. Electricity rates were low, but only because the monolithic federal utility, Eletrobras, was subsidized with tax money.
Privatization was supposed to solve that problem, but the market-friendly former president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, managed to sell only part of the system in his eight-year tenure, mainly distribution companies; 80 percent of the country's generating capacity stayed in state hands, effectively stifling competition among the distributors. 
Now, instead of selling off more of the power industry to promote competition, the new government says it wants to take back more control of the market. 
Analysts said that Ms. Rousseff's decree this week was meant to divert cash from the private sector to strengthen the state-owned generating companies so that they can finance new capacity. 
But the Brazilian state is too short of cash to be able to afford renationalizing the energy industry, and analysts expect the government to eventually settle for a mix of state and private utilities. 
"They're there looking in the top hat for a rabbit," Mr. Franco said. "But I still hope they'll end up opting for the private way out." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Steven Clancy, center, president of Eletropaulo, Latin America's biggest power distributor and the AES Corporation's main Brazilian unit, says, "We're absolutely here to stay." (Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Nostalgia Abounds as the Concorde's End Is Set 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: LONDON, April 10 

 BODY:
After 27 years of supersonic travel lofting rock stars, executives and the rest of the Champagne set across the Atlantic, British Airways and Air France said today that they would retire their fleets of Concordes this year.
 The announcement brings the end of an era when the delta-winged jet stood for the ascendancy of technology and economic hope. Today, hard-nosed executives vied for the lyrical edge in mourning its demise. 
 "Concorde changed the way people traveled," said Rod Eddington, British Airways' chief executive. "With its going, we must lose some of the romance from aviation." 
Air France's chairman, Jean-Cyril Spinetta, said: "Never has such a beautiful object been designed and built by man. This aircraft is not going to stop, because it continues to live on in the human imagination."
Richard Branson, chairman of Virgin Atlantic Airways, who has a history of tweaking British Airways, raised the possibility today that Virgin would take over its rival's castoffs. Since the announcement, "we have been flooded with calls from the public, including B.A. staff, asking us to see if we can keep Concorde flying," he said. "This might come to nothing, but I believe that every effort should be made to keep Concorde flying, as it is such an important symbol of British innovation."
If that unlikely effort fails, though, the Concorde is dead.
The airlines ascribed their decision to falling passenger demand and steadily increasing costs of maintaining the fleet. But in recent years, Concorde's status has been battered, first by safety fears after a crash outside Paris in 2000 that killed 113 people and then by the broader slowdown in air travel since the Sept. 11 attacks.
Successive years of war in Afghanistan and Iraq, moreover, have further dented the mood of business confidence that once made Concorde an emblem of worldly success.
Airlines across Europe and the United States have been reporting steady declines in passenger numbers, especially on long-haul flights to and from America. In recent months, Air France's Concordes have regularly flown with 80 of the 100 seats empty, the airline said.
Sara John, a spokeswoman for British Airways, said the withdrawal of Concorde would be "permanent as of October this year" but did not say when the last flight would take off. British Airways said it would sell 1,000 discounted tickets costing up to $6,200 for round-trip Concorde flights until the end of August -- less than half of the top price of $13,500 that a round-trip ticket normally costs. Air France set May 31 as the date for its last scheduled Concorde flight.
With global economies slowing and stock markets falling, Concorde has come to stand as an emblem of high-rolling luxury at a time when many people are experiencing layoffs and declining fortunes. That, too, has inhibited the high-rolling business set.
"If you're laying people off and telling people in your business to tighten your belt, senior executives then find it inconsistent to go to the airport and get on Concorde rather than subsonic aircraft," Mr. Eddington of British Airways said.
But many who flew on it were nostalgic, recalling its particular blend of spartan seating, delicate canapes, noisy take-offs and ineffable speed.
"It was the best travel experience anyone could ever have," said Tyler Brule, founder of Wallpaper, a style magazine. "It gave you the ultimate luxury, which is time."
"It's not the most comfortable flight," he said, "but it was the most incredible feeling. You felt as though you were hurtling through the air in a missile."
British Airways and Air France insisted that the retirement of the planes was not related to the crash on July 25, 2000, when an Air France Concorde burst into flames on take-off and crashed close to Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris. After the disaster, the plane was grounded in Britain and France while safety modifications were made. Supersonic flights were reintroduced in November 2001.
"We have complete safety at Concorde, complete confidence in its ability to fly safely," Mr. Eddington said. "This is the end of a fantastic era in world aviation, but bringing forward Concorde's retirement is a prudent business decision at a time when we are having to make difficult decisions right across the airline."
Air France said: "This decision is motivated by deteriorating economic results observed over the past months and which accelerated since the beginning of the year."
Concorde has been flying in commercial service since January 1976. Its first test flight took place in 1969.
At that time the British-French Concorde was also part of the cold war competition between East and West, spurred by the first supersonic test flight in late 1968 by the Soviet Union's larger and faster Tupolev TU-144.
That plane crashed at the Paris Air Show in 1973 and a later model crash-landed in 1978, ending Moscow's brief romance with supersonic passenger flight.
Since the British Airways Concordes went into service in 1976, the airline said, they have carried 2.5 million passengers -- not in the same great comfort as in the first-class cabin of a subsonic airliner but at great speed, crossing the Atlantic at 1,350 miles an hour at an altitude of up to 60,000 feet.
A routine crossing takes less than four hours and the fastest was just under three hours.
The airlines say 12 of the original 20 Concordes are still in service; British Airways has seven and Air France has five. The airplane was not a commercial success but stood as an emblem of prestige for British Airways and Air France and for the top-end travelers like celebrities and corporate bosses.
Its four fuel-guzzling engines made so much noise that Concorde could not be used on regular flights over populated areas and, carrying only 100 passengers, it was not as cost-effective as wide-aisle subsonic planes flying at slower speeds.
Not only that, the aging fleet seemed prone to alarms even with the modifications after the Paris crash. As recently as February, passengers were alarmed by a series of engine, rudder and nose-cone problems.
Air France said Concorde flights produced losses of around $50 million in the year ended March 31.
For all that, passengers judged that their time -- or their image -- was worth the price of the ticket.
"It really felt like you were a member of an extraordinary club, the last real travel club," Mr. Brule said. "Every time you flew there'd be at least 10 people you knew to say hello to, and there'd be another 10 who you recognized. You could have Madonna in the seat in front of you, John McEnroe behind you and Joan Collins diagonally opposite you. In the days before Sept. 11 there'd be at least three or four people up in the cockpit with a glass of Champagne."
Closing the service will cost British Airways $132 million, Mr. Eddington said. Mr. Spinetta of Air France said it would cost $65 million to retire the five Air France Concordes.

HEADLINE: Economy May Be Better Than You Think 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
PERHAPS the economy in 2003 will turn out to be a bit like the war in Iraq: a slow start that got the critics carping, followed by a surprisingly strong surge to the finish. 
 The stock market's reaction to all the good news from Iraq has been something less than impressive. This week the pros who trade stock index futures overnight generally expected rallies when the stock market opened, but were disappointed by the hesitance of real investors to bid up the prices of actual stocks. 
 There is plenty of pessimism about the economy. The Business Roundtable, a group of chief executives of large companies, reports that most of its members say their sales will increase over the next six months. But they are still pessimistic about the economy, and many plan cuts in employment. Page C7. 
What was most striking about that report was that nearly 80 percent of the executives say it is the consumer who scares them. Asked to name the "greatest economic challenge facing corporate America," few chose the strong dollar's damage to exports, or weak foreign demand or rising health insurance costs. But 27 percent cited "weak consumer demand," and 52 percent picked "consumer uncertainty" stemming from war and terrorism.
In fact, the economy has not been all that bad. Retail sales are growing at a tepid pace, but high gasoline prices get a good part of the blame for that. "The money that went to the gas station didn't go to Wal-Mart," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of ITG/Hoenig. With oil prices plunging, Wal-Mart could get it back.
Then there are the unemployment insurance statistics. The seasonally adjusted number shows that the number of recipients is up 5 percent since the end of January. But the actual numbers -- before seasonal adjustment -- show a 7 percent decline.
The seasonal adjustments assume that as the weather gets better, more people find jobs. That has happened, but not to the extent expected. You can blame the weather or war-induced pessimism. Or you can see evidence of an impending double-dip.
The probability is that it is not the double-dip. The plunge in oil prices will help the economy after the war, but growth will be slowed for a bit by the need for businesses to work off excess inventories acquired to provide security in case war or terrorism disrupted international trading routes. Then we will see if consumers are as worried as businesses think they are.
There is a fair chance that, with pessimism both here and in Europe so strong, the next round of economic statistics will be better than expected. Seasonal adjustments could exaggerate the recovery from the weather-depressed months of February and March, thus making the rebound look stronger than it is, but the relief rally that helped stocks as the war began could help the economy now.
The economy is not ready to boom, and the major surprise of the last three years remains just how slow the economy has been to respond to the Federal Reserve's stimulus after the bursting of the stock market bubble. The era of virtually free capital for favored companies, largely in technology and telecommunications, produced more overcapacity than anyone understood even in 2001.
The economy is going to have to get by without much contribution from those sectors, but there is reason to hope for an increase in spending by other businesses after the managers get over their fears that consumers are about to stop spending.
The stock market's war-relief rally peaked three weeks ago, and prices have bounced around since. But it is interesting that the worst performers since then have been the old bubblicious tech and telecom companies. Companies in other industries have done better. In that, the market may be making a good economic forecast.

HEADLINE: An Increase in Aircraft Orders Narrowed the U.S. Trade Deficit in February 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10 

 BODY:
The trade deficit unexpectedly narrowed in February, the Commerce Department reported today, as aircraft exports surged and American companies spent less on imported equipment.
 The $40.3 billion deficit was nonetheless the third highest ever. Economists had expected a deficit of $42.0 billion. 
 The trade gap in goods and services compared with a revised $41.2 billion deficit in January and a record $44.9 billion imbalance in December.
Exports would have fallen without the 80 percent increase in aircraft sales, to $2.5 billion, as Boeing delivered 14 jetliners to foreign buyers in February compared with 9 a month earlier.
Consumer goods exports fell 7.2 percent in February, led by a drop in pharmaceutical shipments.
The European Commission today cut its first-half growth forecast, adding to suggestions that overseas demand for American-made goods might be slow to recover. Fewer exports may restrain a United States economy struggling to regain strength.
"It's hard for us to keep up much momentum in exports if the rest of the world isn't doing that well," said Carol Stone, deputy chief economist at Nomura Securities International in New York. "The U.S. is growing better than the rest of the world," she said, and that may fuel demand for imports and slow exports. Nomura economists had expected a February trade deficit of $40.5 billion. 
A separate report from the Labor Department showed that import prices rose in March for a fourth consecutive month, led by higher costs for natural gas, raw materials made from petroleum, and paper.
The index of import prices increased 0.5 percent after jumping by 1.7 percent in February. Excluding petroleum, the index increased 0.9 percent, the biggest gain since the government began keeping records in December 1988. In February, the nonpetroleum index rose 0.4 percent.
The Commerce Department report showed that exports rose 0.5 percent, to $82.4 billion in February, from $82 billion the previous month. Imports fell 0.4 percent, to $122.8 billion.
The decline in imports reflected less demand for computers, civilian aircraft and generators.

HEADLINE: No Boycott of Restaurants, But the French Still Object 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK

 BODY:
There is no actual organized boy cott of French restaurants in New York City.
 That fact would seem to preclude the owners of French restaurants from assembling members of the news media to urge an end to the boycott. 
 But these are clever owners, members of a group that promotes tourism in the city. Dozens of them gathered yesterday at Le Cirque on Madison Avenue, and with the help of the equally clever men and women of the public relations industry, they managed to attract dozens of not-so-clever reporters and photographers. The event was titled "NYC Restaurants Unite to Oppose Boycott of French Restaurants." 
To be sure, French restaurants and their employees and suppliers are suffering, said Sylvain Fareri, the owner of La Metairie on West 10th Street, who did not attend the news conference. Mr. Fareri said his business was down 15 to 20 percent from the average for this time of year. But he added that while there may be some protest against French products from people angered by the French government's opposition to the war in Iraq, the problem for French restaurants in New York is the economy, stupide.
By way of example, he noted that at 2 p.m. last Friday, La Metairie had only one reservation on its books.
"If you open a new restaurant and you have a French name and no reputation behind you, people do not know you are American, maybe then you will feel a boycott," he said. "I see people looking at the menu outside, and I go stand outside, and they say, 'Oh, it's a French restaurant; let's move on.' Maybe that's a boycott. Or maybe they just want to eat Italian."
Lespinasse, the elegant restaurant in the St. Regis Hotel, announced yesterday that it would close this month, blaming a slow business climate. The announced closing did not really seem related to "any anti-French sentiment," said Tim Zagat, a creator of the restaurant guides that bear his name and a member of the executive committee of NYC & Company, the city's convention and visitors' bureau. 
At the event at Le Cirque, which ended just before lunchtime, chefs and owners from the "21" Club, Vine, Tavern on the Green, La Caravelle and many other restaurants, along with Mr. Zagat, spoke out against the boycott (which the chefs and owners quickly conceded did not exist).
They surrounded a lectern, dozens of them in suits or white chef's jackets. The intention was to implore New Yorkers to dine out, but the setting did not befit begging. A chandelier with a dozen lamps hung above their heads. There were bronze carvings of helmets and swords on the walls, striped pastel curtains adorned with metallic stars, two mirrored fireplaces and paintings of monkeys in hunting coats mounting horses or picnicking in the park and falling deeply in love.
"We're calling on all visitors and New Yorkers alike to support an industry that does so much for the city," Mr. Zagat said. 
The speakers were asked to quantify the effect of the boycott they had described. Cristyne L. Nicholas, the chief executive of NYC & Company, spoke of reports from restaurant owners in her organization that reservations were down perhaps 5 to 15 percent. She later said in an interview, "There is no boycott; there were isolated incidents that were disturbing." Those incidents, she said, included the cancellation of reservations.
Jacques Capsouto of Capsouto Freres in TriBeCa said the city's blanket ban on smoking in restaurants, which took effect March 31; the war; and the unseasonably cold weather, among many other factors, had all hurt French restaurants.
The restaurateurs signed an enlarged copy of an advertisement summarizing their views, which they plan to print in periodicals owned by Manhattan Media, a publisher of community newspapers.
Ms. Nicholas said the group could not afford to buy advertisements in publications with greater circulation.
"There is such a thing as earned media," she said, using a term she defined as creating events deemed newsworthy enough to be covered by major news media.

PERSON: Joseph T. Farrell 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
He Put the Rage in Outrageous Ticket Prices

BYLINE:  By ROBIN FINN

 BODY:
THE temptation is to accuse Joseph T. Farrell -- the predictably dapper chief executive of Broadway Inner Circle, the theater ticket service that brought us the indispensable $480 premium orchestra seat for "The Producers" -- of committing the Great White Way version of highway robbery. Must be the combination of silver hair, silver stubble, silver tie and silver tongue offset by that sunny out-of-season tan that arouse suspicion -- he just hopped off a flight from Florida, so jealousy is factoring into first impressions.
 But wait. Hear him out -- which requires tuning out the unmusical screech of car horns from the clogged-up thoroughfare outside his less than luxurious office at 690 Eighth Avenue, near 44th Street. This is definitely not a V.I.P.-approved space: nary a doorman or velvet rope in sight, not even a coffeemaker to take the edge off a damp day. Then again, Mr. Farrell, 49, insists that he himself is simply "a serial entrepreneur," and not, like the 20,000 high-rollers from 30 different nations in his client base, a genuine V.I.P. He just happens to know where they like to sit when the curtain goes up and whom they want to mingle with once the curtain goes down. 
 "I didn't create the V.I.P.," says Mr. Farrell, instinctively going on the defensive, but sweetly. "What I created is the situation where a V.I.P.'s money is going to the rightful recipient, the people who create and present the shows, not some scalper." The most he ever paid a scalper was $275 apiece for tickets to "The Lion King."
Proximity has its privileges. And its price. At Broadway Inner Circle, it is typically $240 per musical and $180 for what Mr. Farrell calls a straight play. Actual prices are printed on the Inner Circle ticket, which makes for smoother tax deductions for corporate clients. Scalpers don't offer this service, nor do they supply a concierge to escort clients to their seats even if, as captains of industry can do, the client forgets his tickets.
"Our client base is traditionally not the type of person who calls Ticketmaster or Telecharge and spends $100 on a seat; our client goes to scalpers and spends anywhere from three or four to seven hundred dollars for seats. So if you look at it that way, we're not converting $100 tickets to $240 tickets; we're converting $300, $400, $500 tickets to $240 tickets." Interesting math.
MR. FARRELL, who says he devotes 20 percent of his working life to nonprofit organizations like the St. Louis Sports Foundation in his hometown, swears there's even a smidgen of philanthropy lurking beneath the stratospheric price of the Inner Circle theater experience, a service born out of the stampede for prime "Producers" tickets in 2001 and now offered by a dozen Broadway productions. Union workers, he says, reap around 5 percent of a ticket's face value. "So every time we sell a $240 ticket, the union gets twice as much as it gets from a $100 ticket sold at a profit by scalpers."
The idea for Broadway Inner Circle sprang up when Mr. Farrell went to dinner with a group that included Rocco Landesman's wife, Debbie -- Mr. Landesman, another of the "Producers" producers, is president of the Jujamcyn theater chain. She told him her husband had a new play. "She was lamenting the fact that if the production isn't a hit, the producers lose millions, and if it is, vast sums of the profits go to these four guys over in Jersey scalping tickets."
It was a lightbulb moment for Mr. Farrell, who got his start in sales peddling Hallmark cards and whose past entrepreneurial ventures include the St. Louis Steamers soccer franchise, the Delaney's Restaurants chain and Allied Health Group, a Florida-based managed-care organization sold to Magellan in 1997. He suggested that the producers do what every shrewd sports owner does: offer a V.I.P. package. Mr. Farrell pioneered just this sort of thing back in St. Louis in 1987 when he created a "$500 uber-ticket" for a volleyball game between the American and Soviet Olympic squads. A few days after the dinner, he was asked to jump-start Inner Circle.
He was born in St. Louis, where his father was a sales engineer. After-school jobs were mandatory, and his psychology degree from the University of Missouri was self-financed. He lived in his hometown for 44 years before deciding it was no fun being landlocked and moved to Florida, but he retains an interest in a St. Louis blues club called Broadway Oyster Bar (coincidence, coincidence) for sentimental reasons. His favorite all-time play is "Glengarry Glen Ross." It's a self-directed j'accuse thing. 
Five years ago he and his wife, Kristen, and their four children, made Casey Key their home port. Their yellow house sits on stilts. The Gulf of Mexico doubles as their front yard. The tennis legend Martina Navratilova is their newest neighbor. Mr. Farrell travels often; those permanent squint lines are remnants of his mountain-climbing days (Cotopaxi in Ecuador and the Matterhorn top an impressive list of scaled peaks). His resume says he resides in Seat 3-C on American Airlines, and three or four days a week he is here tending to ticket sales. And expansion.
The bad news, for cheapskates, is that Broadway Inner Circle isn't just on Broadway anymore: the Los Angeles rendition of "The Producers" has joined, and London's West End is next. So the V.I.P., a species that does not appear endangered, drives the global theater economy? 
"Thank God." Thank God for V.I.P.s? "Well, at least I think so."

HEADLINE: McGreevey Meets Mayors, and Feels a Chill 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, April 10 

 BODY:
A few weeks after James E. McGreevey was sworn in as governor in January 2002, he spoke before a group of New Jersey mayors in the State House and was greeted like a conquering hero.
 As the former mayor of Woodbridge, Mr. McGreevey was on a first-name basis with many people in the audience, and his familiarity with their policy concerns and willingness to propose bold and expensive solutions brought the new governor spontaneous outbursts of applause and congratulations. 
 Today, Mr. McGreevey once again spoke to the state's mayors, at their annual convention, but the lukewarm response he received was a striking indication of the strain that has developed between the governor and one of his key constituent groups during his 15 months in office. 
Mr. McGreevey was greeted by tepid applause as he took the stage more than an hour late and explained that his daughter had been ill. Audience members listened politely as he launched into his oft-repeated speech about the state's plans to curb suburban sprawl. Halfway through his remarks, after promising to renovate 200 municipal parks and build two new state parks, Mr. McGreevey paused for a moment, then departed from his written text.
"That was an applause line, by the way," the governor said. After a moment's silence, the audience clapped. 
The issue that has come between Mr. McGreevey and the mayors is the same problem causing him grief with unions, legislators, educators and nearly anyone with a voice in state government: New Jersey's budget deficit. For the second straight year, Mr. McGreevey is facing a mammoth budget gap and has vowed not to raise income or sales taxes. And for the second straight year, his deficit-reduction plan has included a freeze in the amount of aid the state doles out to municipalities.
Last year's freeze forced many New Jersey municipalities to choose between raising property taxes on homeowners or encouraging the kind of new development that would increase their tax bases. So to some in the audience at the New Jersey Conference of Mayors convention at the Trump Taj Mahal casino here, Mr. McGreevey's call for tighter controls on development sounded like a double dose of gloomy economic news.
"It's kind of a bitter pill to swallow," said Chuck Chiarello, mayor of Buena Vista Township in Atlantic County, a Democrat and a longtime supporter of Mr. McGreevey. "Suburban sprawl is one of those issues that everyone is concerned about. But everybody here has to take care of their own backyard, and people are getting a little worried."
Mr. McGreevey and his advisers have heard similar complaints from virtually every point on the state's political compass, and the governor's poll numbers have begun to worry a few political advisers. But Mr. McGreevey has said that governors nationwide have seen their approval ratings sag as the economic slowdown drags on, so he is determined to keep pushing the anti-sprawl agenda he campaigned on.
As he began his address to the mayors, Mr. McGreevey voiced concern for the economic pressures they are facing. "But despite these challenges, we are making progress in making our state a better and safer place to live," he said. Then Mr. McGreevey outlined his detailed proposal for a state plan to preserve open space by steering new development to targeted areas. 
After receiving polite applause at the end of his speech, Mr. McGreevey was ushered to his next engagement -- speaking to a tourism group upset by his plan to raise taxes on casinos -- and the mayors quietly left the room.
"I think he means well," said John Logan, a Republican who is the mayor of Vernon Township in Sussex County. "But he took office at a really bad time."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. James E. McGreevey addressing the mayors' conference. His plans include freezing aid to municipalities and limiting new development. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Rise a Bit as Investors' Attention Shifts to Profits

BYLINE:  By Reuters

 BODY:
Better-than-expected results by the Internet bellwether Yahoo buoyed technology stocks yesterday.
 The blue-chip Dow also rose slightly in light trading as investors turned to economic indicators and corporate results after anxiously trading on news about Iraq for months. The quarterly earnings season picks up next week, and many companies have warned that results will not meet estimates. 
 "There are some real questions out there that need to be answered about how fast earnings growth will be and is the economy slipping back into recession," said John Caldwell, chief equity strategist at the McDonald Financial Group. "We don't think it's that bad, or anything close, but the market's definitely worrying about that." 
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 23.39 points, or 0.29 percent, to 8,221.33, after seesawing close to break-even for much of the session. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 8.87 points, or 0.65 percent, to 1,365.61, based on the latest figures, after trading lower much of the day. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 stock index added 5.59 points, or 0.65 percent, to 871.58.
Advancers edged out decliners by a ratio of about 10 to 7 on the New York Stock Exchange, and almost 8 to 7 on the Nasdaq. Volume was light, totaling 1.24 billion shares on the Big Board, and about the same on the Nasdaq.
The stocks of many retailers rose on investors' hopes the winding down of war in Iraq would buoy consumer sentiment. The S.& P. retailing index of 31 companies gained almost 2 percent, with all but two components rising.
Children's Place Retail Stores rose $2.19, or 20 percent, to $12.94. The company said sales at stores open at least a year fell sharply in March, but its shares surged as the results were much better than expected.
Banks also got a lift, with all but one member of the S.& P. banking index of 29 companies up. The index rose 1.6 percent. SunTrust Banks, a large Southeast regional bank holding company, said first-quarter net profit rose almost 8 percent, which beat expectations. Its shares jumped almost 7 percent, or $3.52, to $55.08.
Yahoo offered a bright note at the start of the earnings season and climbed $1.40, or 6 percent, to $24.27, after reporting late Wednesday that it had swung to a quarterly profit from a year-ago loss. The company also said full-year revenue would be at least 5 percent higher than forecast earlier, because of a rebound in advertising and growth in broadband services.
Shares of the Fox Entertainment Group, which holds the United States entertainment assets of the News Corporation, plunged to their lowest level in nearly six months. As analysts criticized News Corporation's plans to take over DirecTV, the No. 1 United States satellite television service.
The structure saddles Fox with an additional $4.5 billion of debt, and will force it to issue 74 million new shares to News Corporation as part of the transfer.
Fox shares fell 17 percent, or $4.65, to $22.60.
Hotels.com, an online hotel reservation site, rallied $10.20, or 19 percent, to $63.50. USA Interactive, the media group run by Barry Diller, said it would buy the remaining public stake in Hotels.com for about $1.1 billion. USA Interactive rose $1.59, or 6 percent, to $26.69.
Genentech declined $1.43, or 3.9 percent, to $34.99. Genentech said its first-quarter net profit rose 59 percent. But an analyst attributed the company's results to "reining in expenses, lower taxes and higher contract revenue."
IDEC Pharmaceuticals sank $2.35, or 6.9 percent, to $31.59. IDEC's fortunes are related to Genentech, which helps market its cancer drug Rituxan.
Treasury bond prices fell as stocks rose. The benchmark 10-year note dropped 9/32 , to a price of 99 15/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, climbed to 3.95 percent from 3.90 percent on Wednesday.
The 30-year bond declined 16/32 , to a price of 106 20/32 . Its yield rose to 4.94 percent from 4.90 percent.

HEADLINE: City Unemployment Rate Rose Again in February 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT

 BODY:
The unemployment rate in New York City climbed to 8.8 percent in February, from 8.6 percent in January, while dropping slightly in the suburbs and upstate, according to state figures released yesterday. Jobs in the city continued to decline in construction, manufacturing, the film industry and finance, and to increase in health services. 
 The data, from the New York State Department of Labor, showed that the statewide unemployment rate, when seasonally adjusted, fell to 6.1 percent in February, from 6.3 percent in January. Nationally, the jobless rate is 5.8 percent, up from 5.7 percent in January. 
 "What you're seeing is a continuation of the trend in unemployment," said Jim Brown, a labor market analyst for the labor department. "It's been rising, and it's probably going to continue to rise for a few months as the economy remains weak. And you're seeing a mixed to weakish job picture -- some seasonal growth but well below historic levels."
The city's unemployment rate, based on a monthly household survey, has been rising steadily since dipping to 5.2 percent in January 2001. The last time it was 8.8 percent was in November 1997.
Although the unadjusted data showed an increase of about 12,000 jobs in New York City in February, several economists said those numbers translated into a loss of 10,000 to 12,000 jobs when seasonally adjusted. Barbara Byrne Denham of The New York Stat, an economic newsletter, said that was the city's largest one-month decline since last July.

HEADLINE: Executives See Weak Economy Continuing 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
Chief executives of large companies, perhaps the most accurate economic forecasters recently, expect the economy to remain weak over the next six months but do not foresee a new recession, according to a survey released yesterday.
 Only about one company out of 10 plans to increase employment in the United States in that period, according to the poll of 120 chief executives by the Business Roundtable, an association of leaders of large companies. The rest, some 90 percent of companies, are divided almost evenly between those that plan job cuts and those that expect to hold employment at current levels. 
 "We've got a pretty weak economy," said John T. Dillon, the chairman of the association and chief executive of International Paper. "We all feel great about the war. But we've got to have economic security as well as security for our homeland." 
Since the economy began weakening in 2000, chief executives have consistently made more pessimistic, and more accurate, predictions than Federal Reserve officials or Wall Street economists. 
The executives polled estimated that the economy would grow 2.2 percent this year. Wall Street economists and other private sector forecasters predict growth of 2.4 percent for 2003, down from their forecast of 3.5 percent a year earlier, according to Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a newsletter that surveys them each month.
With oil prices having fallen significantly in recent weeks and American forces having taken control of Baghdad, few remain concerned about a new recession. Only 2 percent of executives said the economy would not grow at all this year, and none forecast a contraction, according to the Business Roundtable.
The most recent recession began in March 2001, and the economy began growing again late in 2001.
The number of people filing new claims for unemployment insurance fell last week to 405,000 from 443,000 the previous week, the Labor Department reported yesterday. The four-week moving average of new claims, which many economists consider a more reliable indicator than the week-to-week data, fell to its lowest level in more than a month.
Ian Shepherdson, chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y., called the drop an encouraging sign, noting that jobless claims were often the labor market's signal to change directions. But, he added, "it is impossible to know at this point if this week's decline is anything more than noise."
The poll of chief executives was conducted last week, before the Iraqi government began collapsing, and about half of the executives called consumer uncertainty about the war the greatest economic challenge facing corporate America. Still, Mr. Dillon said he did not think that the evidence of military success in Iraq would be a turning point for the economy.
"I think there will be a short-term improvement as inventories are rebuilt," he said. "Inventories have been held at very, very low levels because of all of the uncertainty in the world. But frankly, the fundamentals we're talking about here are largely not war related."
Businesses are using less than 80 percent of their capacity, Mr. Dillon said, and they will not begin investing in new equipment or hiring more workers until demand increases. Many companies are still suffering through the overhang of the 1990's boom.
In the survey, 27 percent of executives said they planned to cut their capital spending over the next six months and 55 percent said they would make no change. Eighteen percent expected to increase it.
A sharp decline in capital spending -- business investment in new factories, equipment and technology -- has hampered the economy since 2000.
Slightly more than half of executives forecast an increase in their own sales in the next six months, but as a group the executives seemed less hopeful than when they were polled in December. Then, 71 percent said they thought that sales would increase over the next year.
Speaking to reporters, Mr. Dillon called on Congress to pass President Bush's tax-cut proposal, saying it would lift consumer demand and stock prices.
Many senators, including some Republicans, are worried that the proposal is too costly, and while economists are divided on the long-term benefits of the plan, few consider it likely to help the economy significantly this year.
About 50 members of the Business Roundtable, all chief executives, met with Mr. Bush at the White House yesterday afternoon to discuss strategies for helping the economy.

HEADLINE: A Gilded Age of Sumptuous Dining Comes to a Close in the St. Regis Hotel 

BYLINE:  By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Lespinasse, the airy, gilded four-star restaurant in the St. Regis Hotel that was for 12 years the preserve of European and corporate royalty, celebrities and commoners able to afford its sumptuousness announced yesterday that it would close April 19.
 The owners, citing a dearth of profits, said the restaurant's Old World elegance -- which has been likened to that of an exquisite chateau -- had been unable to sustain it during "the current economic and world political climate," according to a statement. 
 It is unusual for a four-star restaurant to close without having lost a star, and the announcement follows by seven months the closing of another Manhattan institution, the Russian Tea Room, the domain of caviar and blini on West 57th Street. 
The closing would reduce to five the number of Manhattan restaurants given a four-star rating by The New York Times. (The others are Bouley, Daniel, Alain Ducasse, Jean Georges and Le Bernardin.) 
Lespinasse (pronounced less peen AHSS), at 2 East 55th Street in the hotel on Fifth Avenue, has a staff of 32, including a kitchen crew of 12. It stopped serving lunch last week.
"We carried it as long as we could," said Guenter H. Richter, managing director of the St. Regis. "Any reopening will be determined by the pace of the economic recovery." 
Some in the food trade viewed the closing as a seismic blow to the city's high-end restaurant business. The industry has been hit hard by a winter of lashing snowstorms and security alerts that kept tourists and business people at bay. 
And in recent weeks, round-the-clock war bulletins have left diners dialing for take-out while clutching their cable remotes. (There was no indication that anti-French sentiment related to the war had anything to do with the closing.)
Tim Zagat, founder of the restaurant guide, said he was not shocked at the announcement of Lespinasse's closing. "The food was very, very good," he said, "but the decor was a bit too ornate, and the furnishings were outdated and heavy." 
While Mr. Richter said he viewed the closing as temporary, he added that the announcement was not a sympathy ploy presaging a miraculous rebirth, since the St. Regis has given formal notice to the workers' union, the New York Hotel Trades Council. Its employees have been informed of the closing, "and we have no intention of changing our mind," he said. The union confirmed that it had received the notice.
Some who have worked there said the restaurant has never made a profit. Mr. Richter declined to comment, but explained that "it was not created to be a restaurant where we expected a high return -- our hotel required a restaurant of that caliber." 
In flusher times its corporate owner, Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide of White Plains, might have been able to sustain the losses. "But our occupancy has experienced a dip in a quarter that is never busy," Mr. Richter said. Meals will still be available at the Astor Court restaurant in the lobby and the King Cole Bar. 
The restaurant took its name from the hostess of a Paris salon that drew philosophers, nobles and diplomats. At Lespinasse, visitors luxuriated in the hushed, timeless universe of its pale beige and gold antique decor and were cosseted by a wait staff whose approach was inaudible, thanks to the custom-made rose carpet. The room's five towering floral centerpieces were updated weekly. 
The chef Gray Kunz, a Singapore-born Swiss, became the restaurant's genius-in-residence from 1991 to 1998, and critics swooned over his Asian-accented French cuisine. 
Critics also praised the prize-winning wine list, which balanced young wines with an abundance of rare vintages and was reprinted throughout the evening as wines sold out. 
After the departure of Mr. Kunz in 1998, the toque passed to Christian Delouvrier, formerly of Les Celebrites in the Essex House. Mr. Delouvrier gave more emphasis to classical French themes, while showcasing the culinary traditions of southwest France. 
"Of course I feel sad," Mr. Delouvrier said yesterday. "I want to thank all of the loyal customers, and all of the employees who work with me, for their support." 
Mr. Delouvrier said he was considering several employment options, but his first task would be editing an autobiography adorned with recipes, "Mastering Simplicity: A Life in the Kitchen," due from John Wiley & Sons in the fall. It will trace the roots of his cuisine from Gascony to Paris and New York.
