HEADLINE: Philosophies Clash on Commuter Tax 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 10 

 BODY:
At the crux of the conflict between City Hall and Albany over whether to tax New York City commuters is a difference in mind-set: the governor sees the issue in political terms while the mayor views it as a matter of practical survival, even if that bucks political reality. 
 The governor, George E. Pataki, ran against a commuter tax when he was re-elected in November and, in addition to winning more votes in New York City than any other Republican in the last half-century, he dominated the downstate suburbs with nearly 60 percent of the vote. 
 He also used the issue in a series of effective television ads to hammer his Democratic opponent, H. Carl McCall, who said, on video, that he favored a reinstatement of the tax because no one had ever complained about it. Reversing course now would force Mr. Pataki to break a prime campaign promise. 
The death of the old commuter tax (at 0.45 percent) was barely noted in 1999, when a strong economy fueled record surpluses in the city and the state. Repealing the $1.10-to-$1.25-a-day levy on commuters did not seem like such a bad idea at the time.
Indeed, the topic was thought to be so uncontroversial that Sheldon Silver, the Democratic speaker of the State Assembly, shepherded its demise in part to help some of the suburban lawmakers in his party, despite the fact that it drained $500 million a year from the city treasury, some for his own district in Lower Manhattan.
But the times have changed; the economy is sputtering. Unemployment is high, with little evidence of improvement on the horizon. The new attitude in the suburbs is one that state lawmakers of both parties describe with one word: anxiety.
Suburban voters are facing double-digit property tax increases and a Metropolitan Transportation Authority fare increase that raised the price of commuter rail tickets by 25 percent, made tolls 50 cents higher at some bridges and tunnels and raised the basic costs of subway rides. Many suburbanites who work on Wall Street have seen their incomes plunge in recent months and are in no mood to help the city. A commuter tax would simply be a piling-on.
"If New York City were in a financial bind by itself, perhaps there would be a great willingness to help," said an aide to a leading Republican senator. "But the state is also in a financial bind, and we need to make sacrifices together. It is not as if those commuters are not getting hit already or are getting a free ride on the back of the city."
The governor spoke against the commuter tax again today, at an appearance in New York City, saying it would cost the city "thousands of jobs." But even if he wavers later, the Republican Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and about 17 Republican senators who represent commuters in the city's suburbs are all lined up against it.
Despite these hard-boiled political realities, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is studiously pushing the issue at every turn, borrowing from his successful strategy in a fight for control of the city's schools. In that case, the governor agreed with him. Today, the mayor said he believed that Albany's leadership triumvirate -- Mr. Pataki, Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno -- would not let him down, though he appeared mildly critical of Mr. Pataki's blunt antitax stance.
"I think you have to separate out the politics of how do you adjust tax rates up when needed from the easy political move of reducing tax rates when you don't need them," Mr. Bloomberg said when asked about the pros and cons of taxes.
The mayor wants to raise about $1 billion by extending the city's income tax to commuters but dropping the rates to a maximum of 2.7 percent. His pitch is simple: He believes that he has already taken harsh action, by raising property taxes 18.5 percent, laying off 600 workers and announcing plans to lay off 5,000 more while also facing a $90-million-a-year bill for increased counterterrorism costs in the New York Police Department.
As with his manner on policy and fiscal matters, Mr. Bloomberg often seems to believe that being right on the merits is good enough and views the politics involved as mosquitolike distractions that others ought to ignore.
Aides to Mr. Bloomberg have criticized Albany for what they view as a lack of alternatives for city fiscal relief, spawning a round of bitter remarks between the staffs of the mayor and governor over who has better ideas.
But some Albany lawmakers said it was City Hall that offered no alternatives. They ask whether Mr. Bloomberg has a tin ear for the complexities of Albany politics, and thereby the state, or has a strategy that is not immediately obvious.
The mayor is not posturing, his aides said, but plainly making his case on the merits: If the city falters, the state will too. To underestimate his understanding of Albany politics would be a mistake, they said.
"Tax reform is a fair way to spread the burden of supporting essential city services to those who benefit from them," said Edward Skyler, a spokesman for the mayor. "The mayor is well aware that until the budget is done, nothing is off the table and recent history bears that out."
Albany's politics are like a funhouse mirror at times, so the outcome could still spin out in a variety of ways, perhaps as a variation of the mayor's proposal. It remains to be seen if Mr. Bloomberg's single-mindedness will be effective.
But given recent signs at the State Capitol, it appears that he has made no progress to date, as pressure builds in Albany and City Hall to pass budgets to resolve huge gaps.
As Mr. Bruno said after a meeting this week with the governor and Mr. Silver, "The commuter tax is not going to happen."
As if that was not clear enough, he added: "I have been saying for six months that it is not doable, not going to happen and nothing's changed. And there are other alternatives. All people have to do is look at other alternatives and be creative and be imaginative and stop being just, you know, single-minded."

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: SOUTHEAST ASIA; 
In Far East of Many Muslims, Press Is Anti-U.S. but Hardly Pro-Jihad

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: BANGKOK, April 10 

 BODY:
"Heartening," one Filipino columnist wrote today after watching scenes of cheering Iraqis on television. But, he added, "it's still an unjust war."
 Baghdad seemed farther away than ever, and more puzzling, in Southeast Asia, a region whose Muslims had opposed the war in dutiful but somewhat uncertain solidarity with their Arab brothers. 
 The press in Islamic Indonesia and Malaysia has been almost uniformly critical and often derisive about the war. The tone has been the same in the Philippines, a Roman Catholic nation with close American ties and a significant Muslim minority. 
But the opposition has had a half-hearted, been-there ring to it, lacking the intensity and the calls for jihad that accompanied America's attack on Afghanistan more than a year ago and that still run through the Arab media in the Middle East.
When Garin Nugroho, a leading Indonesian film director, wanted to show his opposition to the war, he announced that he would refrain from drinking Coca-Cola -- for a day.
The press in the region seems to feel less obligation now to stand in solidarity with Islamic brothers in the Middle East and a bit more leeway to offer a glimpse of the other side of the argument. The tone is striking in a region where Al Qaeda has found refuge and is seeking recruits.
"It's a challenge for the media to remain balanced in their reports of the war," said Ulil Abshar-Abdalla of the Liberal Islam Network in a radio discussion of press coverage.
In an attempt to present the American, Arab and Asian perspectives on the war, the private Indonesian station Metro TV, in its daily program "Iraq Under Attack," is showing images from CNN, Al Jazeera and Cable News Asia.
"Even in so-called Islamic media, the tendency has largely been toward not portraying this war as a religious one," said Atmakusumah Astraatmadja, chairman of Indonesia's independent Press Council. "Iraqis have been fleeing to Indonesia for years, and refugees usually flee countries with oppressive policies."
The wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, he said, are "related to the survival of Americans decades ahead, while we can only think of planning for tomorrow." He added: "I don't quite like the arguments, but they have their own reasons, not just to hit at suggested terrorists."
In Malaysia, where the press is firmly under the thumb of the government, opposition to the war has been modulated by pragmatism. Public figures are quoted warning that anti-Americanism and boycotts can be politically and economically damaging.
"Malaysians have been urged not to vent their anger by boycotting American brands as the action would make a dent in our economy," said the minister of youth and sports, Hishammuddin Tun Hussein, quoted in The Star, an English-language daily.
Public protests have been carefully appropriated by the Malaysian government for maximum political gain as it looks toward parliamentary elections in the coming year. The point is made repeatedly that the criticisms are antiwar rather than anti-American.
At the same time, any attempt at protest by opposition parties is squelched -- particularly calls for Muslim solidarity by the Islamic party known as PAS.
"The war is not a war between Christians and Muslims," said Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. "There is no crusade. Many Christians including Pope John Paul and other Christian leaders opposed the attack on Iraq. But we fear, eventually, the targets are Muslim countries."
Dr. Mahathir, who was transformed from gadfly to ally when he gave America full backing in its war on terror, has begun to annoy the United States again with repeated barbs about Iraq.
Washington threatened diplomatic and economic reprisals last month after he called Americans cowards and bullies and said: "Maybe after Iraq, Iran; and after Iran, probably Syria or Libya." No leader could be sure he would not be next, he said.
The small government-owned afternoon daily, Malay Mail, has been particularly harsh, with headlines like "When Will This Parody End?" "High Noon for Cowboy Bush," and "Israel the Real Winner."
In the Philippine Daily Inquirer, the columnist Rina Jimenez-David described the cheering crowds in Baghdad and wrote, "The images are heartening indeed." But she added, "While 'regime change,' one of the stated reasons for the campaign, is a near certainty by now, that still doesn't make this unjust war a just one."
The Philippines is the most pro-American nation in Asia, and polls there show that most people support the war. But this is also the country with some of the most unfettered media anywhere. Columnists and editorial writers have indulged themselves in paroxysms of anti-American wit.
"When the allied forces are done leveling Iraq to the ground, will the world let them off with an 'Oops, sorry. At least we made sure there were no weapons of mass destruction?' " Jenny Manuel and Gai Olivares, regular columnists in The Daily Tribune, wrote last week.
"Americans have this hero complex," they wrote. "They're the Great Liberator! You'll see it in their movies; they always come in with their superior technology and save the world, whether it's from aliens, mammoth asteroids or giant spiders."

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: A MILITARY TOWN; 
War Strains Germans at American Base

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO

DATELINE: ALAMOGORDO, N.M., April 10 

 BODY:
Vera Kieren, a teacher at the Deutsche Schule here, said it happened when her husband told a convenience store cashier recently that their daughter did not drink Coca-Cola. 
 "The cashier said, 'But she does live in this country, doesn't she?' " said Ms. Kieren, who moved to Alamogordo with her family three years ago from Baden-Baden, in southwestern Germany. 
 "It's been a bit tense for us with the issues in Iraq." Ms. Kieren said, surprised at the implication that any right-thinking parents in the United States would have their child drinking Coca-Coca. 
Perhaps some friction was inevitable. Since 1992, the German Air Force has conducted pilot training operations at nearby Holloman Air Force Base, drawn by the clear azure skies and sparsely populated expanses that American pilots have trained in for decades. As those operations have grown, this city has seen its German population balloon to 2,000, or nearly 1 in 15 residents.
But when the German government began to oppose the Bush administration's policy on Iraq, many American-born residents here began to re-evaluate their feelings about their new neighbors. 
"I have a son in the Navy, so I'd like to see the Germans more involved," said Richard Zierlein, owner of the Fix-It Center, an appliance repair store. "We have a substantial number of people from our community deployed in Iraq, so I'm sure many people feel the same way."
Others in Alamogordo have opposed the German military presence here ever since training operations were shifted to Holloman in 1992 when George Air Force Base in California closed. Now those residents have found a new issue to latch on to. 
"The German war position is another darn annoying factor about them being here," said Robert Jones, 73, a rancher and former president of the New Mexico Cattle Growers Association. "I do not like the possibility that German aircraft could crash on my land, setting off fires and killing my cattle." 
Such sentiment has not kept Germany from steadily reinforcing its military and cultural presence in Alamogordo, a city best known for its proximity to the site of the first atomic bomb explosion but one that already had historical connections with Germany. 
Hundreds of German prisoners of war were interned here in World War II. After the war, German scientists were taken to nearby White Sands to develop rocket-launching technology in a clandestine program code-named Operation Paperclip.
"Past and present, the German community has blended right in with the rest of the people," said Mayor Donald Carroll. 
In recent years, the German community has created its own multidenominational church, the Johanneskirche. The private Deutsche Schule, or German school, has 180 students in grades 1 through 10. 
There is a German aisle in the local Lowe's supermarket, carrying products like Feinkost herring fillets, Ritter chocolates and Panni Spaeztle, home-style egg noodles. 
And the Germans of Alamogordo have many supporters. "We make the distinction between the Germans here and the political ones over in Germany," said Ed Carr, executive director of the Economic Development Council for Otero County, of which Alamogordo is the seat. 
Germans inject a substantial amount of money into the local economy. They spend nearly $1 million a month in and around Alamogordo, and their government invested $140 million in improvements at the Holloman base. They have pumped new life into the real estate market -- many lease sprawling ranch-style homes -- and they spend money outside Alamogordo as well, on tourist excursions to escape temperatures that soar above 100 degrees.
"If you want to know something about the United States, ask our German neighbors," Brig. Gen. Bill Lake, a former commander of the 49th Fighter Wing, which is based at Holloman, said in a recent issue of Airman magazine. "They take the time to enjoy themselves."
Still, what was once was viewed as a plum assignment, with a 50 percent pay increase for overseas duty and a housing allowance, has become relatively less sought after. An uncertain economic outlook in Germany and reductions in its air force have resulted in fewer applicants for German military jobs abroad, a German officer said.
"Many people are not willing to leave Germany because they're not sure their old jobs will be there when they return," said the officer, Capt. Marc Probst, a spokesman for the German air defense school, a separate operation about an hour's drive south of Alamogordo at Fort Bliss, Tex. "They are afraid to get caught out of the loop."
Each year, the Germans invite about 4,000 people from Alamogordo for an Oktoberfest celebration on the base, replete with beer, live oompah bands and bus transportation to prevent drunken driving incidents. 
Even so, Heinz Hinterleitner, the principal of the Deutsche Schule, said in an interview: "It's an awkward situation, because the soldiers left on the base here are the Germans. The Americans are gone because of the war."

HEADLINE: House Endorses Oil Drilling in Arctic National Wildlife Refuge 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 10 

 BODY:
House members endorsed oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge tonight as they considered a wide-ranging energy measure that seeks to spur domestic energy production and provides tax incentives to oil and power companies.
 Siding with the Bush administration on one of its top energy initiatives, the House defeated on a 228-to-197 vote an effort to strip the drilling plan from the measure. Lawmakers did support limiting development to a 2,000-acre "footprint" in the 1.5 million-acre coastal plain of the refuge on the North Slope of Alaska. 
 The Senate, which is developing its own energy measure, rejected the drilling plan in a crucial budget vote last month and Republican leaders there say they do not intend to return to the issue in their energy proposal. But House advocates of drilling said they hoped to persuade the Senate to reverse that position. 
Sponsors of the bill said that the nation needed to tap more of its own energy resources to decrease its reliance on imported oil and that the Alaskan drilling would help stimulate the economy and was supported by the Native Americans in the area.
"The Eskimos that live there want this drilling," said Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska. "We can do this safely."
Opponents of the drilling, who include Democrats and moderate Republicans, said the refuge was a national resource that needed protecting. They said the drilling vote was particularly wrong-headed given that lawmakers defeated an increase in auto gas mileage standards that its authors said would save more oil than the refuge could produce.
"What right do we have as human beings and what sense does it make as a nation to open a pristine area to drilling when we are not willing to take basic steps toward conservation?" asked Representative Sherwood Boehlert, Republican of New York. 
Returning to a sweeping energy policy that stalled last year, Republican authors of the bill defeated several efforts to alter the measure, which touches on all aspects of national energy production and use.It is an outgrowth of an energy plan drafted in the early months of the Bush administration under the supervision of a task force headed by Vice President Dick Cheney.
"It advances a balanced approach to energy production and use by accomplishing and encouraging a responsible, diverse mix of energy sources and options," said Representative Billy Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana and chairman of the Energy Committee.
Critics said the measure was full of "industry goodies" while giving short shrift to energy conservation and undercutting some important environmental restrictions. The bill provides $18.7 billion in a wide array of tax breaks, many of them for oil and gas companies, besides opening the refuge to oil exploration. 
"It is a bad bill," said Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, the senior Democrat on the Energy Committee.
The supporters of the bill showed their strength in an early vote by soundly defeating on a 268-to-162 vote a proposal to require a 5 percent reduction in automotive fuel use by 2010, which its sponsors said equated roughly to an average standard of 30 miles per gallon. 
Opponents of the auto mileage standard proposal said it could harm the economy by forcing automakers to cut production of popular sport utility vehicles and increase the risk of car crash injuries in the smaller cars that would meet the standards.
"Bringing smaller cars in results in more deaths on the highway," said Representative Bart Stupak, Democrat of Michigan, the state that is home to much of the auto industry.
The House also defeated a proposal by Mr. Dingell to rewrite electricity rules in the measure. Democrats say the proposal could put consumers at risk of price swings and complained that the bill does not address the sort of market manipulation regulators say contributed to the energy crisis in California and the West two years ago.
"It has virtually no protections against fraud," Mr. Dingell said.
Backers of the measure say the changes in the electricity market will make utilities more competitive. 
Though opponents said the measure does not do enough to promote conservation and development of new energy sources, it does grant tax credits for solar and wind power and encourages homeowners to make energy-efficient improvements.
Authors said that the measure recognized that the transition to new types of power would take years and that oil, gas and coal would remain the main fuels for the near future.
The bill grants oil and gas companies tax breaks to encourage production from marginal wells and those in deep offshore waters, allocates millions of dollars for the development of new coal technology, eliminates a tax on diesel fuel for trains and barges and allows utilities to more quickly write off the cost of new transmission systems.

HEADLINE: Plan to Alter A Yardstick For Pensions 

BYLINE:  By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

 BODY:
Corporations would find billions of dollars of pension shortfalls eliminated overnight under a proposal being prepared to address a longstanding issue in pension accounting.
 The proposed legislation, being drafted by a Democrat and a Republican who sponsored changes in retirement laws in 2001, would create a permanent replacement for the 30-year bond in certain pension calculations. An interim measure, allowing companies to use a more favorable rate, is set to expire at the end of the year. 
 The proposal, embraced by the nation's biggest corporations, would use a rate that is tied to high-rated corporate bonds and that is higher than both the interim measure and the rate that companies have traditionally used to measure their pension obligations. The higher rate, known as the discount rate, makes obligations to retirees look smaller, at least on paper. 
Because companies are required to keep their pensions funded at certain levels, smaller obligations will shrink their mandatory contributions, even though nothing else has changed.
America's companies, large and small, had a total pension shortfall of about $300 billion at the end of 2002, according to the government agency that insures pensions. That was by far the largest total deficit in the history of that agency, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, and it has aroused concerns about the health of the pension system. The worst deficits are found among a relatively small number of companies, in sectors like the auto and airline industries and deregulated public utilities.
Many big companies, most notably General Motors, have said they must make billions of dollars of contributions to their plans in the next few years to comply with funding requirements. Company pension plans have weakened in the last three years as stocks and interest rates have plummeted.
Companies received some temporary accounting relief at the beginning of 2002, but will show an immediate weakening if that measure expires at the end of this year with no new rate.
Large companies have lobbied hard for relief. Actuaries say that for every percentage point rise in the rate, pension liabilities appear 10 to 15 percent smaller. The new proposal would raise the rate by about eight-tenths of a percentage point, based on the market environment at the end of last year. Under the old calculation pegged to the 30-year bond, companies would have used a rate of 5.84 percent, versus 6.67 percent under the interim measure. If the new proposal had been in place at the end of the year, the rate would have been 7.42 percent.
For General Motors, to use one very large example, the proposed rate would have reduced liabilities by about $7 billion. G.M.'s level of pension funding would have been 91 percent instead of 75 percent. The funding level of a pension plan determines whether a company must make contributions. Other companies have smaller pension funds than G.M., but their liabilities would also look smaller. 
Congressional aides said they expected the proposal to be included in a broader retirement savings package to be introduced today by Representative Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio, and Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland. The two sponsored legislation two years ago that allowed workers to make larger contributions to their retirement savings plans and eliminated some pension rules. 
Though companies have made forceful arguments for the proposed change in pension accounting, the change would not necessarily help all companies, or help employees, over the long run. For companies with severe pension deficits and weak finances over all, the change could cover up the weakness longer.
That may not matter if market conditions improve and pension funds recover by themselves. But if unfavorable conditions persist, the accounting change would conceal fatal illnesses at some pension funds, which would ultimately fail.
Pension plans are insured by the government, but only up to specific limits, as the pilots of US Airways recently discovered when their benefits were reduced.
In addition, when a pension fund is taken over by the government, the cost is borne by other companies that sponsor pension plans and pay insurance premiums. As the pension agency's deficit grows, so does the likelihood that it will raise its premiums, causing companies that have kept their pension funds robust to subsidize those that have failed to do so.
The pension agency has questioned the approach Congress is contemplating, saying it blurs together issues that should be kept separate: the nuts and bolts of pension accounting and the question of whether companies are setting aside enough. The suspension of the 30-year bond in 2001 caused a reassessment of pension accounting and has prompted some academics to call for a more thorough review of how pension values are measured. 
"We must first find an accurate measure of pension liabilities," Steven A. Kandarian, the agency's executive director, told the Senate Finance Committee this month. "Once pension liabilities are accurately measured, appropriate funding rules can be addressed."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Market for Priciest Apartments Declines

BYLINE:  By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
The Manhattan real estate market, in a reversal of former patterns, is finding strength in more modest apartments and weakness at its most expensive end, according to a market survey of condominium and co-op apartments.
 The survey, the Insignia Douglas Elliman Manhattan Market Report, reported that overall apartment prices were stable or fell only slightly last year, despite a recession, fears of terrorism and a volatile stock market. The average price remained more than double that of a decade ago. 
 The number of sales recorded by the survey last year were up sharply from 2001 and the second highest on record. That was partly because of the aftershocks of the World Trade Center attack, which stalled sales in the last quarter of 2001 and led to a surge in sales in the first half of last year. A period of softening sales and prices followed. 
But the most significant growth, according to the survey, occurred in the market for studios and one-bed-rooms. Sales of one-bedroom apartments increased 32 percent, to 3,305 from 2,497, the second-highest yearly sales total on record. Sales of studio apartments increased 11 percent, to 1,275 from 1,149. 
In contrast, the sales of apartments with at least four bedrooms fell 13 percent last year, to 118 from 135, and were 35 percent below the 181 sales recorded in 2000.
Jonathan Miller, president of the Miller Samuel appraisal company, who prepared the report for Douglas Elliman, said that within the overall averages, there were some significant changes.
He said the lowest mortgage rates in 40 years had stimulated sales and led to higher prices in more modest studio, one-bedroom and smaller two-bedroom apartments, while having a limited effect on larger and more expensive homes.
"We are seeing a bottom-up real estate recovery, with smaller apartments being the first to respond to lower mortgage rates," he said. Buyers of lower-priced apartments are more likely to finance most of the purchase price, he said, and are more sensitive to interest rates. 
"The market is very hot because of interest rates," said Joanne Kennedy, a principal of Coldwell Banker Hunt Kennedy, a Manhattan real estate agency. She said one of her brokers recently worked with a young couple renting a $2,950 one-bedroom apartment. They discovered that they could buy a $445,000 one-bedroom apartment they loved in the West 60's, put 30 percent down and cut monthly housing costs to $2,420, and get a tax deduction on top of that. "The first-time buyer has a great opportunity," she said.
In 2002, the median price for one-bedroom co-ops rose by 7 percent to $343,000, while prices of studios rose by 2 percent to $299,000. Co-ops make up about three-quarters of all sales of studios and nearly two-thirds of all sales of one-bedrooms. The median price for a condominium studio was $280,000 and for a one-bedroom was $429,000, both down slightly from 2001.
Condominiums tend to cost more than co-ops because the maintenance costs are less, the rules are not as strict as those for co-ops and there are fewer purchase restrictions.
The weakness in the market for the most expensive apartments can be seen most starkly on the Upper East Side. The Douglas Elliman survey recorded only 36 sales of co-ops with four or more bedrooms last year, compared with an average of 89 a year during the previous decade. Prices for those apartments fell by $295 per square foot last year, or 21 percent, to an average of $1,092 per square foot, or about $3.3 million for a 3,000-square-foot apartment. 
With that softness, the neighborhood lost another distinction. The report showed that prices for Upper West Side cooperatives of all sizes approached the level of those on the Upper East Side in 2002, $617 per square foot, compared with $619 per square foot. Two years earlier, prices on the Upper East Side were 8 percent, or $42 a square foot, higher than those across town.
In TriBeCa and SoHo, where apartments tend to be the largest and prices the highest, average condominium prices rose last year. Half the condominiums sold cost more than $1.5 million, an increase of 11 percent from 2001 prices and 20 percent from 2000. But even so, prices for the largest apartments, with three or more bedrooms, dropped significantly in 2002. The price for a typical three-bedroom fell 17 percent, to $1.87 million.
The new survey confirms the sense of many brokers that the market has gone from being a sellers' market to a balanced one, with neither buyers nor sellers having a strong advantage. 
They see the market at a turning point, but no one is sure which way it will turn. Rising mortgage interest rates could drive prices down, Mr. Miller said, but a postwar economic upturn could lead some hesitant buyers to make a commitment. 
"There are a lot of people and a lot of money on the sidelines," he said.

HEADLINE: In Jersey City, a New Assessment of a Diner's Value: Priceless 

BYLINE:  By MARIA NEWMAN

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, April 10 

 BODY:
To make way for downtown traffic, city leaders decided last year to seek the demolition of the Flamingo diner, one of the last mom-and-pop businesses in its booming financial district. But the plans opened up a new lane of traffic -- a parade of protesters who beat a path to City Hall.
 Today, after months of hearing a growing clamor from the Flamingo's supporters, Mayor Glenn D. Cunningham announced that he would spare the wrecking ball and allow the 24-hour diner to stay where it has spent the last 35 years, rather than razing it for a street widening. 
 The mayor made his announcement at the Flamingo, in the midst of the lunchtime crowd, with some of the customers and longtime employees crying tears of relief. The owner, Andy Diakos, a Greek immigrantwho was dressed in his everyday cook's uniform -- a white shirt and pants -- hugged Mr. Cunningham.
"I've listened to the people," the mayor said. "God bless the Flamingo, and may she fly forever."
Mr. Cunningham said he was swayed by the 10,000 signatures gathered on a petition to save the diner, the crowds of hundreds who showed up at several City Council meetings to protest the closing, and the calls he received from many patrons, especially elderly customers who said the Flamingo was one of the few 24-hour places where they could still get an affordable meal.
Instead of tearing down the building, at the corner of Montgomery and Greene Streets, the city will now make Greene Street one-way during rush hour, the mayor said.
The city had offered Mr. Diakos more than $1 million for the diner and the four-story, red-brick Victorian-style building in which is situated. 
Using the city's power of eminent domain, officials said they needed to tear down the building to accommodate the increased traffic created by a new office building under construction by the securities firm Goldman Sachs, which is expected to employ 6,000 people.
But Mr. Diakos said he was not interested in the money, but only wanted to keep running the diner, where he works six or seven days a week alongside several relatives.
City officials were not counting on the determination of his three daughters, who were raised working in the restaurant alongside their parents and aunts and uncles. The young women hired a real estate lawyer, and mobilized the Flamingo's loyal customers to call on the council during meetings.
"All my father ever wanted to do was to continue running the Flamingo," one of the daughters, Kalliope Diakos, 30, said today as she stood next to the mayor. "I am happy that the city has not turned its back on my father and my family."
Ms. Diakos, who works in sales and marketing for HBO, graduated from the London School of Economics, she said. Her sisters, Joanna, 28, and Maria, 27, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. 
"It's because of his hard work that we could do that," Kalliope said.
Mr. Cunningham, who is running for the State Senate in the June 3 primary, and has said he will seek re-election as mayor, said he had not spoken to Goldman Sachs about his decision. 
"I'm pretty sure Goldman Sachs would have preferred the building to go down," Mayor Cunningham said. "But I've checked their voting address, and they don't vote in Jersey City."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Halliburton Unit's Contract Is Worth Up to $7 Billion
The Pentagon contract given without competition to a Halliburton subsidiary to fight oil well fires in Iraq is worth as much as $7 billion over two years, according to a letter from the Army Corps of Engineers.
 The contract also allows Kellogg Brown & Root, the Halliburton division, to earn as much as a 7 percent profit. That could amount to $490 million. Page B12. 

Tape Played in HealthSouth Case
Last month, while Richard M. Scrushy was chief executive of HealthSouth, he urged the chief financial officer to "fix" the company's financial records, according to a secretly recorded conversation. The suggestion was made the day before the Securities and Exchange Commission accused him of directing an accounting fraud. C2.

Nokia Plans to Eliminate 1,800 Jobs
Nokia plans to cut 1,800 jobs at its unit that makes equipment for mobile networks. The maker of cellphones warned last month that its networks unit would have its first operating loss since the company started accounting for the business separately, in 1996. Nokia is scheduled to report its first-quarter figures next week. World Business, Section W.

Continued Weakness Is Forecast
Chief executives of large companies expect the economy to remain weak in the next six months, but do not foresee a recession, a survey by the Business Roundtable found. C7.

The Commerce Department reported the trade deficit narrowed in February, to $40.3 billion, as aircraft exports surged and companies spent less on imported equipment. C7.

Wal-Mart Stores, J. C. Penney and other retailers reported sales were weak in March as shoppers curbed spending. C7.

USA to Acquire Rest of Hotels.com
USA Interactive said that it had agreed to acquire the 32 percent of Hotels.com it did not already own for about $1.1 billion in stock. C5.

Concorde's Days Are Numbered
British Airways and Air France announced that they would retire their fleets of Concordes this year. The airlines cited declining passenger demand and steadily increasing costs of maintaining the fleet, which began service 27 years ago. World Business, Section W.

Yahoo Earnings Bolster Markets
Better-than-expected results by the Internet bellwether Yahoo buoyed technology stocks. The Nasdaq composite index rose 8.87 points, to close at 1,365.61. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 5.59 points, to 871.58, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 23.39 points, to 8,221.33. C7.

Illinois Setback for Philip Morris
The Illinois Senate adjourned until Tuesday without reconsidering a bill to reduce a $12 billion bond Philip Morris USA was told to post if it wanted to appeal a state court ruling. C2.

Tenet Reports a $55 Million Loss
Tenet Healthcare lost $55 million in its fiscal third quarter as payments from Medicare dropped sharply and it wrote down the value of certain hospitals. C2.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Day to Day, but Making a Living; 
Immigrant Laborers' Wages Top Minimum, Study Finds

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
You've seen them or men like them: Gonzalo Javier and eight others standing on the sidewalk in front of a paint store in Woodside, Queens, waiting for a contractor to drive up and offer them a day's work. 
 But how many paint stores and how many Gonzalo Javiers are there around New York City? 
 In the first attempt to survey the informal system that provides workers for painting, landscaping, construction and housekeeping jobs, a study has found that 6,000 to 8,000 day laborers regularly congregate at 57 places in the metropolitan area. The study, which surveyed 290 day laborers last summer, also found that they earn, on average, $9.37 an hour in the spring and summer and $7.61 an hour during the slower winter months. 
"These folks are in demand," said Prof. Edwin Melendez, one of the study's two authors and director of the Community Development Research Center at New School University. "There are job opportunities out there, and American natives are not fulfilling the demand for a lot of this employment." 
Gonzalo Javier is, in fact, a typical day laborer. He is an illegal immigrant from Colombia. In the survey, three-quarters of the laborers acknowledged that they were illegal immigrants, and more than 90 percent came from Latin America (roughly one-third from Mexico, one-third from Central America and one-third from South America).
Mr. Javier is working to send money to his wife and two children, now 5 and 7. "I am able to send them money every week, so I have a lot to be thankful for," he said recently, his eyes growing moist at the thought of not seeing his family in four years. "Sometimes I ask myself whether the sacrifice is worth it, but the economic situation is so bad back in Colombia that I have to stay."
The survey found that day laborers say they send, on average, $3,600 back to their families each year.
Woodside, where Mr. Javier waits for work, is one of the larger day laborer sites, the survey discovered. It stretches for a dozen blocks along Roosevelt Avenue, where as many as 300 immigrants gather for jobs that pay $8 to $12 an hour.
Other sites are smaller, like the corner of Hooper and Lee Streets in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where about 20 women -- Hispanics, Haitians and Eastern Europeans -- go each morning hoping to land housekeeping jobs that pay $6 to $7 an hour. 
Professor Melendez, who teaches urban policy, detailed some of the difficulties day laborers face. "They take risks when they go to work with people they haven't met before," he said. "Sometimes they're abused in terms of not getting paid or getting pushed around by contractors."
But in some of its most surprising findings, the survey found that many day laborers earned considerably more than the minimum wage of $5.15 an hour, and that many said they liked the life they had chosen. 
Jose Carmona, a Peruvian who has been a day laborer for nine years, echoed the summer survey's findings last week as he waited on Roosevelt Avenue. "In my opinion," he said, "you can make more money here than if you work in a factory or a supermarket. If I work in those places, I wouldn't earn enough to send money to Peru." 
Some days Mr. Carmona earns $80 as a painter's helper, other days $120 as a master painter. If a contractor or homeowner picks him to work only three days in a week, he will probably earn more than $300 with no taxes withheld, far more than the $206, before taxes, that many immigrants earn in full-time minimum-wage jobs.
The survey found that monthly mean earnings for day laborers were $855 last May, with some workers saying they earn more than $1,500 in a good month. Fourteen percent of the laborers said they earned $7 or less an hour, 63 percent said they earned $7 to $10 an hour, and 23 percent made more than $10 an hour.
Mr. Carmona lives with his wife and three children just a few blocks from his day laborer site, and he sends $150 a month to his mother in Peru. "I don't feel exploited," he said. "It's a happy life. I get to see my kids a lot."
Manuel A., 57, an illegal immigrant from Mexico who declined to give his last name, said the life of a day laborer was not always so sweet. "A lot of the times the people don't pay you," he said, standing with 40 other immigrants on a recent frigid morning at the corner of Gramatan and Sidney Avenues in Mount Vernon, in Westchester County. "At the end of the day, they'll say, 'We don't have any money,' or 'We'll come back and pay you another day.' And when they come back another day to pick up workers, they hide from you."
Fifty percent of the day laborers surveyed said they had not been paid one or more times, and 60 percent said that at times they had been paid less than the agreed-upon wages. 
To identify the places where day laborers wait for work, the study's authors asked for information from community groups, immigrant advocacy groups, churches and experts on immigration. In addition, when they found day laborers, they asked what other sites they used. The authors acknowledge that they may not have discovered every site in the metropolitan area and that new sites are always popping up.
To conduct the survey, 11 bilingual graduate students from the New School randomly chose 290 day laborers from 29 of the 57 sites for one-hour interviews, and the day laborers were paid $20 each for their time. A Ford Foundation grant helped finance the study.
While the survey found many places around the city and suburbs where day laborers congregate, even in affluent suburbs like Roslyn Heights on Long Island and Mamaroneck, in Westchester, this does not mean that the laborers are always welcomed. In 2000, two Mexican immigrants in Farmingville, on Long Island, were promised work but were instead taken to a basement and beaten. Other towns have been more welcoming. Glen Cove and Freeport, both in Nassau County, and Mount Kisco in Westchester provide indoor centers where the laborers can wait for contractors while sheltered from the elements. 
"Communities generally feel ambivalence," said Nadia Marin-Molina, executive director of the Workplace Project, an immigrant advocacy group in Hempstead, on Long Island. "There are people who accept day laborers as part of the work force, and there are people who feel hostile about seeing immigrants in their communities." 
The vast majority of day laborers are men. Only 5 percent of those surveyed were women, but that figure was still higher than the number surveyed by a similar survey, taken in 1999 in Los Angeles, which included no female day laborers. The Los Angeles study was conducted by Abel Valenzuela Jr., director of the Center for the Study of Urban Poverty at U.C.L.A., who was co-author of the New York study. 
Most day laborers have not made it a career -- 45 percent of those surveyed in New York said they had been day laborers for less than a year, and only 16 percent said they had been at it four years or longer. 
They may not have many job options. One-third of the day laborers said they did not seek permanent jobs because they lacked legal papers, and one-third said that the reason was inadequate English. 
But they do fill a need. One contractor in New Rochelle, N.Y., who uses day laborers, and who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said: "These guys are great. They work hard. A lot of white boys don't want to work hard. They drink, they smoke pot, they give you a hard time."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Day laborers came to Roosevelt Avenue in Queens this week, hoping to be picked to work by this contractor. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)(pg. D5) Map of New York highlighting areas the immigrant laborers are picked up for work. (pg. D1)

HEADLINE: Planning the 9/11 Memorial 

 BODY:
Yesterday, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation introduced a 13-member jury to judge an international competition for the design of a memorial to the victims of 9/11. The memorial that will eventually be built at ground zero is the part of the downtown renovation closest to the heart of most New Yorkers. By any measure, the jury is a balanced, distinguished collection of individuals, including Maya Lin and Vartan Gregorian, as well as architects, art historians and a representative of the families of 9/11 victims. 
 The timetable for the memorial competition is ambitious. The development corporation hopes to announce a winning design in the fall of this year. But there is another value to consider besides speed, and that is public participation. The review process that led to the selection of Daniel Libeskind's plan for the World Trade Center site allowed many opportunities for the public to express opinions at nearly every stage along the way. In fact, one of the most striking things about that process was the way it evolved from a nearly inchoate set of ideas about how to proceed into a dialogue among architects, officials and the public that greatly enlarged the public's franchise in urban planning. 
 The corporation and its memorial design jury will need to keep that example in mind over the next few months. Insiders in the process say that one of the corporation's major concerns is trying to protect the integrity of its jury, to keep it from being unduly influenced by public opinion. But if the past year of architectural deliberations proved anything, it proved that the public is fully capable of expressing opinions on these matters in a way that enriches the discussion without compromising the end result. The jury must do its work unhampered. But without full and formal participation by the public, that work will never seem complete.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook; 
Braving War and SARS to Meet in Vegas

BYLINE:  By ANDRES MARTINEZ

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS 

 BODY:
I coughed on the flight out, though I was trying as hard as I could to make it one of those nonchalant "just a cold -- don't even know where Hong Kong is" coughs. No need to quarantine the plane, really. The gentleman in the aisle seat looked me over, not quite convinced. 
 Once in SARS-wary Las Vegas, my cabdriver, Jethro Parker, told me the whole convention might need to be quarantined if so many as one Asian visitor fell sick. 
 Remarkably, almost 90,000 of us made it out here for the annual National Association of Broadcasters convention. That's down from 115,000 attendees a few years back, but still a respectable number when you consider that the once carefree act of travel now entails defying a recession, the threat of terrorism, an ongoing war and, of course, the mysterious respiratory disease called SARS. One prominent network television executive was spotted wearing a mask on the flight out.
Las Vegas, much like Orlando, Fla., the other iconic American destination built on the promise that planeloads of tourists and conventioneers would be flown in, is especially vulnerable to today's travel-related anxieties. The loss of one locally based carrier, National, led a Wall Street analyst who covers casino stocks to question whether enough planes were landing here each day to fill the city's more than 125,000 hotel rooms. And the suspension of some flights by Japan Airlines and Singapore Airlines has led to concerns that casinos' best customers, Asian high rollers, may stay away.
Still, for all the concern, this week's broadcasting convention has been a heartening tribute to the resilience of commerce. European exhibitors seemed especially nonchalant about traveling in this age of serial anxieties. "We are a little more laid back about these things, I suppose, having become accustomed to the threat of the I.R.A.," said Ben Moore, a London-based salesman at BT Broadcast Services' elaborate booth, which included a makeshift pub. "You have to evaluate these risks statistically." Rosalia D'Aprano, who was promoting a digital and satellite telecommunications exhibition that is to take place in Venice in October, said the risks of being hit by terrorism while traveling had to be put in perspective: "You are more likely to be run over by a car at home, especially back in Italy the way people drive." ANDRES MARTINEZ

HEADLINE: NYC; 
New Gigs For the Wizard Of Baghdad

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN

 BODY:
IF New York political leaders are as shrewd as they want us to believe they are, they will lose no time in tracking down Muhammad Said al-Sahhaf and signing him to a personal services contract. Gov. George E. Pataki, in particular, could use him as a tonic for approval ratings that have begun to look a bit wan.
 In case his name does not leap off the page, Mr. Sahhaf is the Iraqi information minister -- or he was until he disappeared midweek along with other leading functionaries of the Saddam Hussein regime. 
True to the spirit of the ruling Baath Party, Mr. Sahhaf toed a Marxist line in this war. Only his muse was Chico Marx, who said in "Duck Soup" to a woman he was conning, "Who you gonna believe -- me or your own eyes?"
Those American tanks rolling into the Iraqi capital? Figments of the imagination, the minister insisted. American soldiers? "The infidels are committing suicide by the hundreds on the gates of Baghdad." On and on he went, spinning enough material to keep "Saturday Night Live" going for five years.
O.K., the man has a slight credibility problem. Nobody's perfect.
But you have to give him major points for bravado and fierce loyalty. They are virtues that if channeled properly, could serve some New Yorkers well in these difficult days.
There is ample American precedent for taking an enemy, making him a friend and putting him to work. This is hardly rocket science. Come to think of it, what better example than that embodiment of rocket science, Wernher von Braun?
Dr. von Braun, who died in 1977, was the brains behind the United States space program in the 1950's and 60's. But before that, in Germany, he threw in with the Nazis and designed the V-2 rockets that Hitler fired at London during World War II.
Well, bygones have a way of becoming bygones.
Is Mr. Sahhaf any less worthy? New York politicians might think about it.
Governor Pataki, for example, has not shaken off a consensus that he tried to pull a fast one this month with federal antiterrorism money intended for New York City. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had done the heavy lifting in Washington. At the last minute, the governor loped in, demanding a changed formula that would have given him, not the mayor, the upper hand in spending the cash.
Even some of his fellow Republicans called it an unseemly money grab. Mr. Pataki had no choice but to retreat.
Imagine what Mr. Sahhaf could have done for him. The Iraqi would have looked reporters in the eye and scoffed: What money grab? This is a pioneering form of revenue sharing. Oh, and that 50-cent increase in the mass transit fare approved by the Pataki-controlled Metropolitan Transportation Authority? That's a service enhancement.
Who knows? He might have gotten three or four people to buy it. You can't blame a fellow for trying, especially if he speaks with conviction.
MR. BLOOMBERG, too, could use a man of such special talent. One often-heard knock on the mayor is that he isn't tough enough in his dealings with President Bush and Mr. Pataki, fellow Republicans both. Mr. Sahhaf would have no qualms about slapping them around.
Do you think that a man who referred to American and British leaders as "louts," "blood-sucking bastards," "animals" and "stooges" is about to let a governor, or a president, scare him? No way. A mild-mannered mayor needs an attack dog like that.
If New York government doesn't work out for Mr. Sahhaf, there are always business opportunities.
He could go to work flacking for the Yankees pitcher David Wells, who is himself given to playing fast and loose with the facts. Mr. Wells would do well to have a kindred spirit handling his publicity.
The Rangers could hire Mr. Sahhaf to assure hockey fans that their failure to make the playoffs for six straight years is the core of a clever rebuilding strategy. (That is, unless those other habitual losers, the basketball-playing Knicks, land him first.)
L. Dennis Kozlowski, the Tyco tycoon and a symbol of corporate greed, could send forth Mr. Sahhaf to tell the world that his outlandish spending was a crafty plan to stimulate the economy. Surely "Urban Cowboy," the Broadway musical that has received some of the most dreadful reviews in years, could also benefit from the Iraqi's deft touch. 
And if Mr. Sahhaf can't make it in New York -- not everyone does -- there is always that midnight train to Georgia. There just might be a spot for him at the Augusta National Golf Club.

Turkey Keeps Close Eye on Iraqi Kurd Situation
Turkish government officials exercise extreme vigilance against any possible flicker of Kurdish separatism, a watchfulness that continues to shape the country's response to the war in Iraq in potentially crucial ways. A3

Israel and Palestinians Clash
In three stealth attacks, Israeli soldiers and Palestinian militants caught each other off guard in strikes that left two soldiers and four militants dead in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. A7

Russian Economy on a Roll
Russia's domestic output grew by 4.3 percent in 2002, but some private experts say the true number is above 5 percent. That is the third year of robust growth, and it makes Russia the second-fastest-growing nation among emerging economies, behind only China. Some, however, question how long that can continue. A6

School Fire Kills 28 Boys
Twenty-eight boys perished after a fire consumed a boarding school for the deaf in the city of Makhachkala in the Russian republic of Dagestan. At least 106 other boys were injured, 22 critically. A6

Cuba Pressures Dissidents
The Cuban government's recent crackdown has left 80 dissidents with lengthy prison terms. It has also left American and European diplomats wondering why President Fidel Castro would jeopardize delicate but vital commercial relationships to put down a peaceful movement of librarians, journalists and democratic activists. A8

NATIONAL A14-22

F.B.I. Investigates Agent In Chinese Spying Case
A former F.B.I. agent arrested this week in Los Angeles in an espionage case had not been given a polygraph test in his nearly 30 years with the bureau, and the F.B.I.'s lax oversight of his relationship with an informer now accused of being a Chinese double-agent appears to have violated many internal policies. A14

Suit Over Looks and Bias
In a lawsuit filed by a manager who was ordered to hire "hot" saleswomen, a court made a far-reaching decision that could make it harder for employers to fire workers because of how they look. A14

House Approves Alaska Drilling
House members endorsed oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge as they considered a wide-ranging energy measure that seeks to spur domestic energy production and provides tax incentives to oil and power companies. A22

Deal on Tax Plan Falls Through
A deal struck by House and Senate negotiators on Wednesday to postpone a decision on how large a tax cut to allow unraveled after a ruling by the Senate parliamentarian that would have limited the reduction this year to less than half of what President Bush requested. A22

Judge's Words Delay Process
Republican Senators delayed work on the nomination of a judge to the federal bench after Democrats attacked his writings on sexual equality, religion and abortion. A22

Leadership Change at Academy
After months of criticism over its handling of a sex scandal, the United States Air Force Academy installed two new leaders at a ceremony before thousands of cadets. A19

EDUCATION

New Rules at Harvard
Reversing an admissions policy it announced last year, Harvard College announced that, as of next fall, it would no longer allow applicants who filed for early admission to apply early at other colleges. A21

NEW YORK/REGION D1-8

Drug Operation Was Run Like a Company, Police Say
Police shut down a drug operation that was run like a small corporation out of a block of apartment buildings on W. 146th street, arresting 38 people, confiscating nearly $100,000 in cash, and stationing uniformed officers where the dealers once stood, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said. D1

Historic Firehouses to Close
Five firehouses thatare among some of the most distinguished buildings in northern Brooklyn are scheduled to be closed, along with three others elsewhere in the city. Over the last century, Brooklyn's population has spread southward, and officials say the high number of firehouses in the northern part of Brooklyn no longer makes sense. D1

Delays in Anthrax Cleanup
The Postal Service announced that the final step in cleaning out the anthrax from a mail-sorting plant in Hamilton, N.J., that was contaminated 18 months ago will not begin until this fall. And they said that final cleanup and installation of new equipment will probably not be finished until next April. D1

For the first time in the current budget crisis, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg raised the specter of fewer police officers, firefighters and teachers on the payroll if the city does not get financial help from the state. D3

HEADLINE: GOLF; 
Sodden Lot Will Be Site of Protests Tomorrow

BYLINE:  By BILL PENNINGTON

DATELINE: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 

 BODY:
With the proper historical marker, it could pass for just another small Civil War battleground. Then again, cleared of trees, grassy and unoccupied, the five-acre lot half a mile from the main entrance to Augusta National Golf Club would also make a good picnic ground.
 Saturday, it will probably be something in between. An estimated 900 demonstrators and 125 sheriff's deputies and state troopers will be corralled on this nondescript, fenced-in parcel for the only official protests scheduled during the Masters. They will be joined, unofficially, by thousands of red fire ants that plague the tract: just kick up some dirt; they are itching to march, too. 
 After a new city ordinance regulating protest demonstrations, two court challenges and some limited backroom negotiating, this is where Augusta will play host to the eight groups that filed formal requests for one-day protests, including Martha Burk and the National Council of Women's Organizations, Jesse Jackson's Rainbow Coalition and a splinter group of the Ku Klux Klan. Each plans a demonstration, in some manner, that deals with the men-only membership of Augusta National Golf Club.
And who owns this drab lot, sitting down in a hollow, across the road and not quite within site of the famed golf course? Augusta National bought it last year. That's right, the club is host for its own protesters.
If all goes as planned, not since Augusta somehow evaded General William Tecumseh Sherman's combustible advance from Atlanta to Savannah will the city have so artfully bypassed a firestorm.
"We'll let 'em do it, get it over with and then go home," Lt. Johnny Whittle of the Richmond County Sheriff's Department said as he sat in his cruiser on the edge of the protest site today. "Hopefully, everybody will be happy and have fun. Well, I guess everybody won't be happy. But we'll treat them right, anyhow."
The local sheriff's deputies will serve a central role Saturday, using their cruisers as pickets, of sorts, among the picketers. They will be lined up bumper to bumper to create physical barriers, partitioning the various groups and establishing penned-in areas. Demonstrators will not be allowed to move from group to group.
Richmond County will have 57 deputies and their cruisers in the lot. Adjacent Columbia County said it would send 40 deputies. The Georgia State Police will send 20 troopers.
"We have a Plan A and a Plan B and a Plan C," said Lieutenant Whittle, who also said there would be a bus and a van to transport anyone who violated the protest guidelines to the Richmond County Jail. "But we don't want to have to do that."
The police do not expect everyone who filed for a permit to appear Saturday, but among those they do expect are representatives of the Brotherhood Organization of New Destiny, a group of religious conservatives who have frequently been critical of Jackson's Rainbow Coalition. And the police have heard from a group called Golfers for a Real Cause, as well as a demonstrator who wants to demonstrate in support of the war in Iraq and another group called People Against Ridiculous Protests.
Todd Manzi, an unemployed advertising executive from Florida, has been in Augusta all week trying to draw attention to the two Web sites he created in the hope of discrediting Burk's credentials to speak on behalf of American women in the Augusta National debate. Manzi will protest Saturday, and he has also rented a parking lot next to the site to sell some anti-Burk paraphernalia.
Today, Manzi was alone in the five-acre lot wearing a yellow rain slicker while holding an umbrella and standing next to a placard critical of Burk's cause. Most people in passing cars, who have to peer down into the lot, appeared more confused than curious. But occasionally, some drivers would beep their horns and Manzi would wave his umbrella in salute.
The lot, unmowed and turned muddy by several days of rain, is not much of a setting for the climactic event after 10 months of national debate over Augusta National's membership policies.
The lot is several feet below the grade of Washington Road, the busy highway that passes by the club and its famed Magnolia Lane, slightly less than half a mile away. Burk has called it a pit, but that is an exaggeration. There is, however, no sidewalk leading to the lot.
Asked how it would be decided which groups would congregate where on Saturday, or if they would have their choice of spots within the five acres, Lieutenant Whittle smiled and said, "First come first served."

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Hospital's Debt Rating Reduced 

BYLINE:  By Alison Leigh Cowan (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
A bond-rating firm lowered its assessment of Mount Sinai-N.Y.U. Health System's bonds yesterday, putting them below investment grade for the first time since Mount Sinai Hospital and NYU Hospitals Center merged in 1998. The firm, Fitch Ratings, said that the "decline in financial performance of the system and the significant challenges faced by the system, primarily Mount Sinai Hospital" prompted the lowering of its rating to BB+ from BBB-. 
The outlook on the bonds was also revised from negative (when it was classified investment grade) to stable. Last week, Mount Sinai reported losing $72 million last year and said it may lose at least that much this year. The hospital's spokesman was not available for comment last night.

HEADLINE: Airlines Fear the Loneliness Will Persist 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD

 BODY:
The nation's airlines, which blamed the war in Iraq for a plunge in business that forced the layoffs of more than 10,000 employees and the elimination of dozens of flights, are not expecting the postwar era to be much brighter.
 The weak economy, continued fears over terrorism and the complicating factor of the mysterious illness SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, are likely to offset any increase in travel that could be expected once it is clear that the conflict in Iraq has subsided, industry officials and analysts said yesterday. 
 "We are not planning or counting on any bounce back," said Douglas A. Hacker, executive vice president of United Airlines, a unit of the UAL Corporation and the No. 2 carrier behind American Airlines.
E. Han Kim, professor of finance at the University of Michigan Business School, explained the predicament for airlines. "Everything being equal, I would say, yes, the airlines would come back, but everything is not equal," he said. "SARS is hurting some airlines just as much as the war and, unfortunately, you can't bomb SARS." 
Indeed, Mr. Hacker said in an interview yesterday that SARS, which had its first outbreaks in Asia and is highly contagious, was having the same effect on United's Pacific routes as the war was having on its traffic across the Atlantic. "What it looks like is kind of a continuation of war" on Pacific travel, Mr. Hacker said. The complexities involving overseas travel have made it difficult for any airline to plan for the next few months, United included, he added.
"In this kind of environment, you can't have a forecast," Mr. Hacker said. "Our crystal ball remains pretty cloudy. We're kind of getting used to that. Our main theme is, 'Let's work against a pretty ugly scenario.' "
Even under more normal conditions, this time of year has typically been one of the most sluggish travel periods. While traffic usually increases slightly during the weeks around Easter and Passover, it is generally slow until the middle of May, when colleges end classes for the year and family vacations begin.
This year, officials at airlines, rental car companies and other travel businesses say advance reservations for later in the spring and summer are relatively weak. Travelers have delayed booking their trips even longer than usual. So, even with the war appearing to be close to conclusion, airlines can expect that travel will be soft for the next six weeks, and possibly longer, said Sandy Rederer, an aviation consultant in Arlington, Va.
"My guess is that we remain semi-mired for some time," Mr. Rederer said. "There will be a lag before people get over the deferral of travel that was delayed before the war." 
John Heimlich, an economist with the Air Transport Association, a trade group, agreed that the short-term outlook was gloomy. Fare discounts can be expected to draw some passengers back, he said, but at a cost. "I think what we'll see in the next several weeks is that volumes will start to improve at much lower fares per mile."
In reality, the last thing the industry would want, politically, would be a strong rebound in travel. Airlines have been lobbying for a $3 billion relief package that would include assistance for more than 10,000 workers who have been furloughed since the start of the war, on top of 100,000 who have lost their jobs since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. The House and Senate have passed slightly different measures that have been folded into legislation financing the war; that legislation is now being considered by a conference committee of the two bodies.
The White House, however, has called the package too generous, and the potential bailout has prompted debate over whether the war was to blame for the airlines' problems or whether they stem from business decisions.
"That's the business they're in, and war is part of the risk," said Kevin Mitchell, president of the Business Travel Coalition, which represents corporate travel departments and business travelers.
Mr. Mitchell argued in testimony before Congress that the airlines did not warrant help unless they took steps to limit executives' salaries and imposed other streamlining measures. Lately, a number of airline executives have taken salary reductions, after cutting the pay of employees in the wake of the war.
On Wednesday, the air transport association released figures showing that the war had caused the steepest drops in travel this year, though it said that SARS was having an effect as well.
For the week ended Sunday, the group cited a year-over-year 17.4 percent decline in overall travel, including domestic and international routes. Domestic travel fell 14 percent during the week, while the Asia-Pacific region was off more than 25 percent. During the week of March 23, there was a 10 percent decline for overall travel.
Mr. Heimlich said the declines were even more significant given that traffic had risen in the first couple of months of 2003, although from mediocre levels in 2002.
Robert Mann Jr., an aviation consultant based in Port Washington, N.Y., said SARS was having a substantial effect. "We've seen disruptions of service that even exceed the reduction in schedules due to the economy and the conflict in the Middle East," he said.
Mr. Mann said he was particularly concerned about the effect of the respiratory illness on United, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in December, well before the war began, and provides service to Asia. The other major United States carrier to do so is Northwest Airlines.
He and other analysts have expressed concern that the drop in travel could be another obstacle in United's bankruptcy revamping. "For United, it's, 'Gosh what else? Will it be the locusts next?' " Mr. Mann said.
That is overstating United's predicament, Mr. Hacker said. "We are more optimistic about the more rapid return of domestic bookings and revenue than we are internationally," he said.

HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES 

BYLINE:  By Dave Kehr

 BODY:
Helping to Keep New York Busy
 Wall Street is quiet on the weekends but not nearly as quiet as film production has been in New York since 9/11. One of the few indie productions not to take the Toronto route lately is "Rick," a nonmusical adaptation of Verdi's 1851 opera "Rigoletto" transposed to the canyons of Lower Manhattan. 
 "Rick" is being made by ContentFilm, a New York-based production and distribution company that has already filmed Sigourney Weaver's "Guys" and the Sundance hit "Party Monster" in the city. The picture is being shot with Sony's 24F video system to keep costs down, and to allow the production to remain in New York rather than heading off to a more forgiving economic climate. 
A recent Saturday visit to the set found Bill Pullman, who plays the imperious, abrasive businessman who is the film's title character, folded into a tiny corner office in an Exchange Place insurance company. There was barely enough room in the cozy, wood-paneled cubbyhole to accommodate Rick's overflowing desk, not to mention the imposing actor, the camera crew and a dense flock of overhead lights put into place by the cinematographer, Lisa Rinzler ("Pollock"). 
Just to make it interesting, the set was shaken every few minutes by subway trains, rumbling through what sounded like the office next door. "Rick" will be the first feature directed by Curtiss Clayton, a film editor whose many credits in the independent film community include "Drugstore Cowboy" (1989), "To Die For" (1995) and "Buffalo '66" (1998). 
The sequence being shot involved a young job seeker (played by the comedian Sandra Oh) forced to submit to an interview with the casually sadistic, hermetically self-involved Rick. When he didn't cut her off, the subway did. But Ms. Oh gallantly pushed on, and with each take Mr. Pullman sank deeper into his character, finding more implicit menace and sheer strangeness built into each line. 
" 'Rick' is a story about a man who reaps what he sows,"' said Ms. Oh, "and my character, Michelle, is unwittingly the Oracle at Delphi. Rick and his co-workers treat her quite cruelly, and Michelle just gets mad."
Ms. Oh added, enigmatically: "She colors his life in a certain way, and then various events, some really tragic, happen to the character of Rick. Things come back to him." 
The screenplay for "Rick" is by Daniel Handler (a novelist better known under the pseudonym he adapts for his children's books, Lemony Snicket). It is a contemporary version of Verdi's opera about the deformed jester whose mockery of his master's victims brings on a curse that leads to tragedy for himself and his daughter.
"It starts off on a farcical tone and gets progressively heavier until the ending is really quite severe," Mr. Clayton said. "So the tone is very tricky. Rick is brought around to see the tragedy he has made for himself, but he doesn't really have any stronger self-awareness at the end than he does at the beginning." 
Mr. Pullman said: " 'Rick' is its own piece, but yet it is this curious reflection on the cave wall of 'Rigoletto.' And 'Rigoletto' was an adaptation of a previous play by Victor Hugo. To me it's always a surprise how modern 'Rigoletto' is because of the ambiguities: Rigoletto is a jester, he's compromised, but he's also charismatic and interesting. The daughter is the victim, but she's also making her own trouble." The role of Rick/Rigoletto's daughter is being played by Anges Bruckner of "Murder by Numbers." 
Of his screenwriter, Mr. Handler, Mr. Pullman said: "I haven't met him yet. He has a dark sensibility, but a way of turning the darkness into a different aspect. Like he says in the Lemony Snicket books, 'This is a sad story, so if you don't like sad stories, don't read this one.' With 'Rick,' it sounds sad, but it's also kind of engaging."

Schwarzenegger Sequel
Can 10,000 Arnold Schwarzenegger fans be wrong? 
Well, maybe. Some of them must have paid good money to see "End of Days." But as of Tuesday, 10,606 of them had signed a petition posted on the Web site thearnoldfans.com, urging Warner Brothers to move ahead with John Milius's "King Conan," the long planned and long deferred sequel to Mr. Schwarzenegger's "Conan the Barbarian," which Mr. Milius ("The Wind and the Lion," "Big Wednesday") wrote and directed in 1982. (Conan fans do not consider Richard Fleischer's 1984 "Conan the Destroyer," which also starred Mr. Schwarzenegger, worthy to be mentioned in the same breath with Mr. Milius's epic work.)
"I've got to have Milius back," said Randy Jennings, who has operated TheArnoldFans.com with Rene de Jong since 1998. " 'Conan' was my favorite movie of Arnold's when I was growing up, even more than 'Terminator 2.' "
The hesitation, both on the part of Warner Brothers, which owns the sequel rights, and Paradox Entertainment, a Swedish company that owns the rights to the barbarian character created by Robert E. Howard, appears to stem from a basic business quandary: would it be more profitable to continue the series with the middle-aged Mr. Schwarzenegger (he is now 55) or find a younger face and bulging physique to replace him? 
Mr. Milius's script is an action- packed but movingly elegiac study of the aging Conan, who is forced against his anarchist nature to become the ruler of a remote corner of an emerging empire. While battle scenes abound, written in Mr. Milius's chiseled, Hemingwayesque style, the tone is finally somber and reflective, as in one of John Ford's late westerns. The script also gives Conan a son, who is taken away from him and raised by an evil emperor, a role that would seem perfect for a younger star who could draw in the kids. 
"It didn't take long at all for the 10,000 signatures to appear," Mr. Jennings said. "We just put it up four months ago. Which is amazing, since it usually takes something political to reach these kinds of numbers."

Ahead of Cannes
Six weeks before its May 14 opening, the Cannes Film Festival has announced two titles that will be shown in the festival's prestigious Official Selection program. The opening night film with be "Fanfan la Tulipe," a remake of a much beloved 18th-century adventure novel filmed by Christian-Jaques in 1952. The remake stars Vincent Perez and Penelope Cruz and is directed by Luc Besson protege Gerard Krawczyk. 
The next day, May 15, will bring the premiere of the Wachowski brothers' "Matrix Reloaded," on the same day it opens commercially in the United States.
