HEADLINE: Selling a Rainbow, and a Pot of Gold 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
IN the Norman Rockwellesque towns of Maplewood and South Orange, N.J. -- neighboring communities where colonial, Tudor and Victorian homes nestle below the gentle slopes of South Mountain Reservation -- racial and ethnic diversity is promoted as a real estate selling point.
 The jitney tour for prospective buyers rumbles through every neighborhood of what local leaders refer to as "two towns, one community" -- beside narrow railed-porch homes selling for $190,000 near the train stations, along winding roads dotted by $350,000 center-hall colonials, past million-dollar mansions farther up the mountain. 
 Local real estate brokers are urged to show buyers every section of the two towns. The South Orange/Maplewood Community Coalition on Race, created with financing from the two towngovernments seven years ago, places advertisements in urban neighborhoods like Park Slope, Brooklyn, trying to attract people who prefer integrated living. It offers low-rate second mortgages -- as down payment assistance or to help with fix-up costs -- to buyers willing to move into those parts of the towns where they will contribute to the mix. 
To bolster property values, one civic committee works to ensure that ordinance codes are equally enforced on every block. The school board -- shared by both towns -- has created a program to make the elementary school with the lowest test scores more attractive to students and teachers from all around the towns.
And, given that the rate of home-price appreciation in the two towns surpassed those in all but one of the contiguous communities over the last 10 years, the strategy seems to have been successful. While the median price in Millburn, the most affluent of all the towns in the area, increased by 101 percent from 1992 to 2002, the median price in both Maplewood and South Orange rose by 99 percent.
The inclusiveness campaign -- along with other factors -- certainly attracted Natalie Monroe Thigpen.
Ms. Thigpen, 38, lives with her 5-year-old daughter, Madeline, near the duck pond in South Orange. The pond is at the foot of Flood's Hill, a long slope where "when it snows there are hundreds of kids sledding," she said. "That's definitely one of the selling points."
There is also the "wonderful" Fourth of July fireworks display at the hill, said Ms. Thigpen, who is African-American, "thousands of people sitting out on blankets with picnic baskets, candles, wine." Then there are the jazz concerts, the art galleries, the theater companies -- "yes, plural," she said.
Ms. Thigpen is the marketing director for Seton Hall University, which is on the east side of South Orange. She moved to town in 1996 from neighboring East Orange, paying in the "mid-$200,000's" for a four-bedroom colonial on tree-lined Highland Road.
"There are other communities where you can get all this," she said. "But then you say to yourself, I would also like to live in a community that's more and more about what this country is coming to look like."
Jessica and Gary Sachs took a more circuitous route -- from Brooklyn to Georgia to Maplewood -- for similar reasons.
"We went from having Schumer as our representative to Gingrich as our representative," Mrs. Sachs said of the family's seven-year sojourn in Alpharetta, Ga., 15 miles north of Atlanta. "It was gorgeous, wooded."
It was in 1994 that Mr. Sachs, 49, a trial lawyer, took a job in Georgia. Mrs. Sachs, 46, a freelance writer, could "work anywhere," she said. Their daughter, Eva, now 11, was 3 at the time.
The Sachses, who are white, had purchased a two-bedroom, prewar co-op in Park Slope in 1989 for $235,000. They sold at a loss. "It was February of '95; the market was rough," Mr. Sachs said. "We ended up at $194,000. It hurt."
The sprawling raised ranch they bought in Georgia -- a three-bedroom with floor-to-ceiling windows looking out on more than an acre, with a pond -- cost them $236,000. Last May, after Mr. Sachs accepted a new job in Manhattan, the Georgia home sold for $269,000.
At first, the family considered a return to Park Slope. "It was out of reach," Mrs. Sachs said. "My husband looked at comparables and it was $200,000 higher than when we left, even in the same building."
The Sachses looked at towns in Connecticut, Westchester and other parts of New Jersey. "I was concerned they would just be white bread," Mrs. Sachs said. "We spent almost eight years in Newt Gingrich's district and I found it isolating."
Then they heard about the emphasis on racial, ethnic and lifestyle diversity in Maplewood and South Orange. And so, 10 months ago, for $299,000, they bought a three-bedroom colonial on the east side of Maplewood. "We live on a street where it's very much 50-50, black and white," Mrs. Sachs said. "We were very welcomed to the neighborhood; people came out of their houses to introduce themselves." 
Mr. Sachs said, "It's Mayberry meets New York City, very much the best of both urban and suburban worlds."

Seeking Cultural Richness
'Cosmopolitan Chic' In the Suburbs
For Barbara Heisler-Williams, executive director of the South Orange/Maplewood Community Coalition on Race, it is "cosmopolitan chic in this old-fashioned neighborhood."
"The conventional wisdom that heterogeneous communities are somehow less desirable is shifting," she said. "People look for a stable, culturally rich community, and here they have the luxury of all that in a community that's also diverse."
The shift is, perhaps understandably, most apparent among people used to living in cities. "When they were singles or young married couples, they lived in diverse urban environments," said Dr. James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "And when they move into the child-rearing stage, they seek out equivalently diverse suburban environments."
In Dr. Hughes's estimation, South Orange-Maplewood -- and particularly the work of the coalition on race -- "is a state-of-the-art model for communities around the country."
The advertisements that the coalition places in local newspapers in city neighborhoods and in The New York Times, say things like: "What do Maplewood/South Orange, N.J., and Park Slope Have in Common? Fresh mozzarella. 21 breads. Gourmet coffee. Live jazz."
They also say, "Only 29 minutes to Midtown."
To be sure, the real estate market in the region that includes South Orange and Maplewood was significantly bolstered by the 1996 inauguration of New Jersey Transit's Midtown Direct train service to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan -- eliminating the need to transfer to a PATH train in Hoboken and shortening the ride by about half an hour.
"Some people will say it's Midtown Direct," said Ms. Heisler-Williams, whose organization was founded the same year the train service was improved. "But we did an analysis of other communities on the Midtown Direct train line, and over the same period our growth in values has surpassed the other communities. So there's something else going on; it's not just Midtown Direct."
Viewed over the last decade, according to statistics gathered by Superior Information Services, a Trenton-based real estate research company, the median price in Maplewood increased by 99 percent, from $160,000 in 1992 to $320,000 in 2002. In South Orange, the median price also rose by 99 percent over the decade, from $171,000 to $340,000. By comparison, the median price in Millburn, the most affluent of the contiguous communities, rose by 101 percent, from $325,000 in 1992 to $654,500 last year. 
By using a different formula covering only 1995 through 2001 -- boom years in the region's real estate market -- the race coalition's statistician, George Robinson, came up with somewhat differing trends.
"We decided to use the assessed value of each home sold as a reference point and then determine how much that home's sales price had varied from its assessed value," Mr. Robinson said. The coalition determined the average of the ratio of sales prices to the assessed values for all the homes that sold in a given year. And then, by comparing the averages from year to year, it was able to estimate the change in home values for the entire community. "We have determined percent changes in value for each of the two towns and a number of other towns in the area," Mr. Robinson said.
In Maplewood, the average ratio of sales price to assessed value increased 72.3 percent between 1997 and 2001 (the last year for which the coalition made calculations), and in South Orange it increased by 84.7 percent. By comparison, in Millburn over the same period, there was a 54.1 percent increase -- 18.2 percentage points lower than Maplewood's increase during the period, and 30.6 percentage points lower than South Orange's increase.

Two-Town Tours
A Jitney Ride As Marketing Tool
 It wasn't the numbers that persuaded Diane Thomson and James Loadholt to make the move to Maplewood two years ago. It was the jitney ride.
"We went on a two-town tour; a volunteer from the coalition showed us every neighborhood," Ms. Thomson said. "Being an interracial couple, we felt positive about a community that had a coalition promoting dialogue on race issues."
Ms. Thomson, 45, a home organizing consultant, grew up in Appleton, Wis., (population 70,000) -- "bigger than Maplewood," she said -- and moved to New York in 1986.
Mr. Loadholt, 48, a marketer for a financial printing company, had lived a full Brooklyn experience. As a child, he witnessed white flight from Bedford-Stuyvesant, and then, as a teenager into his late 20's, from Crown Heights. After that, the one-bedroom, rent-regulated apartment in Park Slope where Mr. Loadholt lived, for 20 years, served him and his new wife just fine until their son, Jared, now 6, occupied the slightly-larger-than-crib-sized homemade bed in the corner.
Buying in Park Slope was out of the couple's reach; so they looked at some suburbs, including communities "described as integrated," Ms. Thomson said. "For us it felt very much like two sides of the tracks, economically divided, and the poor people were people of color."
Then they took the jitney ride. "The gentleman giving the tour pointed out how racially and ethnically diverse communities are usually in transition, which totally resonated with me," Mr. Loadholt said. 
Ms. Thomson said: "We didn't feel the economic extremes. They do exist here, but not with such definition."
Their 1932 three-bedroom English colonial with original kitchen and ornate woodwork cost the couple $270,000. And Mr. Loadholt began commuting to Manhattan, riding the jitney -- its rush-hour function -- to Maplewood's Tudor-style, complete with cupola, train station. "Even the way Maplewood chose the three jitney routes, it was very communal," he said. "They made sure to go through every neighborhood."
On the ride, Mr. Loadholt said, "You're discussing doctors, the school system, that community network thing." And in his daily experiences, "No, there are almost no racial overtones."
It wasn't always so.
Burned into William Calabrese's memory is the day, back in the 60's, when he and his baseball buddies crossed the line from East Orange to play in South Orange.
"I'm someone who wasn't born with a silver spoon in my mouth," said Mr. Calabrese, who grew up in neighboring Newark and then East Orange. Later, in the mid-1970's -- despite that day -- Mr. Calabrese moved to South Orange, opened a pharmacy and, since 1991, has served as president of the South Orange Board of Trustees -- in effect, the mayor.
"I was about 11, and the friends I came with were Afro-Americans," he said. "We were singled out. They said, 'You can't play on our ball fields.' I was never so embarrassed; I couldn't understand why that would happen. It's always stayed in my mind." 
"Now," Mr. Calabrese said, "this town is a model for what America should be like. You can live on any block, any part of the town. And the point is we're growing because of that."
Maplewood's mayor, Victor DeLuca, said there is still progress to be made. "We still have pockets of town that are predominantly one race," Mayor DeLuca said, pointing out that the town is about to redevelop Springfield Avenue "because, historically, it has been a dividing line."
"We need to continue to work to make sure that our integration efforts are successful throughout the town," he said. "I don't think any community can say that they've solved these problems."
In the 50's, South Orange and Maplewood were overwhelmingly white. But over the ensuing decades -- through the turbulence of the civil rights era, the 1967 riots in neighboring Newark, the years of white flight, race-based steering by unscrupulous brokers and, over time, the economic advancement of some African-Americans -- the two towns would increasingly face concerns about racial tipping.
In 1990, according to census data, the population of the towns stood at 38,115, of which 80.7 percent was white, 14.9 percent black and 4.4 percent other ethnic groups. But by 2000, with the population increasing to 40,232, 60.3 percent of the residents were white, 32.6 percent black and 7.1 percent other groups.
It was in 1997 that the two towns, at the urging of a group of residents, contributed $50,000 each to create the coalition on race, which has since evolved into a nonprofit organization with about 2,000 members. 
Concern about racial tipping may have played a role in the founding of the coalition. But as Ms. Heisler-Williams, its director, said: "Percentage is no longer valid. The notion that one too few white people or one too many people of color somehow vastly changes the community is just absurd."
Dr. Hughes at Rutgers concurred: "Many studies in the 60's and 70's attempted to quantify the tipping point. But there's been a major shift in attitudes in the United States in regard to the desire for diversity."
"In the 50's, 60's and 70's," Dr. Hughes continued, "there really was white flight from the cities seeking uniform and homogenous environments -- the parents of the baby boom. But the baby boom itself, and even the baby bust population, now often rejects those types of environments."
In fact, said Ms. Heisler-Williams, it is not just city dwellers who have come to South Orange and Maplewood in recent years. "We have a lot of people who had moved far west in New Jersey, trying to get away from the city," she said. "But that became a quality of life issue; they were so far out that they were commuting when their kid was playing T-ball."
What the coalition tries to do through its marketing campaign, she said, "is create balanced demand, make sure that every one of our neighborhoods is seen as equally desirable and accessible."
For Friedes and Tito Valbuena, it was an ad in a local magazine promoting the coalition's loan program that tipped them toward the balanced mix in South Orange.
"We lived for 20 years in Astoria, Queens; a six-family, prewar walk-up," said Mrs. Valbuena, who is research director for a life insurance company. Mr. Valbuena, an architect, was tired of his reverse commute to an office in Maplewood. They are both 57.
"We'refrom the Philippines, and it's hard when you go some places and you stick out because you're the only person who looks different," Mrs. Valbuena said, "which is why we loved New York."
The couple paid $185,000 for a small, 1900's railed-porch home on Riggs Avenue in South Orange, which, like all roads in town, is lined by old-fashioned gas-fueled street lights. The house has "two big bedrooms and one small bedroom," Mrs. Valbuena said. "The bathroom off the first-floor kitchen has that old kind of claw-footed tub."
"It's all small lots along our street -- like Astoria, side by side," she said, "but across the street they have big lots."
What convinced the couple that they would feel at home in the community was the $7,000 second mortgage offered by the coalition for moving to a neighborhood where they would add to the mix. The interest rate on the loan was 3.5 percent, with payments deferred for a year. "You can't beat those terms," Ms. Valbuena said. "We used it for moving costs." The loan program, through Allegiance Community Bank, is subsidized by the two towns and the Fund for an Open Society, a nonprofit group based in Philadelphia.
"The objective was precisely to preserve the diversity of the community," Ms. Valbuena said. "In other places I didn't find that kind of a solid signal that they really were serious about diversifying. That's what attracted us."

A Multifaceted Approach
How One School Is Being Upgraded
 For the Thomson-Loadholts, the interracial couple from Brooklyn, the most solid signal was how the community chose to bridge the achievement gap at the school where their son, Jared, is in kindergarten.
"My son goes to the Seth Boyden Elementary School on the poorer side of town," Mr. Loadholt said. "The school was allowed to slip, so that it needed a special program to bring it back. There was a racial component."
The South Orange-Maplewood School District has a record of significant educational achievement. Last year, 93 percent of the 416 graduates from the district's one high school, Columbia High School, went on to college. On New Jersey's eighth-grade language arts test last year, 87.4 percent of the students in South Orange-Maplewood passed, surpassing the 82.7 percent average pass rate for the state. On the fourth-grade language arts test, the district had a 90.9 percent pass rate, while the state level was 86.3 percent. 
Two years ago, at Seth Boyden -- the second year of the district's program to close the school's achievement gap -- 78.2 percent of the fourth-grade students passed the reading test. By last year, that had improved to 87.6 percent.
"Rather than busing," said Ms. Thomson of her son's school, "the district brought in a consultant to develop a multiple intelligence approach, addressing the fact that people learn in different ways. We are also the center for teacher training."
Mr. Loadholt said: "The heartening thing is the way the board of ed made it a demonstration school where the curriculum is attractive enough so people want to send their kids there, so that some of the better teachers want to work there."
"It's not a finished experiment by any means, and there are issues," he said. "But at the same time, the fact that this community took this approach is not an accident."
It was no accident that Julia Burch and Aixa Cintron -- a lesbian couple with two small daughters -- chose Maplewood.
Ms. Burch, 40, a freelance writer, began hunting on the Internet after Dr. Cintron, 42, was hired as a professor at the Fordham University School of Social Work. At the time, in October2000, the couple was temporarily staying in Brooklyn after moving from Cambridge, Mass.
"I found a mention on Planet Out, a gay Web site, that Maplewood was one of the best small towns for gay families in the country," Ms. Burch said, "and certainly the only one in the New York area mentioned on the list."
"I did a little Yahoo map thing," she said. "We never really imagined ourselves as suburbanites."
And so, early one Sunday morning, the couple -- along with Ino, then only a year old (Amelia was not yet born) -- took a drive. "We drove into Maplewood and stopped in a park for an urgent diaper change," Ms. Burch continued. "There weren't many people there. But who we did see was a gay male couple, two daddies with their kids, and two mommies with their kids. And we just kind of laughed and said, 'It's true.' "
The couple bought a four-bedroom fixer-upper "at the corner where Maplewood intersects with Newark, Irvington and South Orange," Ms. Burch said -- for $185,000. 
Dr. Cintron said living in Maplewood has been a blessing, particularly for Ino, now 3. "She's very articulate, and we run into enough couples like us so that when she finds kids who have one mom and one dad, she is able to say, 'We're a family, too, and it's two mommies.' "

HEADLINE: LIFE'S WORK; 
War's Irrepressible Presence in the Office

BYLINE:  BY LISA BELKIN; This column about the intersection of jobs and personal lives appears every other week. E-mail: Belkin@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
BACK in the old days, you couldn't watch a war in real time. (Those were the same old days when there was no such expression as "real time.") And you certainly couldn't watch a war while at work.
 World War II was brought stateside on grainy newsreels seen by movie audiences. Vietnam was jarring, yes, but it was still contained between the start and end of the nightly news. Most of the visuals from the first gulf war (the ones not provided by the Defense Department) were taken from hotel room windows with a night-vision scope, not from "embedded" cameras capable of illustrating play-by-play commentary. 
 This war, on the other hand, allows us to tune in at any moment -- all war all the time. "Allows" may be the wrong word. We must tune in. We can't escape it, because the same technology that brings us this war also brings us our e-mail and our interoffice memos and our project research. This is the Internet's war, the computer screen's war, a war that has come to the workplace.
Go to Yahoo to search for a phone number. The headlines will tell you the latest tally of the dead and injured. Go to Netscape to check the stock market. You can see more streaming video of statues being toppled in Baghdad. Or go to a trading floor the way Jenny Fielding does every day. As an investment adviser with Morgan Stanley she sits surrounded by computer screens, hers and hundreds of others, all with an inset of CNBC. Huge television sets that loom in her field of vision are also tuned to the war.
In the early days, she says, when American forces were first bombing Baghdad, the voices of the traders would periodically go silent and the rows of monitors would rumble and echo as one. "It was like being in the middle of the war," she said. "It was that loud."
But while the images might be the same from one office to the next, the fact is we are all watching different wars. The one being watched by the families of soldiers is the most personal of these. They scan the screens looking for familiar faces, listening for a particular battalion name. No wonder they are finding it hard to focus on work.
The war I am watching distracts me in its own way. My war threatens my baby sitter's younger brother, Eric Cole, a Navy corpsman waiting for orders to ship out. And it threatens scores of my colleagues, some of whom I love like family, and whose job description now includes risking their lives in real time and in color. Word of Michael Kelly's fatal crash in the Iraqi desert came to me over my office computer. So did news of the deaths of reporters I have never met, but whose need to tell this story I viscerally understand.
The war Ms. Fielding is watching, in turn, is one of numbers and predictions. War as an investment strategy. "At work, war talk is all about the market," she says. "If the futures are up, the question is, 'What's going on in the war?' "
Her war has become internal, as the work she does battles for significance with the grief and destruction she sees on her sea of screens. "I find it a bit sickening to have to call clients and talk about their investments when all this dying is going on," she says.
And this, in turn, leads her to yet another kind of war -- the unspoken one she fights each day with the traders who sit around her, most of whom, she gathers, feel much more gung-ho about this military action than she does.
"People couch things in terms of, 'Let's get this war over so the market can go up,' " she explains. "And I sit there in the middle of all this and think: 'No, let's get this war over so more people don't die. Let's get this wrapped up so we're not there doing something immoral anymore.' "
I have been receiving a steady stream of e-mail messages from workers facing this same intraoffice war. A public relations executive wrote to tell me that her boss had given out yellow ribbons to all employees and she felt that the underlying message was that "if you don't wear them, you are seen as anti-American." An architect wrote that making sardonic comments about the war is what passes for sport in his office, so he keeps his own pro-war views to himself. All this adds an extra scrim of tension to a workday already strained by everything from a faltering economy and fears of terrorism to worries about catching SARS.
Ms. Fielding is developing strategies to avoid all these battles -- the ones in the gulf and the ones closer to home. Time was when she turned on the news every night, but now she craves music instead. She also used to eat lunch at her desk, but now she takes long walks around the city to clear the noise of war from her head. And when the trading day ends at 4:30 and everyone turns off their computers and goes home, Ms. Fielding has begun to stay behind. She sits alone in the empty room savoring the peace -- a word that takes on extra meaning lately -- and quiet.

HEADLINE: Back to the Second Shift 

BYLINE:  By ELLEN L. ROSEN 

 BODY:
WHEN Flo Wiener had her second child 12 years ago, she was ready for a break from practicing law. She quit her job at the New York State Attorney General's office and chose, as she puts it, to "do the June Cleaver thing." She stayed home for nine years, but as her children grew older, she began contemplating a return to the work force. 
 "I had been seriously considering going back to work for a year," said Ms. Wiener, who lives in Edgemont. "One opportunity had come up but it wasn't right because it didn't fit with my public sector background." 
 Eventually she met another Scarsdale resident who had retired from his corporate law practice and was forming a legal services organization for children. "We met, we hit it off, I said I'd work 60 percent time and he said fine," she recounted. 
Grace Flowers had a career in retailing before her three children were born. But after a 15-year break from work, she established a floral design company in her Greenburgh home. She was inspired by the flowers her husband, Robin, a vice president for public relations at AT&T, often brought her. 
"I loved them and didn't want them to die, so I started researching how to preserve them," she said. "I sold them from my home and did dried floral arrangements for brides. That led me to think I should expand further and learn fresh flower arrangements." 
She sought certification from the Southern Westchester BOCES, the cooperative educational center, and learned business skills from the Women's Enterprise Project in White Plains. Over the last four years, she has grown her business.
Ms. Wiener and Mrs. Flowers are among many throughout the county who have successfully "sequenced," the term coined in the 1980's by a University of Minnesota professor to describe the transition undertaken by professional women who quit their jobs to stay home with their children -- sometimes for years -- and then resume old careers or begin new ones. 
THERE are no statistics on how many women take time off to raise their children and subsequently return to work. According to the 2000 United States Census, of the 118,669 women in Westchester with children under the age of 18, 42,982, or 36 percent, are not working outside the home. The overall number of mothers at home increased by almost 5,000 over the last decade. 
The number of women home includes many professional women in the 1990's, who, buoyed by a bull market and a confidence that work but not childhood would wait, left their jobs. But the children born at the height of the baby boomlet in 1991 are now entering middle school, and many of those same mothers are wending their way back into the work force. Whether spurred by children who are old enough to be more independent or a change in personal financial conditions, many have dusted off their resumes and found new jobs after years of staying home. 
Their success results from perseverance, networking and at least some luck. While it is usually easier to leave the work force than it is to come back, many women are able to return, said Ellen Galinsky, the president of the Families and Work Institute in Manhattan. "The reality is that for most there is no one career path." 
The key is to view old jobs and time at home as integrated rather than isolated experiences. "Everything has a thread," said Maggi Landau of Edgemont, who made the transition from practicing law to running a business, with several years at home in between. "Where was it written in stone that I have to follow a certain path? There can be consistencies between jobs and you can learn from what you did before and apply it now."
THE biggest impediment to returning to work is often figuring out what to do. The first step, many say, is to talk with friends and acquaintances. "Often women don't understand how much of a network they have through volunteer and school activities," said Marcia Brumit Kropf, the vice president of research and information services at Catalyst, a nonprofit organization that works with business to advance women. "Through different venues, whether school, religious institutions or sports, you will meet other people who can help you gain entree back into the world of work." 
But she added: "You're unlikely to come back to a senior position as though you never left. You will have to show that you have skills for the current world. Projects taken on a consulting basis can serve you well and show what you can do."
Another problem facing women is the loss of confidence they feel after years at home. "Employers and women don't always value the experience gained from being home," said Ms. Galinsky. "But if you learn to be an authority with kids, and learn to do different things at the same time, these are good skills for the work force." 
Many of the women at home re-enter the work force in fields like education and real estate, where they can arrange flexible hours and work close to home. Others seek corporate work, or start small businesses of their own. Although the current economy is weak, it "shouldn't be an excuse for people not to begin the process of looking for work," said Nancy Collamer, a career counselor based in Old Greenwich, Conn. 
But, added Silvia D. Carroll of Miraset Personal & Professional Development Services in Pelham, "It takes a little longer and a little more work to get in." 
And once the job is found, re-entry is not as simple as donning a new suit.
"The biggest surprise for a lot of these women is that it's a lot tougher to balance home and work life," said Ms. Carroll. "They think it will be a simple transition, if they get their ducks in a row, especially if their kids are grown. But it is a challenge, and I advise people to take on part-time work or work from home as a bridge, so it's less of a shock."
Sally Genster Robling of Larchmont is one who segued successfully back into corporate marketing after a year's hiatus. She worked initially at General Foods Corporation in White Plains, but then her husband took a job in Philadelphia and she moved to the Campbell Soup Company, based in Camden, N.J.. When they decided to move back to Larchmont in 1999, she stopped working to get reacclimated in Larchmont. "I was class mom and did all the lieutenant stuff I wanted to do," she said. "I also worked with the church, but mostly I spent time with my children. But at 46 I didn't feel that it was responsible not to be professionally engaged. And I found it hard to go from 60-hour weeks to being home."
After receiving a call from an executive recruiter, she said she became "open to thinking about returning to work." She called the head of human resources at Campbell's, who introduced her to the new head of American Standard, the company that manufactures bath and kitchen products as well as electronics. She worked out an arrangement that enabled her to work part time. "It's a wonderful deal, although it does require a degree of flexibility," she said. "I don't control my schedule because I respond to my businesses. But I love my work. I thought for a long time of what I wanted to do."
While Ms. Genster Robling kept her career connections alive, those who have lost touch with former colleagues can get started again by networking with acquaintances met through volunteer work or in the neighborhood. Sometimes, said Ms. Carroll, it is important to set up simple informational meetings just to learn about a field of work.
Maryann Dennen followed this route. After her oldest child was born 13 years ago, Ms. Dennen, an accountant, returned to her job at Merrill Lynch where she "worked for a month or so before realizing that the job wasn't conducive to having kids." She left and stayed home for nine months, but then began teaching corporate finance at Manhattan College in Riverdale. After her second child was born in 1992, she stopped altogether and subsequently had a third child. In 1995, when her youngest was almost a year old, she started her own accounting and financial services company.
"I was given the opportunity just from meeting people in Bronxville," she said. "I was doing community work, whether for the Junior League or schools, so clients found me." 
Beth Smayda of White Plains says that volunteer work helped her land a job at MBIA, a municipal bond insurance company based in Armonk. Before her oldest child was born prematurely in 1986, Ms. Smayda worked as a municipal bond analyst at Moody's Investor Service in Manhattan. She intended to go back to work part time, but it wasn't an option back then, she said.
"Since I realized my son would need additional care, with weekly doctor's appointments, I decided to stay home, which fortunately I could do financially," she said. "I decided that as long as I was home, I'd have my kids at that time." 
Ms. Smayda had two other children and became involved with the League of Women Voters and worked on the White Plains city budget. "Through some of my volunteer work, I knew someone who worked at MBIA and had a job interview arranged through him," she said. "They hired me at the same level at which I left Moody's."
Fran Columbus of White Plains has never stopped working and has held a variety of demanding jobs. But after a stint as executive director of a Manhattan law firm, she started a consulting practice closer to home. She felt that "teenagers need more of a presence at home than younger children." 
She kept up contacts with executive recruiters, telling them to call her when the right job came up. That position presented itself this year; with her younger child a senior in high school, Ms. Columbus went to work as the chief operations officer of the Jewish Community Center in Manhattan. "The intellectual challenge of work is an important part of who I am," she said. "I want my daughters to understand that because I want them to have the same."
While most who have jumped off the career track acknowledge that they could do so because of their spouse's income, there are single parents with no financial cushion who have had similar gaps. Terri Geary, a West Harrison resident, was an events planner at McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm, before she had her son, Robert, now 4. But after 15 years in the field, she lost her job a year after her son was born. Out of work and suffering from health problems, she said she endured a "rough three years." She landed a job with a hotel company, but was laid off after Sept. 11. Ultimately, she found a job at California Closets in Hawthorne. Although her expenses are high and her income is a fraction of what it was, she said that after her son was born she had known she had to make a career change. 
CHANGING family circumstances can also prompt career changes. Ms. Landau was a successful real estate lawyer who had worked at a large New York law firm and then moved to a health care company and then to a real estate development company. But when her daughter was in eighth grade, she said, "Although I loved my job it dawned on me that my kids would leave home in a few years, so I quit cold turkey." But a few years later she was ready to work again.
"I realized that even when you're off, your personality doesn't change," she said. "I ran the P.T.S.A.. for the junior-senior high school. And then I decided my kids were old enough for me to return to work when my husband was diagnosed with cancer." 
Her husband, Bobby Minter, ran Rainbow Media, a sales, marketing and advertising company. When he became ill, she got involved in the business. After her husband died, she began running it.
"We all have the capacity to step up and do anything," she said. "Just allow yourself to make mistakes and then you can learn."
Often, the biggest difficulty for women who have been home for a number of years is determining whether they want to return to their former professions or find a new direction. The county's libraries have a program, the WEBS Career and Educational Counseling Service, which offers myriad career services. The program includes group sessions that "help residents get a clear sense of who they are and what they offer and to be able to connect with others going through transition," said Elaine Sozzi, who heads the 23-year-old program.
Westchester County also provides some workshops for women with no professional training as well as others seeking to start businesses. Anne Janiak, a former mayor of Scarsdale, runs the Women's Enterprise Project in White Plains, which she describes as "micro-enterprise development program that helps women achieve economic self-sufficiency through entrepreneurship." The group offers a 15-week course in owning a small business, with instruction in financing, marketing and time management skills. The group, which also provides mentors, works with women on public assistance as well as homemakers who need to re-enter the work force because of changes in their lives. More than 300 women have been through the program and close to 50 percent have started businesses as a result, according to Ms. Janiak.
One participant was Afra Sepulveda of Yonkers, who had worked for years at the investment banking firm Bear Stearns Companies, in the production department, where she managed as many as 45 people. But she lost her job in 2001, which she found shocking. 
"I thought I was a necessity, but that wasn't the case," she said. "It was a very difficult period, although I was laid off along with 800 other people. " She attended the Women's Enterprise Project, and decided to start a floral design business. Although she says she's making roughly 40 percent of her previous income she has no regrets. "The business is moving along and I have expanded. And I like being independent." 
Westchester Community College in Valhalla provides training and support through its Women's Forum, said Susan Shumejda, the program's director, which helps those looking for work to regain their confidence and understand their strengths. "Women can be nervous about stepping back into the classroom," she said. "Often the only notes they've written are excuse notes for their children." 
Even for professional women, the fear factor exists. "The women I work with are very talented, capable women, and yet have not been in the conventional workplace for a while," Ms. Collamer said. "Even when you were employed, there's a sense of being the new kid on the block and having to learn the ropes, the politics and the company when you start a new job. For a woman who has been out of the workforce the learning curve is a little steeper. But the good news is that people say it was tough, but then it's fine." 
Those who have jump-started their careers acknowledge that it often takes time to achieve a new family balance. But the nonfinancial rewards of going back to work can be as meaningful as the new salary. 
"Work keeps home in perspective and home keeps work in perspective," said Ms. Smayda.

HEADLINE: Report Cards That Bring Smiles 

BYLINE:  By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER school districts got their report cards from the state, and in much of the county the news was very good. 
 Eighty-five percent of the students who entered high school in the fall of 1998 graduated in June 2002, compared with a state average of 75 percent. 
 And the average scores for Regents performance on the English, math, United States history and global history were in the 80's and 90's -- well above the score of 65 needed to last year qualify for a Regents diploma. (Many students also took a fifth Regents exam, in science). 
Besides buoying the spirits of school administrators, these results figure into the competition between districts that is reflected in property values and assessments of real estate's desirability. 
Which is not to say that there aren't districts like Yonkers where there is plenty of room for improvement.
And the standards will keep getting tougher. The graduating class of 2003 will need a passing score of 55 or better on all five Regents exams. The graduating class of 2004 will have to pass the English test and both history exams, United States and Global), with a score of 65 or above, and the class of 2005 will have to pass all five required Regents with a score of 65 or above. And in 2005, the Regents-only diploma becomes the requirement for all, with the option of a local diploma eliminated. Dr. Debra Jackson, the superintendent of the North Salem Central District and president of the Chief School Officers' Association for Putnam and Westchester Counties, said the county schools performed well for a couple of reasons. 
"There's a commitment to education throughout all our communities, no matter what the socio-economic demographic, and in the region, we have a real commitment to staff development," she said. "We're able to do a lot of analysis of students, and putting the latest educational research in the hands of classroom teachers."
Dr. Edward J. Shine, the schools superintendent of the Rye City school district, said: "In the last five years, we've revised all our curriculum so that, at the very least, the state standards were included. Initially, we were focused on the test, but over the long haul, we've been able to incorporate all the educational issues into what we do, so that the amount of test prep would be minimized."
In Rye Neck, where - other than in the science exams - 100 percent of the students passed the required Regents, district administrators credit a concerted effort to provide academic support for all students as a key factor for these results.
"We've been working hard at making substantive changes in curriculum and instruction," said Dr. Peter J. Mustich, the schools superintendent. "We've been working with students who need support and help through after-school tutorials, as well as informal support services, improving what's going on in the classroom, and during the past three to five years, being more careful about test analysis and data. The district's expectations are more rigorous, and everyone's risen to the occasion. We're happy with the results, but we caution that the test results can change every year, and we have to constantly work on how we do." 
In Port Chester, where there is the highest percentage of non-English speaking students in the county, 89 percent of the students passed the Regents English exam with a score of 65 or better, while 98 percent earned at least the minimum score of 55. 
"We're bundling essential skills from elementary school on, and doing massive improvements to curriculum and instruction," said Dr. Charles Coletti, the school district superintendent. "It's not about money. We spend less per pupil than any district other than Yonkers or Mount. Vernon. We take teacher-student accountability very seriously."
For its part, Yonkers expects that its current strategy of offering extra academic help in after-school, Saturday and vacation tutoring sessions will translate into improved results.
"In general, we're moving forward," said Jerilynne Fierstein, director of public relations for the Yonkers public schools. "We have double English-language arts periods, advanced courses in math and science in the middle school and are fidning ways to help our students on the Regents."
For the forseeable future, the tests are inevitable. 
"Everyone worries about them," said Dr. Shine of the Rye City district. "If you look at these test scores as analogous to an organism, then if the test scores are sound, you can go off and do other kinds of things. We've tried to weave the tests into the fabric of what we do, and find a way to balance it. It's not going away."

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
Show Me the Deal That I Really Want

BYLINE:  By GREGORY JORDAN 

 BODY:
WHEN he negotiated contracts for baseball stars like Cal Ripken Jr. and Kirby Puckett, Ronald M. Shapiro flouted the most cherished creed of sports agents: show me the money. Instead, he advised these baseball stars to accept relatively moderate pay packages in return for the right to spend their entire careers with the same teams, allowing them to plan their post-baseball business careers.
 Therein is a lesson for corporate America, says Mr. Shapiro, 60, who still represents sports stars and now also has companies as clients. Rather than practicing the winner-take-all aggression endemic to professional sports, he believes business leaders should follow the path of cooperation and compromise. 
 His management consulting firm, the Shapiro Negotiations Institute in Baltimore, has signed up clients like MBNA, the credit card issuer; Automatic Data Processing, a provider of payroll services; Hearst-Argyle Broadcasting, a TV station group, and the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
It doesn't hurt that he has his fingers in so many business pies. In addition to running his institute, which he founded in 1995, he has negotiated contracts for sports stars and entertainment celebrities like Oprah Winfrey at his Shapiro, Robinson & Associates talent agency. He also remains active in his corporate law firm, Shapiro Sher Guinot & Sandler in Baltimore; runs his own book publishing company and another that prepares law graduates for the bar exam, and is the author of "The Power of Nice" (John Wiley & Sons, 1998), about deal making.
It doesn't hurt, either, that he spices his talk with the sports metaphors that many corporate executives love. "I try to ground the anecdotes with my own business and legal experience," said Mr. Shapiro, who has represented four members of the Baseball Hall of Fame, and continues to advise them. "The bottom line is always that the other side needs a win as well."
Mr. Shapiro's system simulates negotiating sessions that play down competition and draw on the playing-field dynamic of teamwork to teach common goals. He says it also applies some of the conflict-resolution techniques described in a 1981 business book, "Getting to Yes: Negotiating Agreement Without Giving In," by Roger Fisher and William Ury. 
"This runs counter to the prevalent deal model of getting the last pound of flesh," said Mr. Shapiro, who has been mentioned as a possible future baseball commissioner. "But in an age where Warren Buffett is saying C.E.O. pay should be cut and deals like Enron's are over, we are trying to restore a long-term approach."
John R. Cochran III, president and chief operating officer of MBNA America Bank, is one of Mr. Shapiro's biggest fans. "We'll have one of our top programs come up for renewal and Ron will come in and role-play, sit across from the sales team and show them what the other side wants," Mr. Cochran said, adding that Mr. Shapiro has also helped customer service representatives in their work and taught collectors "how to position a customer who is behind on payments to pay MBNA before other companies."
At Johns Hopkins School of Medicine in Baltimore, Dr. J. Raymond DePaulo Jr., head of the department of psychiatry, credits Mr. Shapiro's techniques with helping him broker deals both inside the institution and with donors and investors.
"This method is miles away from what I see from the bankers and businessmen at the Davos World Economic Forum," Dr. DePaulo said. "First, you are not really negotiating but trying to understand and educate. Then, you get the rhythm of your proposal in sync with the rhythm of the other side's."
Some experts say Mr. Shapiro's approach can work against a client. Kenneth L. Shropshire, a professor of legal studies at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania who, with Timothy Davis, wrote "The Business of Sports Agents," said a bigger contract might have better served Mr. Puckett, for example, in his recent legal and personal troubles. Mr. Puckett, a member of the Hall of Fame, was left blind in his right eye by glaucoma in 1996 and could no longer play baseball. He went through a nasty divorce and was later accused of sexual assault, though he was acquitted this month. He had a $32 million, five-year contract that began in 1992.
 PROFESSOR SHROPSHIRE says Mr. Shapiro's way can work, or not. "You have got to compare the Puckett situation with Ripken's business success," he said.
"Given that the sports stories have an appeal in the business world, if I were an executive I would still want to hear from the agent who negotiates the deal that sets the market. Some agents repeatedly get that above-market deal, and, the ethics of sports agents aside, I would want to hear that side, too," he added.
But other clients even apply Mr. Shapiro's methods to labor relations. Stephen Bisciotti, chief executive of the Allegis Group, a recruiting and staffing firm in Hanover, Md., and co-owner of the Baltimore Ravens football team, says Mr. Shapiro's emphasis on inspiring, rather than scaring, the troops helped his company manage the fast growth in the late 1990's. "Jack Welch was famous for saying you have to cut the lowest-performing 10 percent of your people annually," Mr. Bisciotti said, referring to the former chief of General Electric. "But, under Ron's system, we learned that you keep the lower performer who is more devoted to the company."
Mr. Shapiro often uses the labor conflicts in Major League Baseball as an example of how not to negotiate. At consulting sessions with Illinois Power, he set up sessions in which management and labor switched sides, something he would do to help resolve the festering disputes between baseball team owners and players.
"With baseball, we still see the mutually destructive, win-lose approach on both sides, and the world sees how calamitous that can be for the industry and for management and labor," said Mr. Shapiro, who was a lead mediator in the 1994-95 strike. "It's a perfect example for corporations of how not to do things. There is no spirit of partnership."

HEADLINE: JERSEY; 
Get a Horse (On Second Thought, Don't)

BYLINE:  By Neil Genzlinger 

 BODY:
I FIGURED out ages ago that the most efficient way for a man to get something he wants is to give it to his wife for her birthday. Thus mine in recent years has received a lovely set of Jack Olsen's true-crime books, a subscription to ESPN the Magazine and a video of the 1985 horror film "Re-Animator" (so rendered on the video box).
 But what I've always really, really wanted -- hasn't everyone? -- is a horse. So it seemed like a sign from above when I read the other day that Cook College at Rutgers was having a conclave called "Horses 2003." 
 I would, I reasoned, zip over to the event, browse, barter and have a nice-looking horse standing in the yard when the wife came down for breakfast on her birthday, which is this weekend.
Cook College, the state's land-grant institution, where things agricultural are taught, is one of the more pleasantly odd places in the Garden State. Animals graze alongside fields where students are playing lacrosse. The prints in the spring mud are as likely to be hoof as foot.
One building has a sign at the door that says "Welcome to the Swine Facility."
The campus seemed the perfect place for a suburban man to find the horse of his dreams -- his dreams generally consisting of romantic images of gorgeous, no-maintenance horses like the ones in movies and cigarette commercials. But the glow began to fade as I scanned the conference program. 
There were no useful presentations on the things I was interested in, like "How to Ride Your Horse at an Impressive Gallop So the Wind Flows Through Your Hair in That Really Sexy Way" or "Swooping Pretty Girls Up and Placing Them Behind You on the Saddle in a Single Motion Without Ever Breaking Stride." 
Instead, the titles were alarmingly unromantic: "Basic Hoof Care and Shoeing," for instance, and "The Scoop on Poop: Managing Your Manure." 
Not being interested in such details -- those would, after all, be the wife's responsibility, since the birthday horse technically would belong to her -- I skipped the seminars. I thumbed through a booklet that came with the registration material called "Horses 2003 Proceedings," hoping to rediscover the fun side of horse ownership, but I stopped when I hit these words, under the heading "Common Parasites and the Problems They Cause":
"Gasterophilus (bots) are flies in their adult form. Interestingly, these flies do not have functional mouthparts and cannot feed. They live long enough to mate and lay their eggs around the mouth, legs and shoulders of the horse. Larvae, which hatch from the eggs, enter the mouth, burrow into the oral tissue, where they remain for a while, then re-enter the mouth."
There's more, but you don't want to read it, and neither did I. So I tossed the book and headed straight for the vendor fair. 
I figured that, this being a horse conference, the vendors would be selling horses, but there wasn't a steed in sight. Instead, there were people hawking a dizzying array of horse-upkeep paraphernalia. There was "TractGard colic and ulcer preventive." There was "Rio Vista Hoof Manicure natural moisturizing cream." There was something in a 1,000-milliliter bottle (price: $25.95) whose label was written entirely in a foreign language except for two distinctly English words: "horse" and "deodorant."
Let me just take a moment to offer a word of caution to any other novice who might wander into a vendor fair at a horse conference: resist the temptation to try these products on yourself. The Bio-Pulse magnetic therapy blanket, for instance, may sound as if it will cure what ails you ("Sore in the back from stiffness, arthritic conditions or hard work?"), but it will look far more ridiculous on you than it does on a horse. 
An InflammaSaver maximum-strength anti-inflammatory and immune system booster is not, it turns out, an improvement on aspirin, and "Gourmet Stable Cookies -- baked fresh daily" are not nearly as tasty as the name implies.
Anyway, I left "Horses 2003" without a horse. More than that, I left concerned over the fact that the horse is our state animal. I know all about the role of the horse in our economy past and present, but shouldn't the state animal be something that anyone can own without having to devote inordinate amounts of time to parasite control and hooficures? 
The hamster, I believe, remains unclaimed by any other state.
The wife will no doubt be disappointed to not receive a horse for her birthday. But I'm sure the Beer of the Month Club membership will ease her pain.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Nancy Doniger)

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
A Bronx Cheer for Manhattan

BYLINE:  By JOE CONCHA; Joe Concha is a freelance writer who lives in Hoboken.

 BODY:
"YOU still live in Hoboken, huh?" an old acquaintance asked, innocently but with an oozing of condescension. "Don't you feel old still being there?" 
 It was not the first time in my 31 years that I had been exposed to such a pompous inquiry from friends trying to live the "Must See TV," "Friends" dream of life in Manhattan. 
 Maybe I am missing out on Lizzie's V.I.P. parties at Bungalow 8, the culinary masterpieces of Nobu or the cultural education only found at the Guggenheim. 
Tickets to "The Producers."
Jazz at the Blue Note.
Monday nights at the China Club with Jeter and Giambi. 
Working out with Gwyneth at Equinox.
But my friends who live in Manhattan are not living in this fantasy world either. 
Tune into "Sex and the City" for a few episodes and one cannot help but believe that casual intercourse and nightly blowouts are as much a part of everyday existence in the Big Apple as Starbucks and The Village Voice. The ugly fact is that though your city friends crow about a scene they are probably not privy to, the reality of a post-9/11 economy means that these same people are probably working longer hours than ever simply to survive. 
The circular lifestyle becomes increasingly vicious: The job exists to pay for the apartment that primarily serves as a place to get enough rest and have enough energy to go to work to pay for the apartment.
The supercilious dialogue truly begins when people who once lived in Jersey are invited to a Hoboken event and curiously go into complete denial that their past addresses ever existed. I invited one old friend to a bar party in Hoboken -- a girl who is convinced she IS Carrie Bradshaw -- and she responded: "Why don't you just have the party in the city? I don't feel like going all the way out there." You would think "out there" was a trek to Baghdad rather than a simple trip across the river. 
Manhattanites feel a sense of accomplishment from completing the progression to maturity and freedom when moving out of Jersey and into the concrete jungle. In their mind, the stairway to success reads: junior high school, high school, college, briefly back home with parents, Hoboken (or insert other North Jersey towns here) and, finally, New York City. Getting stuck at any of the rest stops on the way to urban utopia is considered failure. 
Another friend recently chided me about a date I had planned in Hoboken.
"What are you going to do?" he asked with a smirk. "Pick her up in your Camaro with Bon Jovi blaring and grab a meal at Sizzler?" 
Three weeks later, I am pleased to report, Seth needed to borrow $40 just to make it to his next paycheck because his rent and dinners with his Upper East Side, higher-maintenance-than-the-Giants-Stadium-turf girlfriend were eating him alive. Perhaps he put the cash to good use and went to swanky Trust downtown, where $40 can buy a three whole drinks. 
"It must be so inconvenient going out in the city and having to take the PATH back to Hoboken at 3 a.m.," is another commonly echoed advantage of calling New York home. But when applying basic math, the cost of a $35 cab ride to Hoboken, say, twice a month, is only $70 and almost as fast with no traffic at that time of night. Given the difference in the prices of rent (in Hoboken, the average one-bedroom rents for $1,335 as opposed to $1,875 in Manhattan) that $70 suddenly doesn't resemble the national debt. 
I once lived in a studio two blocks from Central Park at 95th and Columbus. Nice area. Plenty of restaurants, bars and shops. And it was too cool to tell women that I had a place on THE Upper West Side (given my location, the word "upper" was particularly accentuated). Still, I felt strangely isolated in a city of eight million people. 
Going to a place where everybody knows your name may not be your thing, but Hoboken at least offers the choice. 
So go ahead, New York. Make the unsophisticated cheese that lives "there" the butt of your predictable jokes. When the chuckles subside, have fun writing out the $300 monthly check to park your car. Or enjoy your painful journey getting out of the city to go to the beach. Good luck finding a good shopping mall. 
Hobokenites will just sit here and soak up our bigger apartments, larger savings accounts and $3-to-anywhere-in-town cab rides. Oh, and those cozy B.Y.O.B. restaurants that are Hoboken's signature really have us feeling mortified to be stuck on the Jersey side of the world. 
What, you city folk really thought all $12 bottles of wine cost a minimum of $40, as they do in most New York restaurants? 
Finally, when leaving a Yankee game after the home team wins again, sing along to Sinatra's "New York, New York" blaring throughout the stadium. After all, who else is more appropriate to croon about the virtues of New York than an Italian guy from Hoboken? 
"You still live there, huh?" 
Yeah. Life is tough.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
A New Investment, Courtesy of Canada

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO 

 BODY:
INCOME trusts, which have surged in popularity in Canada, are being offered on the New York Stock Exchange as antidotes to shrinking stock portfolios and tiny fixed-income returns. 
 The income trusts generally provide rich income streams, as high-yield bonds do, but the trusts are actually equity investments. Their value can shift sharply, and the payouts are by no means assured. 
 Despite the risk, many investors in Canada have been drawn to income trusts because of the prospect of consistently high yields. "Because a large number of baby-boom investors are nearing retirement, they're looking for stability of income," said Stephen Pincus, a partner at Goodmans, a law firm here that has helped structure many trusts. "They can't afford to invest in stocks, which require a long period of time to harvest capital gains." 
Like real estate investment trusts, the Canadian income trusts raise capital through an offering of units, or shares. They invest that capital in the equity and debt of an operating company and distribute most of their pretax operating income to investors. Shareholders can count on the income only if the underlying business continues to generate stable cash flow. 
In early March, the Fording Canadian Coal Trust, which controls North America's biggest exporter of coal for making steel, listed its units for sale on the New York Stock Exchange. The trust replaced Fording common stock as part of a merger with two other Canadian coal producers. Fording's shares closed at $19.08 on Friday, roughly the level at which they were listed. Three other Canadian trusts -- the Enerplus Resources Fund, the Pengrowth Energy Trust and the PrimeWest Energy Trust -- have also listed in New York. 
More than 100 trusts have been set up in Canada the last two years. They accounted for 57 percent of the value of new listings on the Toronto Stock Exchange in 2002, said Kirby Gavelin, head of equity capital at RBC Capital Markets here. Currently, he said, the trusts account for about 7 percent of the market value of the S.& P./TSX composite index, the main benchmark for stocks on the Toronto exchange.
Canadian income trusts were initially confined largely to the oil, gas and real estate sectors. But those set up recently are in industries as diverse as horticulture, food processing, check printing and telecommunications. The most suitable candidates have been well-established businesses with stable cash flow that is not required for new capital investment.
"Beware of businesses with significant reinvestment needs," warned Gordon Tait, who watches income trusts at BMO Nesbitt Burns in Calgary.
The typical yield on an income trust is 8 to 14 percent. Most have also produced significant capital growth. An income trust index compiled by BMO Nesbitt Burns gained 6.4 percent in the 12 months ended March 31, compared with a 17.1 percent decline in the S.& P./TSX composite. Many Canadians protect the distributions from taxes by holding the trusts in registered retirement savings plans.
The Canadian trusts have received relatively little attention from Americans, in part because of the small size of most of the offerings, typically around 250 million Canadian dollars each, and because of the uncertainties of investing in foreign securities.
United States residents are subject to a 15 percent Canadian withholding tax, though this can be applied as a credit against American taxes. Under Canadian law, no more than half the units of any trust may be held by foreigners. Currency risk is also an issue, because almost all the trusts, including those listed in New York, pay their distributions in Canadian dollars. The currency has strengthened in recent months; it now trades at68.85 American cents.
Michael E. Lewitt, president of Harch Capital Management in Boca Raton, Fla., said that although he is familiar with the securities, his company has not invested in them or recommended them. "It's something we haven't really thought about," he said.
But Mr. Pincus of Goodmans said, "As time goes on, I think we'll see a greater number of American investors participate in this vehicle." 
Some American businesses have raised financing in Canada by selling income trusts. One is the Specialty Foods Group Income Fund, based on a processed-meats business in Cincinnati, which raised 201 million Canadian dollars last month. 
American companies generally have not formed income trusts in the United States because they would be regulated as mutual funds, with strict reporting requirements and limits on fees, according to Andrew F. Viles, a partner at the law firm of Goodwin Procter in Boston. From an investor's point of view, he said, "one of the great things is that it's like a fixed-income product, so long as the business continues to perk along as it has."
The trusts' risks stem from their status as equity holdings. The absence of any cash-reserve buffer makes them especially vulnerable to changing business conditions, but some investors may not be aware of that. "You've got widows and orphans buying units and expecting dividends on a regular basis," said Kenneth Pearce, a partner at the law firm of Blake, Cassels & Graydon here. 
THE risks were evident late last month when the Halterm Income Fund, whose main asset is a container port in Halifax, Nova Scotia, suspended income distributions after two shipping lines moved their business elsewhere. And the Sun Gro Horticulture Income Fund of Bellevue, Wash., whose underlying business is North America's biggest peat moss distributor, warned last month that its earnings for the 12 months ended March 31 would not be enough to cover distributions. 
The prices of both trusts' units, which are listed on the Toronto exchange, have slumped sharply.
Leslie A. Lundquist, who manages an income trust fund for Bissett Investment Management in Calgary, Alberta, cautioned that the trusts, by and large, "are fully valued, and there are probably pockets that are more than fully valued." Still, Ms. Lundquist said, "if you choose your trust carefully, you can get very nice cash distributions, even if you do see a bit of weakness in the capital value."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Next Time, Follow the Spenders, Not the Talkers

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
WHERE is the big relief rally in stocks that so many strategists have predicted and even more investors have been pining for? As with all the any-minute-now rebounds since the stock market peaked more than three years ago, this one is AWOL. 
 It is especially exasperating to many investors that the stock market has shrugged off not only the quick United States military victory in Iraq but also the reports on Friday of an increase in consumer confidence and retail sales in March. For the week, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.2 percent; for the year, it is down 1.3 percent. 
 Before the war, many market pundits had reasoned that the prospects of a conflict were weighing on stocks. Once the successful prosecution of the war became obvious, many of these people predicted that shares would surge. Instead, they have struggled. 
It brings back memories of January 2001, when Alan Greenspan started lowering interest rates. Remember the soothsayers who noted that stock prices were always higher six months after a series of interest-rate cuts began? 
Stock market strategists are often wrong, of course, and not only because they are human. Many are also in the business of generating trading commissions for their firms. Such commissions are far more likely to come from bullish pronouncements than from advice that investors remain on the sidelines or bet against rising stock prices.
Investors are understandably interested in an intelligent assessment of where the market might be headed. But rather than rely on big-name strategists for a view, investors should look at the expectations of large institutional investors, based on their actual bets made in stock-index futures. 
These derivative securities allow investors to bet on where they think the indexes, like the S.& P. 500, are going. RiskMetrics, a financial analytics company in New York, has analyzed S.& P. futures prices and determined how many investors are moderately positive, wildly optimistic or outright negative about the overall market for the next three months. 
At the moment, for example, while many strategists are calling for a hefty rally, only 19 percent of futures investors have bet that the S.& P. will rise more than 10 percent. Most of these investors -- 62 percent -- appear to believe that the index will trade in a range of plus or minus 10 percent. Some 14 percent have wagered that it will be 10 to 25 percent lower in three months. 
Professional traders in the government bond market use a similar tool -- federal funds rate futures -- to assess the thinking among investors about where interest rates might go. Bond traders either bet alongside or against these expectations.
Investors in stock-index futures can be wrong, of course. But a look at recent history shows that a majority has often been correct. For instance, in early January 2001, while the pundits were pounding the table for stocks, 54 percent of stock-index futures players had wagered that the index would remain in a range of plus or minus 10 percent. And 12 percent had made bets that the index would fall as much as 25 percent within three months. By the end of March, the S.& P. had fallen 9.6 percent.
And at the end of November last year, as investors bid up stocks on the glimmers of an economic rebound, 60 percent of stock-futures investors had bet that the rally was unsustainable. They were right. 
"This is an assessment of what investors in the S.& P. futures market believe, so it gives you a real feel for the actual money that is being bet on where the market is going," said Michael Thompson, a risk strategist at RiskMetrics. "It is the voice of the market rather than the voice of an individual strategist." 
And considerably more credible.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Carrying On When Suits Are in Camouflage

BYLINE:  By FARA WARNER 

 BODY:
DANIEL TRAVERS considers himself lucky. Before he was called to active duty in Iraq, Mr. Travers, a colonel in the Marine Reserves, was able to train a "second in command" to take over his civilian job as a logistics manager at Siemens Westinghouse Power in Orlando, Fla.
 But his co-workers are still coping with his absence. "People have come to depend on his strong personality and his leadership abilities," said his boss, Rick A. Merker. "His absence has left a vacuum." 
 As the armed forces rely heavily on reservists like Colonel Travers, 47, to fill important roles in the Middle East and at home, companies are quickly learning that dealing with the absence of important executives goes far beyond completing day-to-day tasks.
Much harder is filling in the gaps in creative, managerial and other skills that make many reservists so valuable in their civilian jobs.
At Ask Jeeves, an Internet search company in Emeryville, Calif., colleagues of Ronald W. Burkett, an account manager who is also a major in the Army reserves, are keeping in touch with his main clients, including Hewlett-Packard and the Navy. Major Burkett, a former Apache helicopter pilot, is on active duty in Houston, training soldiers on computer programs that help them simulate air and ground missions.
But his colleagues at Ask Jeeves said they couldn't replace the skills that help Major Burkett, who is known as Win, bring in sales.
"Revenue is really important during these economic times," said A. George Battle, chief executive of Ask Jeeves. "Win is one of our best producers, and we're a small company. We have people who can fill in, but that's like saying the Chicago Bulls know everything that Michael Jordan can do."
Reservists are also hard to replace in the military.
More than 218,000 reservists and members of the National Guard have been put on active duty because of the action in Iraq. That is the largest call-up since the Persian Gulf war, when about 265,000 reservists were called to active duty, according to the Defense Department.
Reservists and members of the National Guard -- all 1.22 million of them -- now make up 48 percent of all the armed forces, according Lt. Col. Stephen G. Brozak, a Marine reservist who is the spokesman for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve.
The support agency operates a Web site, www.esgr.org, that provides information about the Reserves and the National Guard and civilian employment requirements.
"Reservists have become indispensable to the military as it has downsized -- there's been a 40 percent reduction in military personnel in the past decade," Colonel Brozak said. "Some military positions now are filled solely by reservists."
Reservists are even filling senior-level military positions. Last August, for example, James M. Collins Jr., a major general in the Army Reserve, took a three-year leave from his job at Weyerhaeueser to become the deputy commanding general and chief of staff of First Corps, stationed at Fort Lewis in the state of Washington.
General Collins says the Army has increasingly turned to the Reserves and National Guard to find people with specific skills. Sometimes, as in his case, skills are found in those who have worked both inside and outside the military.
Weyerhaeuser, he said, decided not to replace him as manager of information technology while he was on active duty, instead assigning his duties among other employees.
Though reservists often fill jobs in the United States, many are serving in combat zones. Colonel Travers was in Iraq in early April as deputy commander of the Marine Rear Area Operations Group. His job in the military mirrors his civilian job managing inventory and distribution.
Dr. Michael J. Paletta, the corporate medical officer for the Hospice of Michigan, in Detroit, also has skills that make him crucial to both his military and his civilian bosses. But he has gone even further than Colonel Travers in planning for active duty.
Dr. Paletta, 45, who is a colonel in the Air National Guard and the surgeon general of Michigan, has already written a specific plan so that his staff is ready to take over his patients. But even with such planning, he expects that the staff will face a challenge in caring for the more than 900 terminally ill patients at the hospice -- 170 of whom are under his direct care every day.
"Health care companies are much leaner than they used to be," he said. "There are no surplus executives here."
Dr. Paletta, 45, has not yet been called to active duty, but he is still balancing his civilian and military roles. He has orders with the Air Force that require him to be on call to train medics in combat medicine and in biological and chemical decontamination.
Technology and some advance planning are making it somewhat easier for reservists to keep track of their civilian jobs even when they are on active duty.
Major Burkett, 38, has kept in touch with his colleagues through phone calls and e-mail messages. The colleagues are accustomed to such virtual contact. Major Burkett, who is based in Houston for Ask Jeeves, works with four other sales representatives who work from offices in Massachusetts and California.
Before he left for active duty, Major Burkett was able to send e-mail messages to all his clients to explain his absence. Then he got on his cellphone to his colleagues. "I said: 'Have you got an hour? Because I'm going to a brain dump on everything I know,' " he said.
Despite the planning, Major Burkett's boss, Robyn N. Baer, vice president for account management, said it had been difficult without him.
"Clients fall into two camps," she said. "Some accept people filling in for Win; others say they'll wait for him to come back."
Some companies hire replacements for active-duty reservists, though federal law requires them to hold reservists' jobs open. Many companies voluntarily continue to pay salaries and health care benefits for reservists and their families.
BUT the use of executive replacements often means reconsidering how teams work together -- and what they work on.
When Col. James E. Couch, 50, a first vice president and counsel at Bank One in Columbus, Ohio, went on active duty in December, the two other real estate lawyers in his team felt his absence immediately.
After talking with Colonel Couch, the bank's general counsel, Molly Carpenter, decided to hire another lawyer. "But she's not just doing Jim's job," Ms. Carpenter said. "The whole team's work has been shifted because each lawyer has subspecialties. It's hard to find the same mix as it was when Jim was here."
Unlike some other reservists still in the United States, Colonel Couch has little time to think of anything but his military job. He is the deputy division chief for the Iraq task force at the Army National Ground Intelligence Center in Charlottesville, Va.
"My team keeps in touch," he said. "But they are very gracious about not burdening me with questions about work."
